HEADLINE: Brazil Picks Experience and Age for Cabinet

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 10

 BODY:
Choosing experience over youth, Brazil's President has completed a thorough Cabinet shake-up intended to give new momentum to his troubled two-year-old Government.
Jettisoning his inaugural dictums that no minister should be over 40 years old and that no minister should have served in previous governments, President Fernando Collor de Mello on Friday chose a Cabinet of seasoned administrators and conservative politicians with party support in Congress. 
 "They Don't Use Jet Skis," Veja magazine said in a headline, referring to Mr. Collor's first phase of government, which was marked by athletic feats by officials.
While his first Cabinet largely included technocrats in their 30's, Mr. Collor's new Cabinet is composed almost entirely of men over 50. Four of the 11 civilian ministers served as ministers in military governments in the 1970's, and half of the Cabinet belonged to Arena, the political party that supported the military.
"Of Brazilian conservatives, they are the best on the market," said Alexandre de Barros, a frequent critic of the Government. "Collor is finally putting in place people who correspond to a serious conservative government."
Several new ministers come with important endorsements from their party blocs in Congress. Mr. Collor's party controls only 5 percent of seats in Congress, and his public approval rating in February was only 15 percent.
Some analysts contrasted moves made by Mr. Collor with steps taken this week by President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru, who closed Congress and arrested political opponents.
"The difference between Peru and Brazil is that Fujimori never made the effort that Collor has made," Alfred Stepan, a Columbia University political scientist, said in a telephone interview from Brasilia. "Collor understands that his Government and his future need a broad party base."
For 10 days, Mr. Collor fruitlessly negotiated an alliance with Brazil's dominant center-left party, the Brazilian Social Democratic Party. But party leaders, afraid of hurting their chances in municipal elections this fall, declined to join the Government.
 
Brazil 'at a Crossroads'
 But two party members of international reknown accepted posts. Celso Lafer, a Cornell-trained political scientist, is to be sworn in Monday as Foreign Minister. Helio Jaguaribe, a prominent sociologist, becomes Secretary of Science and Technology.
"Brazil is at a crossroads," Mr. Jaguaribe said at a Brasilia news conference when asked why he had joined a conservative Government. "Either we get out of the swamp of underdevelopment and backwardness, or we will confront a social convulsion of dimensions difficult to calculate."
Reflecting the generational change, Eliezer Batista, a 67-year-old former President of Brazil's largest mining company, has become Secretary for Strategic Affairs, replacing a 31-year-old technocrat linked in press reports to an influence-peddling scandal.
With Brazil's economy slowly improving, Marcilio Marques Moreira remains Economy Minister.
In February and March, inflation fell to a monthly plateau of 22 percent. After initial protests, Brazil's left now accepts privatization of deficit-ridden state companies. And Brazil is expected to reach a deal with foreign creditor banks over renegotiation of its $49 billion commercial debt.
"Brazil is looking a lot better in April than in last October," said Mr. Stepan, who has studied this nation over the last 25 years. "Inflation has flattened out, and you have a much more predictable presidency."

HEADLINE: U.S. Response to Youth and AIDS Is Criticized

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
A House committee expressed alarm today at the spread of AIDS among adolescents and condemned the Federal Government's response as "a national disgrace."
The panel, the House Select Committee on Children, Youth and Families, concluded that Federal efforts were "underfunded, uncoordinated and largely unsuccessful" in prevents AIDS among teen-agers. 
 The committee said Federal prevention efforts were hampered by moralistic restrictions against explicit or specific information about high-risk sexual practices and the effective use of condoms.
"Denial of the problem at the Federal level, where leadership should be paramount, is a national disgrace," the committee said.
"Few Federal resources are dedicated to research or data collection that involve adolescents and their health care providers," the committee said. "Prevention efforts to curb risk-taking behavior among youth are sketchy. And use of explicit information about preventing H.I.V. infection is often discouraged or even prohibited."
Eight of 14 Republicans on the panel took issue with the findings, saying AIDS among teen-agers is primarily "a behavioral problem" rather than a health problem.
In a dissenting report, they said sexual abstinence and strengthening the family, not more Federal Government programs, were the answer.
"Safe sex for teen-agers today is clearly not using condoms but in using self-restraint -- abstinence," the Republicans said. "The fact that some teens engage in unhealthy behavior should not discourage us as a society from promoting moral conduct."
The panel, led by Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado, described its report as the first comprehensive report on AIDS among teen-agers.
The frequency of exposure to H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, among adolescents is not known, the panel found. But the number of teen-agers who have AIDS has increased by more than 70 percent in the past two years.
AIDS is the sixth-leading cause of death among people 15 to 24 years old.
Among teen-agers, there were 401 reported cases of AIDS in 1989, while in 1991 there were 789 cases, the panel said, citing information provided by the Federal Centers for Disease Control. Among those 13 to 24 years old, cases increased to 8,949 from 5,524 in the same period. Those figures do not reflect the number of people with H.I.V. who have not developed AIDS.
The panel said that while the number of cases among teen-agers was relatively small, nearly one-fifth of all AIDS cases in the United States occur among people in their 20's. Because the incubation period from infection with H.I.V. to diagnosis of AIDS can be eight to 10 years, many may have been infected as teen-agers.
 
Avoiding Discussion
 The report said the disease centers requirements for basic educational materials were overly restrictive and avoided discussion of homosexuality and specific behavior that was risky. It said new public service announcements by the disease centers failed to mention either condoms or sex.
The report also found:
*Less than 5 percent of the Federal AIDS budget, excluding Medicaid, goes for research, programs or services that benefit teen-agers.
*By age 20, 68 percent of females and 86 percent of males are sexually active. Among sexually experienced youths 18 and 19 years old, nearly 25 percent of females and 20 percent of males report having six or more partners. Only half reported using condoms.
*AIDS among teen-agers "is spreading unchecked" regardless of geography or economic status. Blacks represent 37 percent and Hispanics 19 percent of reported AIDS cases among teen-agers.
*There is no coordinated Government effort targeting teen-agers.
Signing the minority dissent were Frank R. Wolf of Virginia, Clyde C. Holloway of Louisiana, Lamar Smith of Texas, James T. Walsh of New York, Bob McEwen of Ohio, Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania, Dave Camp of Michigan and Bill Barrett of Nebraska.

HEADLINE: Paths of Patient and His Therapist Cross on Dark Journey Leading to Death

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD with SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, April 11

 BODY:
He was a brilliant child who taught himself to read by the time he was 4 years old and was so strong-willed that as a pre-schooler he refused to take a dose of aspirin until he read the instructions on the bottle himself.
But at the Harvard Medical School, Paul Lozano, the son of Mexican-American immigrants, became lonely and depressed. He sought help from a distinguished psychiatrist on Harvard's clinical staff, Dr. Margaret Bean-Bayog. Then began an agonizing downward spiral in which Mr. Lozano was repeatedly hospitalized, and in which Dr. Bean-Bayog used therapy that she herself has described as "somewhat unconventional" to depict herself as his mother. 
 He later told family members and other doctors of a bizarre sexual relationship with Dr. Bean-Bayog. And a year ago this month, after she had terminated his therapy, he committed suicide at the age of 28.
When his family found his body on April 2, 1991, they could tell he had showered and sprayed himself with Calvin Klein cologne. He was sitting at his desk with his medical books open. He had injected himself with a lethal dose of cocaine.
 
Rare Glimpse Is Offered
 Much is still unknown about Paul Lozano's brilliant rise and sad fall, now the subject of a lawsuit by his family alleging malpractice and wrongful death, and an inquiry by Massachusetts' State Board of Registration in Medicine. But his case has drawn attention far beyond Harvard and the arcane world of psychiatric regulation.
For all its mystery, it offers a rare look into the normally private relationship between therapist and patient, through 3,000 pages of notes and documents that are now available in court records. Besides Mr. Lozano's hospital records and Dr. Bean-Bayog's treatment notes, they include sexual fantasies of Dr. Bean-Bayog, written in her own hand, and flash cards she prepared for him, with sentiments like "I'm going to miss so many things about you, the closeness and the need and the phenomenal sex."
The story raises questions not only about what happened between Mr. Lozano and Dr. Bean-Bayog, but about how the regulatory bureaucracy and psychotherapists should respond to allegations of improper treatment.
Whatever the truth, Mr. Lozano's case comes at a time when medical authorities have been under criticism for reacting slowly to a rising number of complaints about psychotherapists' having sexual relations with their patients, though the complaints have usually involved male therapists. Kenneth S. Pope, a psychologist in Los Angeles who has written a book about the issue, estimates that 7 to 12 percent of male therapists have sex with their patients, compared to 2.5 to 3 percent of female therapists.
 
Another Psychiatrist's Views
 In Mr. Lozano's case, another psychiatrist who treated him in the fall of 1990, Dr. William Barry Gault, complained to the Massachusetts Board of Registration in Medicine soon after learning about Mr. Lozano's allegations against Dr. Bean-Bayog.
But the board lost the letter. And even after being given a file of documents about the case in March 1991 by a lawyer for the Lozano family, the board did not begin a serious investigation until this month, following press accounts about the lawsuit. One of the many questions about this case is whether quicker action by the board might have saved a life.
 
The Patient
A Happy Child, A Brilliant Mind
 By all accounts, Mr. Lozano had a happy childhood, and a large, loving family. He was born in 1962 in Upper Sandusky, Ohio, a town of 5,900 people, the youngest child of a construction contractor.
The family knew he was exceptional by the time he was 4 years old, says an older sister, Pilar Williams. At 5 he tried to order a Mercedes-Benz by mail. He challenged his teachers; he once refused to attend a chemistry course he believed was being wrongly taught, returning only to take the final exam and receive a top grade.
On the basis of their therapy sessions, Dr. Bean-Bayog said she believed that Mr. Lozano was sexually and physically abused as a child. But Dr. Thomas Watkins, the family's pediatrician, said he saw no signs of child abuse or emotional problems. Paul Lozano was "a happy, friendly, well-adjusted young man," said Dr. Watkins. 
 
'Love and Care'
 One of the Lozanos' close friends for many years was Bethny Foltz, the Children's Service Supervisor for Wyandot County, Ohio. "It was obvious there was a lot of love and care in their family," Mrs. Foltz said. There were no signs of abuse, she said, nor any indication that his mother suffered from severe mental depression, as he later told Dr. Bean-Bayog.
Mr. Lozano also told Dr. Bean-Bayog that he tried to kill himself twice as a boy, but no family member or friend recalls such episodes.
At high school in Upper Sandusky, Mr. Lozano earned all A's and was such a brilliant student, said Charlotte Leeth, his English teacher, that he once wrote an essay on philosophy that won a statewide contest, although the school offered no course in philosophy.
After Mr. Lozano's junior year, the family moved to Texas because of the downturn in Ohio's economy. Still, he seemed to adjust. At Coronado High School in El Paso, he became close friends with Armando R. Castellanos.
 
A Pair of 'Nerds'
 "We stuck to our books a lot," Mr. Castellanos said in a telephone interview from Ouijongbu, South Korea, where he is now an Army captain. "We were your nerds." Mr. Castellanos said he saw no signs of depression in his friend.
Both students were recruited by the United States Military Academy. Mr. Castellanos said they had a hard time with the discipline of West Point and accumulated some demerits, though Mr. Lozano had fewer than he did. For the first time, Mr. Lozano got mediocre grades, a transcript shows.
Then early in his second year, Mr. Lozano dropped out of West Point because he decided he wanted to be a doctor, his friend said. If he had stayed at West Point, he would have had to serve nine years in the military after becoming a doctor.
Mr. Lozano entered the University of Texas at El Paso, where he got back on track, earning all A's and graduating with honors in microbiology. His chemistry professor, Jim Becvar, recalled him as being "very quiet and a very good student."
 
A Puzzling Relationship
 But in the chemistry lab a relationship began that raises a hint of mystery about Mr. Lozano. He met a fellow pre-med student, Evelyn Susan Burlingham, and -- to the surprise of his family and his professor -- married her just before graduation. The marriage was soon annulled.
Mr. Lozano later told Dr. Bean-Bayog and others in Boston that his family had forced him to annul the marriage, and that he was very angry about it, her treatment notes show. But his sister says the marriage was a ruse to try to help his new wife get into Harvard Medical School, and that when she was turned down, they called the union off.
 
The Therapist
Personal Troubles Despite Acclaim
 Dr. Bean-Bayog's reputation is so exemplary that many friends are convinced she is being framed by the Lozanos and press accounts. Dr. Edward J. Khantzian, an associate clinical professor of psychiatry at Harvard who has worked with her for 20 years, said, "She has as fine a reputation as a professional can have."
Dr. Bayog grew up in Iowa City, where her father was chairman of the department of internal medicine at the University of Iowa. She went to Radcliffe College, where, she wrote in a report for her 25th reunion, she did not expect to be a happy woman.
She was not happy, she wrote, until she discovered psychiatry." It gave her "access to a personal psychoanalysis which transformed my inner and outer opportunities," and enabled her "to change myself so I could, finally, to my family's surprise and relief, marry."
In 1984 she wed Dr. Rogilio D. Bayog, a Filipino-born psychoanalyst whose wife had died of leukemia. Since 1982, she has been an assistant clinical professor at Harvard Medical School.
As with Mr. Lozano, there is an episode in her life that raises an unanswered question. Court records show she was convicted of drunken driving in June 1984 and placed on two years' probation. Herself an expert on treating alcoholics, she had to attend an alcohol-rehabilitation program.
Mr. Lozano first consulted Dr. Bean-Bayog in September 1984, shortly after arriving at Harvard Medical School. According to her notes, now available in court, he had seen her lecture and came to her "worried about his college heavy drinking." But there is no evidence from friends or family members that he ever drank heavily.
But he was depressed, Dr. Bean-Bayog wrote. She recorded him saying, "Don't like being here." Mr. Lozano also confided that his "girlfriend" had not been accepted at Harvard, that they had "split up" because his family did not approve of her.
Mr. Lozano did not go to see Dr. Bean-Bayog again until July 3, 1986.
In a series of weekly sessions, Mr. Lozano spoke about his depression and suicidal thoughts. "School is fine, but quite sad," she recorded him saying.
Mr. Lozano confessed that he had a "bad habit" of liking stuffed animals and had "a cute little dog," her notes show. That made it hard for him to work in a laboratory that summer where experiments were done on beagles, who were later put to death.
In September 1986, Dr. Bean-Bayog's notes show, Mr. Lozano said he had gone up to the 13th floor of the Harvard School of Public Health, where he had opened a window and "calculated the length of time to hit the ground."
Finally, her notes show, on Sept. 24, 1986, he said, "Wish I was dead right now." Dr. Bean-Bayog had Mr. Lozano admitted to McLean Hospital in suburban Belmont, Mass.
There, Mr. Lozano's trouble was diagnosed as depression and he was treated with drugs. He seemed to be doing so well that Dr. Bean-Bayog wrote to the Harvard Medical School, "Fortunately his disorder has responded beautifully to treatment and he is mending rapidly."
He was discharged in November 1986 and went back to his classes.
At this time, Dr. Bean-Bayog also began to see Mr. Lozano more often, three or four times a week, to find the roots of his depression, her notes say. "I have never had a patient work so hard and fast in treatment," she wrote.
 
Devising a Therapy
 It was during this time, in late 1986 and early 1987, that Dr. Bean-Bayog devised her "unique" therapy, playing the role of a "nonabusive mom" to "help calm him down when he was out of control," as she told the medical board earlier this month.
She wrote out flash cards, with sentiments like: "I'm your mom and I love you and you love me very, very much. Say that 10 times." She later told the medical board that these sentiments "principally were dictated" by him.
Apparently during the same period, Dr. Bean-Bayog wrote 55 pages of graphic sexual and sadomasochistic fantasies, which somehow ended up in his apartment. She insists they were private notes, and that Mr. Lozano broke into her office and stole them.
Several therapists in Boston questioned why, presuming her account was true, she would leave them in her office at all, risking their discovery by a patient. But her supporters said it was good practice for a therapist to write down such fantasies as a way to guard against acting on her feelings.
In some places she seems to refer to the childhood abuse she believed Mr. Lozano had suffered. "I am in a heap, sweating and disheveled, and so sad I can't feel any boundaries to it," she wrote in one fantasy. "So this is what they did to you." She added that she was "sad, terribly sad, for the baby, the boy, the 8-year-old boy."
In early 1987 Mr. Lozano became depressed again; Dr. Bean-Bayog's treatment notes say this was partly because he stopped taking his medication. That May, when he threatened to jump off a building once more, she had him recommitted to McLean Hospital.
During this stay Dr. Bean-Bayog took him several articles about childhood sexual abuse and asked him to read them and tell her his reaction. "Might explain something, how I could never get close to someone," she recorded him as saying.
But it was also during this stay that a psychiatrist, Dr. Frances Frankenburg, raised doubts about Mr. Lozano's veracity. After meeting with Mr. Lozano's mother and sister and watching them interact with him, Dr. Frankenburg wrote that staff members had long talks with him about whether "he was merely a liar."
Dr. Frankenburg also warned Dr. Bean-Bayog that Mr. Lozano might have "conned" her, Dr. Bean-Bayog acknowledged in her notes. Moreover, she said Dr. Frankenburg was "concerned I was overinvolved, inappropriate and dangerous to the patient."
After his discharge in June 1987, Mr. Lozano apparently did better, and while continuing to see Dr. Bean-Bayog several times a week, he managed to keep up with his medical school work, although at the suggestion of his advisers he switched into a Ph.D. program in cell biology. This meant he spent more time in laboratories and less dealing with patients.
But in November 1989 Mr. Lozano began to be tormented again, her notes reflect. His anxiety was touched off when Dr. Bean-Bayog told him she could no longer afford to see him three or four times a week. He had been paying only a fraction of her bill.
In January 1990, she told him that she planned to adopt a baby and would take a maternity leave, according to one of her notes.
Around the same time, according to a close associate of hers who is familiar with the case, Dr. Bean-Bayog also began to demand that Mr. Lozano join a drug-abuse program.
In March 1990, she suspected that he had stolen a hallucinogenic drug from a Harvard hospital, and that it had made him temporarily psychotic, according to her notes. She called the police and had him admitted to the Faulkner Hospital in Boston.
 
More and More Worried
 By now, he was worried that she planned to terminate him. According to her notes, he asked her, "Do you know what it is like to hate your mother?"
Mr. Lozano was discharged from Faulkner after a month, but a few weeks later Dr. Bean-Bayog had him admitted again. She made some plans to find another therapist for him and then terminated him as a patient in June 1909, while he was still in Faulkner. His family has charged that she dropped him too abruptly, when he was very ill and was in a hospital, both often considered ethical violations.
"Is this the last time I'll ever see you?" he asked, according to her notes. "What should I do with all the stuff you gave me?"
 
The Tragedy
Two Certainties: Death and Grief
 For years, Mrs. Williams, now a 38-year-old critical care nurse in El Paso, had wondered about her younger brother's sudden decline. But neither Dr. Bean-Bayog nor the hospitals where she had had him admitted offered any explanation, Mrs. Williams said. In fact, Dr. Bean-Bayog discouraged Mr. Lozano from contacting his relatives, since she believed they were the source of his illness, her notes indicate.
Once when Dr. Bean-Bayog had Mr. Lozano admitted to a hospital, she refused to tell his family his whereabouts until Mrs. Williams threatened to call the police, Mrs. Williams said.
Marcos Lozano, Paul's father, flew to Boston in June 1990 and demanded to know why Dr. Bean-Bayog was ending treatment. According to Norma Kilgore, another of the sisters, Dr. Bean-Bayog replied: "Your son is 80 percent suicidal. You know this runs in the family. He'll probably kill himself. I've done all I can for him."
 
'Go to My Apartment'
 After Mr. Lozano began treatment with another therapist, Dr. Gault, he called Mrs. Williams in El Paso and told her, "Go to my apartment and you'll understand."
There, she found, "He had everything meticulously, meticulously in order." And what she saw -- the flashcards and the letters and the sexual fantasies written by Dr. Bean-Bayog -- led her to say, "Bingo, there's the madness."
Under questioning by Dr. Gault, according to documents filed with the family's lawsuit, Mr. Lozano said Dr. Bean-Bayog had engaged in sexual activity with him.
These issues -- whether Dr. Bean-Bayog had a sexual relationship with her patient and whether her therapy was proper -- are now under investigation, both in connection with the lawsuit and in the state inquiry.
In a recent emergency session, the board found that her treatment "did not conform to accepted standards of medical practice." But it did not strip her of her license and referred the case for further hearing to the state Division of Administrative Law Appeals.
Did Dr. Bean-Bayog try to take Mr. Lozano back to infancy and become sexually involved with him? Did she let her own fantasies become intertwined with his? Or did Dr. Bean-Bayog simply do her best to help a nightmare patient, experimenting with what she has acknowledged was "somewhat unconventional" therapy? Or is the answer somewhere in the middle?
 
Accounts Unconfirmed
 In fact, in two weeks of interviewing Mr. Lozano's friends and family members for details of his past, The New York Times could find no confirmation of many of the accounts he later gave to Dr. Bean-Bayog about his childhood.
"What is so hard to understand is that no one ever asked us about these stories," said his sister Pilar Williams, one of Mr. Lozano's five older siblings and the member of the family closest to him emotionally.
Psychiatrists say the reason such a story might not be checked is that many of them believe deeply that the therapist must keep everything in confidence in order to help the patient.
A murky issue is whether Dr. Bean- Bayog's therapy was proper, especially because therapists themselves often disagree on what correct treatment is.
Amy Stromsten, a licensed social worker who first met Mr. Lozano when he was admitted to McLean Hospital in 1986, has given an affidavit in the family's malpractice case. In an interview, she said, "His death was hastened by her therapy."
"This was a wonderful kid who just needed his medication, and she put him into regression therapy, totally disorganizing him," Ms. Stromsten said. "If someone has been sexually abused, you don't take them back there and retraumatize them while they are suicidal."
 
The Demons Return
 In February 1991, after electric-shock treatment prescribed by Dr. Gault, Mr. Lozano seemed improved and returned to El Paso with plans to work in a local hospital. But after two weeks, his demons returned.
"He started clinging to his stuffed animal and he started talking to me in his infantile voice," Mrs. Williams said. He kept muttering, "I miss Margaret."
Finally he said, "I'm hearing her voice again."
"What is the voice telling you?"
"She's telling me to kill myself."
Gathered around his grave on the anniversary of his death, his family mourned the loss of their most brilliant member. In the cold wind, Epiphany Lozano, his mother, kissed her hand and bent to touch his grave.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Behind the Scenes;
To President's Campaign Manager, It's Been a Season of Smooth Sailing

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
Public approval of George Bush's Presidency has been scraping along at historic lows for two months. A third of all Republican voters have consistently rejected the President through the spring's primaries. A drumbeat of news reports is depicting the White House as adrift and bereft of bright ideas. And the prevailing view of Mr. Bush's campaign performance is that it has been, ah, uneven.
Not to worry, says Robert M. Teeter. 
 "You cannot get distracted totally by the primary and forget why we're here. We're here to win the election in November," Mr. Teeter, the Republican poll taker who is running Mr. Bush's campaign, said in a recent conversation. "Disarray stories are around, but, obviously, I don't believe them. In fact, I'm kind of surprised, because I think the campaign is running very well."
He paused and then added, "To be honest with you, I think it's running spectacularly well."
 
Too Nice for Job?
 "Well" is not the adverb of choice among many leading Republicans. Some of them say Mr. Teeter is too complacent, too contemplative, too short of the hair-trigger reflexes a good manager needs for a Presidential political fistfight.
They also say he is too nice. In some Republican campaign circles, his nickname is Blood and Guts, a sarcastic reference to Mr. Teeter's reluctance to employ the pit bull politics that Mr. Bush's last campaign manager, Lee Atwater, used to mangle Michael S. Dukakis in 1988.
"Here's a guy who's an optimist, a guy who has that James Stewart, 'Wonderful Life' quality," said one top Republican campaign consultant. "James Stewart never threw the first punch. Teeter won't either. It's his strength, but it's his biggest weakness."
Witness the last two months, in which Mr. Teeter's campaign was first blind-sided by the anger of New Hampshire voters over the economy and then idled as Mr. Bush's conservative challenger, Patrick J. Buchanan, pasted the South with a blizzard of negative advertisements and caustic speeches.
Mr. Buchanan has since faded. But critics nodded knowingly early last month when, hours before the expiration of Mr. Bush's deadline for Congress to pass his economic-growth legislation, Mr. Teeter was still huddled at the White House with the chief of staff, Samuel K. Skinner, debating the timing and tactics of the President's response.
Mr. Bush had laid down his deadline 52 days earlier.
"There's much too much tactical figuring out what they're going to do in next 48 hours," the House Republican whip, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, said the next day. "They just do not understand the rhythm and strategy of organizing and building a nationwide grass-roots effort."
And yet, there is no ignoring Mr. Teeter's guiding principles: that primaries, public opinion and the economic angst propelling Mr. Bush's nose dive are transient; that people vote the long run, and that voters will conclude that in the long run Mr. Bush is superior to any challenger.
For one thing, Mr. Teeter is no novice. He has worked for the campaigns of every Republican President since Richard M. Nixon -- six campaigns over 24 years. He devised much of the 1976 Republican strategy that carried Gerald R. Ford from 30 points back in the polls to within an ace of Jimmy Carter.
For another, Mr. Teeter's cool approach is a proven winner. "There's no reason to make a drastic shift," he told The Detroit Free Press in May 1988, when he was the principal strategist for a Bush Presidential campaign swooning in the polls against Mr. Dukakis. "There's plenty of time to run the campaign and get the public to focus on the candidate. The polls will right themselves."
And Mr. Bush won easily.
 
Prediction of Closeness
 During an interview at Bush-Quayle headquarters, in a plain 12-story building four blocks from the Oval Office, Mr. Teeter predicted that this year's contest would be far closer. But he argued against making book against Mr. Bush just yet. Two critical elements of the 1992 Presidential race -- the Democratic nominee and the state of the economy in the fall -- are still a matter of guesswork, he said, and the underlying themes of the campaign are only now emerging.
Beyond the economy, he said, he detects new uneasiness about the future. He sees rising fear among middle-class voters that the nation's social fabric is unraveling, and a sense that their financial destiny has suddenly become hostage to events and economies far from their borders.
In Bush campaign parlance, the issues are "jobs, family and peace," and Mr. Teeter is excited about them. "What you've got in that sense is a merger between the two historic big issues in American Presidential elections, which are foreign policy and the domestic economy," he said. "I think there's nobody in the world better placed to integrate those two things and lead the country, based on his experience and ability, than the President."
Mr. Bush's experience, ability and vision are what Mr. Teeter intends to pound into the electoral psyche this spring. The messages will be blended like a fine recording so that Mr. Bush does not sound like a Johnny-one-note, too strident or obsessive on a single topic, but comes across as a reasoned, broad-minded leader.
 
Some Disappointment
 Such insights have made Mr. Teeter perhaps the most respected campaign adviser in either party, although even the best can fumble.
Mr. Teeter was paid nearly $80,000 last fall to advise Dick Thornburgh, an old friend and Mr. Bush's former Attorney General, who was running for the Senate in Pennsylvania. Mr. Teeter told Mr. Thornburgh to run on his record as an experienced and able Washington hand, said one of Mr. Thornburgh's chief aides, Murray Dickman.
Mr. Thornburgh began his race in August with a 40-point lead in the polls. He lost in November by 20 percentage points to a Democrat who painted him as part of the Washington problem rather than part of the solution.
Mr. Teeter gave some of the best advice of the campaign, Mr. Dickman said. But in retrospect, he said, "all of us, including Bob, made a serious mistake" in not paying closer heed to the volatile mix of voter unhappiness toward the Washington establishment.
So this time, Mr. Teeter's planning has added a fourth issue, Congress, to the re-election agenda. The object is both to attack Democrats and to cast Mr. Bush, who as Vice President and President has now been in the White House for a longer uninterrupted stretch than anyone since Franklin D. Roosevelt, as the outsider come to do battle against entrenched Washington.
Mr. Teeter has been more successful since the Pennsylvania contest in guiding the primary campaign against Mr. Buchanan. Mr. Teeter said he deliberately let the Buchanan forces outspend the far-better-financed Bush campaign throughout the South and New Hampshire. Mr. Buchanan, he said, did not run a cost-effective race, and Mr. Teeter did not think that spending more money would add that many more votes for President Bush.
The tactic drove Bush workers to distraction, but it may have worked, since Mr. Buchanan is now out of money and Mr. Bush has a lot to spend. Richard Wirthlin, who was Ronald Reagan's poll taker, said in an interview that it was a very wise decision, and was an example of where Mr. Teeter's laid-back style, counterintuitive though it may be, worked well.
Mr. Teeter allows that the Bush themes have not always come together perfectly in the campaign's initial months. But he says that Mr. Bush opened his re-election race in mid-December under less than ideal conditions: late, with an unanticipated primary opponent, with a new chief of staff and a reshuffling of the White House policy-making machinery, and with pressing economic problems to tackle.
Given that, he said, the campaign has done "spectacularly well" to assemble a nationwide network of fund-raisers and organizers, hire its staff and conduct a frenetic two-month primary campaign across 18 states.
"Sooner or later we'll get judged on our results," Mr. Teeter said. "That's why I guess I like politics so much."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Disarray stories are around, but, obviously, I don't believe them. In fact, I'm kind of surprised, because I think the campaign is running very well," said Robert M. Teeter, President Bush's campaign manager, despite the rejection of the President by a third of Republican voters at the polls. (George Tames for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Slump Vs. Wetlands in Trenton Bill to Revive Construction Permits

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 11

 BODY:
In a battle pitting builders against citizens groups and environmentalists, the New Jersey Assembly is to vote on Monday on a bill that would automatically extend through 1994 all building permits that have expired in the last three years.
Builders say the extension will spur construction in a time of recession. But citizens groups say it would damage the environment by allowing builders to skirt strict laws passed since the permits were issued. 
 The so-called fast-track legislation was passed by the Senate earlier this month in a 33-to-1 vote that was heavily Republican. The bill also has strong support among Assembly Republicans, who control that house, 58 to 22.
Gov. Jim Florio, considered a strong supporter of environmental protection laws but also eager to turn around the state's sagging economy, said he was particulary concerned that the bill not endanger the state's fragile wetlands. He said that Scott Weiner, commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Protection, was working with legislative leaders to preserve safeguards in the bill.
 
Florio Watching Bill
 "My understanding is that it is undergoing some changes, and I will take a look at what emerges," the Governor said.
Environmentalists have said they are worried that projects drafted several years ago would not have the same prohibitions against potential damage to wetlands and other environmental considerations that are now mandatory in many local permit laws.
In two examples of protections they are seeking to preserve, the environmentalists cited limiting the number of sewer hookups allowed in developments, which has been reduced in some areas, and requiring higher levels of waste-water treatment.
The bill would grant an automatic extension of most local building permits that expired after Jan. 1, 1989. Because some of those permits were originally issued in 1986 or even earlier, environmentalists maintain that developers will be able to push ahead with projects approved when enviromental restrictions were not as strict.
 
'Poised to Wipe Out 10 Years'
 "Our concern is that without legitimate analysis, the legislation is poised to wipe out 10 years of environmental municipal planning and the gains the Legislature itself has adopted to protect the environment," said Rob Stuart, director of the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, which opposes the permit extension.
Mr. Stuart called the legislation "a power play by the development community to achieve what they have lost at the municipal level, using the recessionary climate as a smokescreen."
Mr. Stuart and Ed McCool, executive director of New Jersey Common Cause, maintain that the lobbying power and campaign donations of the builders are a major factor in the swift advancement of the legislation.
The two citizens groups, joined by New Jersey Environmental Federation, issued a joint statement after the Senate vote linking the success of the legislation to the $443,000 that real-estate interests and builders contributed in last year's legislative elections.
 
Postponed by Recession
 "This legislation moved thorugh committee and the Senate before most people knew what effect it would have," Mr. Stuart said.
But builders and the Republican backers maintain that the proposed extension is driven not by political considerations, but by the need to renew proposed construction projects that were postponed by the recession.
The builders maintain that delays in projects that already have permits would simply increase their costs just when construction should be renewed to spur the sagging economy.
Although Republicans generally support the extension, the only no vote in the Senate was by a Republican, Senator William E. Schluter of Flemington, in Mercer County. He argued that any help the extension were to give the building industry would come at the expense of the environment.

HEADLINE: Hudson Bass Running, but Off Limits to Fishermen

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NYACK, N.Y., April 7

 BODY:
In an annual rite of spring, shad and striped bass are returning to the Hudson River to spawn.
For the dwindling number of commercial fishermen on the river, the fish, although plentiful, are a mixed catch -- a legacy of a 16-year-old controversy about toxic PCB's in the river. The bass, considered unfit for human consumption, must be thrown back while the shad are kept for sale as a gourmet delight. 
 The difference stems from the eating habits of the fish, which both return to the river of their birth to lay eggs. The striped bass eat small fish in the river and thus accumulate PCB's, while the shad do not feed in their six-week sojourn in the river and remain PCB-free.
 
General Electric Plants
 PCB's, or polychlorinated biphenyls, were deposited in the river over a 30-year period ending in 1976 from two General Electric plants in Fort Edward and Hudson Falls. Until that time, PCB's were used in manufacturing electrical equipment because of their excellent insulating qualities.
Although little has been done officially on state plans to cleanse the river of PCB's, the PCB levels of the contaminated fish are declining, according to the State Department of Environmental Conservation.
"But you still can't eat the bass; that's the anomaly," said Christopher Letts of the Hudson River Foundation, a nonprofit group that conducts education programs about the Hudson.
Despite the gradual improvement in the Hudson, the state is still backing a controversial plan to dredge contaminated sediments from the river bottom and bury them on land.
If nothing is done, state environmental officials said, future floods in the upper Hudson River could possibly carry PCB now buried in the river sediment downstream to the spawning areas of the bass.
 
Commercial Fishing Potential
 The plan is now under review by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency as part of a complete re-examination of the PCB problem. Its recommendations, which could range from doing nothing at all to approval of the state plan, are not expected until the summer of 1993.
Meanwhile, fish seem to be flourishing in the river, said Robert Gabrielson, president of the Hudson River Commercial Fishermen's Association, who has been fishing in the Hudson for 50 years.
In addition to large numbers of striped bass and shad, the river supports a population of "millions of catfish," blue crabs and American eels, he said. If commercial fishing for them were permitted, he said, "the economic value to the Hudson Valley would be enormous."
"There's been no decline in the fish, only a decline in fishermen," he said, attributing it to the state ban on commercial fishing for striped bass. "When I was a young man, there used to be hundreds of fishermen on the river. Now there are only 40 to 50."
In 1991, the last year for which figures are available, the state issued 90 commercial shad fishing licenses, down from 144 in 1988.
One of the license holders, Ron Ingold of Edgewater, N.J., fishes in the shadow of the George Washington Bridge. Mr. Gabrielson, another license holder, and his son, Robert Jr., fish out of Nyack, just north of the Tappan Zee Bridge.
 
Shad and Striped Bass
 Mr. Ingold and Mr. Gabrielson set nets in the river, trapping the fish as they swim upriver in the flood tides twice a day. Using old-fashioned muscle power, they pull the nets up by hand and remove the fish, which weigh three to four pounds, one by one.
Coming into the Burd Street Marina here in two boats last Monday, the opening day of the shad season, the Gabrielsons unloaded several boxes of fish.
Mr. Gabrielson pulled the boxes of shad into his ice house for shipment later to the Fulton Fish Market in New York. He left the others containing striped bass with two technicians from the Department of Environmental Conservation, Peter Liebig and Robert Morse, for PCB testing.
The Federal Food and Drug Administration guidelines for safety in fish are less than 2 parts per million of PCB's. The limit is based on studies showing that PCB's could cause cancer in laboratory animals, but there is no conclusive evidence showing that it is a human carcinogen.
In its latest official report, dated December 1991, the State Department of Environmental Conservation said that PCB levels in striped bass had markedly declined in the lower Hudson River. In 1978, the average level was 18.1 parts per million, dropping to 6.1 in 1980 and 2.79 in 1990.
"While this report presents some good news about PCB levels in striped bass in the Hudson, it is not a clear sign that all is well," said Thomas C. Jorling, commissioner of the department. "Concentrations of PCB remain high enough to present a risk to the public health and the environment."

GRAPHIC: Photo: PCB levels have been declining in the Hudson River, although little has been done officially to cleanse it, but some fish are still inedible. Robert Gabrielson, right, president of the Hudson River Commercial Fishermen's Association, said that if more commercial fishing were permitted, the value to the Hudson Valley would be enormous. Fishing with him in Nyack, N.Y., was Andrew Brennan. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Top Athletes Are Being Wooed to Fill Some Big Shoes

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
Forget the burning question about how the United States basketball team will fare at the Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, with Patrick Ewing, Charles Barkley and the other pros taking on the world.
Consider this one: How good at selling shoes will the Algerian runner Noureddine Morceli be? Or Jane N'Goto, a 3,000-meter specialist from Kenya, or the triple-jump record-holder, Inessa Kravets of Russia? 
 Morceli is under contract to Nike; N'Goto and Kravets to Reebok. Both athletic-shoe companies have signed numerous foreign athletes to sponsorship deals to broaden the overseas marketability of their shoes and apparel at a time when their future sales growth is primarily in Europe.
"The more athletes you have around the world, the more you develop a reputation that we're a company athletes want to sign with," said John Duerdan, the Welsh-born president of Reebok.
 
'The Best and the Brightest'
 Companies have been reaching out to bankroll the shoe, apparel, financial and travel needs of athletes rising up from the crazy-quilt economic and political landscape of the former Soviet Union, changing Eastern bloc nations and third world countries. Their goal is not geared to create immediate retail riches but rather to use the spotlight of an Olympic year to show consumers that world-class athletes compete in their products. Said Steve Miller, Nike's director of athletics: "Our philosophy is to secure the best and the brightest."
Reebok, for example, recently signed 12 middle-distance Kenyan runners, including Moses Kiptanui, who in February last month broke the world indoor record for 3,000 meters. Reebok also signed 15 athletes from the Unified Team, among them Lyudmila Norshilenko, the 1991 women's world champion in the 100-meter hurdles, and Rodion Gataullin, the European pole-vault champion.
Nike's stable of world-class shoe-wearing athletes include Sergei Bubka, the Ukrainian pole-vaulter who was the first to surpass a height of 20 feet, Richard Chelimo, the Kenyan long-distance runner, and Katrin Krabbe, the German sprinter.
Sponsoring world-class athletes is nothing new for athletic-shoe companies. Germany's Adidas pioneered the signing of national sports federations and Olympic committees to shoe and apparel contracts and still has ties with about 100 countries. In the United States, Olympians such as Carl Lewis and Jackie Joyner-Kersee serve as well-paid human billboards for shoe companies.
 
Like a Political Spy Trial
 The rivalries between the equipment companies have had all the intrigue of a political spy novel. In 1968, a representative for Puma, the German rival to Adidas, was jailed by Mexican authorities for trying to import shoes into the country for athletes to wear during the Mexico City Olympics. Under-the-table payments to athletes were the rule rather than the exception before athletes were allowed to compete for prize money, and some competitors even divided their loyalties for spoils, wearing an Adidas shoe on one foot and a Puma on the other.
But the emergence of new companies in the game, the diminished power of Adidas and Puma, combined with the new politics of Eastern Europe and the clear emergence of African athletes, have thrown open the doors to pursue available athletes or uncommitted sports federations or committees.
Reebok's pursuit of its Kenyan athletes began several years ago with attempts to secure the sponsorship rights to the entire national team.
"We went through official channels and actually signed a contract, but if you sign a deal with one committee, it's a different committee one week later," said Dave Singleton, the marketing vice president of Reebok's international division. "There was no consistency about whom to approach."
Reebok turned to Kim McDonald, a London-based agent with ties to Kenyan athletes.
"Until about two years ago, African athletes had a bad reputation for being with several shoe companies at once," said McDonald. "They'd say O.K. to Nike and wear Reebok and say yes to Reebok and wear New Balance."
Thirteen Kenyan athletes signed with Reebok in 1991, a roster expanded to 25 last month in a contract worth about $1 million, said McDonald. "To Reebok's credit, they took a lot of athletes they'd never heard of," he said, a strategy aimed at keeping future Olympians in reserve.
The shoe companies are not in a mad frenzy to sign athletes willy-nilly. They are trying to be selective in providing backing to likely and future Olympians who might be featured on television and magazine covers winning international and Olympic events attired in the companies' products.
 
Track Club Pursued
 In 1990, before German unification, Nike pursued the Neubrandenburg track club, a breeding ground for East German champions, including Krabbe, the runner Grit Breuer, the shot-putter Astrid Kumbernuss and the heptathlete Heike Tischler.
"We knew unification was at hand and knew it would be a German training ground," said Miller. "Other companies probably thought about doing it, but it wasn't on the back burner for us. We were very proactive about it."
Nike's support of more than $1 million provides equipment and apparel for the members of the club, a general assistance fund to the athletes, stipends and individual contracts with the top stars and sponsorship of the Nike Neubrandenburg track meet in Germany.
Nike's signing of Bubka, the pole-vaulting star of the former Soviet team, to a long-term contract that is being renegotiated is regarded as the company's glasnost coup. "When he started breaking records, he was wooed by everybody, including J. C. Penney," said Miller. "It was highly competitive. He had worn Adidas as part of the Soviet Union and now he was free."
The Nike-Bubka contract calls for the pole-vaulter to promote cross-training shoes, a small but growing category for the company, while continuing to wear apparel by Adidas. "His domination of an event that requires as much strength and skill is the kind of association we want to build on," said John de la Forest, the vice president of Nike's European marketing.
With the rigid state control of the Soviet Union, Bubka would still be shod in Adidas, the former trailblazer in locking up federations full of athletes. Because of its sheer size and remaining links to national federations, it remains formidable. But it is troubled.
Bernard Tapie, the Frenchman to whom the Dassler family sold Adidas, is reportedly underfinanced, and his president, Rene Jaggi, will leave by year's end.
There are signs of how respect for Adidas isn't what it was when the Soviet Union was a totalitarian regime. One is a recent threat by the now-charterless state sports committee, Sovintersport, to sue the company for reneging on a $2.9 million contract to support former Soviet athletes.
"Because they have ceased to exist, we canceled the contract," said Tom Harrington, the vice president of marketing communications for Adidas, which is outfitting the Unified Team. But Adidas will have a contract with the Unified Team's Olympic Committee, and their athletes may include some of those who competed under the previous contract.
According to Carr, Horst Dassler, whose promotional genius built Adidas and whose death roiled it, "had everybody in Europe under his thumb."
"He told the Russians what to do," Carr said. "Now it's wide open. Nobody is around to tell the Czechs they have to wear the three stripes."
Adidas's weakness opened the doors for Nike and other firms like Mizuno and Asics, the Japanese company that also sells sneakers under the Tiger brand and sponsors the Unified and Italian volleyball teams, among others.
"Other companies can go in and cherry-pick the athletes," said Harrington, adding that Adidas will not spend the cash to pursue pursue federations and athletes wholeheartedly. "It's a free market with all its benefits and disadvantages. We are all battling for the same athletes."
Nevertheless, scores of countries (a list that will be trimmed through July) will wear Adidas apparel in Barcelona, including the Unified, British, French, German, Kenyan and Ethiopian teams, said Adrian Leek, the track-and-field business unit manager for Adidas U.S.A., which is operated by a management team assembled by Peter Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner.
 
Reebok a Late-Comer
 In the early 1980's, Nike had so many world and United States athletes under contract, they did not know how to use them all. Reebok did not have that problem. It came late to the starting blocks.
Paul Fireman, the chairman of Reebok, "went to the Seoul Olympics in 1988 and nobody was wearing Reeboks," said Carr. "It was an embarrassment that Adidas and Nike and Asics had all the world athletes. They've made a conscious effort to identify with world athletes."
Part of Reebok's problem four years ago was that it was better known for fashion and aerobics footwear than for performance shoes top athletes want to wear.
How the shoe companies measure the impact of athlete-endorsed shoes and apparel is an uncertain science, once you shift the emphasis from shoes identified with the likes of Michael Jordan or Bo Jackson. Somehow they know they have to advertise on Olympians' bodies even if they cannot directly measure the impact. Harrington calls the Olympics "our fashion show."
Whether the strategy that puts the Kenyan steeplechaser Moses Kiptanui in Reeboks does anything but cover his feet is debatable. But Reebok says it is a small price to pay. It has a Kenyan distributor generating modest sales and a venture with a distributor in Russia that will open a Moscow store in July.
"I stopped some kids in Red Square and one had a pair of Reebok 4600's on, and I asked where he got them," said Brendon Dillingstone, Reebok's vice president of international operations. "He said on holiday in the U.S. Lots of people are going out of the country and coming back with branded product."
But with domestic sales fairly flat, the only way to expand their presence globally is for the shoe companies to outfit superior athletes wherever they may be.
"We don't retail in every country where we have athletes signed up," said Dusty Kidd, another Nike executive. "It matters more where they compete than where they come from. Richard Chelimo may not be a big name in Kenya, but he's an international star. Where he runs is important."

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Brown;
Codes and Classes On Sex Offenses Draw Praise

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

 BODY:
In the fall of 1990, Brown University here gained notoriety when a so-called rape list - graffiti naming alleged rapists - was found on the walls of a campus bathroom. As a result, the university adopted procedures to deal with sexual assault and harassment on campus. Those procedures are now winning praise.
 The 1990 incident provoked a campus debate about how the university had been handling sex-related complaints. Led by the Committee of Four, four students who becaume the spokeswomen for the cause, students accused the univeristy of ineptness in dealing with the issue. 
 "I know, based on what I've seen since 1991, Brown has been doing a lot for victims of sexual assault and for the campus in general," said Therese Curtin, chairwoman of the Rhode Island State Task Force on Sexual Assault on Campuses. Brown is a member of the task force, which was formed in January 1991.
 "Brown's participating in the state-wide task force speaks positively of Brown's commitment to addressing any policy changes needed," said Peg Langhamer, executive director of the Rhode Island Rape Crisis Center. "I think it is clear that Brown and the other colleges and universities are working together to create the best-quality services for victims and to amend polices where needed."
 Last spring, the University Disciplinary Council successfully heard its first three cases dealing with allegations of sexual assault. As a result of those hearings, one student was expelled, one was put on probation for the rest of his undergraduate years with anotation about the charges on his student transcript, and the third was suspended for a semester with an entry on his transcript.
 Last summer, the university created a separate offense in the nonacademic disciplinary code: sexual misconduct, defined as nonconsensual phycical contact of a sexual nature. Previously, cases involving sexual assault were in a category of behavior that causes or can reasonably be expected to cause physical harm or shows flagrant disrepect for the well-being of others.
 
'Misconoduct,' Not 'Assault'
 "Pursuing cases within the university is more viable than taking cases to the Providence courts, in the sense that many women won't go into the more public arena," said the dean of student life, Robin Rose.
 Toby Simon, the associate dean of the college, said: "Our offense is termed 'sexual misconduct,' not 'sexual assault' - that's by design. The univeristy did not want to have an offense in its code which is a felony in the state of Rhode Island. Also, it is a broader term which encompasses more behaviors, behaviors which wouldn't fall under the strictest legal definition of assault."
 Jesselyn Brown, a member of the Committee of Four who is a senior form Potomac, Md., majoring in American civilization, women's studies and political science, said: "Because we now condemn sexual misconduct in our policy, we send the message that Brown will not tolerate sexual violence on campus and is willing to back it up with disciplinary action. Many other colleges condemn sexual violence in theory but not in action."
 Brown established a sexual-assault task force in the spring of 1991. Divided into committees on policy, education and communication, the task force looks at the issue of sexual assault day to day.
 
Class on Date Rape
 "The task force exists to tackle the ongoing issue of sexual assault on campus and seves as a forum to make sure the system is working," Ms. Brown said. "As long as sexual assault is a problem, the task force will exist."
 A mandatory freshman class meeting dealing with the issue of sexual assault of "date rape" greeted the members of the class of 1995. Entitled "Sex Without Consent: Implications for Brown Students," the meeting was first held during freshmen orientation in August.
 The Sexual Assault Peer Educators, a group of students from all areas of campus life including fraternity and sorority members, athletes and women's advocates, led the orientation. It included a role-playing session involving a series of events leading to the disclosure of sexual assault by one character.
 "It is important for freshmen to know that acquaintance rape does happen on all college campuses and to get them thinking about it," said Karen Hull, a peer educator who is a junior majoring in applied mathematics and economics from Bardonia, N.Y.
 Mr. Brown said: "I think it's important not to forget the rape list. Campuses tend to suffer from institutional amnesia. We need to remember so it does not happen again, so the same mistakes are not made."

HEADLINE: The Quest for a New Zoning Plan

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
THERE may never be a better time to overhaul the Zoning Resolution that governs the physical evolution of New York City. But that does not mean that it will -- or can -- be changed.
The current ordinance, enacted in 1916, encouraged the development of tall towers set in broad plazas, introduced floor-area restrictions as a way of controlling density and divided the city into residential, commercial and manufacturing districts. Since its last thorough revision in 1961, however, it has become so heavily laden with amendments and revisions that it now seems a mass of contradictory impulses, no longer embodying a vision or plan. 
 "The zoning ordinance does both too much and too little," said Peter D. Salins, chairman of the urban affairs and planning department at Hunter College and senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research.
"On the one hand, it is a document of staggering complexity," he said. "On the other hand, with all its detail, all its attempts at fine-tuning, all its layers of discretionary review, all its community and watchdog-group involvement, the increments of development that emerge from this regulatory monster are widely despised on all sides."
And this might be the moment to act. "Because there's so little development, it's probably a terrific time to redo the Zoning Resolution," said Robert F. Wagner Jr., a former chairman of the Planning Commission, at a well-attended planning and zoning symposium held on Jan. 30.
Free from the pressures posed by intense construction, planners have the chance to chart a fresh course in zoning, instead of incessantly fine-tuning a document that took effect 31 years ago, when New York was a much different city, before communities were given a formal role in land-use review. Indeed, under the new Charter, the planning agency must prepare a comprehensive planning and zoning report every four years. The first is due in December and might form the germ of a new zoning ordinance.
However, the same economic paralysis that theoretically would free planners for such a big task has also devastated the City Planning Department, whose full-time staff has been cut 25 percent since 1990. Moreover, the environmental reviews that have been instituted since the 1961 Zoning Resolution might make it financially and logistically impossible to embark on citywide zoning. An environmental-impact statement for a single project can take years to produce and cost millions of dollars.
Perhaps the most basic reason the Zoning Resolution may never be fundamentally rewritten is the lack of political will to do so. If zoning is the regulatory tool by which a comprehensive plan is shaped, some broadly held vision of New York's future would be a necessary precursor to a thoroughly revised ordinance. It is hard to imagine such a consensus' being developed when specific issues like shelters for the homeless and garbage incinerators have proved so divisive.
YET there seems to be widespread agreement that something ought to be done. Few are content with the current zoning ordinance, a cumbersome, bloated, 835-page patchwork that can be navigated only by a handful of specialists, leaving everyone else -- developers, architects, community leaders and neighbors -- at a baffled disadvantage.
"There's certainly a need to simplify the Zoning Resolution," said Richard L. Schaffer, the chairman of the city's Planning Commission and director of the Planning Department. "What I'd like to do is prune away the accreted 30 years of amendments, to the extent possible."
In a broader sense, Mr. Schaffer said: "We need to overhaul the Zoning Resolution to accommodate change in economically realistic ways that are more sensitive to the existing built environment. You've got to overhaul the text and overhaul the maps."
New York created the nation's first comprehensive ordinance with the 1916 Zoning Resolution. By the 1950's, its defects were clear. In language strikingly similar to that heard at the symposium, James Felt, then the planning chairman, said on Feb. 15, 1959, that "the price we pay for clinging to an obsolete zoning structure -- burdened by the weight of amendments it was never intended to support -- is already too high."
The zoning ordinance he introduced that day, crafted by the architectural firm of Voorhees, Walker, Smith & Smith, was adopted in December 1960 after numerous revisions. Now, some people say, the ordinance is once again overburdened.
"The present city system may have come about as far as it can, as a credible regulatory mechanism," wrote Norman Marcus, former general counsel of the Planning Department and a partner at Bachner, Tally, Polevoy & Misher, in a paper prepared for the symposium, "Planning and Zoning New York City -- Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow," held at New York University.
"THE passage of 30 years has not aged the ordinance and its administrative apparatus gracefully," Mr. Marcus said. He called the resolution "a collage of ad hoc, jerry-built and more thoughtful inspirations, grafted onto a long-disowned armature."
"I believe it's nearing a nervous breakdown," said John Shapiro, principal in the planning consulting firm of Abeles, Phillips, Preiss & Shapiro. "We should set about overhauling it with all due speed."
However, Marla G. Simpson, director of land-use planning for Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, noted that "everybody says they're for simplicity, but it depends on whose ox is being gored."
"On that score," she said, "the developers don't sound any different than the communities. They want what they're for to move quickly and they want what they're against not to have a discretionary route."
The most specific and radical vision of a new Zoning Resolution to be offered at the symposium came from Mr. Salins. He differed from many of his colleagues in his view of zoning's basic purpose.
"While planners have long believed that zoning was their God-given and court-sanctioned way of implementing a 'comprehensive plan' and pursuing other planning objectives of the moment," Mr. Salins wrote, it was actually created "to prevent just three kinds of harms: excessive density, the juxtaposition of incompatible activities (especially factories near homes) and the most blatant of visual offenses.
"I propose we go back to the principle that zoning is a harm-preventing, rather than benefit-creating, enterprise."
In contrast to the current 125 district categories and 37 special districts, where zoning rules seek to perpetuate the special characteristics that define a given area, Mr. Salins proposed 18 zoning-district categories and no special districts. He said development ought to be permitted largely on an "as-of-right" basis, without need for discretionary review and special permits.
He urged that zoning be used to support what the market determines to be the "highest and best use" of given sites and that higher-ranked land uses, such as residential, be generally permitted in lower-ranked districts, such as manufacturing zones, instead of being prohibited.
Later in the symposium, R. Susan Motley, a former planning commission member, said, "It horrifies me when I hear conversation about the 'free market,' when I know that large developments are subsidized."
Marilyn Jordan Taylor, urban design partner in the architectural firm of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, proposed a zoning hierarchy based not on use but on degrees of desired change.
RATHER than residential, commercial and manufacturing districts, in her proposal there would be preserved districts, where "the emphasis would be on proscription -- allowing uses to evolve but staying with the physical norm"; stabilizing districts, where "the emphasis would be on balance -- meeting the average" and changing districts, where "zoning tools would require response to specific articulated public objectives" and public investment.
Mr. Schaffer said that, in certain respects, an overhaul of the Zoning Resolution was already under way, with the current development of a comprehensive waterfront plan, a citywide industrial study and a reexamination of community-facility regulations, which have been unchanged since 1961.
Yet even these broad initiatives might be seen as more piece-by-piece layering. And Mr. Wagner, who is now vice chairman of the L H Research concern, a public opinion and market research firm, said any attempt to rewrite zoning "should be done all at once, as opposed to incrementally."
Significant hurdles loom in pursuit of a new or throughly revised resolution.
"While there are many of us in the trenches who think it should be done, we really don't have a very high official who'd take this on as a major political platform," said Sigurd Grava, president of the American Planning Association's New York chapter, director of the graduate planning program at Columbia University and a vice president of the Parsons Brinkerhoff engineering concern.
"The idea of starting from scratch is probably a nightmare," said Samuel H. Lindenbaum, a zoning expert and partner in the law firm of Rosenman & Colin. "The city is divided into 59 community boards and in any community board you can't get them to agree on what's best for that area."
Besides the low rung occupied by zoning on the political agenda and the lack of city planners to carry it out, another obstacle is the absence of an overall plan.
"We need more than a new Zoning Resolution," said Kent L. Barwick, president of the Municipal Art Society, "we need to build a consensus about what we want to be in terms that are sufficiently particular to allow the city to adopt general physical master plans."
Mr. Schaffer said the Planning Department was "going to try, within the constraints of staff and time, to articulate a vision and comprehensive planning policies."
But the commission and department must overcome years of inertia in which the implicit message from City Hall seemed to be, "Make no big plans."
"If anything epitomizes the failure of New York City to plan, it is the fact that the Zoning Resolution is the plan," said Richard T. Anderson, president of the Regional Plan Association. "Most people think of it in physical terms. That's a fundamental mistake."
Yet planning on a citywide scale might become ensared in the city's environmental quality review process (called by its acronym, CEQR; pronounced "SEEK-er") and its byproduct, the environmental-impact statement (known as an E.I.S.).
"IN an ironic turn of events," wrote Michael Kwartler, director of the Environmental Simulation Center at the New School for Social Research, "the idea of the E.I.S., conceived as supportive of land-use planning, has proven in practice to inhibit areawide planning and zoning."
"You really need good environmental planning," Mr. Schaffer said. "At the same time, this litigation-driven process known as CEQR has become a dysfunctional impediment to good planning and to updating the Zoning Resolution and the zoning maps."
"I believe state law allows us to substantially reform the city environmental review process," he said, "and we'll be doing that -- with rule-making, management reforms and developing methodologies for areawide E.I.S.'s for area-wide rezonings."
Stuart K. Pertz, a partner at Haines Lundberg Waehler, successor to the Voorhees firm, said, "There may be a way to posit a plan -- a concept, a philosophy, a position -- which could be clear enough so that people could understand its direction but not so specific that it requres an E.I.S."
"When I was on the Planning Commission," he said, "the reason I was frustrated every minute was that I was told, word for word, that there could not be planning because planning requires an E.I.S. and the city couldn't afford an E.I.S. It was like the police saying, 'We'd like to save people from accidents but we're enjoined from doing so.' "
But Ms. Simpson said, "It seems too facile to say, 'We could do it but for the evils of environmental review.' " She suggested that officials abbreviate the process by limiting impact statements to the most critical areas of concern rather than studying scores of issues in minute detail, more to forestall lawsuits than to enhance planning.
Even if a new Zoning Resolution should be adopted for the 21st century, it would certainly have unintended effects, particularly during the transition from the 1961 ordinance, when developers would exploit provisions that were on the verge of extinction.
Ultimately, even the best ordinance would have limits.
"A zoning resolution is not going to be able to deal with the root problems that are out there," Mr. Wagner said. "You can put any kind of zoning you want in Harlem, but it won't change the fact that 82 percent of all births are to single mothers."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 19, 1992, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about the quest for a new zoning resolution for New York City misidentified the date of the current one. It took effect in 1961.
