HEADLINE: Pulling Down the Corporate Clubhouse

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
It used to be so easy, so civilized, more a social ritual than a chore. The members of the corporate board would fly in the night before, dine with their old friend, the chief executive, sharing after-dinner brandy and camaraderie. Each director would receive a slender binder of briefing papers that, typically, got a cursory read before the formality of the next morning's board meeting. The chief executive called the tune, and the board hummed along.
"Those days of the corporate club are over," said Gerard Roche, chairman of Heidrick & Struggles, a big executive recruiter. "There's a lot more tension between the board and the chief executive today, but also a lot more communication. Things are going in a healthy but uncomfortable direction." 
 Robert C. Stempel, the chairman and chief executive of the General Motors Corporation, found out just how uncomfortable things can get at the giant auto maker's board meeting in Dallas last Monday. He was removed as the head of the board's executive committee, a powerful advisory and decision-making forum, and he was replaced by an outside director, John G. Smale, the retired chief executive of the Procter & Gamble Company. Mr. Stempel remains G.M.'s chief executive, the person responsible for running the nation's largest car maker day to day.
Yet the abrupt move, accompanied by a board statement declaring the need for a "more aggressive management approach," was seen as a striking step by the outside directors to assert themselves and accelerate the pace of streamlining at G.M., which last year lost $7 billion on its North American car operations. (Related stories on the shakeup, Forum, page 15, and on G.M. Europe's Opel, page 6.)
It is but another in a series of recent cases in which boards or big investors have pressed well-known C.E.O.'s to do everything from slim down their pay packets to retire -- and done so successfully.
Last month, the Chrysler Corporation's board told Lee A. Iacocca that he could not stay on as chairman past his slated retirement date of Dec. 31, despite his appeals to the board for an extension. And the company reported last week that Mr. Iacocca took a 35 percent pay cut last year to roughly $3 million in salary, stock and other compensation.
In February, after John F. Akers, the chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, met with representatives of California state's big public pension fund, the company said Mr. Akers would have his base salary cut 40 percent, to less than $1.6 million. At Citicorp, the board urged John S. Reed, the chairman, to bring outsiders into the top ranks of the nation's largest bank and onto its powerful management committee. At Sears, Roebuck & Company, once the nation's largest retailer but a lackluster performer for years now, Edward Brennan, who is chairman, chief executive and president, is under pressure from shareholders to divvy up his jobs because they say he has too much power.
And others like Andrew C. Sigler, chief executive of the Champion International Corporation, have been singled out for receiving bonuses year after year when investors could have done better with Treasury bills than with Champion's stock.
The outside directors' putsch at G.M., a company renowned for hidebound, insular ways, was a surprise, but it -- and the actions at other corporations -- is part of the shifting balance of power in corporate America. The grasp of the iron-fisted C.E.O. is weakening as corporate boards become independent-minded and institutional investors flex their muscles.
As watchdogs on management, and pressure groups, they can be very effective. Institutional investors like pension funds have the biggest shareholdings in most large companies. Legally, the board's role is to oversee the management of a company on behalf of the owners, the shareholders. And naturally, it is the outside directors, in theory, who are best placed to hold management accountable.
"In America, we've traditionally had John Wayne C.E.O.'s, the lone individual with all the power in his hands," said Jay Lorsch, a professor at the Harvard Business School. "But the norms in corporate America are changing under pressure from institutional investors and outside directors."
The roll call of major companies whose C.E.O.'s are now under scrutiny from their boards and big investors is partly a byproduct of the intensity of global competition. Capitalism's watchdogs only become concerned when there are problems. G.M., I.B.M. and Citicorp -- three icons of corporate America -- have all reported 1991 losses that range from sizable to staggering. "The notion of these three companies and their C.E.O.'s being under pressure would have been dismissed as lunacy 10 years ago," said Donald Jacobs, dean of Northwestern's Kellogg Graduate School of Management. "But today, it's simply a fact of life."
Still, far more than general economic conditions are behind the effort to restrain the power of C.E.O.'s. The recent furor over executive pay has been attributable not just to the multimillion-dollar pay packets some C.E.O.'s were lugging home at the same time they were laying off workers by the thousands; it also stems from the fact that they seemed to be effectively paying themselves. Too often, the C.E.O.'s picked the board members, who in turn rubber-stamped huge compensation deals for the C.E.O.
"C.E.O. pay is merely the symptom of the larger problem -- the lack of accountability in corporate America," said Sarah Teslik, executive director of the Council of Institutional Investors, which advises pension funds with total assets of $400 billion.
Executive pay may look excessive but, according to big investors and their advisers, the far greater cost of a system of corporate government stacked in favor of management is companies that are inbred and stodgy, unable to compete successfully against more nimble foreign rivals. "And General Motors is an absolutely classic example of that inability to compete in the global economy," said Ralph Whitworth, president of United Shareholders Association, an investors' advocacy group.
So big pension funds like the California Public Employees Retirement System and the five New York City public employee funds have pushed for a series of structural reforms in corporations, including having a majority of directors be outsiders and putting all outside directors on the board's nominating and compensation committees.
Some big investors and shareholders' groups even advocate curbing the power of C.E.O.'s by splitting up the jobs of the chief executive and chairman, and giving the chairman's post to an outsider. Today, most American corporations combine the two jobs. In Europe, however, splitting the jobs is the norm and more American companies are starting to consider the European pattern -- sometimes because they are being forced to.
The New York City Employees Retirement System and United Shareholders are sponsoring a proxy resolution to break up Mr. Brennan's job at Sears. Like most shareholder initiatives, the resolution is intended mainly as a symbolic step to get management's attention, both at the retailer and in the corporate community in general.
 
C.E.O.'s Get Nervous
 And by that yardstick, the calls for a split chairman-chief executive role are being heard. "Boards are starting to talk about it," said Mr. Roche, the executive recruiter, who is also a director of the Morrison Knudsen Corporation. "It's coming." John Nash, president of the National Association of Corporate Directors, estimates that within five years as many as 40 percent of the Fortune 500 companies will have split the jobs of chairman and C.E.O., compared with the handful that have separated the roles today. "A lot of C.E.O.'s are getting very uncomfortable," Mr. Nash observed.
Appointing a separate chairman and more outside board members who are genuinely independent -- not suppliers, consultants, legal advisers or friends -- are seen as checks on the power of the C.E.O. In a sense, the big institutional investors are addressing a concern about the way companies are seemingly controlled by management insiders that goes back to the 1930's, when A. A. Berle Jr. and Gardiner Means wrote "The Modern Corporation and Private Property," describing how the ownership of American companies became scattered and the stockholders no longer had much influence over the management. More recently, the business historian Alfred D. Chandler Jr., in his Pulitzer prize-winning chronicle of American industry "The Visible Hand," viewed the same characteristics and termed the system "managerial capitalism."
In both management and academic circles, there is a lively debate about just where the balance of power rests today. In Senate testimony last fall, Bruce Atwater, the chief executive of General Mills Inc. and head of the Business Roundtable's task force on corporate governance, said the world of dominant managers and powerless shareholders described by the likes of Berle, Means and Chandler is "unrecognizable in the 1990's." Instead, he went on, large institutional investors control more than half of the shares in America's 1,000 largest companies today and these "powerful investors wield increasing power over the economic system of the United States."
Yet the power of big investors is far less concentrated, or monolithic, than the aggregate numbers might suggest. First, the big corporate pension funds like those covering the workers of G.M. and I.B.M are not pressing corporate boards to change. They are part of the corporate club, and generally keep their mouths shut. So it is only the public pension funds from a handful of states and municipalities -- California, Massachusetts, Wisconsin, New York state and New York City, among others -- that are the institutional activists. Nor are the big funds necessarily monolithic in their views. "Institutional investors have about as much in common as brunets," Ms. Teslik observed.
And even giant funds like the California Public Employees Retirement System, or Calpers, with its $68 billion in assets, typically hold small stakes in a few hundred companies. Its 4.3 million shares of G.M., for example, were less than 1 percent of the auto maker's total stock. Accordingly, a fund's influence on any particular company is limited.
 
Performance Pressure
 But because their investment in corporate America is so extensive, the big funds are being forced to act more like long-term owners. "We can't bail out easily," said DeWitt Bowman, the chief investment officer of Calpers. "So the only way we can improve our performance is to prod corporate America into better performance -- taking a long-term view and managing in the interests of the shareholders."
The reforms Calpers and other big funds are advocating, from executive pay to putting more outsiders in positions of power, are an attempt to send a message to companies. "We've found that poor corporate performance is indicative of a lack of openness in corporate governance," Mr. Bowman said.
Calpers has earmarked a dozen companies to pressure. For example, the California fund is seeking more independent boards at Salomon Brothers and Time Warner, the reform of executive pay policies in companies including I.B.M. and American Express, and improving communication with big investors through the creation of shareholder advisory committees at companies like Chrysler and Polaroid. Similarly, the New York City public pension funds, with total assets of more than $40 billion, are pressing several companies for changes, including appointing more outside directors at General Dynamics and creating an independent compensation committee at Reebok International.
"We're not trying to get involved in day-to-day management," explained Elizabeth Holtzman, New York City's Comptroller and investment adviser to the city's funds. "But we can try to make these companies more accountable. C.E.O.'s may not like it, but they are starting to sit up and take notice when institutional investors express concern."
Most experts and many C.E.O.'s say the increased attention from big investors and the trend toward more independent boards are constructive developments. The shift, they agree, is certainly an improvement over the 1980's, when corporate raiders were the harsh agents of change, the self-appointed policemen of capitalism. "It was very expensive in terms of debt, bankruptcies and resources wasted," said Robert Glauber, a fellow at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government and former Undersecretary of the Treasury for finance. "What we're seeing now is a very healthy sign, the process working from within the system as shareholders press management to reform."
 
The Short-Term Outlook
 Still, some executives and business experts warn that there is a danger in judging corporate performance solely on share prices, the gauge used by institutional investors. "Big investors should communicate with management and this evolution is a positive thing," said Donald Clark, the chief executive of Household International Inc. and a member of the Business Roundtable's corporate governance panel. "But institutional investors tend to have a short-term time horizon, and that's one of the weaknesses of our system, making it more difficult for management to make long-term investment decisions."
Fund managers and efficient-market theorists disagree, but some longtime students of business are also skeptical about the balance of power shifting too far in favor of market-bound fund managers. "Capital markets are efficient but not effective if you are going to compete internationally," said Mr. Chandler, an emeritus professor at the Harvard Business School. "That is one of the real lessons of corporate America in the last 20 years."
 
 
 
HOW TO MAKE CAPITALISM WORK
 "The only way for capitalism to work is for owners to take responsibility," declares Lester Thurow, dean of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Sloan School of Management.
That, in sum, is the rationale for big investors becoming more involved in running the companies whose shares they hold. Big public pension funds have been moving in that direction recently, but they haven't gone far enough, Mr. Thurow says.
Investors like the California Public Employees Retirement System, or Calpers, should be sitting on the board, not having occasional meetings with C.E.O.'s, Mr. Thurow contends. "The nub of the matter is having long-term owners in the boardroom," he said. And, in Mr. Thurow's view, big institutions like Calpers should hold stakes of 20 percent or more in a handful of companies, rather than owning a small stake in hundreds of companies.
In his new book "Head to Head: The Coming Economic Battle Among Japan, Europe and America," Mr. Thurow advocates changing American laws to permit the formation of Japanese or European-style business groups in the United States. The Glass-Steagall Act of 1933, which prevents banks and other financial institutions from owning large stakes in industrial corporations, should be repealed, he recommends, and antitrust laws loosened.
The corporate groups would link financial institutions, companies and suppliers -- each owning a stake in other members of the group, and each with a stake in the long-term health and survival of the other. Such groups, Mr. Thurow says, would be better cushioned against economic adversity and better able to compete internationally.

 
 
CHECKS AND BALANCES AT THE TOP
 Benjamin M. Rosen, the chairman of the Compaq Computer Corporation, owes his post to the fact that his venture capital firm provided seed money for the Houston-based computer maker. In fact, Sevin Rosen Partners has tried to place its representatives on many of some 50 high-tech companies it has helped start up during the last decade. "We're trying to return to the traditional form of corporate governance where owners are on the board," Mr. Rosen said.
At Compaq, which went public in 1983, chairman and chief executive have always been separate jobs, and Mr. Rosen has always been chairman. Having an outside chairman made it easier to change chief executives last October when Eckhard Pfeiffer replaced Rod Canion as chief executive after a dispute over how quickly the company should move to cut costs and reduce losses.
"The chairman does have a lot more power than just another outside director," Mr. Rosen said. "And when the chairman and the chief executive are the same person, the board is often dominated by the C.E.O."
For his part, Mr. Rosen believes there will be a ripple effect in other boardrooms from last week's shuffle at G.M. "The General Motors thing is going to shake up a lot of outside directors," he said. "It won't be a tidal wave in boardrooms, but it will encourage others to act more independently. And you need genuine checks and balances, people really willing to supervise management."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 19, 1992, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about corporate management misstated terms of a pay cut taken by John F. Akers, chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation. What was reduced by 40 percent was Mr. Akers's total 1991 compensation, not his base salary. The article also misstated circumstances leading to the cut, announced in February. I.B.M. representatives did not meet until March with the California Public Employees Retirement System, which had complained about Mr. Akers's pay, and he was not at that meeting.

PUB-DATE: April 12, 1992

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1720 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Voters;
These Voters Want Change, But Don't Have a Candidate

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB

 BODY:
Like most everyone at the Northeast Bronx Senior Citizens Center, Anita Sollino did not bother to vote in New York's Presidential primary on Tuesday, even though she has been a Democrat for more than 50 years.
"I'm a registered Democrat," Mrs. Sollino said over a card game on Thursday, "but that doesn't mean I vote Democratic. I vote for the man." 
 And Mrs. Sollino, like many at the center for the elderly, said that the Democratic candidates as well as the general state of the country left them cold.
 
Conversations About Crime
 Mrs. Sollino, 74, lives in a Bronx enclave of earnestly maintained homes and mom-and-pop shops where the clock seems to have stopped on V-J Day. The problems of urban blight, poverty and crime more recently associated with the Bronx are spoken about rather than experienced here for the most part, and the buzz on the streets is relaxed.
And in this neighborhood of civil servants, unionized blue-collar workers, housewives and retirees, there is a strong sense that no candidate on the national political scene -- Democrat or Republican -- is fully addressing their concerns.
In the primary, the vote in communities like this one -- white, largely working-class and Catholic -- was light and inconclusive. Unofficial tallies indicate that just under 25 percent of the registered Democrats voted in this part of the north Bronx, with Mr. Clinton getting a plurality, if not a clear majority, of the vote in most neighborhoods.
But come the general election, Mrs. Sollino's community -- the adjoining Country Club and Pelham Bay neighborhoods -- will be a prime battleground for President Bush and his Democratic opponent. Crossing party lines in presidential elections is a tradition in these neighborhoods. Post-primary interviews with residents indicated that the recessionary economy and issues like crime, Social Security and welfare weigh heavily, and many voters do not know which party's lever they will turn in November.
These are neighborhoods filled with longtime Democrats who deserted their party in the 1980's to vote for Ronald Reagan and, to a lesser extent, George Bush.
In exit polls taken throughout New York State during last week's Democratic primary, 15 percent of voters said they cast ballots for President Bush in 1988. But in the 75th Assembly District, where Mrs. Sollino lives, Mr. Bush collected 43 percent of the vote four years ago, even though only 18 percent of the voters were registered Republicans.
Whether Mr. Bush can do that well again in Mrs. Sollino's and similar neighborhoods in November is a crucial question. "That's still the battleground where you're fighting to win, particularly in the big states," said Charles Black, a senior adviser to the Bush campaign.
Stanley B. Greenberg, a strategist and pollster for Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, has made a specialty of studying Reagan Democrats, and the Clinton platform was crafted with a clear eye toward them. It stresses broad national themes like an improved economy and national health care, rather than subsidized housing and anti-poverty programs targeted to the inner city.
The debate over what motivates such voters and how to win their approval is sharp and divided. "If everything's equal, they're going to be Democrats, so you use issues to show the difference between the Democrats and the Republicans and you try to draw them over," Mr. Black said.
For the Bush campaign, he said, that means laying the blame for the poor economy on the doorstep of the Democratic Congress rather than at the White House, and stressing Mr. Bush's conservative social agenda, including his opposition to abortion and flag burning, support for prayer in public schools and disdain for what Mr. Black calls "the A.C.L.U. agenda."
Several political analysts and Democratic strategists maintain that the Republican appeal succeeds largely by provoking racial fears and opposition to social programs that benefit the urban poor, most of whom are black and Hispanic. But these analysts also think that conservative white Democrats can be wooed back to a national Democratic standard-bearer.
"They do identify with New Deal politics that were universalistic," said John H. Mollenkopf, professor of political science at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. "They do believe in government and government being able to solve problems if it's their problems rather than somebody else's."
 
'A Rude Awakening'
 After all, Mr. Mollenkopf said, "I think they got a rude awakening in the '80's from the Reagan Administration. Think of the auto workers who went for Reagan."
It seems that many Democratic voters in the northern Bronx agree with Mr. Black's characterization of them as socially conservative at the same time that they agree with Mr. Mollenkopf's characterization that they would support broad social programs as long as they benefit from them. What they are usually uncertain about is how they will vote in November.
"I think it's very much in flux," said Kevin Phillips, the political strategist and author who identified the transitional Democratic vote that bolstered Mr. Reagan in the 1980's. "The economy is obviously a major part of it," Mr. Phillips said, "but beyond that George Bush does not have the cultural appeal to the various types of Reagan Democrats. 'Skull and Bones' doesn't make it at the end of the subway line."
But Mr. Bush might take solace from the sentiment of voters like Frank Mallozzi, a retired furrier who long ago switched his party affiliation from Democrat to Independent. "I'm going to be pretty picky," Mr. Mallozzi said. "I may even go for Bush."
But economic hard times and general disillusionment are pushing other voters in the Country Club and Pelham Bay neighborhoods in the opposite direction. William J. Formisano, a Democrat whose family has run Yore Butcher's on Crosby Avenue for 20 years, said that even though he broke with his party to vote for Mr. Reagan in 1984 and Mr. Bush in 1988, he voted for Mr. Clinton on Tuesday and may well do the same in the fall.
"I might, just for a change," he said. "I voted for Reagan back then because it was going good, and Bush was moving in the same way."
Within the last year, however, he said, his business was off from 20 to 40 percent because of the recession.
A friend of Mr. Formisano, John Rodolico, 40, a bus driver and registered Democrat who did not make it to the polls last week, said he would "like to see somebody different" from Mr. Bush in the White House He said that despite the controversies about Mr. Clinton's private life, he liked the candidate, especially his pro-death penalty stance.
 
Bakeries and Fish Stores
 Bakeries, fish stores and small shops line Pelham Bay's main commercial thoroughfare, Westchester Avenue, and the nearby streets hum with activity. Still, the economic slowdown and its effects crop up often in conversations. Across the street from Mr. Formisano's shop is George's Coffee Shop, a neighborhood fixture in one incarnation or another for 66 years. George Baboukis, the owner and a registered Republican, said his business had dropped 20 percent in a year, the worst slump in a decade. As a result, he said, "this time we are looking for change -- this time you have to go Democratic."
Such support might make it seem that this is the Democrats' year in the northeast Bronx. But that would ignore a disillusionment about politics in general and often about the Democratic Party and its candidates, "I'm a Democrat," said Louis Puccio, 69, a retired cabinet maker, "but who's ever running the Democratic Party, I have no faith in them."
 
'Don't Like the Candidates'
 Michael DeMarco, the neighborhood's longtime City Councilman, understood the sentiment. "Normally you would get a strong Bush feeling," Mr. DeMarco said, "but because of the economy you're not getting the strong Bush feeling. But on the other hand, the people here are not sure they want to go Democratic because they don't like the candidates."
He said that he was only the 30th Democrat to vote when he came to his polling place at 6 o'clock Tuesday night. Usually, he said, about 120 voters would have passed through by that time in any primary.
Among many on the streets and at the senior citizens' center, talk of politics gradually shifts to talk of issues the Republicans hope to capitalize on, namely welfare and crime.
"The welfare in New York is draining us dry," said Rudy Seemayer, who had been a customer and field service representative for R. H. Hoe, a printing machinery company. "There are a lot of liberals like Cuomo who just give the country away while they sit on their thrones."
Others, many children of immigrants, wonder why welfare recipients cannot do what their parents did -- succeed without public assistance. "They should do something," Mr. Puccio said. "My father, he built Orchard Beach," a New Deal public works project. Similar projects should be carried out today and welfare recipients should be required to work on them as a condition of aid, Mr. Puccio and several friends agreed.
 
Talk of Race
 Talk of race, at least with an outsider, was muted. "You're going to have racism, I don't care where you go," said Mr. Mallozzi, the retired furrier. He and others acknowledged that a black person moving into the Country Club neighborhood would have a hard time being accepted by many.
Turning these conflicting feelings into votes may well be the most important political battle of the year. In 1984, Mr. Reagan won New York State by more than a half-million votes. In 1988, Mr. Bush lost by more than a quarter-million votes. In large part that came about because 117,000 Democrats and Independents in New York City who had voted for Mr. Reagan did not support Mr. Bush, according to Mr. Mollenkopf's analysis.
This time who prevails will depend in part upon voters like Mr. Mallozzi -- voters who are troubled and confused. "I'm all mixed up with everything," he said. "It seems it doesn't matter who gets in. I'd like them to be a little more caring for people, the people like me -- I'm comfortable, but I'm not rich."
Pay no attention to his and similar concerns, he said, and "you're gonna have the old feudal system -- rich and poor and no more middle class."

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 8; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 677 words

HEADLINE: Peruvian Official Assails Pressure From U.S.

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, April 11

 BODY:
In an interview before his departure for talks in Washington, Peru's Foreign Minister bitterly criticized the Bush Administration for putting pressure on other governments to isolate President Alberto Fujimori, who seized broad power last Sunday in what many people are calling a civil-military coup.
The Foreign Minister, Augustino Blacker Miller, said in the interview late Friday night that Mr. Fujimori's action had wide popular support among Peruvians and wondered how the United States could be so "naive" as to lump Peru's situation with the military takeover in Haiti last year. 
 "We feel that if we have the support of the Peruvian population, eventually we will get the support of the world because the world cannot deny the fact that this is not a dictatorship when you have 90 percent of popular support," the Foreign Minister said.
Late Sunday, President Fujimori dissolved Congress and the judiciary, arrested more than two dozen members of Congress and suspended the Constitution. He said the actions were necessary to confront severe challenges from Maoist Shining Path guerrillas and drug traffickers as his Government tries to address dire economic problems. He has promised to restore democracy and free elections under a new constitution.
United States officials have condemned the move as a coup and cut off all but humanitarian aid to the Fujimori Government. On Friday President Bush said he would support submitting Peru to "outside pressure," including economic sanctions, to promote a return to democracy.
Behind the United States pressure is concern that Mr. Fujimori's actions could set a dangerous precedent for other Latin countries at a time when the continent is enjoying broad democratic rule for the first time in decades.
The Organization of American States on Monday is to hold an emergency meeting on the Peruvian situation. Mr. Blacker Miller is scheduled to present the Peru's case at the meeting.
The Foreign Minister said he was encountering an intense effort by the United States to dissuade Latin and European Governments from showing any support for what he described as Mr. Fujimori's attempt to "create a real democracy in Peru."
He added that strains in the relationship between Peru and the United States in recent months over anti-drug efforts prompted the Fujimori Government not to warn officials in Washington of its intention to seize broad powers.
The Peruvian Foreign Minister traced strains in the relationship with Washington to the San Antonio summit meeting of seven countries on drugs in February, at which the United States pressured Lima to accept tougher drug interdiction measures.
Since the takeover, those strains have only increased. The Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, Bernard W. Aronson, arrived in Lima the day Mr. Fujimori announced his seizure of power. Fuming, Mr. Aronson canceled a meeting with Mr. Fujimori and returned to Washington.
Mr. Blacker Miller said that while every approach to the United States for help and understanding since the coup has been rebuffed, he has met with a more tolerant reception in Europe and Japan. "The reaction in Europe is, 'We believe you are confronting extraordinarily difficult odds in your fight to proceed with development and therefore we are not going to cry wolf until we see that you are not meeting your promises,' " he said.
Tired, and obviously concerned about the outcome in Washington, the Peruvian Foreign Minister said the seizure of power early this week had been planned for more than two months.
"When you are looking at things from the frying pan it is hard to believe that they could look any worse," he said. "When you are in the frying pan and others are holding the pan, you are the one who is burning, not they."
Mr. Blacker Miller said that he had advised Mr. Fujimori earlier that if radical changes were not made soon the situation with terrorism, a stagnant economy and drug trafficking could get so bad that "we might have a real military coup by the end of the year."

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: April 12, 1992

SECTION: Section 3; Page 16; Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 465 words

HEADLINE: POINT COUNTERPOINT ON I.B.M.

 BODY:
In an article on the Forum page on March 22, Webster Brown, a former engineer with International Business Machines Corporation, wrote about his 26 years with I.B.M.
He told of how the optimism with which he signed on in 1964 for what probably would be a lifetime career eroded to the point that two years ago he took voluntary retirement at the age of 54. He said he feared that had he stayed at the company, he would be weeded out by an employee appraisal system "which gets tougher each year, that seems designed to sweep the company clean of employees who, however loyal and competent, no longer fit in at I.B.M." 
 He accused I.B.M. of initiating a "psycholgoical reign of terror" over employees under the guise of quality improvement.
"In its relentless pursuit of excellence," he wrote, "I.B.M., like many other American enterprises under competitive siege in recent years, has turned from a challenging and caring employer to one ruled by fear and intimidation. Benevolence has become malevolence. People once praised for their excellence now fear for their jobs."
Many readers wrote in response to Mr. Brown's. Last Sunday, Sheldon I. Kurtz, a specialist in employee outplacement in the computer industry, chided Mr. Brown for complaining, considering what Mr. Kurtz saw as I.B.M.'s generosity.
"How unfortuante is it," Mr. Kurtz asked, "that Mr. Brown . . . received in his early retirement program two years of full salary, a lifetime pension elgibility, free health care for himself and his spouse plus many other company-paid benefits?"
Following are a response from Mr. Brown, and a sampling of some of the other letters about the article.
 
Cynicism on a Platter
To the Editor:
There is an aspect to the recent I.B.M. decision to order supervisors to rate 5 to 10 percent of their employees as unaceptable that makes the policy it particularly cynical, perhaps illegal.
The laws on collecting unemployment benefits in New Jersey, at least, provide that an employee who is laid off as part of a company slowdown is entitled to immediate listing, while an employee who is fired for unsatisfactory work must wait several weeks before going on the unemployment rolls, and one who quits to avoid the stigma of being fired may never qualify for benefits at all. And of course, one who retires forfeits any claim.
In addition, a company's unemployment insurance payments are based on a rating of its layoff history. Calling layoffs by other names would keep I.B.M.'s unemployment insurance rating artificially high, and premiums down accordingly.
So if I.B.M. can avoid layoffs by convincing previously acceptable but now "excess" employees to retire or quit, I.B.M. gains nicely, at the expense of employees.
 
NAHUM BACHRACH
River Edge, N.J., March 22

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

TICKER: IBMC (BRU) (94%); IBM (NYSE) (94%); IBM (LSE) (94%); 

INDUSTRY: NAICS334118 COMPUTER TERMINAL & OTHER COMPUTER PERIPHERAL EQUIPMENT MANUFACTURING (94%); NAICS334112 COMPUTER STORAGE DEVICE MANUFACTURING (94%); NAICS334111 ELECTRONIC COMPUTER MANUFACTURING (94%);

HEADLINE: Local United Way Trying to Provide Answers

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
"IN the light of all the excesses I've been reading about, I'd think twice now about giving to United Way," Selma Crowe of Harrison, the owner of a mail-order gift business, said recently. "I always assumed most of the money they collected went to help the needy, not to make their executives rich."
It is not known how many potential donors to the United Way of Westchester and Putnam Counties share that sentiment, but its president, Ralph Gregory, acknowledges that it is a concern. "People want to know about our financial structure," Mr. Gregory said. "The big question is, 'Where is my money going?' We're trying to give answers." 
 The president of United Way of America, William Aramony, was forced to resign in February after it was disclosed that he received a $463,000-a-year salary and a generous expense account. And last weekend the national organization's new management released a report that outlined an extensive pattern of financial manipulation over a five-year period.
 
A Review of Salaries
 Closer to home, Betty Beene, who heads the United Ways of Tri-State, has called for a review of the salaries paid to executives by other nonprofit organizations, for purposes of comparison with United Way salaries here. Ms. Beene earns $240,000 a year and receives an expense account and other benefits like a pension plan and health insurance. Her organization represents 35 affiliates in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, which last year raised $193 million in drives at 1,000 companies.
But it is not only the United Way that is worried about how the recent disclosures will affect contributions to the charity.
"I don't know what we'll do if we don't get funding from United Way this year -- we will probably have to close," said Mary Gaines, director of the Nepperhan Community Center in Yonkers.
"Last year we got $65,000, and still we were stretched to the limit," she said. "In these hard times, more people need our help. The United Way money is our core. With it, we can leverage other funds from the county and the city of Yonkers for our programs."
Asked about the impact on contributions, Mr. Gregory said: "We honestly don't know yet. We'll know more when our 1992 drive starts in a few months. Certainly, a lot of questions are being asked of us, but the people asking them haven't been hostile. They are honestly looking for information, and we are making an effort to be open with them."
In the light of the newest developments, the release of a 59-page report on Mr. Aramony's activities over the last five years, Mr. Gregory said: "The report has been issued to all our board members. They all want to have the opportunity to read it fully before we meet on April 22 to decide whether or not we will pay dues to United Way of America."
Mr. Gregory, a former social worker, earns $108,000 a year.
He agreed with Ms. Beene's decision to subject executive compensation to scrutiny and said that "the study will be released when our salaries come up for review." Ms. Beene's salary will be reviewed in June and Mr. Gregory's in September.
United Way of Westchester and Putnam raised $14.9 million in the 1990-1991 fiscal year, Mr. Gregory said, and spent just less than $2 million for all its management and general costs, "which includes everything, such as salaries, rents, telephone, etcetera." The White Plains-based charity paid $127,000 to United Way of America for promotion, administration and advertising.
 
Advertising Campaign Planned
 Michael Barclay has been a United Way volunteer for 40 years and president of the Mamaroneck chapter for 8 years. To combat the recent negative publicity, Mr. Barclay said, a local United Way advertising campaign will begin shortly.
"It will deal candidly with such things as the local agency's finances and a report on where the money goes," Mr. Barclay said. "We are a completely autonomous organization, and we want to let the public know our purpose."
Mr. Gregory's duties include providing administrative assistance to the United Way Board and its volunteer committees. The United Way Board, which is headed by William M. Mooney, senior vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank in White Plains, is the group that allocates United Way funds to 130 local organizations.
Many of the organizations, like the Nepperhan Community Center, have long relationships with United Way. Since its founding 50 years ago, the center has received funds from United Way and its predecessor, the Community Chest, for programs that have made "a big difference in the lives of the people here," Mrs. Gaines said.
 
Unsure of the Damage Done
 In Tuckahoe, the assistant director of My Sister's Place, Thea DuBow, said the $40,000 it receives from the United Way is used for a program in the schools that identifies and gives counseling to victims of domestic violence. "If our financing from United Way were reduced, the results would be tragic," Ms. DuBow said, "because our program reaches out to thousands of kids who have nowhere else to go."
Mr. Mooney, the United Way Board chairman, said: "Until donors get their questions answered, they are going to think twice about contributions. We won't know how much damage has been done until we start heavy-duty campaigning in the fall.
"But in the interim we will be sending volunteers and staff members around to area corporations to speak, and at the end of the day I think we will have the support of the corporations, especially since we have always enjoyed a good relationship with them."
Most of the contributions to United Way come from the workplace: from corporate donations and voluntary employee payroll deductions. Last year, United Way Tri-State raised $193 million from drives at more than 1,000 companies.
 
Reassurance on Westchester Unit
 The Ciba-Geigy Corporation in Ardsley is one contributing company. "United Way has always been our vehicle of choice for giving because of the efficient way they endow the various agencies in the community," said a spokeswoman, Lisa Robinson.
After the disclosures at the national level, Ms. Robinson said, Ciba-Geigy contacted the local United Way for information. "It seemed doubly unfortunate to us that their problems would adversely affect people in need," she said.
After being reassured that in Westchester the United Way "still functions completely autonomously, giving the funds they collect to local agencies," Ms. Robinson said, "we were satisfied and we will be making our corporate gift. However, we will be watching them carefully."
A strong critic of the way charitable organizations operate today is Milton Goldin, a fund-raising consultant in Tarrytown who works on a flat-fee basis in preparing and managing business plans for yearly fund drives and capital fund-raising campaigns at universities, hospitals and religious organizations. He objects to charitable organizations soliciting funds in the workplace.
 
Executive Salaries 'Are Ridiculous'
 "United Way residential individual gifts have been down for years," he said, "and that should tell you something. Yes, employees are still being strong-armed by their superiors on the job to give, because those superiors have to earn Brownie points with their superiors.
"It's a foolish mess, and the salaries of executives of these charitable organizations are ridiculous. They should be watching every penny, not paying themselves grandiose salaries. Where is the spirit of charity?"
When asked about employee participation, already eroded by the economy, Mr. Mooney said: "The fact that corporations match payroll deductions sits well with employees. And interestingly enough, we have found that in hard times people who have jobs are usually more generous in their contributions."
Mr. Goldin compared philanthropy today with what it was at the beginning of the century. "Today most charities are entertainments more than anything else," he said. "Rockefeller gave tremendous amounts to start medical schools and hospitals. Andrew Carnegie gave huge amounts to establish libraries. They were experimenting. They wanted to see what would work and then, only after the experiment was successful, did the Government take over the hospitals and libraries.
"Now we have a system in which the Government does the experimenting with programs," he added. "Then they hand them over to private citizens to keep supporting them. It's hugely stupid and ineffective."
 
Red Cross Appears Unaffected
 There has been some fear in fund-raising circles that United Way's troubles could affect the public's willingness to give to any charity.
But the American Red Cross chapter in Westchester recently held its major fund-raising event of the year, the Touch of Red Ball, and its spokeswoman, Barbara Rose, said, "We had 300 people, one of the highest attendance records ever."
The Red Cross spends no more than 10 cents of every dollar collected on administrative costs, she said.

HEADLINE: The Health Curriculum Keeps Growing

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI

DATELINE: CHAPPAQUA

 BODY:
"HOW many of you have heard about a situation where a big person tried to do things that are not right to a little person and that make that little person feel 'yucky' ?" Bernice Krehbiel asked a fidgeting class of second graders at the Roaring Brook Elementary School here.
Hands shot up in the room. "Like trying to give a child poison?" suggested one girl. "Isn't that called molestering?" asked another. "No, it's like when grown-ups touch people that are, like, younger than them and, like, you don't want to be touched but they do it anyway," volunteered another. 
 And so began a carefully led discussion on preventing child sexual abuse. Ms. Krehbiel, a nurse-teacher, discussed a child's right to say no to an adult and used a doll to illustrate the differences between "good," "bad" and "confusing" touches. She showed a film that featured puppets discussing how a friend's uncle touched her in private places and how bad that made the friend feel.
Preventing sexual abuse is only a small component of Ms. Krehbiel's health-education responsibilities. The week before, she taught fifth graders about AIDS prevention, using cups of water and drops of blue dye to illustrate how a virus enters the blood stream.
Soon, she will visit fourth-grade classrooms to talk about alcohol, tobacco, caffeine and marijuana. In the fifth grade, children will hear about the dangers of cocaine, crack, steroids and synthetic drugs like PCP. During the course of the year, Ms. Krehbiel will have covered numerous health subjects, from dental health to eating disorders.
Ms. Krehbiel asked the second graders to think about people that they could talk to and trust. She told them most of the adults they knew were good people, but that a few had something wrong with them that made them want to do undesirable things to children. She explained that such people needed to be helped. The class talked about parents and neighbors and baby sitters and coaches. They practiced yelling "No!" in unison.
 
State Sets the Agenda
 After 40 minutes, it was time for Ms. Krehbiel to move to another class. As she left, she handed out study sheets and reminded the children that the door to her office was always open if anybody wanted to talk about the subject some more.
The health education that youngsters are receiving at Roaring Brook Elementary School is both standard and exceptional. It is standard, because the State Department of Education has mandated that certain subjects (including lessons in preventing sexual abuse and teaching about AIDS) be taught in the schools. It is exceptional because Chappaqua is one of a dwindling number of school districts that can afford to employ a certified school nurse-teacher, a professional who is a registered nurse and also holds a teaching certificate.
While each school district is required to have a school nurse, the ones without teaching certification can dispense health services but cannot teach in the classroom.
Though the state requires that a certain range of health subjects be taught to students from kindergarten through 12th grade, it leaves the curriculum and its implementation to each district.
The state requires that 11 broad areas be covered: human growth and development, emotional health, nutrition, environmental health, family-life education, diseases and disorders, consumer health; alcohol, tobacco and other drugs; safety, first aid and survival; community health, and healthy life styles.
But while each district is mandated to have a health coordinator, the actual teaching may be left to a variety of sources, including athletic directors, assistant superintendents, science teachers or general classroom teachers.
"It's a real mixed bag in Westchester," said Barbara LaPilusa, regional coordinator of the Health Education and Services Network for the Board of Cooperative Education Services (Boces). "It would be optimal to have a health coordinator with a health background and have them teach two or three classes a day. But because of our economic situation, most schools can't have that person full time."
 
Teachers Are 'Already Stressed'
 Experts in health education worry that without the personnel, many subjects are simply not being taught in the schools regardless of the state mandate. Classroom teachers are already overloaded with curriculum requirements and many have little training and are also not comfortable with some of the subject matter that needs to be covered.
"It's very difficult for teachers to include health education in their classrooms," said Marsha L. Henderson, a certified school nurse at the Crompond Elementary School in Yorktown and the past president of the New York State Association of School Nurses. "They are already stressed. It is really up to the district to give health education a priority, and right now some districts are doing better than others," she said.
Evaluating the success of health education is difficult, in part because New York State has no standardized tests to ascertain whether children have mastered the required topics. Further, the ultimate goal in much of health education -- a change in life style -- is difficult to measure.
Grace Stevens, associate in School Health Education at the New York State Department of Education, said: "It is very hard to measure attitudes and behaviors. You can show knowledge, but that doesn't mean we are going to cut down on rates of teen pregnancy. In math they need to know that two plus two is four, but it's not impacting on their life style. What makes health so different is that kids can have all the knowledge in the world, but if they are not adopting the behaviors, the knowledge is useless."
Responding to the conflict between the increasing amount of health education mandated by the state and the dwindling school budgets and uneven teaching resources that most districts must cope with, experts in the field are now exploring a new and more global approach to the subject.
The New York State Department of Education has developed "The Comprehensive School Health and Wellness Initiative," an encompassing approach to teaching health. In this strategy, health education is not only the job of the school nurse or the health teacher but also the purview of the physical education staff, the food services staff, the guidance counselors, the classroom teachers and everyone else involved in a child's education, including parents.
The state has developed a training model of this type of approach that it is offering to districts. Ms. Stevens said it began training districts in January 1991 and will have trained 19 districts by this June.
 
Multiple Messages Stressed
 "We have to get away from seeing health as either instruction or health services," Ms. Stevens said. "Those are only two parts of the big picture. We need to think of health on entirely different terms. You can't just do a semester of health education and expect to change life styles. You have to give multiple messages through multiple channels," she added.
At Boces, health-education specialists are developing a sample curriculum that will integrate health topics into other subjects. For instance, in one guide for a high school economics class, students will look at the high cost of AZT, one of the major drug therapies for AIDS, rather than looking at the economics of the gross national product. Lessons suggest including an HIV link to language arts, social studies or English.
"For instance, as they study poetry, students could read about AIDS instead of reading and writing about trees in the forest," Ms. LaPilusa said.
Even on an elementary level important health messages can be integrated, Ms. LaPilusa said. In physical education, she said, rather than emphasizing competitive sports, teachers can promote lifetime fitness and teach aerobics instead of archery.
 
'There Has to Be a Big Picture'
 "There has to be a big picture," Ms. LaPilusa said. "These lessons have to be more integrated into the curriculum because there are too many mandates, and teachers do not have the time to teach them separately. But children do have to get the message. One thing we know is that if kids aren't healthy, they can't learn," she said.
That is something that Ms. Krehbiel, the nurse-teacher, knows all too well. She has seen children with nervous systems so raw that they jump at school bells or become overwhelmed by such common school experiences as riding the bus or attending an assembly. She knows that children who come into her office with stomachaches and headaches are often simply suffering from stress -- whether it is from excessive pressure to do well, from living in dysfunctional families or simply from living in a world where learning about AIDS and child abuse are part of their everyday reality.
"The turmoil that some of these little ones have is scary," Ms. Krehbiel said. "We see small children coming through with such high levels of anxiety. They need coping mechanisms, they need to learn how to reduce stress. Sometimes one of the most important parts of my job is just giving these children some reassurance."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bernice Krehbiel, a nurse-teacher, using doll at Roaring Brook Elementary School to illustrate her lesson on sexual abuse. (Suzanne DeChillo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Face Lift for Galleria in White Plains

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
LIKE many shopping centers of its vintage, the Galleria at White Plains has begun to show its years. The 880,000- square-foot enclosed mall in the heart of the city's urban downtown area is due for a face lifting, say its owners, who are planning to spend $8 million on the project.
"Times change," said Gerald M. Cope, a Philadelphia architect who has been hired to design changes for the mall, which was completed in 1980. "The Galleria is looking a bit tired. It needs to be more contemporary, more upbeat." Most shopping centers, the architect said, need refurbishing every 10 or 12 years to keep pace with shifts in marketing and consumer trends. 
Last week the White Plains Common Council approved the first phase of plans to renovate the Galleria's entrance on Main Street, a project that is to begin within a month.
Because the Galleria is a town center "in the true sense of the word and not standing in the middle of a field somewhere like a suburban mall," Mr. Cope said, his plans attempt to address two needs: to blend the design of the entranceway with the surrounding downtown area and at the same time adorn it with lanterns and display windows to call attention to the shops inside.
 
Other Malls Announced
 Long-range plans call for renovation of another entrance on Grove Street, a new color scheme and fresh landscaping inside the mall, reglazing existing skylights to allow more natural light to shine through, new flooring throughout the mall and increased seating in the Food Court for the estimated 12,000 customers who visit the mall each day.
The Galleria's face lifting coincides with recent announcements that developers of two proposed shopping centers in White Plains have finally received financing for their projects and are planning to begin construction this year. Developers for a third project are optimistic that their plans will proceed once financing is obtained.
Although James L. Czech, president of the real estate investment and management group in Chicago that manages the Galleria, said the threat of competition posed by the new malls had not influenced his company's decision to revamp the shopping center, merchants here welcomed news of the renovation.
"If they don't give this place a better look, it's going to go downhill, and we will lose our customers," said Atonio Calero, owner of the Hairstylist, a beauty salon that has been in the Galleria since it opened.
 
Making a Good First Impression
 "The mall is so old looking," said Daneen Harrison, a saleswoman at T-Shirts Plus. "It's so dark and boring compared to Danbury Fair Mall."
Agreeing with the merchants, Mr. Cope said, "The whole architecture needs to be lighter and lacier, like a backdrop, so the stores can sparkle."
"In malls, first impressions are terribly important," he added. "And shoppers today are very discerning."
Despite competition from newer regional malls in Connecticut and New Jersey, and despite the impact of the recession, which has hit the retail sector of the economy especially hard, Mr. Czech, president of J.M.B. Retail Properties Corporation, said the Galleria maintained a 90 percent occupancy rate last year and its 150 stores have continued to average about $405 a square foot yearly in revenues.
"That's a very healthy number," said Mr. Czech, whose company manages 93 malls in the United States. "The Galleria continues to be in the top five malls in the country" in terms of sales per square foot.
"We read a lot about an economic downturn, and some tenants may not be thriving," he said. "But in general, sales at malls remain strong, despite the outside forces."
Shopping centers, an expert in the field agreed, appear to be somewhat recession proof. "Malls aren't built in reference to a specific economic environment; they are in it for the long haul," said Donald L. Pendley, director of public relations for the International Council of Shopping Centers in Manhattan.
The trade council's research confirmed that stores in the 37,975 shopping centers nationwide fared better than other retail establishments in the last several years. Overall retail sales for the country, Mr. Pendley said, were 2 percent better last year than in 1990, whereas retail sales in shopping centers averaged 3.5 percent higher during the period.
Surprisingly, the difficult economic climate has, in at least one way, helped merchants in shopping centers. Renovations of existing malls are taking place at an unprecedented pace because developers, faced with the reduced availability of loans for commercial real estate, are finding it difficult to obtain money to build new centers, Mr. Pendley said.
As more dollars are funneled back into aging malls and more emphasis is placed on the visual appeal of malls, retailers in shopping centers are reaping the benefits -- along with the landlord who usually gets a percentage of the sales after the tenant reaches a certain break-even point, Mr. Pendley said.
 
A Medium-to-Large Mall
 The Galleria, which is owned by Cadillac Fairview U.S., a Canadian-based consortium of pension funds, and J.M.B., is considered a medium-to-large mall. With its two anchor stores -- J. C. Penney and Abraham & Straus -- it is slightly larger than the Stamford Town Center, which occupies 875,000 square feet, but smaller than the Danbury Fair Mall, which has 1.3 million square feet.
The Galleria -- a mall where prices are generally in the upper-middle range -- has what Mr. Czech called "a broad-based appeal" for customers.
Of the three other malls that developers are planning to build here, one would be what is known as a power mall, with competitively priced goods, and the others would be fashion malls selling more expensive merchandise than is generally offered at the Galleria.
"If and when other malls come to White Plains," Mr. Czech said, "these renovations now will insure that we maintain the foothold and the type of customer base we have established here. I don't see us in competition."
 
Other Malls Will be 'More Upscale'
 At the Athlete's Foot, a sporting-goods store in the Galleria, the assistant manager, Lisa Azimi, said she was not worried about the possibility that two fashion malls might move nearby.
"The other malls are going to be more upscale," she said. "It's not a threat to us, because the average person from White Plains won't go over there to spend a couple of hundred dollars on a handbag. Those malls are going to be more for the Fifth Avenue types."
In addition to revamping the entrances and redesigning the interior of the mall, the developer is sharing with the city the costs of upgrading parking lots serving the mall.
The enclosed parking areas are owned by the city, which is responsible for maintaining and policing the area. The lots, with 2,815 metered parking spaces, are being repainted, and new lighting is being installed. The cost of the project is expected to be about $1.4 million.
 
Parking Lot Crime Called Minuscule
 "In the last couple of years, the city has been combating a perception problem, that the parking area is not safe," said Kevin D. Fish, director of the White Plains Parking Authority.
Although Mr. Fish said the crime rate in the lots was minuscule, he said the city was nevertheless installing high-pressure sodium lighting and more signs, "so people feel better."
With 50,000 cars using the lots each week, there is "only a car theft now and again, or maybe a car radio stolen," said Capt. James Harding of the White Plains Police Department.
 
A Look Back to the 1970's
 As the plans moved ahead last week for the Galleria and the proposed shopping centers, Mayor Alfred Del Vecchio looked back to the late 1970's when leaders here were debating whether to tear down an old courthouse to allow the mall to be built in its place.
"We decided then to take a decaying city center and revitalize it when other civic leaders were putting their malls on the outskirts of town," the Mayor said.
"Without development, White Plains would have been history," he said, "just another garbage pail on the map, like what happened to too many other downtown areas."

HEADLINE: 116-Year-Old Company Thrives on Innovation

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
DESPITE 30 years of decline among Connecticut manufacturers, optimism reigns at Stanadyne Inc. in Windsor. To understand why, it helps to consider the company's history.
Many other Connecticut business are just starting to learn about diversification and international markets. But in 1947 the Hartford Machine Screw Company was adjusting to the slowdown in military contracts after the war and began making diesel-fuel injection pumps for cars and trucks. In the 1980's, with the number of American-made diesel-powered cars dwindling, the company, now called Stanadyne, started selling its injectors in Japan and Europe. 
 And as I.B.M. starts what it has heralded as a 1990's management innovation, spinning off small entrepreneurial units within the larger company, Stanadyne is readying the first in a series of products it developed through the same process, started three years ago. One is a unit to recycle antifreeze that can be used by operators of cab and bus fleets to reclaim 90 percent of what used to be thrown out. Another is a new type of oil pump for the Northstar 4.6-liter V-8 engine that will be used in the 1993 Cadillac Allante sports car.
 
'We're Here to Stay'
 "Within a relatively short time we got some products we think are going to do very, very well," said the director of power products at Stanadyne, Lee P. Janik.
The company's executive vice president, William D. Gurley, said, "We're here to stay."
The company's work force in Windsor, site of its largest installation, is going to grow significantly "over the next two to three years," he said. "We've actually been hiring over the last year, in some key skills."
Mr. Gurley said Stanadyne employed 2,250 people worldwide, about 950 of them in Windsor. Mr. Janik said the success of Stanadyne's manufacturing operation in Connecticut, a state where manufacturing has been on the wane, was propelled "by self-preservation."
Mr. Gurley said success was, "a matter of being able to recognize when you've got to do things differently, and then making the change." The company has "been willing to try things that are different," he said.
Brian V. Beaudin, senior vice president of the Connecticut Business and Industry Association and director of its Manufacturers' Council, said other companies will have to follow Stanadyne's example, if they hope to survive.
"There's a lot more innovation going on in manufacturing now, compared to three or four years ago," Mr. Beaudin said. "The defense business that has been the meat and potatoes of a lot of manufacturers is gone, so they're saying, 'How can I take the equipment I've got, and the processes I have, and do something else?' "
 
Proof of State's Strength
 Mr. Beaudin said that necessity often propelled manufacturing companies to become pioneers of new management styles. In the 1980;s manufacturers went through the efficiencies and cutbacks that banks and insurance companies are pursuing now, he said.
A spokesman for the State Department of Economic Development, Joseph Cohen, said Stanadyne "is proof that among Connecticut's strengths are its research and development capabilities and the transfer of technologies into new products." He added, "It's why we believe that, with its skilled labor forces and a history of innovation, Connecticut is going to come through these tough times with our jobs base and our business stronger than ever."
Hartford Machine Screw was established in 1876 to develop what became the first automatic screw machine. It produced screws for the sewing-machine industry and, in the late 1800's, a booming bicycle business. By the early 1920's it phased out production of standard screws and began manufacturing custom-designed ones, for businesses like nearby Pratt & Whitney, which used the screws in the first successful air-cooled aircraft engine.
During the military buildup before and during World War II the company prospered in the fastener business, but with the demand for fighter planes down after the war, it began to look to other markets. In 1947 it recruited Vernon Roosa, an inventor with an idea for a diesel-fuel injection pump. The following year it moved to the plant on 27 acres in Windsor, still its home.
The company's diesel-pump technology, including products like diesel filters and water separators, has been used in automotive, agricultural, and heavy-equipment engines. During the 1970's, when the fuel crisis curtailed gasoline supplies and domestic use of diesel engines climbed, the company expanded its Windsor plant and bought two others in North Carolina. The company's name, which had earlier been changed to Standard Screw, had now become Stanadyne, the "dyne" coming from dynamometer, a device for measuring an engine's power.
The same qualities that made diesels attractive during the fuel crisis make them better engines from an environmental perspective, Mr. Gurley said.
"If you're worried about global warming, diesels make more sense," he said, noting that diesel engines burn 30 to 40 percent less fuel than gasoline engines, with corresponding reductions in emissions of carbon dioxide and nitrous oxide.
 
Selling in Japan
 Diesel engines, Mr. Gurley said, last longer. The typical diesel car does not need major engine service for 150,000 miles, he said, and big trucks routinely go 500,000, get a rebuilding and proceed to 1 million miles.
When gasoline supplies eased in the 1980's, Americans wanted to return to the quicker pickup that a gasoline engine offers. So Stanadyne turned its attention to overseas markets, including Japan.
"We've seen nothing in that market in terms of the protection or the other barriers you read about," Mr. Gurley said. "We've only faced the usual rigors of competition -- quality issues, technical issues and value."
In 1988, with the help of investment bankers, a group of Stanadyne executives bought the company from the stockholders. The previous year the company established a foothold in Europe by buying a United Technologies plant in Brescia, Italy, and a business owned by Altecna, a division of Fiat.
"So if 'Fortress Europe' slams closed, which is looking less likely but could still be possible, we're now inside the European Economic Community and ready to expand our operations there," Mr. Gurley said.
But with its international operations growing, Stanadyne was facing a shrinking market at home. "We recognized that our business in the U.S. would be fairly flat," Mr. Janik said. "So we got together a small resource group of engineers, marketing people and so on, to do entrepreneurial work."
Recalling how Stanadyne got into the filter business 20 years ago, because no one else was making diesel-fuel filters sophisticated enough for its fuel pumps, the group started talking about other uses of filtering technology. Some members recalled hearing about the problem with spent antifreeze.
After long use in an engine, antifreeze is contaminated by sludge and other materials that rob it of its ability to keep the engine's temperature within strict limits. It had to be drained out, disposed of as hazardous waste and replaced.
The Stanadyne team designed a system that draws off ethylene glycol, the active ingredient in antifreeze, and leaves a sludge behind, Mr. Janik said.
Operating at its full capacity of 100 gallons a day, the $10,000 machine, which uses a process called reverse osmosis to cleanse the antifreeze, pays for itself in a year through reduced replacement cost for antifreeze, he said. The oil pump for the new Cadillac Allante is another example of the entrepreneurial group's work. "We got in line behind three others who wanted to provide that pump," Mr. Janik said. "But our design got us in the door."
Stanadyne's engineering group proved itself willing to make changes to accommodate different engine designs, he said.
"A couple of times the engineers would talk to Cadillac on the phone about some changes, come out here and set up and have the new part on the way to them the next day," Mr. Janik said.
Mr. Gurley said: "The business has changed over the years, and it's going through another transition now. I could claim it was vision, but it was really the realities of the market that pushed us to do what we've done throughout our history. And that's what's pushing us still."
