HEADLINE: Ultimate Insider, Ultimate Outsider

BYLINE: By Joseph Finder; Joseph Finder, the author of "The Moscow Club," a novel, and "Red Carpet: The Connection Between the Kremlin and America's Most Powerful Businessmen," writes frequently about international affairs.

 BODY:

THE CHAIRMAN
John J. McCloy: The Making of the American Establishment.
By Kai Bird.
Illustrated. 800 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $30. 
THE journalist Richard Rovere was once challenged to name the chairman of the Establishment, that predominantly WASP ruling class that for decades had steered American domestic and foreign policy. He pondered for a while. "Suddenly the right name sprang to my lips. 'John J. McCloy,' " Rovere declared. "My God, how could I have hesitated?"
It was a logical choice: John J. McCloy, the friend and adviser to nine Presidents, the Wall Street lawyer par excellence, the chairman of the Council on Foreign Relations (emblematic institution of the Establishment if ever there was one), the Rockefeller Foundation, the Ford Foundation and the Chase Manhattan Bank, the president of the World Bank, the virtual dictator of postwar Germany for three years as commissioner of occupied Germany, a member of the Warren Commission . . . and the resume goes on and on. Named in C. Wright Mills's influential 1957 book, "The Power Elite," as part of that group's "inner core," a lifelong Republican who did his most significant work for Democratic Presidents, McCloy was the behind-the-scenes power broker, the eminence grise who for years embodied the American governing class.
A short, stocky, bald, plain man, an unprepossessing figure, McCloy was, by most accounts, less than brilliant -- and yet, as Dean Acheson observed, he had "an expansive, happy nature with no littleness, suspicion or jealousy about it," as well as a knack for working easily with difficult personalities.
John J. McCloy had an extraordinary influence on the course of this century, but three years after his death at the age of 93 his name has been all but forgotten by the general public. "The Chairman" by Kai Bird, a contributing editor of The Nation, is the first biography of the man Harper's Magazine once called "the most influential private citizen in America." Although McCloy was said to have feared that this account -- 10 years in the making -- would be hostile, it is exhaustively researched and remarkably evenhanded.
The great paradox of McCloy's life was that the Establishment's chairman of the board was in fact born poor -- on the wrong side of the tracks, as he often put it. His strong-willed mother supported her family as a hairdresser, "doing heads" of Philadelphia society ladies. She managed to send her son to boarding school, Amherst College and Harvard Law School. The young McCloy seems to have been possessed of a genius for knowing which circles to move in. Affable and diligent, he gained entree to ranks of society from which he would have otherwise been excluded, in part by becoming a star tennis player.
McCloy, always keenly aware of being an outsider, was fond of relating an incident from his youth that came to attain an almost totemic resonance. As a college student, prompted by his mother, he walked up to the door of the Rockefeller mansion at Seal Harbor, Me., and asked for a job; the butler slammed the door in his face. Soon after, McCloy somehow managed to secure a position teaching sailing to the Rockefeller children, including Nelson and David, both of whom were later central to his career.
He became a well-regarded corporate attorney at several New York law firms and joined all the right clubs. Recruited to Washington by Franklin D. Roosevelt's Secretary of War, Henry Stimson, McCloy was eventually appointed Assistant Secretary of War. Like Woody Allen's Zelig, he seemed to turn up everywhere -- smoking cigars with Churchill amid the ruins of the House of Commons; consulting with Charles de Gaulle, George Patton and George Marshall; participating in the discussions over whether to drop the atomic bomb on Japan.
BEFORE then, it had fallen to him to make one of the most difficult decisions of World War II, certainly one of the most controversial decisions of his career. As Mr. Bird writes, he was responsible "more than any other individual" for getting the President to issue the infamous Executive Order 9066, calling for the resettlement of more than 100,000 Japanese-Americans from the West Coast to "relocation centers" (or, as Roosevelt more bluntly called them, "concentration camps"). McCloy justified the decision by proclaiming, "If it is a question of safety of the country, [or] the Constitution of the United States, why, the Constitution is just a scrap of paper to me."
Mr. Bird discloses, too, that at least as early as 1943 McCloy was one of the very few in Washington who had information about Hitler's proposed Final Solution and who had the power to do something about it. Yet he refused to believe that the Nazis were systematically exterminating the Jews. (As Mr. Bird points out, McCloy's skepticism was shared by, among others, Felix Frankfurter and Walter Lippmann, both Jews.)
As Stimson's liaison to the War Review Board, McCloy opposed a plan to bomb the railways leading to the death camps, on the ground that it would have diverted precious resources and would have been useless in any case. Mr. Bird maintains that it would have saved some 100,000 Jews at Auschwitz from being gassed, and that McCloy "bears substantial responsibility for this misjudgment." Whether the bombing would have saved these Jews remains a matter of fierce dispute.
In March 1945 Roosevelt greeted McCloy in the Oval Office with arm extended in a Nazi salute, saying, "Heil McCloy -- Hochkommissar fur Deutschland." McCloy declined the position, urging that Roosevelt pick a military man. But when Harry S. Truman offered him the same job four years later, he finally accepted, thus entering one of the most controversial periods of his long career.
AS High Commissioner for occupied Germany, McCloy granted clemency to dozens of Nazi war criminals. He freed, or reduced the sentences of, most of the 20 SS extermination squad leaders, whose crimes he freely conceded were "historic in their magnitude and horror." Of the 15 death sentences handed down at the Nuremberg trials, McCloy carried out a mere five. Of the remaining 74 war criminals who were sentenced at Nuremberg to prison terms, he let many go free -- most notoriously the industrialist Alfried Krupp, who had been sentenced at Nuremberg to 12 years in prison for using concentration camp inmates as slave labor. Krupp, accompanied by most of his board of directors, walked out of the Landsberg prison in 1951 to a cheering crowd and a champagne breakfast -- with his fortune and industrial empire intact.
Much of the world was outraged. "Why," Eleanor Roosevelt wrote to McCloy, "are we freeing so many Nazis?" The answer, Mr. Bird explains, was far from simple. For one thing, McCloy faced threats on his own life, and immense pressure from the German public and even from Pope Pius XII to grant a blanket amnesty -- "a well-organized conspiracy," McCloy recalled, "to intimidate me."
But the chief reason, according to Mr. Bird, was Realpolitik pure and simple, the Larger Considerations: the onset of the Korean War had made more important than ever a pro-American West Germany, rearmed and thus a bulwark against the Russians. The Truman Administration, and McCloy in particular, did not want to undermine our staunchest friend, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany. This meant, apparently, appeasing West German public opinion as much as possible and gaining the support of the most prominent West German industrialists. With the fate of the West in the balance, what did a few Nazi war criminals matter?
Moreover, Adenauer's men were not reluctant to use blackmail, telling McCloy that if the Nazis imprisoned in Landsberg were hanged, "Germany as an armed ally against the East was an illusion." As one I. G. Farben executive whom McCloy freed remarked acidly, "Now that they have Korea on their hands, the Americans are a lot more friendly."
After the war, and a quarter-century after the Rockefellers' butler had shut the door in McCloy's face, Nelson Rockefeller recruited McCloy as a name partner in the New York law firm of Milbank, Tweed (whose chief client was the Chase Bank). He was now officially in the Rockefeller fold. In time, the Rockefeller family made him chairman of Chase, with the implicit understanding that he was to groom the young David Rockefeller to take over.
Never rich himself, McCloy had become a reliable trouble-shooter for the rich. "His status in the company of such men of wealth was not that of an equal," Mr. Bird acutely points out, "but these uncrowned members of the American aristocracy depended upon his legal talents to insulate their wealth and social status from the uncertainties of a democratic republic."
By the late 1950's, when Richard Rovere identified him as the chairman of the Establishment, McCloy was regularly attending intimate stag dinners at the White House as a member of Dwight D. Eisenhower's "unofficial Cabinet." John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, both outsiders to the Establishment, recognized the importance of cultivating the chairman. As President Kennedy's disarmament adviser, McCloy negotiated the withdrawal of Soviet missiles from Cuba; he was one of the "Wise Men" recruited by McGeorge Bundy in 1965 to advise President Johnson on Vietnam policy (but really to secure Eastern Establishment backing for the war). Johnson, who felt awkward around patrician types, was told by Mr. Bundy (no stranger to the patriciate himself) that "the key to these people is McCloy," who "belongs to the class of people who take their orders from Presidents and nobody else." When McCloy and his friends in the Council on Foreign Relations refused to side publicly with the President on Vietnam, Johnson bitterly complained, "The Establishment bastards have bailed out."
Throughout the late 1960's and the 70's, McCloy continued to exert an enormous influence on American foreign policy. In 1979, when David Rockefeller and Henry Kissinger began pressing the Carter Administration to admit the deposed Shah of Iran to the United States for medical treatment (actually, for asylum), they asked McCloy to orchestrate the extensive lobbying effort. His motivations were not entirely disinterested: Milbank, Tweed provided legal counsel to the Shah, who also had billions of dollars on deposit with Chase. Every Christmas, the Shah sent his friend Jack McCloy five pounds of Beluga caviar.
The reputation of the American ruling elite barely survived the turmoil of the 60's, and late in his life McCloy came to be regarded increasingly as the Establishment archdemon, the master manipulator. His role in the Japanese internment and his role in the decision not to bomb Auschwitz were now seen in the unflattering light of historical revisionism.
Despite the range of John J. McCloy's accomplishments, one suspects that his name is little known today because he wanted it that way. He realized early on that the key to his influence was his lack of public visibility, and he ceded the limelight to the larger egos. Unlike some of his more flamboyant peers -- Stimson, Acheson, Frankfurter, Averell Harriman, Allen Dulles -- he wasn't a larger-than-life personality; he was, perhaps deliberately, ever the colorless lawyer. Unlike, say, Walter Lippmann, he was no intellectual. He was the earnest working-class boy who had, by dint of hard work, tireless public service and a not inconsiderable gift for schmoozing, managed to make his way into the Establishment's inner circle.
And it is here that "The Chairman" disappoints. We do not really get a sense of McCloy as a flesh-and-blood character; we aren't given the opportunity to explore the tensions, the sociological nuances, of the ultimate insider who was really the ultimate outsider -- the poor boy, as James Reston has written, who lived "most of his life among the rich." We see the paradoxes of his life, but we don't understand the contradictions within the man.
STILL, Mr. Bird's range of sources is quite impressive, including scores of interviews and hundreds of Government documents that were declassified under the Freedom of Information Act, and his assessments are judicious. Although "The Chairman" lacks the telling detail and anecdotal texture of another recent book that treats McCloy and his circle, "The Wise Men" by Walter Isaacson and Evan Thomas, it will certainly join the ranks of those accounts essential to a full understanding of how politics in this century was conducted behind the scenes.
In his last days, his power ebbing, McCloy had become a "jovial gnome," as Henry Kissinger once called him, with a trying "penchant for anecdotes." At the age of 86 he happily accepted an invitation to testify before a Congressional commission investigating the wartime internment of the Japanese-Americans, expecting the deference normally accorded an elder statesman. Instead he was attacked; when he described the conditions in the camps as "very pleasant," he was greeted with loud laughter from spectators at the hearing. This man who had made so many of the crucial decisions of a turbulent century, this symbol of the American Establishment, was now a relic of a bygone era.
Yet in the light of what we have lived through, at least since Watergate, it has become fashionable in certain circles to wax nostalgic for the good old days when our leaders who guided us into the American Century were drawn primarily from a close-knit social circle imbued with an ethic of public service and noblesse oblige. The mixed record of John J. McCloy may help temper that nostalgia, suggesting that perhaps, for all its many virtues, the American Establishment may have borne within itself the seeds of its own decline and fall.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: Bay Shore

BYLINE: By BRET SENFT

 BODY:
BAY SHORE is a hamlet of wealth alongside poverty -- of mansions on the Great South Bay waterfront a mile from low-income housing. Like many Long Island communities, its downtown was hard hit in the early 1960's by the opening of nearby shopping malls.
Residents say, however, that it offers quiet, well-kept streets, a respected school system and waterfront recreation. 
 To spur downtown business, the Town of Islip -- as an unincorporated area, Bay Shore is governed by and responsible to the town -- has created service roads and parking behind Main Street to ease traffic and rezoned downtown, reducing the commercial area and introducing residential. And a renewed popular spirit has helped stabilize the community.
"Bay Shore is going to re-happen," said Ken Turrisi, an architect-developer and 10-year resident.
Its history is rooted in large estates. John Mowbray bought most of what is now the eastern part of the hamlet from the Penataquit Indians in 1708. To the west, Stephen Van Courtlandt had built his Sagtikos Manor in 1692 in what is now West Bay Shore. Such large holdings were later subdivided, and housing developed on individual lots.
"That's why, today, you go anywhere off Main Street and see seven, eight houses in a row, and none are the same," said John G. Pullis, president of the Bay Shore Historical Society.
The community changed names several times: Penataquit to Sodom (briefly) to Mechanicsville. By the 1880's, it became Bay Shore, an apt description, and was a burgeoning resort town.
After World War I, however, rail service expanded and its grand hotels and boarding homes declined as tourists went east to the Hamptons or took the steamboat to Fire Island (Fire Island ferries still operate off the foot of Maple Avenue).
Energies shifted to entertainment and commerce. The Regent moviehouse opened on Main Street in 1915, as did a Vitagraph film studio on Fourth Avenue (its productions starred Fatty Arbuckle, Norma Tallmadge and Marie Dressler). In 1926, the ornate Bay Shore Theater opened on West Main, with both vaudeville and movies. In the 40's and 50's, downtown had a Sear's, a Loeser's, a Friedman's and thriving smaller businesses.
Manus H. O'Donnell, a 37-year resident and assistant school superintendent for personnel, recalled Main Street in the 50's: "Friday night was like Fifth Avenue on the Easter Parade. Really -- you had trouble moving along the sidewalks."
But the early 1960's brought a huge mall to Sunrise Highway: the 857,000-square-foot South Shore (with Macy's and J. C. Penney), where a 400,000-square-foot expansion is planned.Businesses and major supermarkets followed.
In the early 1970's, deinstitutionalized mental-health patients from nearby Central Islip and Pilgrim State Hospitals drifted to downtown; in 1977, Suffolk County's largest social-services center opened between Third and Fourth Avenues north of Main, providing welfare, Medicaid and parole programs.
OLD hotels (converted to single-room-occupancy residences) and shabby apartments above stores filled with welfare clients and former patients. Drug traffic and prostitution increased downtown. But recent meetings between business leaders and town councilmen have led to legislation calling for phasing out S.R.O.'s and apartments above stores along Main Street by January 1997. The Chamber of Commerce has noted a tenfold increase in attendance at such meetings in the last two years.
Away from the blighted downtown areas, housing prices range from $1 million-plus for waterfront estates to $150,000 for colonials around Southside Hospital and $125,000 for ranches and split-levels in northern and western sections, according to Lorraine Lovgren, owner of Century 21 on East Main Street and president of the Chamber of Commerce.
There are 1,313 rental apartments, 312 units in co-ops and just one condominium, the 128-unit Windermere, with two tennis courts and an outdoor pool. Its prices range from $179,000 for a two-bedroom unit to $250,000 for a five-bedroom.
Eric G. Ramsey Jr. Associates on West Main Street noted an increase in starter home sales. Although Ramsey specializes in waterfront properties, Mr. Ramsey said, "We're selling a lot of affordable housing in the $150,000 to $250,000 range."
Robert and Anne Marie Virgilio moved from Islip soon after their wedding in 1990 to a two-bedroom colonial in the Brightwaters Farms section west of downtown. Mr. Virgilio, who works at the New York Stock Exchange, commutes from Babylon, where the Long Island Rail Road's diesel service changes to electric.
"A lot of young families have bought into the area," he said. "During the summer, this is a great place to be. We have a boat. Docking in the town marina [with 503 slips, the largest on the South Shore] is tough to find, but you can get a slip at a private home."
There are about 350 slips at four private marinas, said Frank Mina, the owner of Shoreline Marina, and "hundreds more" privately owned.
Ervina Lew, a lifelong resident and writer who teaches in Brentwood, lives with her husband, Robert, in a high-ranch on Penataquit Point with a panoramic view of the bay. "The kids who grow up here, whether rich or poor, have the experience of knowing they are living in a microcosm of the real world," she said, and the waterfront "provides everyone with recreational opportunities usually reserved for the privileged."
The school district has 4,500 students in seven buildings: Three primary (grades K-2), two intermediate (3-5), Bay Shore Middle School on Brook Avenue (6-8), and Bay Shore High School on Third Avenue (9-12). Busing assures a racially and economically balanced school population. There is a dual Spanish/English language enrichment program taught to all K and first-grade children, reflecting the community's 12 percent (and growing) Hispanic population.
THE high school has a marching band that has won major county and state awards, an orchestra, a theater program and a full complement of sports. In 1989, the school district was one of 139, out of a statewide total of 740, chosen for a pilot program for the state's Excellence and Accountability Program to improve quality through community involvement and curriculum development.
St. Patrick's, a Roman Catholic elementary school on Main Street, offers K-8 education to the parish's 4,600 families.
New development includes construction of 13 units for the elderly by Mr. Turrisi, the developer, on the long-condemned Baybright Hotel site; conversion of the Bay Shore Movie Theater (closed since 1981) to the Great South Bay Y.M.C.A., with a pool, weight training room, gym, and pre-school, and development of the old Regent moviehouse -- for years a porno theater -- to a first-run cinema, whose adjacent adult bookstore is to be replaced by a walkway to town-built parking.
Main Street has, among other things, Muscles (a popular yogurt/fast food place), RSVP Tuxedos, Bay Shore Lighting and H.A. Kalt Boutique and Shoes, a local fixture since April 12, 1937. But most residents go to Sunrise Highway and its shopping complexes for goods and services. Fine waterfront restaurants include Porky & Glenn's at 24 Cottage Avenue, Captain Bill's on Ocean Avenue and Harbor House on Maple Avenue at water's edge.
Golf enthusiasts have three county and two town courses a short drive from Bay Shore.
Since 1987, a Community Forum has guided member civic associations in addressing local issues, such as reviewing plans for the former Bay Shore Drive-In site (soon to be a nine-acre Home Depot Center, with 19 acres as housing for the elderly or partial commercial use), or organizing an antidrug, midnight vigil along Second Avenue.
"It's empowerment of the people, working in harmony with the government, to bring about positive change in the community," said the forum president, Selwyn Powell.

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Newport, R.I.;
Meeting Needs At the Low End

BYLINE: By Elizabeth Abbott

 BODY:
THIS city is working with Rhode Island's housing agency and a private developer on a project of 30 one-family houses for first-time home buyers of low to moderate income.
Ground will be broken next month on the three-and-a-half-acre Beacon Street project, which should be completed within a year, said Bruce Bartlett, the city's director of Planning, Zoning and Development. 
 While housing prices have fallen because of the recession, most are still too high for most first-time buyers, he said.
In 1990, the median price of a one-family house in Newport was $140,250, according to the Rhode Island Housing and Mortgage Finance Corporation, the state's housing agency. The average in 1990 was $183,118.
"I don't think you can find anything below $120,000," Mr. Bartlett said.
The 1990 census found a median income for a family of four here to be $34,490, he said, adding that the disparity between income and housing prices made Newport one of the least affordable of the state's Island's 39 cities and towns.
The Beacon Street houses, which will have at least two bedrooms, will sell for about $80,000, Mr. Bartlett said. Buyers must meet income guidelines set by the housing agency -- no more than $40,600 for a household of two and $46,690 for a household of three or more.
Half the units will be reserved for those who must meet income guidelines set by the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, which are lower than the state's, Mr. Bartlett said. HUD's limits are $27,500 for a household of two and $30,450 for a household of three.
In 1989, the state housing agency gave the city a $527,000 land bank loan to buy the vacant site, which straddles Newport and neighboring Middletown. The interest rate is 3 percent, Mr. Bartlett said. The New England Affordable Housing Corporation, a local development firm, has agreed to buy the lots from the city and the city will use the proceeds of the sales to pay back the loan, he said.
The housing corporation will build and sell the houses, keeping the profits from the sales, Mr. Bartlett said.
Created by the Rhode Island General Assembly in 1973 with a mandate to create safe, decent housing for low- and moderate-income families, the Rhode Island Housing and Mortgage Finance Corporation is a quasi-state agency that finances housing development through the sale of bonds and low-income tax credits.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
As Many British Readers Relax on Saturdays, Their Newspapers Thrive

BYLINE: By SUZANNE CASSIDY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, April 12

 BODY:
With its circulation and advertising shrinking, the British press has found one surprising success story: Saturday newspapers. Once unpopular afterthoughts, Saturday newspapers are now selling more copies than their weekday counterparts and are challenging the weekend pre-eminence of the country's Sunday papers.
Over the last six years or so, Britain's five serious national dailies have expanded their Saturday papers, adding magazines and leisure and review sections that have won both readers and advertisers. 
 Save for The Financial Times, the serious broadsheet dailies have all lost circulation over the last year. But their editors say the losses would have been worse had they not been offset by gains on Saturday.
By charging more on Saturdays than on weekdays, The Daily Telegraph, The Times and The Independent have been able to offset a decline in revenues, which have been depressed by the recession. Last month, The Guardian also raised its price.
Over all, advertising for Saturday papers has risen sharply in recent months, according to The Guardian.
In one week in February, the newspaper said, The Times, The Daily Telegraph, The Independent and The Guardian averaged a combined total of 66.5 pages of advertising on weekdays. But on Saturday, it said, advertising totaled about 326 pages. Recent figures for The Daily Telegraph showed that two and half times more advertising space was sold for Saturday than for the average weekday.
"Six or seven years ago," said David Pugh, group marketing manager for The Telegraph newspapers, "if we'd said we're going to turn Saturday into the most successful day of the week, most people in publishing would have laughed."
The Saturday surge, said Jonathan Fenby, deputy editor of The Guardian, comes amid a long-term decline in the Sunday newspaper market. Now, Mr. Fenby asserted, "Saturday is the beginning of the weekend" and people want to start their weekend reading on Saturday.
More than Americans and most Europeans, the British are avid newspaper readers. Britain has 11 national dailies, including two large middle-market tabloids, The Daily Mail and The Daily Express, and several sensationalistic tabloids, most notably The Sun and The Daily Mirror.
And unlike the American press, the British newspapers have not faced intense competition for readers' time from television, which here offers only a fraction of the programming available in the United States.
The trend toward larger Saturday papers began in 1985, when The Financial Times started its Weekend section, and picked up speed in 1988, when The Independent introduced its color magazine and leisure and review section. The Independent's editor in chief, Andreas Whittam Smith, said those sections had "a brilliant effect on circulation." Indeed, in February, The Independent's circulation averaged about 406,000 on Saturdays, compared with 360,000 on weekdays.
At The Financial Times, the Weekend section features subjects ranging from personal finance to gardening. The Saturday paper now attracts about 25,000 more buyers than the weekday paper, which has a British circulation of about 180,000.
At The Times, its editor, Simon Jenkins, has expanded his Saturday paper to three broadsheet sections and a color magazine.
 
'Stopped the Rot'
 "We've sort of stopped the rot, stopped those Monday-to-Friday Times readers from buying a rival newspaper on Saturday," he said. There is, he added, "no question of a doubt that The Times would have been in worse shape if we hadn't made these expansions."
The Guardian, meanwhile, says it has picked up about 10,000 readers on Saturdays since it added a second broadsheet section in February.
At The Telegraph, Mr. Pugh said, Saturday expansion was part of his paper's "long-term strategy of overtaking The Sunday Times."
With a circulation of 1.05 million, The Daily Telegraph was deemed better placed than The Sunday Telegraph to compete with The Sunday Times, which dominates the market with a circulation of 1.17 million. From September to February, The Sunday Telegraph's circulation averaged just about 563,500, down from 671,400 about three years before.
So, a Saturday features section was added in 1987, the Sunday color magazine moved to Saturday in 1988, a supplement for young readers was started in 1990 and in February the Saturday paper began a weekly television guide. With each innovation, the newspaper gained advertising and tens of thousands of readers.
 
Problems on Sunday
 Mr. Pugh acknowledged that the stronger Saturday paper might have hurt The Sunday Telegraph, but said The Daily Telegraph needed to respond to increased competition.
And Mr. Whittam Smith, as editor in chief of both The Independent and its sister paper, The Independent on Sunday, said that by improving his Saturday paper, "we probably did make it harder for ourselves." But he said Saturday and Sunday papers could coexist because they served overlapping, but different markets.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Independent
Perot's Quest -- A Special Report;
A Man Who Says He Wants To Be Savior, if He's Asked

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES with DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, April 12

 BODY:
H. Ross Perot seems to have this compulsion about rescuing things.
In the 1970's he was called upon to rescue Wall Street. When revolution gripped Iran, he bankrolled an effort to rescue two of his employees held hostage in a Teheran prison. In the 1980's it was General Motors and the Texas schools. Now, Mr. Perot is thinking about trying to rescue the country. 
 But only if he is asked.
At a time when huge chunks of the electorate seem to be hopping mad at incumbents and have expressed dissatisfaction with the choices that the parties are putting forward as Presidential candidates, the elfin, crewcut Texas billionaire is poised to cast himself as a kind of Lone Ranger from the Lone Star State ready to ride into Washington to clean up the mess.
 
A Myth in Danger?
 Mr. Perot's independent pre-campaign campaign has been buoyed by his legitimate feats and a largely uncritical press that has helped inflate his achievements to near mythic proportions. But that may be ending.
When he spoke Friday to the American Society of Newspaper Editors convention in Washington, Mr. Perot faced questions that finally provoked him to sharp replies, a response that seems to be typical of his style when challenged by reporters.
When asked in an interview in Dallas last week about his motive in running for President Mr. Perot said, "What you see is what you get," and added: "If we're going to spend all morning looking for hidden agendas, then you're just burning up my time and yours. I don't want to do this. Is that clear enough? Is that clear?"
He said he would make a decision on whether to formally become a candidate by June, and some who have advised him say he will probably toss his Stetson in the ring.
"There is no question he's going to go," says a top Democratic strategist familiar with some of Mr. Perot's deliberations and who insisted on anonymity.
If he does run, the 61-year-old Mr. Perot, who built Electronic Data Systems into the world's biggest computer services company before selling it to G.M., will be an unconventional candidate in a topsy-turvy political year. Political experts say any Presidential aspirant should have a broad constituency, an agenda, a campaign machine, seasoned advisers and fire in the belly. Mr. Perot clearly lacks the first four.
But he may be inching toward a mandate. Since he announced on March 16 on the Cable News Network program "Larry King Live" that he was prepared to run if enough signatures were gathered to place his name on the ballot in every state, nearly 1.8 million calls have been placed to his offices urging him to join the fray, his aides say.
The method of dipping one toe into the Presidential creek is vintage Perot, reflecting his habit of seeking challenges and his disdain for the ordinary political process.
"I consider the whole process as one that attracts the wrong kind of person," he said in an interview here. "These are people who are ego driven and power driven."
 
Writing His Own Speeches
 Mirroring Mr. Perot's political independence is his determination to control his campaign personally. Scorning political consultants as "handlers and cosmetologists," Mr. Perot said, "No one is going to write my speeches for me."
For the moment, he is relying mostly on three longtime associates for advice: Mort Meyerson, former president of E.D.S. and now an independent investor in Dallas; Thomas W. Luce 3d, chief executive of First Southwest Company, a Dallas bank, and Thomas D. Barr, a New York lawyer.
But he was not above soliciting advice from one Washington insider, Lloyd Cutler, a former White House counsel under Jimmy Carter. Mr. Cutler is supporting Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. The time may be drawing near when candidate Perot will need expertise for advertising, surveys and strategy.
The time also may be coming when his claims and comments are greeted with skepticism.
For instance, while Mr. Perot's aides boast of the 1.8 million calls he has received, nearly a third of those were logged before MCI, the telecommunications company, set up a more sophisticated system to handle the volume. Before MCI did that, company officials say, every person who tried to reach Mr. Perot's offices was counted, whether the call got through or not. A person who got a busy signal and called back was counted twice.
 
Strategy
Lots of Money, Lots of Obstacles
 The plain-talking Mr. Perot, whom Mr. Barr compares to Harry S. Truman, has the potential to create mischief for President Bush and Mr. Clinton in the general election insofar as he has struck a chord among voters yearning for change and an end to what they see as gridlock and vacillation.
A staunch supporter of the military, Mr. Perot opposed the Persian Gulf war, declaring that the Emir of Kuwait was not worth fighting for. His solution for Iraqi aggression: send a commando force, possibly with Israeli help, to assassinate Saddam Hussein.
"He has a bias for action," said Mr. Luce, whose answer puts American voters on notice that as President, Mr. Perot might resort to direct action if going through channels failed to produce results.
A telephone poll of 1,521 voters nationwide conducted in late March by the Los Angeles Times found that 21 percent said they would vote for Mr. Perot, as against to 37 percent for President Bush and 35 percent for Mr. Clinton. The survey found that Mr. Perot's support was strongest in New England, on the West Coast and the Middle Atlantic states and weakest in the Deep South and Farm Belt. The survey had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Such surveys lead political analysts to speculate that Mr. Perot could prevent either Mr. Bush or Mr. Clinton from achieving a majority in the Electoral College. Mr. Perot said that if he saw himself playing only a spoiler's role, he would remove himself from the race.
Some political strategists say, however, that boomlets for third party and independent candidates are not unusual in the spring of election years. In March 1980, for example, in a race headlined by a weakened President Jimmy Carter and former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California, polls showed Representative John Anderson, a Republican from Illinois, with nearly a quarter of the vote as a third-party candidate. In the November election he received 6.7 percent.
But Mr. Perot enjoys advantages that would make Mr. Anderson swoon. First of all, he is stupendously rich, with a personal worth of between $2.5 billion and $3.5 billion, longtime associates say. Because he would not need Federal campaign aid, he would not be bound by spending restrictions and might spend $100 million or more, nearly twice as much as the legal limit for his opponents.
"We had a guy in Texas, Clayton Williams, who ran for Governor, and I thought he was rich," said Jim Oberwetter, chairman of the President Bush's campaign in Texas. "He spent $10 million of his own money and charmed a large portion of the electorate who voted in the primary" before making what many voters considered offensive remarks about rape and losing to Ann Richards in the general election in 1990.
"My concern," Mr. Oberwetter added, "is what if Ross Perot charms the American people on a few issues that we all agree on?"
 
Daunting Obstacles
 To become a force in the Presidential race -- indeed just to get his name on the ballot in every state -- Mr. Perot faces daunting obstacles. Each state has its own rules for qualifying, and some are difficult.
In New York, for example, Mr. Perot would have to gather 20,000 signatures from registered voters, including 100 each from 16 of the state's 31 Congressional districts. He must file the petitions between Aug. 11 and Aug. 18, but cannot start collecting signatures until July 7. People who voted in the recent primary are not allowed to sign.
"There are a lot of rules in a lot of states that are plainly designed to keep independents like Perot off the ballot," said Mr. Barr. He said Mr. Perot may have to go to court to gain access to some state ballots.
 
Issues
A Vague Agenda, But Plenty of Fire
 Some political strategists, especially those working for other Presidential candidates, say Mr. Perot has enjoyed great approval because the public does not know what he believes in. Indeed, in an interview he demonstrated an ability to be maddeningly vague, and grew prickly when pressed.
Under prodding, Mr. Perot said that he favors a capital gains tax cut -- though at different rates for investments in businesses and investments in securities. He also believes the President should have the power to veto specific items in spending bills, backs abortion rights and favors aid to the republics of the former Soviet Union.
Though he says the national debt is the most important issue, it is difficult to pin down his solutions. He says the country must build its industrial base to rebuild its tax base. To do that, he says, the nation should learn from successful examples of cooperation between governments and the private sector, like those in Japan.
As for the Federal budget deficit, Mr. Perot says $180 billion could be saved by the elimination of waste, fraud and abuse. He believes more efficient tax collection could provide an additional $100 billion a year, and that a further $100 billion could be gained by insisting that European and Asian countries reimburse the United States for the costs of their military defense.
On issues like affirmative action, drugs and gun control, Mr. Perot is much less specific. He says he wants to "get the guns out of the hands of violent people," for instance. But registering firearms or requiring a waiting period before their purchase would not accomplish that, he said.
The battle against drugs? "I won't get into them until I can build a consensus with the American people, if they've got the stomach for it," he said. "All I'll get from you guys is sound bites and distortions. But it won't be pretty."
 
Image
A Go-Getter Has Some Success
 Starting from humble roots in Texarkana, Tex., Mr. Perot has achieved success in business and a larger-than-life reputation that he sometimes jokes about. "I am not a legend," he said in a recent speech, "But I am a myth."
If he is, it is a myth built on action.
Henry Ross Perot was a go-getter, breaking horses, delivering newspapers and earning Eagle Scout rank. He won an appointment to the Naval Academy, where he was in the middle of his class academically but was elected its president. In 1956 he married the former Margot Birmingham of Greensburg, Pa.; the couple have five grown children.
He became a top computer salesman for International Business Machines Corporation in Dallas, but I.B.M. discouraged his idea for selling computer services rather than the machines themselves. So in 1962, with $1,000 borrowed from his wife's savings, Mr. Perot started the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, which initially bought unused computer time from owners of large units and sold it to companies that could not afford such equipment. When E.D.S. shares were first offered to the public in 1968, Mr. Perot became a wealthy man overnight.
From success in business, Mr. Perot turned to action in other arenas. But closer examination of his exploits suggest that while they show daring, resourcefulness and tenacity, not all were complete successes.
In 1970, with some Wall Street brokerages having troubles, officials of the Treasury asked Mr. Perot to invest $5 million in one failing concern to prop it up and restore the faith of small investors in the stock market. Mr. Perot agreed, but after three years, and losses totaling $60 million, he decided to dissolve the firm.
 
Tilting at G.M.
 The struggle between Mr. Perot and the G.M. management in 1986 is a case in point. Mr. Perot had sold E.D.S. to G.M. for $2.5 billion in 1984. As part of the deal, he got a stake in G.M. and became a director the company. But almost immediately he began clashing with top officials over the competitiveness of the company.
Ultimately, Mr. Perot sold his G.M. stake back to the company for $700 million, but the episode was an example of his having to retreat after charging head down into a immovable object.
In 1984 Mr. Perot headed a state commission to overhaul the Texas schools. He proposed an appointed, rather than elected, state school board, competency exams for teachers, smaller classes and a rule that failing students would temporarily lose eligibility for extracurricular activities, including high school football, a Texas passion.
Mr. Perot pushed the ideas through a special session of the Texas legislature, paying lobbyists from his own pocket. The "no pass, no play" football rule and tests for teachers still stand, but one of the most significant alterations, the appointed state school board, was later rejected by voters.
In the Iran rescue, Mr. Perot was "more lucky than smart," he has said. The Shah was busy battling the Muslim fundamentalists who would eventually remove him from power, and diplomatic efforts failed to free the two employees, who were jailed on accusations of bribery. So Mr. Perot hired a former Army colonel to train E.D.S. employees for a rescue attempt.
But as the raiders were planning the jail break in their hotel rooms, a resourceful young Iranian E.D.S. worker helped foment a riot by anti-Shah dissidents near the jail. The mob stormed the prison and released the E.D.S. executives along with thousands of other inmates. The rescue team and the executives fled to Turkey.
That rescue occurred in February 1979, a date of no particular importance to Mr. Perot. But there is a date that has been significant in his life: his birthday, June 27.
It has frequently been the date when milestones occurred. It was on June 27 that he was sworn in as a midshipman at the Naval Academy and when he founded E.D.S.
"After a while it was just something I decided to have some fun with," he said.
Now he has said he may make a formal campaign announcement "sometime in June." It will not be too surprising to those who know him well if his attempt to rescue the American economy and political system begins on June 27.

HEADLINE: From Middle Class to Jobless: A Sense of Pride Is Shattered

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
Like a mantra said daily over the shambles of his life, Marvin Pedowitz repeats: "I'm not going to lose my cool. I am in control."
Only at moments of great stress, like the other morning when his car battery died and he could not drive to a job interview it had taken weeks to line up, do the words fail him. 
 For Mr. Pedowitz, a 39-year-old accountant, and tens of thousands of other solidly middle-class men and women thrown out of work by the weak economy, the recession has gone on too long. The effort to maintain a sense of control over their lives, emotions and dignity has become a daily challenge.
 
Credit and Favors Exhausted
 Their unemployment benefits are running out. Their savings are nearing exhaustion. Their credit cards have long been overdrawn or canceled. Family members and friends can't be asked for more loans. Rent or mortgage payments have not been made in months. And eviction or foreclosure threats are turning up in the mail along with the piles of bills.
Public assistance agencies in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey report strong increases in applications for help over the last year. Many from the middle class are turned away, state and local officials say, because however painful their plight, they continue to hold paper assets that disqualify them.
The American middle class may represent a point of view more than an income range. It may be rooted in an attitude that its members control their economic destiny: they can provide for the necessities of life, build savings and provide for future needs.
 
A 'Shellshocked Group'
 Walking into a welfare office is confirmation of their fear that they have hit bottom. "They are a completely shellshocked group," said Nancy Glass, commissioner of the Westchester County Social Services Department, which has recorded an 18 percent increase in welfare cases since 1990. "And for those in the area who have been told they will be laid off, or fear they will be, it is white-knuckle time. Most of them carry such big mortgages in Westchester County that if anything goes wrong financially they have no space to wiggle." She said that more people seemed to be applying for the first time who formerly held middle-income jobs.
Going broke is new and frightening for white-collar workers with good educations and incomes who never worried about job security until the day they were laid off. Even those who lost upper-middle-class incomes were not immune and were horrified to see prolonged unemployment rapidly scuttle their assets and dreams.
And for thousands who have been out of work for a year or more, their bank accounts running on empty, prosperity is not around the corner. Increasingly, they fear, the welfare office is.
"I live in a different America today than I did two or three years ago," said Mr. Pedowitz, who has been out of full-time work since 1990, has fallen behind on his child-support payments, has no home of his own and stays ahead of bill collectors by living with friends in New Jersey whom he repays by doing their tax returns.
"I was raised to think that if you got an education, acquired skills and made sound investments, you would always have a job and money in the bank," he said, looking shattered as he recalled the suddenness of his fall from suburban grace.
"I'm partially at fault, I admit it," he said. "I got overextended at the end of the 80's. But it was what everyone was doing: paying more for a house than you could afford at the time, but it was the smart strategy. Housing prices were always going to go up. Get yourself big tax deductions. The list was endless. We were told no one should begrudge himself for wanting a piece of the pie."
The illusions evaporated like gossamer mists when jobs were lost. If new work was not found within months, the speed of the plunge into debt tied to fat mortgages, home equity lines of credit, auto loans and credit card overload jolted those who never before doubted their rightful places in the middle class.
Some have been forced to turn to state agencies and charitable groups, grateful to get assistance where it is available, stunned when it is not.
"I am faced with losing what I have spent a lifetime building up," said Zoltan R. Szebenyi, 49, of Holmdel, N.J., who said that he had been paid more than $100,000 a year as a salesman of motivational programs until the economy took a nose dive.
In a divorce settlement in 1989, he acquired a new $155,000 mortgage on his house, using the cash to make a settlement with his former wife. Now, monthly mortgage, tax and insurance payments totaling $1,760 have scuttled his savings and put him in risk of foreclosure.
 
Job at Half Old Salary
 In February, Mr. Szebenyi went hat in hand to Project Paul, a program run by the Roman Catholic Sisters of Mercy in Keansburg, N.J., and received an emergency grant of $1,500 to help keep the mortgage company at bay until he could find work. Last month he landed a job, but at half the salary of his old one, he said.
"Many middle-class people don't come to us for help until they're at the last gasp of their unemployment benefits and savings," said Sister Kathleen O'Halloran, director of Project Paul.
In Monmouth County, New Jersey, middle-class unemployed people are applying for assistance at a greater rate than ever before, based on background interviews when the applicants are screened.
"This is the last stop on their search for help," observed Mary DeRidder, administrative supervisor of income maintenance for the County Division of Social Services.
Brenda Brock, who interviews the applicants, said: "The ones I see are in a complete state of shock. They come from having had it all to losing it all."
They express anger and frustration, even rage, Ms. Brock said, when they come up against a system they have long heard about but never encountered and are forced to respond to endless questions and requests for financial statements to document their hardship.
Food stamps are easier to get than cash assistance, and there has been a 73 percent increase in the county program in the last two years.
For many, crossing that threshold is crossing a psychological line that carries them out of the middle class, said Alison Erb, head of the office. "They are baring their soul," Ms. Erb said. "It is all the worse if they go through the application, are informed they qualify and then are shocked to learn how little they get."
The maximum a single person receives is $111 a month in stamps. A family whose head still receives unemployment benefits may qualify for only $50 a month in stamps for the entire family, Ms. Erb explained.
Peter Deitche, a union ironworker in Fords, N.J. whose hourly pay scale is $22.51, plus $14 in benefits, has worked only 4 of the last 16 months and has fallen behind on his mortgage and other bills. He said he had no qualms when the Housing Coalition of Middlesex County helped him obtain cash through the Red Cross to pay his mortgage and utility bills for a month, in addition to giving him a $75 food voucher.
"I was very appreciative," he said. "I didn't feel bad at all. I looked the clerk at ShopRite right in the eye when I handed her the voucher. I'm no social parasite. I honestly need the money."
State and Federal programs provide money for eligible applicants. But the middle-class unemployed are running out of assets and applying for aid while the budgets of public agencies and private charities are strained trying to meet the needs of the groups they traditionally serve.
 
Charities Aid Former Donors
 Budget cuts forced the Nassau County Social Services Department to lay off 20 percent of its staff earlier this year, "while our caseload keeps growing, growing, growing," said Lynn Krishner, a spokeswoman.
At Catholic Family Services of New Haven, staff counselors say middle-class people who used to make contributions are now turning to the agency for help themselves.
"If they used our counseling services in the past they were covered by insurance, and their payments helped subsidize the poor," said Patricia Nere, the district executive director. "Now we're asked to subsidize their care, but we haven't found new sources of revenue." She said 85 percent of the new cases were white-collar families.
To make matters worse, Ms. Nere said, chronic unemployment among the middle class is contributing to family breakdowns, vanishing spouses, substance abuse "and a horrible increase in domestic violence."
"My real fear," said Ms. Nere, "is that it's just the beginning, that we haven't seen our worst year yet."
Mr. Pedowitz, the out-of-work accountant, dreads the day he may have to stand in a line with others seeking public assistance.
"The reality is I'm not middle class anymore; I'm not even eligible for social programs that someone living in a public housing project is," he reflected, his voice rising to the level of lament before he caught himself.
"I'm not going to lose my cool," he repeated. "I am in control."

HEADLINE: Russian Developments Could Delay West's Aid

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
The Russian Government's moves to slacken its tough economic reforms and hints by free-market advocates that they might resign could delay the flow of Western aid to Russia and the creation of a ruble stabilization fund, economists say.
The $24 billion aid package announced by President Bush just before the current meeting of the Congress of People's Deputies in Moscow was intended to help President Boris N. Yeltsin press ahead with changes, but his backtracking last week, caused largely by pressures from the hostile legislature, could delay important pieces of the package. 
 The Russian Government's moves to ease credit and otherwise appease members of the Congress antagonistic to rapid changes will probably push up Russia's already daunting inflation rate, economists say, and make it harder to create conditions for stabilizing the ruble.
These developments are also expected to raise new obstacles to Russia's signing an agreement with the International Monetary Fund. Officials from the industrialized nations known as the Group of Seven say an I.M.F. agreement would be crucial to unlocking billions of dollars in I.M.F. and bilateral aid and allowing the $6 billion ruble stabilization to move forward.
 
Yeltsin Quitting as Premier
 Yegor T. Gaidar, the chief architect of Mr. Yeltsin's economic reforms, hinted that he might resign after the Congress voted on Saturday to force Mr. Yeltsin to relinquish his concurrent position as Prime Minister within three months. Mr. Gaidar fears that without Mr. Yeltsin as prime minister, it will be impossible to push through reforms.
Today in Moscow, the two sides said they had narrowed their differences, and Western analysts said they hoped that this meant that the commitment to reform would not be diminished. But some were apprehensive nevertheless.
"This week's developments could endanger the possibility of an I.M.F. agreement," said Stanley Fischer, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and former chief economist at the World Bank.
On a visit to Moscow two weeks ago, Treasury Under Secretary David Mulford praised Mr. Yeltsin's economic reforms, but he said that to qualify for I.M.F. aid, Russia would have to tighten up those reforms by, for instance, cutting the budget deficit further. Mr. Mulford and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady are scheduled to visit Moscow on Tuesday to discuss aid and the state of reforms.
"People are somewhat concerned about the developments this week in Moscow," a senior Treasury official said. "But I don't think anyone is willing to say that this will necessarily slow down the process."
The moves the Yeltsin administration announced this week to placate legislators appear to conflict with the tightening up that Group of Seven officals are seeking. The Government said it would increase pensions, provide up to 200 billion rubles in new credits to cash-strapped state farms and factories, and delay plans to let energy prices jump to world levels. Raising energy prices would cut domestic consumption of oil and increase oil exports, helping improve Russia's balance of payments.
 
Ruble Stabilization Crucial
 While they worked behind the scenes to put together the huge Russian aid package, Treasury officials said they hoped extensive new aid would start flowing a few weeks after Russia joins the I.M.F., which is expected to take place in late April. They also said they hoped that a ruble stabilization fund would start in June or July, adding that stabilizing the ruble was crucial for steadying the teetering economy.
"Their decision to ease up on the budget and on credit will make it much more difficult to stabilize the ruble," Professor Fischer said. "All the things I have heard in the last few days make it less likely they will get a ruble stabilization fund in June."
Mr. Yeltsin's painful reform program has included lifting most price controls, slashing subsidies to consumers and cutting the budget deficit and money supply growth. Many of those measures are part of a preliminary I.M.F. program.
This last week's moves boosting outlays and easing credit are sure to create tensions with the I.M.F. An I.M.F. team is scheduled to go to Moscow next week for negotiations on an agreement.
"It looks as if both the deficit and inflation are going to be higher, so I don't see how some of these I.M.F. guidelines can be fulfilled," said Padma Desai, an expert on the Russian economy at the Harriman Institute at Columbia University.
Economists say that before beginning a ruble stabilization fund, it is necessary to rein in inflation because so long as prices rise, many Russians who can will deposit their savings in hard-currency accounts abroad. This will hurt Russia's balance of payments as well as confidence in the ruble.
Treasury officials also say Russia will have to unify its many different exchange rates into a single rate as well as agree with the I.M.F. on what exchange rate the ruble should have. Then Russia might have to wait for the ruble to float to the target level before the fund kicks in.
Once a unitary rate is established and the ruble is stabilized, convertibility will be more or less achieved, many economists say.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Stocks Plunge After Friday's Gain

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, April 13

 BODY:
Any lingering optimism from Friday's strong rally here evaporated today, with relentless selling pressure again sending the stock market into frightening downward spiral.
The market rose slightly in the morning in a tentative effort to sustain the upswing. But the overwhelmingly negative sentiment that has dominated the market for the last two weeks then took hold. A lack of positive news about the market or the economy was interpreted as bad news, analysts said. 
 The Nikkei index of 225 issues tumbled throughout the afternoon to close down 614.01 points, or 3.4 percent, to 17,236.65. The Nikkei lost 3.8 percent last week, in spite of Friday's rally, the index's fourth-largest in percentage terms.
Trading volume remained light, about 280 million shares, a sign that most investors are watching the carnage in the market from the sidelines.
"We're all pretty baffled," said Bill Brown, the president of Scudder Stevens and Clark Japan Inc., a unit of the big American asset-management company. "With this kind of volume, anything can happen."
The weak Japanese economy and prospects of falling corporate profits have taken a toll on the market for most of this year, but the decline turned into a rout two weeks ago, as investor confidence was shattered by what was regarded as a weak Government response to the situation. The Government pushed forward spending on public works projects, and the Bank of Japan reduced a critical interest rate.

LENGTH: 1331 words

HEADLINE: At Caterpillar's Helm, Calm and a Global View

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., April 11

 BODY:
Donald V. Fites winced when asked if the bitter dispute between 12,000 striking members of the United Automobile Workers union and Caterpillar Inc., was likely to have sweeping consequences for labor-management relations. Instead, the chairman of the giant construction machinery company said, it is merely a labor dispute -- though a formidable one -- with ramifications confined to one company.
"I don't think this thing has any larger ramifications," Mr. Fites said. "I believe that view is being put on by the United Auto Workers in an effort to try to whip up the passions of our employees and to try to make them feel that they have broader support. 
 "I find it inconceivable that for the mighty United Auto Workers union, with 900,000 members, and we, with less than 2 percent of that, that this is a life or death thing for the U.A.W. I don't believe it is."
But Mr. Fites's opinion is apparently not widely held. Many company executives, academics, analysts and Mr. Fites's counterparts in the industry as well as labor leaders contend that the Caterpillar chairman is presiding over the most important labor battle in years. As the two sides prepare to sit down with a Federal mediator on Monday, the dispute is being eagerly watched to see how it will be resolved and who will be most deeply shaken by its outcome.
 
'We're at an Impasse'
 Mr. Fites, in a recent interview at the company's headquarters here, said Caterpillar's aim remained to have its striking workers return, despite the company's pledge to hire nonunion workers as permanent replacements for workers who remain on strike.
He contrasted the strike with that of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization a decade ago when President Ronald Reagan replaced the strikers, saying: "This is not the Patco of the 90's. Our objective is to get our employees back to work. Every day there are more of them coming back, and that's positive.
"But we're at an impasse. I suppose if the United Auto Workers could come forth with a new proposal that was near our final proposal then the impasse would be over."
Union leaders have maintained that Caterpillar's insistence that its offer is final makes a union proposal futile. And union members, who have largely continued to defy the company's ultimatum, continue their picketing, both at the plants throughout Peoria and outside the company's downtown headquarters. By the slogans on the picket signs -- "Get the Fites Out of Caterpillar," and "Will Rogers Never Met Don Fites" -- the target of their anger is the 58-year-old Caterpillar chairman.
It is an unusual position for Mr. Fites, a marketing man who has been widely known and recognized in the company for his capacity to forge harmonious relations with colleagues and workers alike at Caterpillar, where he has worked for the last 36 years. His colleagues attribute that skill in part to Mr. Fites's upbringing on a farm in northwestern Indiana and his 16 years in Caterpillar positions in Europe, South America, Africa and Asia, where he made it a point to understand the cultural differences in the workplace.
 
'So Good With People'
 "One of the real strengths about Don is that he is so good with people and he cares so much about the workers," said Robert H. Coyle, a retired Caterpillar marketing executive for whom Mr. Fites once worked. "He really takes time to get to know people and to ask about their families. And that's what I think bothers him most about the situation. It's what gives him the most pressure."
Mr. Fites, a tall former high school basketball player who was often mistaken in foreign countries for the actor Gene Hackman, insists that his company's hard stance in the labor dispute is simply an effort to enable Caterpillar to attack the practice of "pattern bargaining," in which a union's labor pact with one company sets a standard for bargaining for other companies in that industry.
In that context, Mr. Fites denies that Caterpillar's stand is meant to represent a philosophical position for all of industry, in particular the Big Three automobile makers in Detroit. "We have to be globally competitive and that's why we're taking this stand," he said. "There is no company like Caterpillar in the United States and certainly no company like Caterpillar with United Auto Workers representation.
"We've decided as a long-term strategy that we're going to stay in the good old U.S.A. and we're going to compete globally from this manufacturing base. This is our message."
 
Drive to Compete Globally
 It is just that position on global competition and attack on costs that has motivated Mr. Fites for years, starting long before he was elected chairman of Caterpillar two years ago. In its effort to push productivity and to remain competitive with its arch rival, Komatsu Ltd., of Japan, the company began a modernization program five years ago called "Plant with a Future." That program, which is intended to cut Caterpillar's costs, entailed heavy spending on new equipment and plant modernization. The company also reorganized, giving more autonomy to individual divisions to cut response time, but also cutting 1,000 jobs as a consequence. It was Mr. Fites who led that reorganization.
For Caterpillar, which sells 59 percent of its trucks and excavators overseas, being competitive with foreign makers of that same equipment has been crucial. And Mr. Fites has been a champion of international free trade.
"We always tell the U.S. Government, 'For heaven's sake, don't try to help us by putting up some protective barriers because as soon as you do that, your costs go up and you're that much less globally competitive,' " Mr. Fites said. "The other fallacy of protectionism is that if we think we can protect the automobile industry in this country or any other industry -- in this day and age in this world, I can't see protectionism working."
Mr. Fites has long been known as a strong advocate of free trade and was active last year in campaigning against the extension of steel import quotas, which expired two weeks ago.
Mr. Fites says he sees the United Automobile Workers as favoring protectionism because "I feel they believe that if they can put this protectionist wall around the automotive industry in the United States then perhaps their chances of maintaining the pattern bargaining process will be better."
Mr. Fites graduated from Valparaiso University with a degree in civil engineering and joined Caterpillar soon after graduation in 1956. He received a master's degree in management in 1971 from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he was a Sloan Fellow. He has worked in management positions in South Africa, as marketing director of Caterpillar Mitsubishi Ltd. in Tokyo and as president of Caterpillar Brazil S.A. in Sao Paulo, before returning here in 1981, when he became corporate vice president, and executive vice president in 1985.
Mr. Fites has presided over Caterpillar operations during economic fluctuation in Brazil, during social upheaval in South Africa and during recessions at home. As challenges go, he says the current labor dispute "would rank up there with some of the more interesting and exciting ones." But he added, "It's not a challenge that we don't think we're capable of addressing."
He said his wife and his 27-year-old daughter had been supportive. "They think we're doing what we have to to keep the company globally competitive," Mr. Fites said.
The one exception, perhaps, Mr. Fites suggested, is his 91-year-old father, who continues to live in rural northwest Indiana. When asked if his father shared his views on Caterpillar's strategy with the labor union, Mr. Fites paused for a moment. "My father has been a farmer all of his life and so he has good common sense," Mr. Fites said.
He then added quickly, with a smile: "I doubt he has an appreciation for all the things that take place in a situation like this. He makes his observations."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Our objective is to get our employees back to work," said Donald V. Fites, the chairman of Caterpillar Inc., whose workers are on strike. (Fred Zwicky for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Unusual Path To the Top At Mitsubishi

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 12

 BODY:
By the unwritten rules that dictate who rises to the top of Japan's corporate elite, Minoru Makihara should have long ago been scratched off the list of candidates to head the Mitsubishi Corporation, the crown jewel of Japan's most powerful business group.
In the years after World War II, when most of Tokyo's children were picking their way through the ruins of the city on the way to school, Mr. Makihara was not in Japan at all; instead, he received his education at an elite prep school in New England. 
 When anyone with ambition to become a future leader was battling for a scarce slot at the University of Tokyo, Mr. Makihara was enrolled as one of the few Japanese at Harvard, graduating in the 1954 class that included Edward M. Kennedy, the future Senator, and John Updike, the author. And while his colleagues at Mitsubishi climbed the ladder at headquarters and kept foreign forays brief, Mr. Makihara spent more than two decades in London, Seattle and New York.
So, many people in the company were taken by surprise when Mitsubishi said recently that Mr. Makihara would take over in June as president of the most famous of Japan's trading companies, which deal in everything from oil to dam-building and precious art to agricultural imports. The appointment was widely interpreted here as an effort by Japan's most politically powerful business group to project a gentler English-speaking image to the world.
By his very presence, the polished, cosmopolitan Mr. Makihara reinforces the message that the biggest problem facing Japanese business today is not profits but politics.
Since he returned to Japan several months ago, however, the man known outside Japan as Ben Makihara finds himself in the odd position of reassuring nervous employees and the Japanese press that he is, in fact, as Japanese as he looks.
"My background is very nontraditional," the 62-year-old Mr. Makihara said the other day. "But I am a very traditional person, fairly Japanese in my thinking. Some people go abroad a short time and come back very different. Others go abroad a long time and come back unchanged. I think that I am one of the latter."
Without question, Mitsubishi runs in Mr. Makihara's blood. His father was a Mitsubishi executive, and his wife, Kikuko, is the great-grandchild of the autocratic Yataro Iwasaki, the founder of the Mitsubishi empire.
Even without that background, though, his colleagues and friends say Mr. Makihara offers the best chance that Mitsubishi has of facing down critics who maintain that as Japan's largest keiretsu -- the inter-linked corporate groups that distinguish Tokyo-style capitalism -- Mitsusbishi epitomizes the exclusive, impenetrable nature of Japanese business.
Long gone are the days when the Mitsubishi Corporation exercised direct control over the other companies with the Mitsubishi name. (Among them are Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Mitsubishi Electric Mitsubishi Motors, Mitsubishi Bank and some Mitsubishi companies that do not even have the name, like the Nikon Corporation and the Kirin Brewery.)
The trading company holds a small stake in most of the Mitsubishi group members and still coordinates their talents, much as Mr. Makihara did when, as head of Mitsubishi's American operations, he engineered the purchase of Aristech Chemical. It was a classic Mitsubishi deal: while Mitsubishi Corporation took the lead, other Mitsubishi companies were called in to take a stake or share technology with it.
In a talk the other day, Mr. Makihara argued that keiretsu were still widely misunderstood in the United States and far less monolithic or exclusive than trade negotiators contended. "The sense of strength of the keiretsu is exaggerated," he said. Companies within the group, he said, buy parts and enter ventures with nongroup members.
"We do business with Toshiba, and it isn't one of the Mitsubishi group, and we do business with other non-Mitsubishi companies," he said. "In an economy as competitive as Japan's, you have to."
But Mr. Makihara readily acknowledges that the historical bonds among the companies run deep. The relationships are cemented at events like Mitsubishi's famous Friday lunches, held in the Mitsubishi Club just above Mr. Makihara's office. There, the chairmen and presidents of the Mitsubishi companies -- no one else can join -- discuss the political scene and talk about the direction of the group. It is the kind of event that gives indigestion to antitrust experts.
The chief purpose of the lunch, like most rituals in Japan, is to create relationships rather than get any specific item of business done. But Mr. Makihara says that the lunches have a "mystique that needs to be changed," adding: "Why not make it more accessible? I would suggest that it be more transparent."
Mr. Makihara's colleagues say one of his first challenges will be to broaden the group's international alliances.
At a time when the Japanese auto industry is trying to promote cooperative arrangements with the American Big Three, the most prominent of those deals, Mitsubishi Motors' relationship with the Chrysler Corporation, is tearing apart. Chrysler is liquidating most of its stake in the Japanese car maker, and Mitsubishi executives say that after repeated conflicts with Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, they are hardly sad to see the partnership end.
"The personal chemistry wasn't there," Mr. Makihara said. Mr. Iacocca, he said, "is not really interested in forging an alliance."
For a while, it seemed that Mitsubishi's alternative to Chrysler would be Daimler-Benz, Europe's biggest manufacturer and one of the few enterprises with Mitsubishi's scope. Two years ago, at the initiative of Edzard Reuter, Daimler's chairman, the two groups signed a broad but vague statement of their intent to join forces in a range of areas.
But the discussions have barely inched along, and no one has yet described a vision of ways the two groups can cooperate. "Over time, something will come out of it," Mr. Makihara said. "I don't know what."
While Mr. Makihara's tenure may be measured by such international ventures, his toughest challenges may come from within Japan and within Mitsubishi. He has, for example, cautiously sided with Akio Morita, the chairman of Sony, who opened a debate on whether Japanese companies must give up their incessant drive for more market share.
"I think he is partly reflecting some new thinking which is going on among Japanese companies, that predatory practices, that the constant expansion of market share, must now change," Mr. Makihara said. "But it is easier said than done. Among the trading companies, no individual company can be the only one to stop -- or we will lose our share."
Mr. Makihara said he sensed concerns among a younger generation of Mitsubishi workers. "They raise questions that I am sympathetic with," he said. "They want more challenging work, more interesting work."
The huge Japanese trading companies, however, are hardly known for their flexibility and willingness to change with the times. That was evident when Mr. Makihara welcomed new Mitsubishi employees at an annual induction ceremony the other day: of 219 "career track" entrants, none were women. Even by Japan's standards, that figure stood out.
"In due course, I don't know how quickly, trading companies must bring women into line positions, managerial positions," he said.
It is difficult to tell if Mr. Makihara's caution on such topics is innate, or whether it reflects the fact that he is now back in Japan, and must tow the Japanese line. In the past, Mr. Makihara excelled at fitting into the country where he was working. His daughter, Kumiko, said recently that "when we were living in Japan, we didn't see him much; he was away from the house all the time like a real 'salaryman,' " the Japanese phrase for a white-collar worker. "When we lived abroad," she added, "he was always home for dinner."
