HEADLINE: Rhode Island Bank Chief Surrenders to Face Embezzlement Charges

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 12

 BODY:
Joseph Mollicone Jr., the former bank president accused of touching off the banking crisis that swept this state a year ago, surrendered here today after eluding the authorities for 17 months.
Mr. Mollicone, who is charged with embezzling at least $13 million from the bank he headed, gave himself up at 1 o'clock this morning in the home of Thomas DiLuglio Sr., a prominent lawyer here. He is being held at a state prison in Cranston, where he is to be arraigned on Monday.
 
Led to Bank Crisis
 The 48-year-old banker disappeared on Nov. 8, 1990, after his son dropped him off at Logan Airport in Boston. Attorney General James O'Neil said he did not know where Mr. Mollicone had been since his disappearance, but added that he thought it was "far away." He suggested that the Providence banker might have returned to see his first grandchild, who was born several months ago. 
 Soon after Mr. Mollicone went into hiding, Rhode Islanders learned that the embezzlement of a mere $13 million had led to the state's worst banking crisis since the Great Depression. To cover the $13 million, the Rhode Island Share and Deposit Indemnity Corporation, the private fund that insured deposits in all banks and credit unions in the state, depleted its reserves. That led to the collapse of 44 other institutions.
Less than an hour after his inauguration on Jan. 1, 1991, Gov. Bruce Sundlun announced that he would close those banks and credit unions, freezing $1.7 billion in accounts belonging to one third of the state's one million residents. Although 36 of the 45 institutions have reopened, about 200,000 depositors are still waiting for at least some of their money. Many were forced into bankruptcy.
 
Wife Forced Into Bankruptcy
 Mr. Mollicone's wife, Joyce, was also forced to file for protection from creditors last December because her husband had emptied their bank accounts. She moved from their $600,000 house on Blackstone Boulevard to a small apartment. She also had to give up their condominum in West Palm Beach, Fla. At the bankruptcy hearing, Mrs. Mollicone said she had $50 on hand and $150 in the bank, and that her only assets were $1,750 worth of furniture and $3,500 worth of jewelry, The Providence-Journal reported.
In the months after Mr. Mollicone's disappearance, state officials sifted through bank records to determine whether the bank, based on Atwells Avenue, had links to organized crime. A federal investigation later uncovered both links to organized crime and that the bank was laundering money for a drug cartel in Colombia. A Cranston coindealer, Stephen Saccoccia, was charged last November with running a money-laundering ring, which funneled a total of $715 million through various, including an estimated $3.5 million through Heritage Loan.
The embezzlement was discovered after then-Gov. Edward DiPrete ordered an investigation into reports of irregularities in the bank's lending practices. The investigation revealed that 128 people and businesses listed as loan recipients, never applied for loans and did not receive them. Among those falsely listed as borrowers were Mr. Mollicone's father-in-law, godfather, golfing partners and Mayor Vincent A. Cianci. The loans were also not recorded in the bank's computer.
Instead, the authorities said, the money was used by Mr. Mollicone to pay bills and invest in real estate projects, including the rehabilitation of several downtown offices. He also opened a pizza franchise, said Assistant Attorney General Robert Craven.
"He was the main recipient of money," said Mr. Craven, who is the lead prosecutor before the state grand jury. "We expect that may change if he decides to talk with us."
Mr. Mollicone asked Mr. DiLuglio, a lawyer, to arrange his surrender six weeks ago. Attorney General O'Neil, who negotiated the details with Mr. DiLuglio, said Mr. Mollicone's only concern was his safety. But Mr. Mollicone's attorney, Julius Michaelson, said he was not aware of any threats made on his client's life.
The investigation also raised questions about the operations of the fund that insured the bank, The Rhode Island Share and Depository Indemnity Corporation. Heritage had not been subject to an audit for three years although an audit is required every 15 months under the fund's charter.
The former chairman of the fund, Joseph Belluci, and its president, Peter Nevola, friends of Mr. Mollicone, were arrested in February, after a grand jury charged them with covering up the embezzlement of Heritage Loan and Investment.
The investigation of the state's banking crisis has also led to charges against several others, including Peter Iannuccilli, the former vice president of Heritage. Mr. Iannuccilli has also been charged with helping Mr. Mollicone conceal the embezzlement from bank regulators.

HEADLINE: Racial Tension Erupts, Tearing a College Apart

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OLIVET, Mich., April 10

 BODY:
Normally this is Olivet College's giddy season, the last few weeks of class at the small liberal arts college here that was founded as a bastion of racial tolerance and whose Gothic turrets dominate this tiny rural town.
But a week ago, a racial brawl brought unspoken hostilities to a boil and turned the campus of about 700 students into a living example of the tinderbox that race can still be in this country more than a generation after the civil rights movement. 
 In a haze of rumors about black men and white women that recall 1950's Alabama more than 1990's Michigan, about 40 white students and 20 black students turned on one another in the lobby of a dormitory named after the college's abolitionist founder, the Rev. John Shipherd. Racial epithets were shouted at the black students as the two sides rumbled on the gray linoleum. Two students, one black, one white, were injured and briefly hospitalized.
Afterward, blacks and whites who had crammed together for midterms and shared lunch money and dormitory rooms could not look each other in the face and were no longer on speaking terms.
The jeers and threats against blacks from white classmates and townspeople continued into this week until most of the 55 black students packed their bags and went home with two weeks left in the semester.
Some are debating whether to come back for finals or graduation. Some are debating whether to come back at all. At least eight students have told college officials they will not return. By this afternoon, there were only four black students left on campus, and they were debating whether to leave, too.
"Obviously they don't want us here," said Davonne Pierce, a black sociology major who stayed on campus. "People I never would have expected have called me names. None of us feel we can trust white people anymore."
Watching an evacuation he felt helpless to stop, Donald A. Morris, the president of the college, formally excused from classes on Thursday and Friday all students who feared for their safety. Several dozen whites took him up on the offer as well.
 
Hearing Before Board
 A judicial hearing on the case is scheduled for Wednesday before a board of faculty and students, which could decide to expel or suspend the students it determines caused the fight. Many black students, angered that white students were not reprimanded for the racial threats and name-calling, say that the outcome of the hearing will determine whether they return or not.
Specialists in race relations see Olivet as a kind of everycampus and the week's developments as a painful rebuke of country's early and naive assumptions about solving the matter of race.
"What it shows is that desegregation is not integration," said Joe R. Feagan, a professor of sociology at the University of Florida, who has written extensively about race relations. "The remedial steps we took to deal with racism in this country have been desegregation steps. We have mixed black students in white institutions without doing anything about the attitudes of whites and the culture of the institutions. As a government and a society, we put them there and went home."
Olivet is an unlikely place to try out integration. It is a poor, rural town of 1,700 people, virtually all of them white, surrounded by cornfields and automobile parts factories. Neighboring towns are feared by blacks because of rumors of an active Ku Klux Klan.
But it was here in 1844 in what was then wilderness that Mr. Shipherd, the Congregational minister who founded Oberlin College in Ohio, decided to start a new college for "students not rich in worldly goods."
Both colleges opened their doors to blacks and women long before other colleges did and were considered havens of racial tolerance. "We thought this was the last place this would happen," Dr. Morris said. "That's why this is such a struggle for us."
But the ingredients for friction have been there for years. The college is a sociological test tube, mixing white students from mostly rural Michigan towns who have had little or no contact with blacks and a tiny minority of blacks mostly from Detroit isolated in a remote and alien setting. It has no black professors or administrators and only one black employee out of 132, the minority recruitment officer, who is frequently on the road.
 
Rift on Interracial Dating
 The first signs of trouble came in the last few months as white male students became more vocal in their resentment toward black men dating white women.
On April 1, a white female student caused a stir when she said she had been attacked by four black students and left unconscious in a field near campus. She was not hospitalized, there were no warrants issued despite a police investigation and college officials are skeptical of the account.
But word of her account spread quickly. Later that night, two trash cans were set on fire outside the dorm rooms of several black student leaders.
The next night, according to accounts from students and college officials, a white sorority member called her brother fraternity for help, saying she was being harassed by some male students. Two black male students and a white male student had knocked on her dormitory door. One of the black students had come to ask about a paper she was typing for him.
The men say matters were civil. She says she felt threatened. Either way, within minutes of her call, about 15 brothers from Phi Alpha Pi, a white fraternity, had arrived and confronted the two black men in the coed dormitory's lobby.
A crowd gathered, more whites joined in and more blacks were summoned by some black female students to even the numbers. It is not known who threw the first punch. Blacks say it was a white fraternity member; the fraternity says things happened so fast it was not clear.
But what is clear is that instead of seeing a roommate or fellow sophomore, the students saw race. In the middle of the fight, one of Mr. Pierce's white friends yelled racial epithets at him as Mr. Pierce, a dormitory resident assistant, tried to break up the fight.
"I said, 'How can you call me that when we were friends, when I let you borrow my notes?' " Mr. Pierce said, still incredulous. "But at that point, it was white against black. It was disgusting. We would go to class and couldn't even look at each other."
The epithets flew longer than the fists did. White students standing on the porch of a fraternity house across the street shouted them after the crowd broke up, saying it was time to get guns.
"It was coming from everywhere," said Gleo Wade, a black freshman. "I didn't look to see where it came from. I was hearing so much of it."
Instantly, blacks and whites took sides with their own race. Student's fear reached such heights this week that black and white students were afraid to go out at night alone, prompting the university to hire security guards to escort students between the campus's four blocks.
Still, of all the slurs shouted that day few students will admit to having said one. And even the white fraternity members who confronted the two black students said that little good had come of it.
"There were a lot of bonds that were broken that didn't need to be broken," said Dave Cook, a white junior majoring in business who was one of the Phi Alpha Pi members at the fight.
Mr. Cook considered one black female student to be a friend. But that was before. "We would high-five each other and study for tests," he said. "But I don't know what she thinks about me. I don't know whether she's hating me or what. I didn't say one word to her, and she didn't say one word to me. Now she's gone."
For many in this generation of white students, born a decade after the great civil rights marches, this is their first experience with racial protest, and many did not know how to take it.
Suzanne Michener, a white junior majoring in education, said: "My generation has never been through anything like this.I didn't know what to say to the blacks I know. I've been thinking, 'Was there segregation here? Did I miss something? Is there something I did wrong?' "
 
Call for Hiring of Blacks
 While the week's events may have awakened some white students, black students say they will not come back until they have reason to feel safe. They say they want some black professors hired, a mandatory course on multiculturalism for all students and a director of multicultural affairs.
The administration has agreed to the demands and plans to begin sensitivity training for faculty and staff and hire a black professor by the fall.
But this week, after telephone threats and rock-throwing and warnings of violence from townspeople and white students, the black students said they were more worried about the ability of the administration to protect them. On Wednesday, they packed their belongings into vans and U-Haul trucks and walked out in both protest and fear.
"It wasn't an easy decision," said Henry Henderson, the principal black student leader. "It would have been easier to stay. But the campus is unsafe and unjust. I can't imagine any of us returning."
Many are jeopardizing their chances at graduate school or facing the likelihood of repeating a semester.
Mr. Henderson is weeks from graduation and is risking acceptance at law school by staying away, but he cannot forget the night of the brawl. "You saw everyone's true colors that night," he said. "Everyone dropped their mask and showed themselves. People who nudged you for answers on a test were calling you coon and spear-chucker."
On Friday, the campus resembled a ghost town, as scores of students, black and white, retreated home to Detroit or Sheboygan to cool off.
"The problem with going back home," said John S. Homer, an economics professor, "is that they're going back to where they were raised, where they got their attitudes to begin with."

HEADLINE: Yeltsin and Foes in Congress Step Away From the Brink

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 12

 BODY:
Russian Government and congress officials spent the day today in secretive huddles, seeking ways to retreat from the confrontation that took shape on Saturday when the country's highest elected council adopted a resolution limiting President Boris N. Yeltsin's right to name his officials.
After a meeting between senior members of Mr. Yeltsin's Government and the Presidium of the Congress of People's Deputies, the two sides said in a statement that "as a result of constructive discussions, it became possible to narrow the positions and to agree on cooperation in advancing radical economic reform." 
 Today, Deputy Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar, the chief economic planner in Mr. Yeltsin's Government, agreed that the discussions had been "very constructive." But Mr. Gaidar again threatened that the Cabinet would resign if he was put in the position of "rubber-stamping the appearance of reform."
The resolution that brought Mr. Yeltsin's officials to loggerheads with the congress was adopted Saturday, after a day of heated debate and innumerable votes. It declared the current course of economic reform unsatisfactory and suggested that the President make substantial changes.
 
Matter of Timing
 The most provocative provision called on him to propose a new Prime Minister and Cabinet within three months. Mr. Yeltsin, who now holds the Prime Minister's post as well as the Presidency, had offered to step down as Prime Minister, but within six months. The resolution was adopted, 647 to 69.
Though the difference between the two positions seemed to be just a matter of a few months, the resolution touched the issue at the heart of the legislative session -- control over the course of economic change.
Mr. Yeltsin and his supporters argue that he and the Government must have full authority and the full backing of the congress to pursue painful economic policies, which include steep price increases and tight money.
In the view of presidential aides, the congress, in rejecting Mr. Yeltsin's request for an extension of his special powers, was essentially trying to curb his freedom of action.
Mr. Gaidar, among others, sharply assailed the measure and on Saturday threatened to resign, while Mr. Yeltsin's legislative supporters spoke of calling a referendum or even moving to dissolve the congress.
 
A Land Where Little Is Final
 The resolution, though formally adopted, was not expected to be the last word. The congress's Speaker, Ruslan I. Khasbulatov, delayed signing the document until Monday, leaving time for amendments. And the brief but tumultuous history of Russian and Soviet legislatures gives ample evidence that few votes are final.
Some legislators privately noted that even if the resolution remained in force, Mr. Yeltsin still had three months to rule by decree, and beyond that had a good chance of naming a Prime Minister of his choice.
In any case, th President was not thought to be enthusiastic about a referendum or to want legislative elections during a period of economic hardship. Members of the congress were likewise thought not to want to intensify the confrontation any more, or to torpedo the Government or the reforms, since Mr. Yeltsin remains a popular figure in this country.
It remained unclear whether Mr. Gaidar's threats to resign were tactical, or if he would in fact step down if the congress persevered in its attacks on his programs. Mr. Yeltsin, the central figure in the drama, was not present during the voting Saturday and has made no public statement since.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

WHEN THE RECESSION DOES NOT END
For tens of thousands of solidly middle-class men and women who have been thrown out of work by the weak economy, the recession has gone on too long. Their unemployment benefits are running out. Their savings are nearing exhaustion. And eviction or foreclosure threats are turning up in the mail along with the piles of bills. The effort to maintain a sense of control over their lives, emotions and dignity has become a daily challenge. A1.

WOMAN SURRENDERS AT THE UNITED NATIONS
Nearly 24 hours after she drove to the United Nations, doused herself with gasoline and threatened to set herself on fire as a protest against using taxes for military spending, a 41-year-old California woman surrendered to the police. The woman, the daughter of a Nobel Prize-winning nuclear physicist, Owen Chamberlain, was taken to Bellevue Hospital. B3.
 
THE TIMES AND DRIVERS REACH AGREEMENTS 
 The New York Times and a major independent newspaper delivery company reached separate tentative agreements with the drivers union that could insure labor peace in the wholesale distribution of New York's newspapers until the year 2000 and speed the opening of The Times's new printing plant in Edison, N.J. B2.
 
THE 'MITZVAH TANKS' READY TO ROLL
The Lubavitch Hasidim call them the "mitzvah tanks" -- vans bedecked with religious sayings, blaring Old World music and trolling for Jews who want to rediscover their religious roots. Tomorrow morning a 90-strong caravan of them -- which may look to the uninitiated like a noisy parade of Winnebagos -- is to set out from the sect's headquarters in commemoration of the 90th birthday of the movement's spiritual leader, Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson. HOUSING FIGHT IN YONKERS
Seven years after a Federal judge ruled that housing in Yonkers was deliberately racially segregated, city officials are trying to sell the idea of desegregation for the first time in the city's history. The new Mayor and ranking City Council members are lobbying hard for a compromise plan, instead of one ordered by the judge. But the effort is opposed by both the Yonkers chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which says it does not go far enough, and leaders of the resistance to housing desegregation, who say it goes too far. B7.

Gov. Mario M. Cuomo revived his plea for sweeping changes in the state's election laws. Collectively, the legislation would make it easier for New Yorkers to run for office, including the presidency, and to register to vote, would establish the public financing of state elections, would limit contributions from political action committees, and would force the Legislature to conduct more of its business in open meetings. THE PUZZLING CASE OF A MISSING BOY
In the end, what matters to Pablo and Odilia Fuentes is that their son Pedro is home -- unharmed during the two years he was missing after mysteriously disappearing one day a few blocks from the family's apartment. But they admit that they are still puzzling over how their son, then 14 years old, could have been found wandering in the Bronx -- and then was placed in New York City's foster-care system -- without anyone notifying the police. Today, contemporary-art museums are liberally dotted about the landscape, and, at age 86, Mr. Aldrich is passing the baton to a new director. Ridgefield Journal, B7.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
One More Time: Magazine Is Reborn

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
After more than a year of intense analysis over its mission and the role of news magazines in general, Time will introduce today its most radical redesign since it began publication 69 years ago.
But relax, readers. It is still unmistakably Time. 
 The famous red border is intact, although a new, enlarged logo is emblazoned across the cover. The magazine itself, however, has been totally reorganized into a crisp eight-page section of news items, a fat middle section of longer and more in-depth articles and a final section devoted to cultural reviews. The type is clean looking and seems easier to read.
"The priority was to define what a news magazine would be in the era of instant communications," said Henry Muller, the managing editor since 1987. "Five years ago when we started to talk about this, two-thirds of the magazine was still driven by last week's news. Now, two-thirds of the magazine is original."
As rumors about the redesign swirled through the magazine industry, the project was conducted in utmost secrecy. Last summer, a Time design team quietly set up shop in an apartment on West 79th Street in Manhattan to create a new structure for the magazine that would accommodate the editorial changes of the last few years.
Few people at Time knew of the safe house's existence. But by summer's end, top executives were slipping in regularly to scrutinize the dummied pages that were tacked to walls and illuminated by spotlights. What they were studying was the redesign. But what they were assessing was whether this would still essentially be Time magazine.
Time officials insist that the redesign is a response to editorial needs and is not part of a larger business plan. Nonetheless, Time derives half of its revenues from circulation, and a magazine with a strong editorial content is obviously in a better position to attract more readers. Time, the largest of the three news magazine, currently has a circulation of nearly 4.1 million.
A few media directors and advertisers who have seen the redesign spoke about it with enthusiasm. More critical comment will have to wait until the redesigned magazine is seen by more readers and advertisers.
"I like it; there is a certain thoughtful logic behind it," said Alec Gerster, executive vice president of media at Grey Advertising. "It is potentially a more accessible, reader-friendly magazine."
And Bud Liebler, vice president of communications at the Chrysler Corporation, called the redesigned magazine an improvement. "It has interesting advertising placement possibilities," he said. "Frankly, I think the sound bite is getting on people's nerves. I think people are looking for a little substance."
 
Reaction From Newsweek
 Time's two competitors, Newsweek and U.S. News & World Report, have been redesigned within the last decade and have indicated no plans to redo themselves again. "The only reason in my view to tamper with the positioning of a magazine is if you think you have a major problem with your readers," said Richard M. Smith, editor in chief and president of Newsweek.
Ever since reports of Time's redesign began leaking out, Time has been bedeviled by two conflicting rumors. The first, dubbed "Time Lite," held that to attract new readers, Time would cater to the purportedly short attention span of the television generation, abandon serious articles and essentially turn itself into a magazine of news briefs. The second rumor -- known as "the Harperization of Time" -- predicted that Time would leave news reporting to newspapers and television and turn itself into a weekly essay magazine.
Time has done neither. The first section, titled "The Week," which will cover all major news events of the previous week, makes it clear that Time is still, first and foremost, a news magazine. Traditional headings that were once stand-alone sections -- World, Nation, Business -- will now be included in this section.
Sometimes, an item will appear as a news brief and also get longer, more thoughtful treatment farther on in the magazine. This week, for instance, the cover features a negative image of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. A news brief on the New York Democratic Presidential primary, which he won, is in "The Week" and an analytical article on Mr. Clinton is in the middle section of the magazine, which editors refer to as "the well."
"The new architecture will help us even further clarify that we are a news magazine," Mr. Muller said. " 'The Week' will have an institutional voice, as Time magazine used to have. It will not be a dull voice, but a voice with authority and with some brio. But the tone and substance of 'the well' should be that of news analysis -- thoughtful, analytical, professional journalism."
He added, "I don't want any part of Time magazine to impose a view on readers, but rather to help them think and give them information."
 
Series of Unsettling Events
 Time, once the most confident voice of its generation, has been through a succession of unsettling events recently, including a staff reduction last fall and a recent management shake-up at its parent, Time Warner Inc. And the magazine is facing increasingly competitive outside pressures for its readers' time. As its editors struggled to redefine the magazine's voice, its business side fought to minimize the effects of the worst recession in magazine publishing in several decades.
Although Time does not disclose specific financial data, its publisher, Elizabeth P. Valk, described the magazine as "very profitable."
"I can't give out actual numbers, but I can assure you this is a very healthy franchise," she said. "I am very comfortable with our four million rate base and expect that we will continue viewing circulation as a profit center and take some of the burden off the advertising side."
Last year, Time's ad pages showed a decline of 20.6 percent from 1990. For the first three months this year, advertising is holding about even with last year.
 
Cost of the Redesign
 Ms. Valk said no extra staff had been added for the redesign. Mr. Muller estimated the total cost of the redesign at less than $250,000, with most of it going for the rental of the apartment, the installation of extra computers and the testing of the redesign with about 250 people in focus groups around the country.
One of the problems facing Time in recent years was the continuing tug between two rival forces: the reporters in bureaus around the world who gathered the news and the editors in New York who compiled the material and wrote the articles.
Mr. Muller said that probably half of Time's articles were written in the field and the other half in New York, but that the point had become moot.
"After five years of what was sometimes a wrenching transition, the 'bureaus versus New York' question has become a non-issue," he said. "We have happily arrived at a point where we now decide who writes a story based on the judgment as to who best can do it, as opposed to where they work."
As part of Time's view that a news magazine must give readers far more substantial fare than a rehash of yesterday's news, the magazine devotes considerable space to articles like its recent cover pieces on "Evil," "Scientology, the Cult of Greed," "The Simple Life," "California, the Endangered Dream" and "Lost Tribes, Lost Knowledge," which portrayed a New Guinea tribesman on the cover with a straw through his nose.
Time says these cover articles were all best sellers on the newsstand, confirming the editors' opinion that they were an integral part of what a news magazine should be in the 1990's.
The principal architects of the redesign were Rudolph C. Hoglund, the magazine's art director, and Arthur Hochstein, the design director. Walter Bernard, a former art director at Time who oversaw the last redesign of the magazine in 1977 and his partner, Milton Glaser, were also called in as advisers.
"It has really been a tearing down of the whole structure of the magazine to interpret Henry Muller's vision of the magazine and give it form," Mr. Hoglund said.
"It feels right," said John Stacks, chief of correspondents. "This magazine five years into the Muller era does much better journalism than it did before, and the design is meant to highlight that."

HEADLINE: Thruway Panel Is to Be Given Broader Power

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo will announce plans on Wednesday to expand the responsibilities of the New York State Thruway Authority as a way to stimulate economic development upstate, a top aide to the Governor said yesterday.
Under the plan, the semi-autonomous authority would assume control of the state's barge canal system, enabling it to collect new revenues from canal fees and long-term leases on land along the waterways, said Mary Ann Crotty, the Governor's director of policy management. That revenue, along with money raised from bonds, tolls and other sources, would be invested in the canal system, the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway and a variety of new projects throughout those parts of the state that abut the 641-mile highway, Ms. Crotty said. 
 "It'll mean economic development and immediate job creation," Ms. Crotty said. "We wanted the Thruway Authority to become the economic catalyst for the upstate region."
 
$312 Million in Tolls
 The Thruway Authority, which raised about $312 million through tolls in 1991, is now primarily charged with maintaining and repairing the long, winding highway, which stretches north from Westchester County to Albany, before veering west, past Buffalo, to the Pennsylvania border. The canal system, which includes the Erie Canal and several smaller upstate waterways, is currently run by the state Department of Transportation, Ms. Crotty said.
Ms. Crotty declined to estimate how much money the plan would generate in its first year, nor would she discuss the specific projects that would be financed. Ms. Crotty said Thruway tolls would not be raised to pay for the plan.

HEADLINE: PENSIONS COVERING LOWER PERCENTAGE OF U.S. WORK FORCE

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The share of America's work force covered by company pensions is shrinking, reversing a decades-old trend of steady growth.
Last year, an estimated 43 percent of workers participated in company pension plans, down from a peak of 49 percent in 1979. While women's participation in pension plans held almost steady, the drop for younger blue-collar men was far steeper than for the work force as a whole. 
 "Pensions are an important part of the private safety net," said David E. Bloom, an economist at Columbia University. "That safety net seems to have developed a tear that got wider during the 1980's."
 
A Frayed Safety Net
 The pension safety net is being frayed by the same powerful forces -- paltry growth in productivity, the globalization of industry, the computer revolution -- that have slowed average gains in wages, sharply widened income disparities and produced an outright decline in blue-collar pay and union membership.
"The groups that were hurt worst in terms of pension coverage -- the young, the male, the less educated -- were those whose real wages and employment fell most," Mr. Bloom said. He and Richard B. Freeman, an economist at Harvard University, have recently completed a study, "The Fall in Private Pension Coverage in the U.S.," that is about to be published in the proceedings of the American Economics Association.
William E. Even, associate director of the Center for Pension and Retirement Research at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, said, "The decline increases the likelihood that these workers will postpone retirement, be poorer when they do retire and rely more heavily on Social Security and other Government transfers."
 
Changing Labor Market
 To be sure, the decline in pension coverage could turn around before most of today's workers retire, should the broad trends that have been buffeting the United States labor market change direction. But there are few strong reasons to anticipate such a reversal.
In the meantime, the pool of money available for business investment could become more limited if a smaller proportion of the work force is enrolled in pension plans. Such a decline would further depress America's low saving rate and compound the problem of slow productivity and wage growth.
"Pensions are the way Americans save," said John B. Shoven, an economist at Stanford University, noting that two-thirds of Americans have no savings other than the equity in their homes and pensions.
In the last decade, pension assets tripled in dollar terms, thanks entirely to the rise in the stock market. That rise equals the entire increase in the nation's wealth -- the broadest measure of savings -- for that period.
On average, company pensions now provide 17 percent of the income of people 55 and older, while Social Security provides 38 percent and personal savings 25 percent. That portion provided by pensions has more than doubled from 30 years ago, and it has been growing faster than income from Social Security, which, in any case, was never meant to be the sole, or even main, source of support for elderly people. The average includes people without pensions, wealthy people with large investment incomes and people who continue to work.
 
Proposals in Congress
 One measure of the concern in Washington over receding pension coverage is that a half-dozen bills have been introduced in Congress, all primarily intended to make it cheaper and easier for small businesses to offer pensions. Small businesses created most of the 20 million new jobs in the 1980's expansion.
"It's hard to find anyone in this town who is unconcerned," said Richard Ippolito, chief economist of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, the Government agency that insures company plans.
To most people, the turnabout in pension coverage has come as something of a surprise. Not so many years ago, Peter Drucker, the management consultant, was predicting an era of "pension socialism" when workers would wind up owning most of the nation's wealth.
But by the end of the 1980's, the average paycheck, adjusted for inflation, was no bigger than a typical worker's pay in 1979. Pay declined outright for that half of the work force with only high school educations or less. While the earnings of young white women with college degrees rose 1.4 percent a year during the 1980's, for example, those of young white men with high school degrees, whose pay still exceeds that of their female counterparts, fell by roughly the same amount.
 
What Workers Prefer
 "If you earn less, you want to save less," said Professor Bloom, who, like other labor economists, thinks of the compensation mix -- how much cash, how much in deferred forms like health coverage or pensions -- as a reflection of workers' preferences.
By the same token, companies had less incentive to offer pensions. "Most companies in my industries have only union employees on a pension plan and most nonunion companies have none," said Henry S. Hilaire, the owner of Central Connecticut Acoustics Inc., a commercial construction contractor, in Wallingford. "Quality people are standing in line to get work. You can get them without offering a pension."
In addition, union membership, which is practically synonymous with pension coverage, has fallen sharply among its biggest beneficiaries, the young and less educated, for reasons that include a less favorable legal climate for unions and fierce foreign competition. In the 1980's, among white men under 35, union membership plummeted by two-thirds among high school dropouts and by nearly half among high school graduates.
 
Without Union Benefits
 "When the union puts you to work, union contractors are required to pay into the union benefit fund," said Robert A. Carroll, 26 years old, a carpenter and member of Local 210 in central Connecticut, who recently has had to take nonunion jobs. "Most nonunion contractors don't cover you until you've been there for a year, and you may not be vested for 10 years. That's hard because everybody in the construction trades goes from job to job."
Thus, it appears that the same economic forces have reduced the demand for less-educated, less-skilled workers, and along the way hurt pension coverage as well.
Some aspects of the pension reforms that were started in the mid- 1970's and early 1980's in an effort to spread coverage may have worsened the decline. These aspects include broadening eligibility, requiring earlier vesting and the creation of 401(k) plans -- tax-deferred retirement plans to which employees contribute and to which employers may also contribute.
 
Shift in Types of Plans
 Among other things, the reforms led to a sharp turn away from traditional defined-benefit plans, under which companies promise a specific benefit level, to defined-contribution plans. Under defined contribution, benefits are determined by how well the pension funds' investments per the 1980's, defined-contribution plans, including the 401(k), doubled as a share of all plans.
"There's an unsettling feeling that in the long run, defined-contribution plans just aren't going to be delivering as much retirement income," said Mr. Ippolito of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation.
 
When Workers Have a Choice
 The defined-contribution plans are not necessarily less generous. Rather, the problem is that such plans are more often voluntary and offer more opportunities for workers to take their money out. A new study by Mr. Even of Miami University and his colleague David A. Macpherson shows that participation in 401(k) plans may have accelerated the decline in coverage among young men.
Young men, whose pay was being squeezed, more often chose not to join a pension plan so as to get more pay up front. Earlier research showed that young workers were only half as likely to join 401(k) plans as older workers. But Mr. Even and Mr. Macpherson discovered that participation rates among men in their 20's and 30's actually declined, from 86 percent to 78 percent, during the 1980's. Among workers in their late 30's to early 50's the rate also declined, but by only half as much.
In 1988, for example, more than 33 percent of the younger men surveyed had the opportunity to be in a 401(k); fewer than 20 percent chose to do so.
And enrollment in 401(k) plans does not necessarily mean that young workers are building retirement savings. Young workers, who typically change jobs frequently, often choose to cash out of voluntary retirement savings plans, according to a study by Emily S. Andrews, senior researcher at Mathematica Policy Research of Washington.
 
Spend Now, Save Later
 If the money is used as a down payment for a house, retirement wealth may not be affected, but often it is used to pay for a car or a vacation or to make ends meet.
"By any definition of saving, younger people are much more likely to spend their lump-sum distributions," Ms. Andrews said.
That was exactly the experience of Edward J. Bandeira, 25, a laborer who drives a truck for a commercial Sheetrock contractor in Newtown, Conn. After the commercial real estate market slumped, Mr. Bandeira opted for a $4,000 lump sum from his union annuity fund. "I moved down to Florida," he said. "I rented an apartment. I spent it. It lasted me almost two years."
Will pension participation stay down? On the one hand, recent record college enrollments suggest that the supply of highly educated workers will expand. That would depress the relative wages of those with B.A.'s or better but lift the relative wages of those who quit schooling after high school. "The question is how much and whether it will be enough to bail this group out," Mr. Freeman said.
On the other hand, increasingly sophisticated technology and globalization could also continue to keep the demand for the less educated and less skilled lagging behind supply.

HEADLINE: Worries Over Another Big Developer

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, April 12

 BODY:
Olympia & York is not the only real estate developer that has bankers worried on both sides of the Atlantic. Heron International, one of Britain's largest privately owned companies, is doing its best to counter fears that it is on the brink of collapse.
Last week, investors and investment bankers placed Heron's bonds into technical default, meaning that bondholders could demand immediate repayment, though a spokesman for Heron stressed that the investors had not done so and would not necessarily take such action. 
 A diversified real estate company with extensive holdings in the United States, Britain and Continental Europe, Heron was especially hard hit by depressed American property prices and the British recession.
 
From Manhattan to Sun Valley
 In the United States, its properties include a 50.1 percent interest in the Heron Tower, a 144,000-square-foot office building at 70 East 55th Street in Manhattan between Park and Madison Avenues, and the Heron Building, a 213,000-square-foot building in downtown Los Angeles. Construction of the Heron Tower II, another office building on the East Side of Manhattan, was suspended. Heron also owns about 9,000 acres in Sun Valley, Ariz., and apartment buildings and offices in Texas.
After significant write-downs in the last two or three years, Heron estimates that its American holdings are worth about $520 million. Its larger lenders include the Bank of America, Barclays Bank and National Westminster Bank.
Heron is struggling under the burden of about 1.3 billion, or $2.3 billion, of debts, including bank loans of about 850 million and bonds with a face value of about 450 million. It had a pretax loss of about 100 million, or about $173.6 million, for the year ended March 31, the first loss of its history.
 
Seeks Debt Agreement
 Gerald M. Ronson, chairman and co-founder of Heron, surprised lenders and bondholders on March 27 by announcing that he was seeking a meeting to reschedule principal and interest payments. He also suspended the trading of Heron's bonds. He met with officials of 82 banks and lead managers of the bond issues on April 3. While he asked for an easier payment schedule, he promised that full principal and interest would be paid.
Heron was weakened by its disastrous 1980 acquisition of Pima Savings, a savings and loan association in Tucson, Ariz. Pima rapidly increased its real estate lending in the 1980's. By the end of the decade, like hundreds of other savings and loans, it was in deep trouble as real estate prices plunged and developers could not repay loans.
The plunge in real estate prices, especially in the United States, caused Heron's net asset value -- or its assets minus its liabilities -- to sink to about 135 million, or $234.3 million, in the last fiscal year, from 585 million, or $1.02 billion, the previous year. That meant that Heron stood to breach some loan covenants by September.
Heron said it intended to sell about 1 billion, or $1.77 billion, of real estate in the next seven years, including most of its American properties, to put its financial house in order.
Since March 27, when Heron announced that it had requested the meeting with lenders, it has stressed that it does not face a liquidity crisis and that it has more than 100 million, or $177 million, in cash. It said it could have carried on until the end of 1993, when it would have had to make some large debt repayments, but acted now in order to deal with its difficulties in an orderly manner.
Fears that lenders might panic and bring about Heron's collapse heightened last week, when most of its bonds, which trade on German, Swiss and Luxembourg exchanges, were put into technical default. Heron's decision to seek changes in the terms for its loans and bonds entitled bondholders or their lead managers to take that action. Since the bonds resumed trading, their prices have dipped only slightly.
The lead managers scheduled their first meeting for Zurich on Monday to coordinate their strategy.
Mr. Ronson, 52 years old, is a leading philanthropist in the British business community, which has helped him to win acceptance in the country's clubby and class-conscious establishment. He founded Heron in 1955 with his father, a Russian Jew who fled pogroms early in the century and settled in Britain.
In 1990, Mr. Ronson was convicted of an illegal plan to support the stock price of Guinness P.L.C. He served about six months in prison and was fined $9.7 million.

HEADLINE: New Leadership Style at World Bank

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
The former commercial banker who now heads the World Bank has brought corporate American management practices to the international lending agency, revamping its vast and highly paid bureaucracy. So far, he has forgone his predecessors' role in setting economic development priorities around the globe.
The reorganization by Lewis T. Preston, the former chairman of J. P. Morgan & Company in New York who became president of the bank on Sept. 1, may have made the institution more nimble in responding to crises. 
 But the elimination of a tier of senior managers and the transfer of 240 front-office administrators to lending jobs has confused and angered many officials, who find it harder to figure out who is making decisions and why.
Mr. Preston's critics contend that his reluctance to take public stands on issues has left the institution and the economic development community without a clear mission in the 1990's.
"Other than some internal reorganization, I don't get the feeling he has left any personal impact," said Richard E. Feinberg, an economist who has written a book about the World Bank and is now the president of Inter-American Dialogue, a nonprofit research group on economic development in the Western Hemisphere based here.
"Preston has not yet grabbed the gavel that is at the disposal of the president of the World Bank to organize international efforts for clearly defined goals," he said.
Since President Bush tapped him to head the bank, Mr. Preston said in an interview last week, he has been learning about development economics. In the meantime, he said, he was concerning himself with helping the former Soviet republics and applying the managerial skills he learned in New York.
"Development lending is very different from commercial lending -- development issues are relatively new to me," he said. "So I think probably one instinctively goes to areas where one has had some experience, and management is one of those for me."
 
More Loans Possible
 Mr. Preston said that the third world needed more and better business schools and medical schools and that the bank might increase its loans for third-world infrastructure projects now that many countries had their foreign debts under control.
The World Bank is a 156-nation lending institution created at the end of World War II to rebuild Western Europe. In the late 1950's, it began shifting its focus to lending money for specific projects in the third world, like building dams, schools and clinics.
More recently, the bank has begun lending large sums to debt-ridden third world countries, to help entire sectors of their economies. The bank's frequent partner, the International Monetary Fund, provides loans and advice to rich and poor countries to help them maintain stable currencies and overall economic growth.
Mr. Preston, who suffers from occasional back pain, spent most of the interview slouched in the corner of an carved-wood sofa covered in glossy bright purple silk. A little more than 6 feet tall and still lean at 65 years old, he wore a dark blue suit and stopped twice to discuss his expensive collection of wild bird paintings on the walls of his two-story penthouse office here.
He pointed out a picture by John James Audubon showing an eagle diving onto a quail in a flurry of brown feathers. "That one was always over my sofa in New York," he said with satisfaction. "A bunch of the clients complained about feeling a little like the quail."
Many World Bank officials may also know the feeling. Less than three weeks after taking office last year, Mr. Preston said he was eliminating the top level of the bank's management, three longtime senior vice presidents who had run competing bureaucratic baronies.
Mr. Preston replaced them with three managing directors, who hold advisory positions and ordered the bank's 16 vice presidents to report directly to him. One senior vice president became the vice president for Europe and the Soviet Union, another became a managing director and the third retired.
 
No Big Shifts Planned
 Coupled with the mass transfers of executive officials to lending jobs, the change concentrated power over the 6,000-employee organization in Mr. Preston's hands. He said in the interview that he planned no more dramatic personnel shuffles and expressed little sympathy for the 240 executives he had transferred.
"Hopefully, they're doing something more productive," he said.
Mr. Preston's admirers within the bank say he has prevailed over a bureaucracy that has resisted change since the days of Robert S. McNamara, the former Defense Secretary who headed the institution from 1968 to 1981.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Analysts Expect Another Fed Cut

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Board has lowered short-term interest rates by six full percentage points over the last 34 months, but a substantial number of credit market analysts say the Fed has not yet finished easing monetary policy.
Last week's cut in the overnight Federal funds rate was seen by some analysts as insurance against possible renewed weakness in the economy. 
 At 3.75 percent, the funds rate now sits at its lowest level in 20 years. But many analysts said the economic benefits of the quarter-point cut engineered by the Fed last week were negligible. Moreover, the conditions that prompted the Fed to move last week show few signs of evaporating anytime soon.
 
Significant, but Not in Size
 The Fed's action "was more significant in the message than the size of the move," Thomas J. Sowanick, senior fixed-income strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company, wrote in a weekly letter to clients.
He continued: "That message underscores the fragility of the global financial markets, assorted political uncertainties and tenuous domestic economic growth. The method of easing also indicates a return to an approach of gradualism. That, in turn, suggests the Fed remains biased toward additional easing."
Steven Slifer, an executive vice president and financial market economist at Lehman Brothers, said the 25 basis points would not do much for the economy because it would not move the prime rate at all. "It will take another quarter-point cut to do that, and I think we can count on that happening in fairly short order," he said.
There has not been much of a pickup in loan demand since commercial banks cut the prime to 6.5 percent at the end of last year. And recent financial troubles in Japan and elsewhere suggest that foreign banks, which have been far more willing to extend credit over the last year than their domestic counterparts, may be forced to curb lending.
 
Decline in Loans and Leases
 According to Federal Reserve data, for the 52 weeks ended on March 25, the volume of loans and leases on the books of American banks had fallen by $70 billion. During the same period, loans extended by branches of foreign banks had increased by $17 billion.
Until and unless bank credit extension revives, money growth will probably remain modest, analysts said. Weak money supply figures for March were widely seen as one reason the Fed chose to lower the funds rate last week.
"We have found out that mild recovery is not enough if it is accompanied by slow money growth," said Robert DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers. "And I am not so sure we are going to get rapid money growth on a sustained basis anytime soon."
As a consequence, Mr. DiClemente said, "you can't rule out another round of easing by the Fed, not necessarily in the next couple of weeks, but over time."
 
Inflation Seen as Benign
 Analysts said the deadlock over fiscal policy would also provide the Fed with the latitude to lower short-term rates again if it wished. And most economists say that inflationary pressures remain benign, despite March's worrisome half-point rise in the Consumer Price Index.
"If fiscal policy were in place, I am sure the Fed would not be doing what it is doing," said William Griggs, a managing director at Griggs & Santow Inc., a New York financial consulting firm.
Mr. Slifer said: "If the economy is as soft as I think, the price increases we saw in March won't stick. I still believe that inflation for the year will turn out to be around 2.5 percent."
To be sure, a good number of economists are of the view that the Fed's easing move last week was its last and that better economic times are imminent. Based on price movements in short-term debt securities at the end of last week, that sense seemed to be shared by most credit market participants.
 
Two-Year Treasuries at 5.14%
 Late Friday, two-year Treasury notes, a good proxy for market expectations about changes in Fed policy, were priced to yield 5.14 percent, 1.39 percentage points above the Fed's new target for the funds rate.
"If the market thought there was some chance of a Fed easing, that spread would be closer to 1 percent," one trader said. "It seems like the market thinks that this is it."
Dana Johnson, chief money market economist at the First National Bank of Chicago, said that the Fed's task of reviving the economy had been completed, and that the time of better economic news "is close."
Data to be released this week will probably not carry that positive tone, Mr. Johnson acknowledged.
Along with many of his colleagues, Mr. Johnson expects March industrial production, retail sales and housing-starts statistics to be weaker than they were in February.
"All of the numbers coming up should be helpful to the market," the trader said. "Barring a major surprise, the market should do better, particularly bonds."

HEADLINE: Mortgage Rates Down in Week

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
Mortgage rates fell significantly last week for the first time this year, and economists predicted further modest declines in the weeks ahead.
Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 8.84 percent last week, down from 8.96 percent in the previous week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac. 
 It was the third consecutive decline since rates hit a high of 9.03 percent for the year during the week ended March 20. It was also the sharpest decline since late December.
Analysts expect rates to continue to drop in coming weeks, but not past the 19-year low of 8.23 percent established in the week that ended on Jan. 10.
On Thursday, the Federal Reserve nudged its target for a key short-term interest rate to 3.75 percent, from 4 percent. The action resulted in a decline in long-term interest rates on bonds, which often serve as a benchmark for mortgage rates.
On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, Freddie Mac said lenders were asking an average initial rate of 6.15 percent, down from 6.22 percent last week. The rates do not include add-on fees known as points.

HEADLINE: The Talk of Hollywood;
2 Titans Clash And All of Filmdom Feels Shock Waves

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, April 12

 BODY:
Forget Bill Clinton and Jerry Brown trashing each other. Forget George Bush and Pat Buchanan. In Hollywood terms, the most highly charged exchange is between two of the most powerful players, Michael Ovitz, the chairman of the Creative Artists Agency, and Jeffrey Katzenberg, the chairman of the Walt Disney studios.
Some film executives say it was actually a shouting match, which is the way people often talk to each other in this town. But what gives the dispute particular resonance is the fact that both men are, despite their enormous success, very sensitive to criticism. And when Michael and Jeffrey, as they are locally known, go at it over the phone, it has some of the same impact here as, say, George Bush in Washington picking up the phone and yelling at Mario Cuomo in New York. The earth trembles. 
 The dispute began several weeks ago when Mr. Katzenberg was one of several film executives to address a conference in New York on the shifting economics of the entertainment industry. The gathering was sponsored by Variety, the entertainment trade weekly, and the investment banking firm of Wertheim Schroder. At the conference, several executives, including Joe Roth, the chairman of the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation, and Mr. Katzenberg, cited the powerful leverage of agents as contributing to the rising costs of making movies. Mr. Katzenberg later had an off-the-record luncheon with some reporters and echoed, in blunter terms, the same theme.
Word got back to Mr. Ovitz that Mr. Katzenberg had singled him out. One film executive who attended the lunch said Mr. Ovitz was not mentioned by name. But Mr. Ovitz, who is arguably the most powerful man in Hollywood, was angry and phoned Mr. Katzenberg. Some people close to Mr. Ovitz insist that the conversation was perfectly pleasant. But in fact, it appeared to be a dialogue, Hollywood-style, with plenty of histrionics. Depending on the source -- whether it's Creative Artists or Disney -- the other guy behaved very badly. In a small town like Hollywood, the Katzenberg-Ovitz battle was carried on about as discreetly as the gulf war.
An uneasy detente now prevails. The two men had a pleasant conversation on Friday in advance of the grand opening of Euro Disney in Marne-la-Vallee, France. They will probably have an official rapprochement one of these days at a front table at Morton's, the executive hang-out.
That's the way peace is declared in Hollywood.
 
Who Goes When
 Harrison Ford is playing chicken with Tom Cruise. Mel Gibson and Danny Glover are, let's face it, too awesome to match. And the Mohicans are plainly shying away from Batman.
It's that nervous time of year in Hollywood when studios, with tens of millions of dollars at risk, are watching one another suspiciously to find the best opening weekend for their big spring and summer releases. Moviegoers in the real world may not think the first few days after a film opens are especially significant, but in Hollywood an opening weekend is nothing less than life and death. A film that opens strongly -- the most powerful openers in recent years were "Terminator 2: Judgment Day," "Back to the Future 2" and "Batman" -- create an enormous psychological and financial wave into which studios toss more money for advertising and hype. Films that perform poorly on opening weekend are treated like mongrels.
"You see what the competition is, you try to deftly position the film, and hope for the best," said Paula Silver, the president of marketing at Columbia Pictures. "This July, for example, we have 'A League of Their Own.' It's about something everyone loves: baseball. Directed by Penny Marshall. With Tom Hanks, Geena Davis, Madonna, Jon Lovitz. You want to take advantage of major-league baseball in July. People will have sports on their minds; the Olympics will be starting after we open. It's a family picture, when people are on vacation and want to see a funny movie. And, of course, I want to be away from those 800-pound gorillas like 'Lethal Weapon 3' or 'Batman Returns.' You don't want to be on top of those."
It is the 800-pound gorillas, and the thought of the Olympics -- which will certainly keep countless potential moviegoers at home -- that makes competing studios cringe. There will be a half-dozen or so 800-pounders -- expensive, star-cluttered movies, many of them sequels -- barreling into theaters over the next few months. Some may collapse under their own weight, and there are rumors that a couple of them are duds. But because the summer is a peak moviegoing time, the studios are jostling one another in their own game of gladiators.
Recently, 20th Century Fox, after a series of high-level meetings, decided to delay the opening of one of its major films, "Last of the Mohicans," starring Daniel Day-Lewis, from July 3 to July 10. "We wanted a week more between ourselves and 'Batman,' " said Tom Sherak, executive vice president of Fox, referring to Warner Brothers' $50 million "Batman Returns," with Michael Keaton, Michelle Pfeiffer and Danny DeVito. It is to open on June 19. (By all accounts, virtually every studio is worried about competing with the sequel to 1989's "Batman," which grossed more than $251 million.)
The most serious game of chicken is taking place between Universal Pictures and Paramount. Universal is betting millions on "Far and Away," a lush romantic drama, set in the 1890's, about an Irish tenant farmer who meets and marries a wealthy woman and immigrates with her to the American West. Studio officials say the film, which stars Tom Cruise and his wife, Nicole Kidman, is skewed to women of all ages and men over 21. Paramount is placing a hefty investment in "Patriot Games," the sequel to "The Hunt for Red October," starring Harrison Ford as the C.I.A. analyst Jack Ryan.
Because both films appeal to similar audiences, (the male stars are big favorites among women), the studios have been jockeying for weeks for opening dates. Initially, "Far and Away," was set to open on June 5. But upon hearing that "Patriot Games" was planning to go head to head with it, Tom Pollock, the chairman of the MCA Motion Picture Group, moved "Far and Away" to May 22, the start of the Memorial Day weekend.
And why did Paramount select (for the moment) June 5 for "Patriot Games"? Because it wanted to distance itself as much as possible from another megamovie, "Lethal Weapon 3," which Warner Brothers will release on May 15.
Fueling the competition for "Far and Away" is Fox's "Aliens 3," starring Sigourney Weaver, which is also scheduled to open Memorial Day weekend. Mr. Sherak, who said the success of the two previous "Alien" films gave this one a powerful built-in audience, emphasized that he was always concerned about the competition. A low-budget Disney film, "Encino Man," intended to appeal to the "Wayne's World" teen-age set, is also opening on May 22 and could prove a surprise despite the big movies.
Richard W. Cook, the president of Disney's Buena Vista Distribution, said such modestly priced films as "Encino Man," and a new comedy, "Sister Act," which is to open on May 29, could very well overcome the gorillas. "Sister Act" stars Whoopi Goldberg and Maggie Smith, and the reaction of preview audiences has buoyed Disney. "It's not much different from the summer that we had 'Dead Poets Society,' against 'Indiana Jones,' 'Star Trek,' 'Ghostbusters' and 'Batman,' " Mr. Cook said.
But Barry L. London, the president of Paramount's Motion Picture Group/World Wide Distribution, put it another way: "If you know an 800-pound gorilla is coming, you move to avoid it or get ahead. You don't get in its way."
 
In the Public Eye
 William P. Lauch finds himself an unlikely celebrity. A soft-spoken 36-year-old architect who lives in the Hudson Valley village of Cold Spring, N.Y., Mr. Lauch says he is now being recognized everywhere: in the supermarket, on the street, in airports. The reason is that last Monday, on worldwide television, he accepted the Oscar for best song that was awarded posthumously to Howard Ashman, the librettist for "Beauty and the Beast."
In his speech, Mr. Lauch said he and Mr. Ashman had "shared a home and a life together," that he was "happy and proud" to accept the award, and that it was the first Oscar given to anyone who had died of AIDS.
Mr. Lauch acknowledged that his acceptance of the award was, perhaps, a major statement. "It was, like, a small event but a very big step," he said in an interview. "Both the Disney Company and the academy have sort of recognized me as Howard's survivor. That was the point I was trying to make. I've seen so many friends die. And you hear stories about lovers or companions who are ignored or dismissed by the family or lawyers or whatever. They're not considered like spouses. They should be."

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Adolescents, at Risk

BYLINE: By DIANE CAMPER

 BODY:
Adolescence is a time of frustration -- for teen-agers and parents. It is also a time when youngsters are at risk of school failure, violence, unsafe sex, substance abuse and other behavior that can derail their lives.
How to help adolescents, particularly 10- to 15-year-olds, lead healthier lives is the subject of a new book, "Fateful Choices," by Fred M. Hechinger, former education editor of The New York Times. The book and its themes are being discussed by about 200 education and health experts at a conference sponsored by the Carnegie Corporation's Council on Adolescent Development in Washington, D.C., this week. 
 "Only the years from birth to age three," notes Mr. Hechinger, "match adolescence in the intensity and rapidity of growth and change. Puberty unleashes new energies and desires." It also unleashes a sense of invulnerability and immunity to danger.
Yet of 28 million adolescents aged 10 to 18, 25 percent are engaged in behavior that's harmful to them or others. Another 25 percent are at moderate risk. The other 50 percent, though apparently growing up healthy, are still at risk of later failure because many of them lack problem-solving skills.
The Carnegie Corporation cited similar statistics in a 1989 report aimed at getting middle schools to serve adolescents better. But the spread of AIDS and gun-related violence give the new book greater urgency. Still, it's not too late to turn an adolescent away from risky behavior. In fact, Mr. Hechinger suggests, it's irresponsible not to try. The consequences of unprotected sex, for example, can result not only in pregnancy but death. And the glamorizing of violence on television and in movies coupled with the free flow of guns contributes to increasing violence and death among teen-agers.
That's why he asks the entertainment industry to be more responsible and balanced in its portrayals of violence, substance abuse and sexual behavior. He also sensibly suggests more health services for teens, including school-based clinics that, among other things, would dispense condoms and provide birth control counseling.
"Fateful Choices" argues the need for more communication between adults and teen-agers -- in families, in schools and in communities. "The sad reality is that young adolescents at every economic level are very often neglected by adults -- even within their own families -- or get lost in the mass, victims of large institutions that undermine their healthy development."
Increasingly, aging adults will rely on the skills and employability of teen-agers, too many of whom are growing up unhealthy and alienated. Promoting healthy adolescents ought to have particular resonance during this election year.

HEADLINE: North Korea, Almost Nuclear-Free

 BODY:
Nuclear renegade. That's what many feared North Korea would become -- a nation capable of producing a nuclear bomb, yet so isolated and paranoid that it would not listen to the world's pleas for sanity.
For months, however, North Korea has been moving steadily in sanity's direction. If it can be persuaded to keep going, peaceful coexistence may yet replace years of hardened hostility on the Korean peninsula. North Korea's one-time enemies can do much to achieve that objective. 
 Pyongyang took an extraordinarily encouraging step Thursday when its National Assembly ratified a safeguards accord with the International Atomic Energy Agency. But the agreement calls for one more crucial step: North Korea must open all suspected nuclear sites to international inspection within 90 days.
It's more likely to do so if it receives assurances that such inspections will be followed, in short order, by normal diplomatic relations with Japan and the U.S. and increased trade and investment. The U.S., Japan and South Korea are not obliged to provide such assurances; yet each has a large stake in a nuclear-free Korean peninsula, and persuasive cards to play.
Washington can tell Pyongyang it's ready to establish diplomatic relations once inspections are under way. Seoul can now propose mutual arms cuts. That would allow North Korea to reduce its own defense budget, which absorbs a prohibitively large portion of its gross national product and saps its economic growth.
Japan can pledge essential aid and investment to be delivered once North Korea allows inspections. Pyongyang would be free to claim that the aid was reparations for the grievous suffering Japan caused Korea during decades of occupation.
But before any of these promises can be carried out, North Korea needs to fulfill its obligations both to I.A.E.A. and to South Korea to allow nuclear inspections by July.
Any list provided to the I.A.E.A. should include sites like the suspected reprocessing plant at Yongbyon. South Korea would also be allowed to inspect all the facilities at Yongbyon and at 20-odd other suspect sites in the North. In return, Pyongyang would be entitled to inspect military and other sites in the South that, it thinks, once housed U.S. nuclear arms and related equipment.
Frequent, timely and reciprocal inspections are essential to end decades of hostility and suspicion between North and South. Washington, Seoul and Tokyo can speed this process by assuring North Korea that it will be welcomed back into the family of nations.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Peru: Ideals in Hell

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Peru has had little genuine democracy despite 10 years of elections. It has no democracy now that President Alberto Fujimori has overthrown a weak, corrupt constitutional government. And what the U.S. and others are telling him is that he will have no chance to restore order and combat corruption unless he first re-establishes democratic legitimacy -- and quickly.
Mr. Fujimori, a stubborn and solitary technocrat, is not listening. For the moment, his self-coup d'etat with military support seems wildly popular. Peruvians have had it with politicians, poverty, drug lords and a losing fight against fanatical terrorists. 
 Peru thus presents in acute and special form what is fast becoming a central problem in U.S. foreign policy: What to do when democratically elected leaders destroy democracy ostensibly to save it.
The issue here is not Haiti-like cases where the military overthrows a freely chosen president. To almost all such takeovers, the U.S. response has to be condemnation and tough sanctions.
Algeria is a tougher case. The armed forces suspended elections that Muslim fundamentalists were on their way to winning. The military assumed that once the fundamentalists took power in a free election, they would never hold another.
Democratic purists condemned the takeover. But the fears of Algerian generals were far from groundless. The U.S. cannot condone such takeovers, as President Bush at first seemed to do. A hands-off or neutral position better suits the complexities, as Mr. Bush soon realized. But sooner or later, secular rulers of Muslim states will have to come to legitimate terms with their people.
Lech Walesa, high-profile democrat, could face the U.S. with a harder case. He might make good on his occasional noises about dumping the stalemated Polish Parliament and governing by presidential decree.
President Boris Yeltsin, another democrat doing the right things, is already running into such a situation. The Russian Congress, also "freely" elected, is stacked with ex-Communists resisting further reforms. To observe constitutional democratic forms could doom reforms and benefit only anti-democratic hard-liners.
Fortunately, Mr. Yeltsin understands the power of democratic legitimacy. And he is thinking of going over the heads of his Congress directly to the people with a plebiscite on his reforms. Which seems to be just the creative formula the U.S. will suggest to Mr. Fujimori.
Starting today, Bush officials will move on two tracks to push Mr. Fujimori back on the path to democratic legitimacy. Publicly, they will continue to censure the coup and reaffirm the cutoff of new U.S. aid. To do less would be to invite other coups in Latin America and elsewhere. To do otherwise would undermine what has to be a central tenet of U.S. foreign policy.
Privately, the Administration will try to deal with the hellish realities of Peru. The fact is that Mr. Bush and most other American leaders are sympathetic to Mr. Fujimori's battle against corruption, drugs and terrorists. And they do not want to do anything to permanently damage these efforts. That means they will keep diplomatic doors open, continue humanitarian aid and not ask for broad economic sanctions -- if political rivals are not bloodied and democratic legitimacy restored.
The trick is how to bring back democracy without also restoring the corrupt power centers Mr. Fujimori (and Washington) rightly seeks to curtail. Washington's solution, like Yeltsin's, is a plebiscite.
Mr. Fujimori promises to call one. But he wants a simple yes or no vote on his rule, while his opponents remain in jail and army tanks roam the streets.
This gambit will give him a quick victory. But U.S. officials will argue that it will not provide long-term legitimacy or power to call for new congressional elections and judicial appointments, and no hold over his corrupt military allies. Instead, they will urge Mr. Fujimori to seek a mandate from a genuinely free referendum on basic constitutional changes.
Such a democratic coup cum plebiscite is not ideal. But in a world now brimming with new and terribly vulnerable democratic leaders, it might be the only way to retain legitimacy and lay the basis for genuine democracy in the future.
