SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1523 words

HEADLINE: YELTSIN'S CABINET THREATENS TO QUIT IN CONGRESS FEUD

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 13

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin's entire Cabinet formally offered to resign today unless an unexpectedly aggressive Parliament halted efforts to scale back the Government's program of economic reform.
Any such dilution of the Russian President's program could lead the West to reconsider its offer of billions of dollars in assistance and jeopardize Mr. Yeltsin's plans for economic recovery.
Yegor T. Gaidar, the Deputy Prime Minister and chief architect of the economic reforms, said the Cabinet had submitted its resignation en masse, reflecting a growing power struggle between Mr. Yeltsin and the Congress of People's Deputies, the highest legislative authority in Russia.
 
Keep Working, Yeltsin Says
 Mr. Gaidar said Mr. Yeltsin had asked his ministers to continue working until the end of the Congress session in the next few days, when he will decide whether to accept their resignations.
Their action was in protest against a resolution adopted by the Congress on Saturday ordering Mr. Yeltsin to relinquish the post of Prime Minister and to name a new Government within three months, as well as to make broad changes in the economic program, which came under sharp criticism. 
 Cabinet ministers said the changes contained in the resolution ran counter to their goal of sharply reducing Government spending, curtailing the money supply and reining in inflation. The Congress proposals included indexing savings accounts in line with inflation, easing the tax burden, and granting a range of salary increases, all popular with the public.
 
Hope for Compromise
 Many deputies said they still believed that a compromise would be struck to avoid the inevitable economic and political crisis that would follow if the Government followed through on its threat to resign.
At the least, the confrontation has already widened the rift between the President and the Congress, just as Russia stands at what many consider the most fateful juncture of its economic revamping, facing either hyperinflation or widespread unemployment.
The Government, led by young economists, has mapped out a program of strict credit and money controls as a condition for the stable ruble and balanced budget that it says are necesssary for the introduction of a market economy. Many in the Congress, which is dominated by former Communists and other Yeltsin critics, argue in favor of propping up old industries and maintaining the lavish social net that existed under Communism.
The struggle also draws on the Congress's desire to regain some control over the Government, which has been largely ceded to Mr. Yeltsin.
Mr. Yeltsin himself has not attended the Congress or made any public comment since Saturday. But he is expected to speak soon.
Moves to defuse the confrontation later in the day fizzled when the Speaker of the Congress, Ruslan Khasbulatov, a former ally of Mr. Yeltsin who has become increasingly critical of the Government, began sniping at the ministers arrayed before him in the tones he often uses in cajoling the 1,046 deputies to the Congress.
"If they want to resign, let them take it up with those who appointed them," he said. "Let no one try to blackmail us. We're not afraid of blackmail."
Shouts of "Disgrace!" rose from the hall, and Mr. Khasbulatov continued: "Don't bother. There's no disgrace. These fellows are just a bit disoriented."
At this, Gennadi Burbulis, Mr. Yeltsin's chief lieutenant, who had been stonily biting his lip, led a walkout from the hall, and in the ensuing hubbub Mr. Khasbulatov adjourned the session and quickly walked out.
 
No Insult Intended
 Mr. Khasbulatov appeared on television later in the evening insisting that he had not meant to insult the Government, saying: "It was just my old professorial habit, saying hey fellows, don't be miffed. If I did insult you, I apologize."
But by then the battle was joined. Mr. Yeltsin's lieutenants said he would soon make a tough address to the Congress, at which he was expected to threaten it either with a draft constitution entrenching presidential rule, or call for a plebiscite to dissolve Congress. His supporters among the deputies started a petition campaign to unseat Mr. Khasbulatov.
What galled the Government most about the resolution adopted by the Congress on Saturday was the order to Mr. Yeltsin to propose a new prime minister to the Congress within three months, a move that would in effect disband the current governing team.
The Cabinet reacted sharply. The resignation statement made public today had been prepared by the ministers late Saturday.
On Sunday, however, the crisis seemed to wane when members of the Congress presidium met with members of Mr. Yeltsin's Government and worked out a compromise resolution that would soften or neutralize those parts of the earlier document that the ministers found most offensive.
It would affirm the course of economic reforms, would make all the Congress demands contingent on financial feasibility, and would delay the law on the Government until Dec. 1, in effect extending the Government's term until then.
On Monday, however, Mr. Khasbulatov went to a discussion of the Constitution and shrugged off efforts to discuss the Government. When warned that Mr. Gaidar was threatening resignation in the halls, Mr. Khasbulatov said, "Let him walk around to his heart's content."
Instead, Mr. Gaidar then gathered reporters in the halls and made his announcement. The decisions of the Congress would block all further reforms, he declared.
"The requirements made by the Congress dooms the country to hyperinflation," he said. "The inevitable result of implementing these decisions of the Congress will be a catastrophic decline in living standards, famine, social upheavals and chaos."
The West, he warned, would draw back the $24 billion in credits it has proposed as long as Russia stayed the course of reforms. Mr. Yeltsin would become "purely symbolic," and the country would embark on a path of "irresponsible populism."
"Using the pretext of tighter control of the Government by the legislative branch, they in effect deny that Government and the President the possibility of pursuing the policy of economic reforms aimed at the revival of Russia," he said.
 
Municipal Government Support
 Mr. Gaidar said all ministers had signed the resignation statement, and within an hour, the Moscow municipal government announced that if the federal Government walked out, it would resign in solidarity.
Mr. Gaidar added that the Cabinet would reconsider if the Congress altered its resolutions or "if the President makes a decision allowing us to function as we must." In the meantime, Mr. Gaidar said, Mr. Yeltsin had asked the Cabinet to carry on until the end of the Congress.
Although there was no comment from Mr. Yeltsin, there was no doubt that he would plunge into the fray when he believed the time was ripe.
There was considerable speculation on what Mr. Yeltsin might do. "Whether the current Government continues the reforms until the results can be judged or whether it steps aside depends entirely and fully on President Yeltsin," Izvestia said on a front page dedicated almost entirely to the drama in the Congress.
In his television appearance, Mr. Khasbulatov showed little intention of backing away from the battle. He accused Mr. Gaidar of taking advice from the International Monetary Fund too "unconditionally," and proposed that Mr. Burbulis and Mr. Gaidar save money by cutting back on their large Government bureaucracy.
"Some members of the Government want to come out from under parliamentary control," he said. "Yes, they are under the President. But they also answer to Parliament."
That seemed to be the key to the battle. An ambitious economist and lawyer who was elected Speaker only through Mr. Yeltsin's arduous intervention, Mr. Khasbulatov seemed determine to regain some of the parliamentary control that was lost when the Congress granted the President temporary powers to rule by decree and to name the Government directly.
 
Khasbulatov Gains Support
 The voting indicated that Mr. Khasbulatov had found support not only among the former Communists, who make up about one-third of the Congress, but also among centrists and "democrats" who share an unease about what they considered a high-handed and secretive team that has taken shape around Mr. Burbulis.
Government ministers, for their part, accused Mr. Khasbulatov of trying to assert personal control over the Congress and Government.
Adding to the confusion was the fact that the Congress, unlike the smaller Supreme Soviet it picks to carry on routine legislative work, has no mechanism of committees or experts to work over documents before they come to the floor. So much of the session is spent haggling over texts, and many still emerge legally flawed.
The resolution on economic reforms, for instance, underwent 370 changes on Saturday, and Sergei Filatov, a Deputy Speaker, conceded that the Congress might well have let slip elements that inadvertently contradicted existing economic policies.

HEADLINE: Chicago's Loop Is Closed Down As River's Water Floods Tunnels

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 13

 BODY:
All business halted in the heart of downtown Chicago this morning and tens of thousands of office workers were sent home after 250 million gallons of water from the Chicago River leaked into underground tunnels and, from there, flooded into basements.
Fearing that the water would short-circuit electrical systems in the tunnels and in the buildings, the city shut off power to much of the Loop, the city's central business district. Officials said the electricity might not be restored Tuesday. 
 It was a most improbable flood: The streets were dry except for puddles of dingy water pumped from basements, and no injuries were reported. But structural and economic damage threatened to be considerable, and the loss of power immobilized many of the city's major institutions. The aisles and counters at the Marshall Field department store went dark. Trials were suspended at Cook County Circuit Court. City Hall was evacuated. So was the Sears Tower, the world's tallest building, with its 7,000 workers.
The Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the primary markets in futures contracts on everything from wheat to stock indexes, were both closed. [Page D21.]
"Closed" signs went up and steel curtains came down on the discount jewelers and shoe shops on State Street. At the Palmer House Hotel bellhops used flashlights to guide guests through darkened halls.
And throughout the business district of the nation's third-largest city telephone calls and staff meetings were stopped in mid-sentence as office workers streamed out of their buildings.
At 11:15 A.M., an hour after city officials warned that they were pulling the plug on the Loop, the lights went out in a 12-square-block area and the city urged evacuation of the entire 100-block downtown area.
The flooding was the result of a breach the size of an automobile in the roof of a freight tunnel underneath the Chicago River. The break sent 250 million gallons of murky river water into the tunnels and the basements connected to them.
Decades ago, the tunnels, 40 miles of crisscrossing passageways, were used to haul coal to buildings in the Loop, and, local lore has it, whisky in Al Capone's bootlegging operation. They have been out of use for 30 years, but contain electrical and fiber-optics circuitry that keep downtown offices running.
 
Breach Near New Pilings
 The breach occurred inches from wood pilings the city had installed in the river last summer to protect a nearby bridge from boats that might slip their moorings.
But today, as city workers dumped stones and sandbags, and later concrete, into the river in an effort to plug the hole that sucked the water into the tunnel below, city officials offered no explanation for the cause of the breach.
"This is a very serious problem," said Mayor Richard M. Daley in an afternoon news conference where tensions were high and answers were short. "We can't give any answers as to who's responsible."
The river is so murky and volatile that no one has actually seen the rupture and it is unclear how it occurred. The tunnel's ceiling is 15 to 20 feet below the river bottom, separated by a concrete casing built in the late 1890's that has become old and cracked, city officials said.
 
Police Assigned to Area
 "Essentially, there is a hole in the bottom of the river," said Earl Knight, the general superintendent of the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District, which is in charge of the area's sewer and water treatment. "It may have developed from a small leak that got bigger and bigger and, then caved in. It could have been a slow leak that led to a sudden break. It may have developed over time."
Later in the day Mayor Daley said the city had begun an investigation, "We are talking to everybody, looking for memos and information on it," he said. "Yes, people did know about it before. These people are going to be held accountable."
Raymond Orosco, the Chicago Fire Commissioner, said that the Loop would probably not have electricity until Tuesday or Wednesday. With the lights out and some downtown burglar alarm systems on hold, the city assigned 200 police officers to the Loop tonight to deter possible looting.
A primary concern today was figuring out how to get the water out of the tunnels before it turned putrid. To do that, the city plans to drill a hole through the old freight tunnel, which is about 40 feet below ground, to a new and larger sewage tunnel 200 feet below. The city wants to drain the water from the old tunnel system by connecting it to a vertical drop shaft that would send the water into the sewage tunnel.
The polluted river water would then flow to a pumping station for treatment before being put back into the river.
"It will take a couple of days to really get down there, break through and make a connection," said Nicholas Melas, president of the board of commissioners of the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District.
The trouble began early this morning when workers found the basements flooded in the older buildings that are linked to the old tunnel. City workers found the source of the flooding when they saw a whirlpool in the Chicago River, like water funneling down a drain, near the Kinzie Street Bridge.
By 10 A.M., city officials realized that electrical equipment in tunnels and basement was soaked and announced that downtown offices would have to be evacuated. By 11:15, the lights had gone out in most of the Loop, the downtown blocks that are encircled by elevated train tracks.
 
Upset for Business
 "This is a disaster," said Eugene T. Sherman, a partner in a downtown law firm who was carrying work home. "This will be a $100 million loss for businesses. This will affect not only Chicago, but the world we do business with."
Work on his firm's cases ceased in an instant. "The phones are down, the secretaries are gone," his son, Thomas, also a lawyer loaded down with briefs, said. "We can't get to the files in the courthouse. We can't meet our deadlines."
Over at City Hall, workers frantically moved computers and copying machines and boxes of birth and marriage certificates out of the basement storage offices that were quickly being overtaken by river water. Some of the records were original and one of a kind and dated back to the Chicago fire of 1871. Today they took up half the lobby at City Hall, as water reached within 18 inches of the ceiling of their former storage place.
A few blocks away, water was being pumped out of the basement of Marshall Field, where hundreds of thousands of dollars in merchandise sat in storage and in danger of ruin.
Maureen Woodman, a court reporter, was just heading into a civil trial when it was suspended. Robert Zerfass, an accountant, was working on a client's income taxes. Ed Matthei, an architect, was drawing blueprints for a cancer center in Michigan. And the product service managers at Xerox were an hour into a meeting.
"We tried to grab what we could," said Jim Knight, one of the managers. "Now we're looking for someplace else to continue the meeting."
Erik Peterson and Steve Jung were among the last people to leave the offices of Arthur Andersen, the accounting firm. They were trying to finish a graphic for a lawyer who needed it for a trial on Tuesday.
Then they couldn't reach the lawyer. He worked in the Loop, too, and his office and telephone were shut down just like theirs.
So the two set out down Adams Street, the three- by four-foot presentation wrapped in cardboard, in search of the lawyer's firm's suburban office, still trying to meet the deadline.
By early this afternoon, the Loop looked like a ghost town. But on the expressways, a welter of homebound motorists created a midday rush hour.
 
Saturation on Television
 As the day's event's unfolded, the flooding became a city fixation, pre-empting soap operas and game shows on television. All day long, local stations showed maps of the Loop and close-ups of the whirlpool in the river.
Toward the end of the day, downtown workers began turning their attention to Tuesday and whether they should go in to work, but found few answers.
The Mayor's Office of Inquiry and Information had little information. "We don't have any message," said a man working the telephones. "We don't have any news. Call back tomorrow."
Many offices had just enough time to back up their computer files and get their workers out before the elevators shut down, much less to plan for Tuesday. Others left broad messages on answering machines, telling clients the obvious, that the office was closed because of the shutdown of electricity.
In a recorded message, the Board of Trade said there would be no trading on Tuesday and that the building would be closed a second day.
It did not take some business people long to find a way to turn disaster into profit. Jim Felton, who works for a property management company, tacked orange fliers, declaring, "We've got 100,000 square feet available" for people to store their goods in a safe, dry place. His office, of course, is outside the Loop.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Water from the Chicago River flooded Chicago's underground tunnel system yesterday, immobilizing businesses in the Loop. Workers pumped water out of the basement of the Chicago Board of Trade. (Barry Jarvinen for The New York Times) (pg. A19)
 
Chart: "The Flood Beneath Chicago"
The Tunnels
 The flooding came from a hole in the bed of the Chicago River, which runs from 15 to 20 feet deep, to a network of underground tunnels that mimic the street grid. The tunnels, which are 40 feet underground, were originally used to transport freight and coal to buildings, but fell into disuse during the 1940's. They have been used since 1960 by Commonwealth Edison for power lines and by Illinois Bell.
 One plan to drain the tunnels would involve creating a new, vertical tunnel that would connect the freight tunnels to the city's relatively new, high-capacity sewage tunnels that lie 250 feet below ground level. These larger tunnels would then carry the flood water out to Lake Michigan.
 
What Happened
 Yesterday morning, flooding was reported in the basements of several buildings in the Loop, downtown Chicago's business district. The water threatened the electrical control systems in the basements of many buildings. It also damaged store merchandise and public records in City Hall.
 Commonwealth Edision shut off power to several buildings at 11:15 P.M. yesterday after the buildings were evacuated.
 City work crews tried to plug the car-sized hole yesterday by using gravel, cement and even matresses.
 
Map of downtown Chicago showing location of flood. (pg. A19)

HEADLINE: Off the Rolls -- A special report.;
The Sorrows, and Surprises, After a Welfare Plan Ends

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 8

 BODY:
Body odor, ammonia and spaghetti sauce battled for control of the air at the Wheeler Warming Center this week as Anita Robinson straggled in, submitted to a search from a guard in rubber gloves and headed for a mandatory lice-fighting shower.
Ms. Robinson, 37 years old, was cut loose from her moorings last fall when Michigan set what might be the most dramatic national standard in a budget-cutting season: it ended a $240 million welfare program for adults it considered employable.
 
New Ways to Suffer
 Since the checks stopped, Ms. Robinson has been evicted from an apartment, found a boyfriend and fallen out with him, and wound up in a shelter for the homeless. But asked about the program's demise, she offered a surprising verdict: "It's made my life better." 
 Most of the welfare money had gone to crack, she said; now she has been clean for 62 days.
Across Michigan, 83,000 adults -- many vulnerable, most poor, five portrayed below -- are trying to adjust, and it is clear that for some, life is not better.
While a few have found jobs, as Gov. John Engler promised, perhaps most, like Ms. Robinson, have exchanged one form of suffering for another. At least one -- Eva Frederick of Copemish -- died. She suffered a stroke, apparently after trying to stretch out her blood pressure medicine.
While the program cuts have their roots in financial emergency, they are growing into something else: an increasingly strident attack on the very idea of welfare. At least 12 other states and the District of Columbia have reduced similar programs, with Ohio cutting off an estimated 90,000 people this month. President Bush is making an attack on the welfare system a central issue in his re-election campaign.
Those in favor of trimming or eliminating programs argue that such steps will do the poor a favor by providing a new impetus to seek work or education. Others say the cuts will just compound the misery of the powerless.
Welfare programs for childless adults are typically known as "general assistance." Unlike the main cash welfare program -- Aid to Families with Dependent Children -- they are financed entirely with state and local money, and eligibility varies widely. The 225,000 Michigan families with children who receive A.F.D.C. were not affected by the cuts.
The heterogeneous ranks of general assistance rolls include strong young men and ailing, aging women, battered wives, parolees and laid-off workers.
As 83,000 complicated lives unfold in Michigan, there are few statistical gauges of what has happened. And even where the facts are clear, different observers will draw different lessons about whether the cuts helped, or hurt, and about who is to blame.
When the program ended, Marcie Devitt, 61, was evicted from her mobile home. But the Federal Government subsequently offered a free apartment. Was the state cruel to cut her off? Should her 12 children be working harder to support her?
Paul Gibson got a job. Ronald Gray kept drinking. Glenn Williams threw himself into his work as a hard-luck haberdasher, scrounging used clothes and reselling them to his neighbors in a welfare hotel.
Anna Washington found a good job but quit it, and wound up seeking cash at a skid-row blood bank, a move that baffles even her. "I don't know what to say about that," she said last week, her arm bound in a bloody bandage.
Six states have no general assistance programs. Michigan's paid an average of $147 a month.
While such programs are often described as welfare for the able-bodied, many of its recipients fall into a gray zone: not officially disabled, but not really able to support themselves.
The legislature created a small disability program aimed at adults who could neither work, nor qualify for Federal disability payments. But advocates are suing the state, saying it is rejecting those who should qualify.
 
What Kinds of Savings?
 When Pennsylvania reduced its general assistance program in 1982, Anthony Halter, a sociologist at the University of Illinois, tracked 113 people cut from the program; a year later, he found, 3 had jobs.
Among the many unknowns are whether the budget cuts will save the public money. Critics of the Michigan action have estimated that if 10 percent of the former recipients wind up in prison or mental hospitals, the savings will be wiped out. The police say they do not yet know if the cuts are causing crime to rise.
The Salvation Army estimates that the cuts have increased homelessness in Detroit by about 30 percent. Samuel Chambers, the head of Wayne County Department of Social Services, puts the figure at about 50 percent.
What follows are a few portraits of the sorrows and surprises that large government changes bring to people's lives.
 
Ailing Mother of 12
A Free Apartment But No Freedom
 When general assistance ended, Marcie Devitt's cash income fell to zero, and she was evicted from the mobile home in Pontiac where she had lived for five years.
A son then drove her to the rooming house where he was living. The manager there cleared out a storage room and let her stay for free.
"So I end up in a house with alcoholics and drugs addicts, just so I don't have to sleep out in the street," she said in an angry, raspy voice.
Ms. Devitt is theoretically able-bodied, but much about her contradicts the theory. She was found to have cervical cancer in 1977, and though it is in remission she has rarely worked since. In 1990, she came down with ulcerative colitis, a condition that brings violent diarrhea and leaves her bedridden with weakness. After the cuts, she said, "I had to go all over begging toilet paper -- churches, Salvation Army."
 
First Divorced, Then Widowed
 Ms. Devitt, who has 12 children and several grandchildren, said she divorced her first husband because he beat her. Her second husband died. She said she worked as a bartender and a beautician until the onset of cancer, and then lived on A.F.D.C. until her youngest child turned 18, ending her eligibility.
She received general assistance for about six years, until her checks stopped in October.
She has applied for state disability twice and been turned down both times, although two doctors have signed forms calling her "unemployable." She has appealed and is awaiting a hearing.
In February, her son left the rooming house for Ohio, and Ms. Devitt moved in with a daughter and four grandchildren. They are getting by on her daughter's welfare check. Ms. Devitt said her other children cannot afford to help.
Recently, she was approved to live in a free apartment, as part of the Federal housing program, but she complains that it is situated "in the middle of colored people," and that she is afraid to move in.
She said the Governor was right to cut back on welfare programs, but wrong to make her a target. "You've got these young people sitting in houses, popping out babies when they're able to work," she said.
Marguerite Kowaleski, her social worker, winced. "Marcie," she said, "remember there's people saying that about you."
 
Worker
He Needs a Job, So He Has One
 Paul Gibson said the cut did just what it was supposed to: it made him get a job. "When I was on G.A., I didn't really need to work," he said, laughing good-naturedly about an indolent past.
Mr. Gibson, 39, said he came to the welfare program about four years ago, after "a run of bad luck." He was dismissed from his job at a car wash and went to live with a friend, whose apartment then burned down.
A social worker gave him a voucher to stay at the Roosevelt Hotel, a shabby warehouse for parolees, alcoholics and others with limited options. He never left.
At the height of the welfare program, a $240 check paid his rent and left him with $38 to spare. He also got $85 in food stamps. Odd jobs and soup kitchen meals filled in the gaps. "It's easy to get caught up like that, because you don't have to do nothing," he said. "Nothing."
 
Going With the Flow
 While many of the welfare hotels resorted to wholesale evictions, the Roosevelt began lining up jobs for its residents. As he had in the past, Mr. Gibson went with the flow, and before long, a temporary job turned to a full-time one in an auto-parts plant.
"Paul was one of the few fellows in here who was willing to work," said Bob Ruscoe Sr., the day manager.
To get to his job on the midnight shift, Mr. Gibson has to catch a bus at 8:30 P.M., which puts him in a full hour and 15 minutes early, time he kills in a cafeteria. When the shift ends at 8 A.M., Mr. Ruscoe picks him up on his way in to the hotel, charging him a dollar.
At $5.30 an hour, Mr. Gibson brings home about $160 a week.
One thing that hasn't changed is the decor of Mr. Gibson's room, which he describes -- a bit too generously -- as "squalid splendor." The dusty piles of scavenged magazines, dirty clothes and greasy plates give his home the feel of a set from "The Munsters."
"There's nothing immaculate about it," Mr. Gibson concedes, "but I've seen rooms a lot worse.
 
Scavenger
Sustained by Faith And Old Clothes
 Since the car wreck that sent him into an extended coma six years ago, Glenn Williams, 37, has talked like he walks: softly and a bit off-balance.
Last week he was sitting in his room at the Roosevelt Hotel, searching for the words to describe his two main interests: used clothes and Christian faith. The sermon playing loudly on his scavenged radio made it hard to hear.
Asked whether he had feared the program's end, he said it was a sin to be afraid -- "God wasn't afraid, after all that He went through." Mr. Williams said he had simply quickened the entrepreneurial activity that had earned him a reputation as the building's best businessman.
Mr. Williams makes the rounds of churches and social service agencies, collecting free clothes. Shirts go to his neighbors for $2 or $3, pants perhaps for $5.
 
Prayers to 'Miniature Angels'
 The sills and shelves of his fastidious room are lined with prayer books, and Mr. Williams said he prays to what he calls "the miniature angels" for food. He also relies on $111 in food stamps and a hot plate.
Mr. Williams, who used to work as a carpet installer, said he has been unable to hold a job since the wreck. He spent several years living with his parents, but that relationship frayed. He moved to the Roosevelt in 1989, after serving 58 days for a robbery that he said his friends committed.
The car wreck has made him forgetful, he said. The welfare office made him join an adult education class, but he could not keep up. He said he recently lost a job in a potato chip factory because he could not remember what to do. Without welfare, Mr. Williams has fallen about $800 behind on his rent, but the hotel has let him stay on: even partial rent is better than an empty room, the manager said, and Mr. Williams is quiet and decent.
"They treat us with love and respect," Mr. Williams said. "From the blessings of God, everything come out beautiful."
 
Drinker
Wine a Companion In a Blurry Life
 "I ain't gonna tell you no lie," said Ronald Gray on the morning of his 43d birthday, smelling of mouthwash. "I still got an alcohol problem."
In the months since his check was cut, Mr. Gray has been evicted by a landlord and a girlfriend, slept in abandoned buildings, and washed up on the steps of a city warming center.
There he got sent to a training program and placed in a residential shelter where he has his own room and what he calls a more comfortable life than before the cuts. "Hey man, I'm super better off now," he said.
Mr. Gray's autobiography varies with each telling but seems to include a stint in the marines and a job on an automotive line. His wife left him in the mid-1970's, he said. The past decade is a blur of failed alcohol-treatment programs and life on the streets.
 
Loving and Losing
 When general assistance ended in October, Mr. Gray was living in a welfare hotel that sent him packing. His girlfriend, who was pregnant, had been living there, too, but a homeless shelter moved her into a subsidized apartment and got her enrolled on A.F.D.C. She let him move in for a while, he said, then found another man.
Since then, Mr. Gray has been cashing in his $111 allotment of food stamps, which brings $78 illegally on the street, hustling odd jobs, and making twice-a-week visits to blood plasma centers. The money buys cigarettes and soap, he said, and "after that, it's all about buying wine."
For the past few weeks, he has just joined a training program run by Operation Get Down, a private social-service agency, that is supposed to teach him to prepare a resume and conduct himself well in job interviews.
 
Blood Donor
Meeting Ends, Pint by Pint
 "Oooohh, I can't get my arm in there," groaned Anna Washington, grappling with her coat as she left a blood plasma center last week, $10 richer and a pint lighter.
Speaking of life-after-welfare, she offered this assessment: "You've got to sell your stamps just to pay your rent, and you've got to sell your blood just to buy your food."
But her story is more complicated than that. Beside the crisp $10 bill in her wallet is a worn license, certifying her as a practical nurse.
In fact, Ms. Washington said, she found a $10-an-hour job at a nursing home in February but quit within a week because she had difficulty making a 5:30 A.M. bus. "Why would I quit a job that paid $10 an hour to live like this?" she asked, puzzled.
 
Getting Her License
 Ms. Washington, 28, said she was let go from a nursing job about a year ago because she could not find a regular baby sitter. She then sent her two children to live with her mother -- wanting to get them out of a dangerous neighborhood, she said -- and began collecting general assistance while living with her boyfriend.
When the program ended, Michigan's social services department paid $50 to renew her license, which had lapsed, and sent her to a group course on job-seeking techniques. With her boyfriend unemployed, Ms. Washington now picks up $50 a week through a part-time job as a home nurse.
Last week's trip to the blood bank netted her only $8 after bus fare and took about two hours by the time technicians screened her for AIDS. A week ago, she said, a phlebotomist-in-training missed her vein, causing her arm to bruise and bloat.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Administration Rethinks Cuts in Municipal Construction

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Under mounting pressure from construction groups, bond dealers and some fiscal monitors, the Dinkins administration has decided that it was a mistake to propose deep cuts in the city's construction spending during a recession and is trying to come up with a way to finance the spending.
Critics have expressed concern that the cuts would hurt the economy and delay vital construction projects, increasing their cost when they are finally undertaken. 
 The decision to back away from the cuts shows how difficult Mayor David N. Dinkins has found it to juggle the various priorities that go into writing the budget. He must listen to bond-rating agencies, which say the city's borrowing is too high; to the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which can offer the city some financial relief but often wants to impose conditions; and to the local economy, which, especially in the construction industry, is heavily dependent on public works projects.
Aides to the Mayor said yesterday that the administration was meeting this week to find new ways to finance the city's massive rebuilding effort without increasing the cost of borrowing money by selling bonds. It is the cost of the interest and principal on those bonds that led the city to make the initial capital-spending cuts.
 
A Search for Solutions
 "There are projects that need to be done and if we can find a way to do them and keep our debt cost down then we plan to move ahead with them," said Philip R. Michael, director of the Office of Management and Budget.
Among the measures under consideration by the administration are changing timetables for building and financing public works, taking advantage of low construction costs, applying for new Federal and state matching funds, and asking the State Legislature for new dedicated taxes to pay for some capital projects. Of these options, new taxes seem least likely.
In addition, the Municipal Assistance Corporation has proposed a joint financing arrangement with the city, in which the state agency would help finance the capital budget by issuing bonds on the city's behalf at a more favorable interest rate than the city could. The interest on bonds would be lower because M.A.C. has a better financial standing than the city.
Trimming the city's capital spending for construction is a critical part of the Mayor's plan for closing a $1.8 billion gap in the $29 billion budget for the 1993 fiscal year that begins July 1.
In January, the Mayor announced plans to cut capital spending by about 30 percent, or $3.7 billion, to $8.5 billion over the next four years. The cut was expected reduce debt payments on long-term bonds that are used to finance the capital budget. Although the reduction was to save only $5 million next year, by 1996 it was to have saved about $250 million in interest and principal repaid each year from city operating revenues.
Mayor Dinkins's press secretary, Leland T. Jones, acknowledged yesterday that the city was working to restore some of the proposed cuts in the capital budget, but he said that it was too early to say what areas would be restored. Most of the $3.7 billion in cuts were to come from school repair and construction, road reconstruction and parks.
 
Economic Stimulation Sought
 "No matter what is restored, there will still be at least a billion-dollar cut in the capital budget and the debt service will be no more than 20 percent," Mr. Jones said.
Mr. Michael, the director of the budget office, said that the administration was rethinking its proposed cuts in the capital budget because of a pressing need to stimulate the local economy and to rebuild the city's crumbling infrastructure. The city has already pledged not to cut work on bridges, sewers and water mains.
Bond-rating agencies have strongly pressured the city to reduce the cost of debt service, which, if the city does not cut its capital program or find another way to finance the program, is expected to account for more than 20 percent of every city tax dollar by 1996.
Critics of trimming the capital budget maintain that it will cost the city tens of thousands of construction jobs and delay repair of the city's deteriorating infrastructure. The cost of making emergency repairs is likely to overshadow any short-term savings gained by cutting the capital plan, the critics maintain.
A new study of the city's capital budget released yesterday found that by delaying capital spending, the city will miss a prime opportunity to take advantage of low construction costs and increased Federal and state matching money available for transportation and clean-air measures.
 
Bargain Rates for Building
 The study, which was conducted by Samuel I. Schwartz, an engineering professor at the Cooper Union Infrastructure Institute, found that construction costs are 20 to 40 percent below the level of five years ago.
"Somehow we've come to applaud every cut in governmental expenditure. But there are some government investments that will solve myriad problems and improve our economic climate," said Mr. Schwartz, who was a deputy transportation commissioner in the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch.
Louis Coletti, who heads the New York Building Congress, an industry group that represents construction labor unions and contractors, said that cutting capital spending would be devastating to the construction and design industries, which have seen 50 percent unemployment.
While he said he was pleased that the Mayor was currently pushing several public works projects ahead of schedule, Mr. Coletti said that he was still worried about the long-term impact of capital budget cuts and called on the Mayor to pursue other measures, like Municipal Assistance Corporation financing.
Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, said that while he understood the need for the city to reduce its debt service, "It is important for the city to maintain a high level of capital investment to insure the city's quality of life."
Mr. Rohatyn said that M.A.C. has proposed providing the city with $1.5 billion to $2 billion of financing that would allow the city to restore $600 million in proposed cuts to the capital budget without increasing debt service. Aides to Mr. Dinkins said that they were still considering the M.A.C. proposal.

HEADLINE: Protesters Disrupt Brooklyn Board Meeting

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
The first meeting of a reconfigured Community Board 14 in Brooklyn was disrupted last night by a bomb threat and later, by angry shouting matches -- evidence that the racially charged protests that have wracked the board for two years show little sign of ending.
The raucous meeting at Edward R. Murrow High School in Midwood came 12 days after the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, announced new appointments he made to the board that increased the number of black members to 16 from 11. 
 For two years a small group of protesters, led by Ernest N. Foster, a local businessman and political aspirant, and the lawyer Colin Moore, have railed against what they have said is a lack of minority representation on the board.
The protests, which at previous meetings have led to threats and assaults, accusations of racism and racial slurs, underscore the intractablity of the issues of race and representation in the racially mixed district, which includes parts of Flatbush and Midwood.
Under the provisions of the City Charter, half the appointments are made from the nominations of City Council members representing the district -- in this case, Susan D. Alter, Una Clarke, Noach Dear and Anthony D. Weiner.
The new appointments included one Hispanic and seven black members. Two black board members were not reappointed. Before this year's appointments, 11 of the board's 50 members -- 22 percent -- were black, while blacks made up 40 percent of the district, according to the 1990 census. With 16 members now, blacks represent 32 percent of the board.
The bomb threat came only moments after the meeting began, a few minutes before 8 P.M. The board chairman, Alvin M. Berk, abruptly cleared the school auditorium. Inspector John V. Schneider of Patrol Borough Brooklyn South, who was at the meeting, said someone called in the threat to the 911 system. The threat proved unfounded.
 
Addressing Grievances
 The meeting remained tense after the 250 people returned to the auditorium, and the public comment session erupted into a shouting match between the protesters and members of the Jewish Defense Organization. A phalanx of police officers separated the groups, and Mr. Berk had to call the meeting to order several times.
City Councilwoman Alter said that the presence of the two sides had the effect of maintaining a relative though angry stability, but only at the cost of preventing an open discussion of the issues facing the community.
"It's sloganeering on both sides," she said after the meeting. "There's nothing substantial. There's no way to go forward from here."
But Olie MacLean, a former board member who is black and who was not reappointed after serving six years, said the borough's leadership had simply tried to maintain the political status quo, "which is addicted to white supremacy."
The protests at the board meetings began early in 1990 as Community Board 14 became embroiled in the boycott of a Korean grocery store on Church Avenue. The protesters -- supported by the Mr. Moore and the political organizer Sonny Carson -- have contended that the racial composition of the board has not changed as quickly as the neighborhoods it represents.
 
Demonstrations at Groceries
 A group protesting the hiring practices at two Korean grocery stores in Brooklyn set up pickets outside those markets yesterday morning, but left peacefully after the stores agreed to hire more black employees.
About a dozen protesters from the African-American Protection Agency, a community organization that says it seeks to help the unemployed, picketed Best Fruit Palace, at 1445 Fulton Street, in Bedford-Stuyvesant, and the nearby KC Fruit Market, at 1490 Fulton Street.

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Shunning Sanctions Against Peru

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
The Bush Administration continued today to sharply criticize President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru for suspending democracy to bring order to his Andean nation. But Washington stopped short of calling for economic sanctions to force him to change course.
While Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d told a special session of the Organization of American States that "you cannot destroy democracy in order to save it," he joined with other O.A.S. foreign ministers in backing a relatively restrained resolution on Peru. The United States has consistently criticized Mr. Fujimori's actions since they were taken on April 5. 
 The Administration's policy, which seems to be shared by many O.A.S. members, appears to be this:
Washington has a great deal of sympathy for the threats Mr. Fujimori faces from drug traffickers and Maoist guerrillas, but in its view, as expressed by Mr. Baker, he has made a "tragic mistake" because his actions will deprive Peru of what it most needs to defeat those threats and the poverty that hobbles his country -- strong and sustained international support and aid and the internal legitimacy that comes from a being a democratic government.
Moreover, Bolivia, Ecuador, Chile and Brazil all share borders with Peru and have told Washington they are wary of taking any action that could lead to the collapse of the central Government in Lima and the rise of drug traffickers and terrorists.
 
A Balance Is Sought
 To balance these competing impulses, the United States and other O.A.S. members seem to have settled for harshly condemning in public what Mr. Fujimori has done while refraining from imposing equally harsh sanctions that would cripple his Government. The aim apparently is to buy him a little time to take the most urgent measures to get his country back under control, with the hope that public pressure will insure that whatever he does he does quickly and then restores democracy.
The O.A.S. resolution passed tonight with 31 of the 34 member nations voting in favor. Two were absent and Peru abstained. It "greatly deplored" Mr. Fujimori's dissolution of Peru's Congress and other democratic institutions and called for their immediate restoration. It also called for the freeing of political prisoners and the dispatch of an O.A.S. mission to Lima headed by Secretary General Joao Baena Soares to help Mr. Fujimori find a way out of the crisis and to explain the consequences if he does not.
The tension in the Bush Administration policy between needing to uphold democratic values but not wanting to do it in a way that would play into the hands of antidemocratic forces or further undermine Mr. Fujimori was reflected throughout Mr. Baker's speech to the foreign ministers of the O.A.S. meeting at its Washington headquarters.
"Today we meet because of the recent tragic events in a great and proud member of this organization, Peru," Mr. Baker said. "I use the word 'tragic' because no nation and no people face a more daunting, dangerous, or terrible set of crises than those inherited by the new democratic Government of Peru less than two years ago.
"No nation and no people need and deserve international solidarity and support more than the Peruvian nation and the Peruvian people," he said. "They confront the deepest economic crisis of their history, the violence and corruption of narcotrafficking, and the most murderous and dangerous terrorist movement that has ever appeared in Latin America."
Mr. Baker added that to the "immense credit" of Peru its Government had carried out a difficult "but courageous" process of economic reform, which had begun to reopen long-closed avenues to new lending from the international financial community.
But Mr. Baker said: "The actions taken by President Fujimori, whatever the justification given, are unjustified. They represent an assault on democracy that cannot and will not be supported by the United States of America. And therefore we have suspended all new assistance to the Government of Peru, and we will continue to do so until constitutional democracy is restored."
"All of us recognize that democracy can be inefficient," Mr. Baker said "All of us recognize that democracy can be slow, and all of us recognize that democracy can be frustrating. But there is no alternative. You cannot destroy democracy in order to save it.
"The only long-term beneficiaries of this assault on democracy in Peru will be those very terrorists and guerrillas who falsely argue that violence is the solution to the problems of the Peruvian people."
Referring to an announcement by Mr. Fujimori on Sunday night that he would hold a plebiscite within six months to begin restoring democracy, Mr. Baker said, "Let me say to our distinguished colleague, the Foreign Minister of Peru, we welcome the initial steps that you have mentioned in your presentation today which have been taken toward the restoration of democracy."
The O.A.S. initially adopted a restrained resolution toward Haiti after military rebels there ousted President Jean Bertrand Aristides last fall, but it quickly followed that up with a resolution imposing economic sanctions. On Friday, Mr. Bush said he would be ready to consider such sanctions against Peru. But O.A.S. officials said there was no consensus in the group for taking such tough actions against a democratically elected President who was suspending his own democracy to deal with corruption and challenges from both drug traffickers and guerrillas.
The O.A.S. members refused a request from an anti-Fujimori delegation to be allowed to occupy Peru's seat at the meeting.
The Peruvian Foreign Minister, Augusto Blacker Miller, made a passionate appeal to give Mr. Fujimori a chance, saying that the Peruvian Congress had systematically deprived his Government of all the tools necessary to deal with the poverty, corruption and political violence in his country.
Mr. Miller insisted that President Fujimori had pledged to allow Peruvians to express their opinions about his policies through plebiscites, adding, "Peru has suspended certain articles of the Constitution but has not suspended the democratic process."
Mr. Baker's public advice to Mr. Fujimori was to release those in detention, fully restore freedom of the press and all other constitutional liberties, initiate national discussions involving all Peruvian democratic groups and re-establish constitutional democracy immediately.

Car Bomb Kills Four
LIMA, Peru, April 13 (Special to The New York Times) -- Urban guerrillas set off a large car bomb near a police station in the Lima suburb of Callao early today, killing four and wounding at least 20.
The 2 A.M. explosion, which heavily damaged an apartment building, was at least the 10th guerrilla attack since President K. Fujimori seized expanded powers eight days ago with the promise to eradicate the rebel movement by the time his term ends in 1995.
The Peruvian Congress, which was dissolved by the President, met today for the second time in a week. More than 100 members of the House of Deputies and 38 members of the Senate met for more than an hour and railed against Mr. Fujimori, calling him a dictator. Some said that there should be no negotiations over the current crisis with the President.
On April 5, Mr. Fujimori announced that he had dissolved Congress and the judiciary branch, suspended the Constitution and placed many lawmakers and journalists under arrest.
All the lawmakers and journalists have been released. But one official of the opposition Apra party, Agustin Mantilla, remains in jail, charged with having a large cache of weapons in his home.

GAUGING THE THREAT OF TB PATIENTS
As tuberculosis has made a comeback, especially among homeless people and those infected with the virus that causes AIDS, states are grappling with ways to deal with problem patients like Milton A. Ellison. Mr. Ellison, a 34-year-old homeless man from New York City, has repeatedly failed to take the medicine that he needs.  Despite the absence of a death-penalty law in New York State, a reputed Mafia member could face execution if convicted in a Federal narcotics and murder trial that is beginning in Brooklyn. HEADLINE: East European Bank Is Split on Its Future

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, April 13

 BODY:
The London-based bank established to foster private investment in Eastern Europe agreed today to study an expansion of its role there, but put off any decision on broadening its financing abilities, after sharp United States objections.
The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development was set up a year ago to provide market-rate loans and equity investments aimed at spurring the growth of private enterprise in Eastern Europe. 
 But Jacques Attali, the bank's French president, wants to expand the institution's role by offering credit on concessionary terms for the restructuring of the poorest economies of the former Soviet bloc and the conversion of military factories to civilian ends.
Nicholas F. Brady, the United States Treasury Secretary, objected, saying an expansion of the bank's role could lead it to clash with the World Bank and other United States-based international financial organizations.
The compromise reached today, after a meeting on Sunday between Mr. Attali and Mr. Brady, was that the proposal should be studied. No time limit was set for this examination.

HEADLINE: C.I.A. Chief Says Focus Will Shift to Economics

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, said today that the Bush Administration had directed that nearly 40 percent of the new tasks of the country's intelligence agencies would involve international economics.
Mr. Gates said a national security review "highlighted the dramatic increased importance of international economic affairs as an intelligence issue." The extensive review, conducted by 14 task forces, envisioned a reshaping of the nation's intelligence priorities through the year 2005. 
 President Bush has approved the recommendations, Mark Mansfield, a spokesman for the C.I.A., said.
In a speech to the Economic Club of Detroit, Mr. Gates said: "Nearly 40 percent of the new requirements are economic in nature. The most senior policy makers of the Government clearly see that many of the most important challenges and opportunities through and beyond the end of this decade are in the international economic arena, and they have fleshed out that insight with a detailed set of requirements for the intelligence community."
The intelligence agencies will also step up efforts to monitor trends in technology that could affect national security and economic competitiveness, he said.

HEADLINE: In Liberia's Illusory Peace, Rebel Leader Rules Empire of His Own Design

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GBARNGA, Liberia

 BODY:
Only the legions of edgy and heavily armed guards at checkpoints leading to this sleepy village give any hint of the grand ambitions envisioned here. For if the guerrilla leader Charles Taylor has his way, this remote outpost will become the strategic center of a vast military and administrative empire.
Already nearly 95 percent of Liberia, the West African nation founded by freed American slaves, is in effect run from Gbarnga by Mr. Taylor's forces. The area has its own currency and banking system, an international airfield, a thriving export trade in diamonds, gold, rubber and timber -- even its own radio and television network. 
 By contrast, Monrovia, Liberia's capital and its once-bustling political and economic center, about 120 miles to the south, is on the verge of ruin.
The capital is administered by an interim government that was installed by West African nations in the autumn of 1990 as part of a regional peace plan.
But these days, Monrovia is on its knees. Were it not for the efforts of the United Nations, Catholic Relief Services and other foreign aid agencies, there would be no electricity, running water or food for most of the 500,000 people.
 
Shadows of Violence
 The situation in Liberia, a nation of about two and a half million, might be regarded as a peculiarity, attracting little international attention, were it not for the threat of still another armed conflict on a continent racked by insurgencies and instability.
Many African and Western analysts believe that Mr. Taylor, who is 44 years old, has been associated with terrorist attacks and anti-government insurgencies in the neighboring nations of Sierra Leone, Guinea and Gambia.
And in the flurry of military activity, recent reports say hundreds of civilians may have been killed in the cross-fire and thousands displaced. There is little sign of peace soon.
"Effectively, Charles Taylor's control over most of Liberia creates a new nation in the region," said Makau wa Mutua, director of the human rights program at Harvard Law School.
"This situation is most tragic," he said, "because the West, which is consumed by changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, has abandoned this small nation as its social and political fabric slowly dies."
 
Accomplishments, as Well
 Perhaps foremost among Mr. Taylor's accomplishments is that he has been able to do so much in two and a half years. The rebel leader, who insists that he be addressed as President Taylor, has never run for office. If elections are again organized, he says, he would be willing to take part, but only as the incumbent president.
Mr. Taylor has built his domain despite the apparent opposition of much of the population. And leaders of the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States, a trading consortium with a military contingent, have repeatedly called on Mr. Taylor to disarm his troops and allow their 7,000-member peace force to enter his territory, a request he has largely ignored.
More recently, the United Nations suspended a $130 million food-distribution program in territory controlled by Mr. Taylor, charging continued harassment of aid workers at checkpoints and the confiscation of relief vehicles.
In December, a United Nations relief aide from Europe was pistol-whipped by Taylor soldiers, and a number of workers have been arrested and detained on allegations of spying.
Aid officials say they have been particularly angered by Mr. Taylor's insistence that food and other supplies be shipped only through the port of Buchanan, which is controlled by his forces, rather than through the much larger port at Monrovia.
"Taylor rules by terror and intimidation," a relief worker said, "and most of us feel it's not worth risking our lives in that kind of situation. One reason Taylor is getting away with it, is most people are afraid to travel up there anymore. It's just too volatile."
 
Flight to and From U.S.
 As a student at Bentley College, near Boston, Mr. Taylor helped organize Liberians in the United States to oppose President William R. Tolbert Jr., whose Government, like its predecessors, was dominated by a minority group of descendants of freed American slaves who migrated to Liberia in the early part of the 19th century.
When Master Sgt. Samuel K. Doe overthrew President Tolbert in 1980, Mr. Taylor returned to Liberia to join the new leadership.
But in 1983, after falling out with Sergeant Doe, by then Liberia's head of state, he fled to the United States. The Liberians sought his extradition on charges that he had diverted $900,000 in Government funds, and a court in Boston found sufficient grounds to detain him. In 1985, while awaiting extradition, Mr. Taylor broke out of jail.
Over the next five years, his whereabouts were largely unknown. According to Liberian and American authorities, he spent much of this period in Libya as the guest of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
In December 1989, Mr. Taylor and about 100 guerrillas invaded northern Liberia from the Ivory Coast. The insurgency gained momentum, even while splitting bitterly into rival factions.
Eventually, a former Taylor follower, Prince Johnson, captured, tortured and killed President Doe.
A five-nation West African force intervened, saying the war was no longer an internal conflict because thousands of their citizens were trapped in Liberia and an estimated half-million Liberians had fled to neighboring countries. Altogether, nearly half of Liberia's people were uprooted, and an estimated 20,000 died.
In October 1990, the West African group formed an interim government headed by Amos Sawyer, a former university professor.
But Mr. Taylor refused to recognize Mr. Sawyer's government, defiantly moving his military and administrative operations here, designating Gbarnga as Liberia's capital and effectively partitioning the country.
Superficially at least, Gbarnga seems far removed from the social and economic chaos that engulfs Monrovia.
The Taylor government, which now calls itself the National Patriotic Reconstruction Assembly, has spent lavishly to create a version of a well-planned bureaucracy. On nearly every corner, signs direct visitors to ministry offices. But often, these are little more than one-room shacks staffed by untrained and illiterate people.
 
The Warrior<He>
The sense of unreality is heightened by hundreds of posters and paintings of Charles Taylor: Sometimes he is dressed in traditional West African garb, wearing a white cap and a flowing gown; in other pictures, he is in a jacket and tie, staring defiantly or posing with foreign dignitaries.
Recently, Mr. Taylor's face has begun to appear with the word "ghankay" written in bold letters underneath. Ghankay means warrior in Gola, one of Liberia's main languages.
Mr. Taylor has denounced Liberia's new "Liberty" $5 bill, first minted in January by the central bank in Monrovia, and prohibits its use in the area he controls; only the old bill is legal tender. He levies a fine equivalent to $3,000 on anyone caught carrying Liberty notes in his territory.
The American dollar is still accepted on both sides, but the exchange rate varies. While the official rate remains one Liberian dollar for one American dollar, in Monrovia the black market pays five to eight Liberian dollars for an American one, and in the Taylor area, the black market gives three to five dollars for an American one.
If many Liberians find doing business in Mr. Taylor's territory hard, the experience of foreigners has been quite different. Liberian-American Mining Company, one of the region's biggest iron-ore producers, has resumed exports to Europe.
 
Riches and Troops
 Analysts in this country say that Mr. Taylor has granted lucrative concessions to a number of foreign diamond and gold exporters, particularly from Germany and France. Now, the taxes and export duties from timber, rubber and mining operations -- which once flowed to the central government -- are controlled by him.
No one knows for sure how many troops Mr. Taylor has, but most analysts say perhaps 10,000. They are a menacing force. Dozens of soldiers, sometimes boys as young as 9 or 10, carry machine guns at the checkpoints.
Mr. Taylor is fighting a threat from a rebel movement including former members of President Doe's army and the Mandingo ethnic group, which in recent weeks have engaged his forces along the Sierra Leone border.
In December, a study of his territory by the Lawyers' Committee for Human Rights, an advocacy group based in New York, found "reports of widespread physical attacks against civilians, including the rape of young women," at the checkpoints.
A similar report in October 1991 by Africa Watch said "dissent is not tolerated" in these areas, "creating fear and uncertainty among the civilian population."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week;
Bush and Clinton Share Win-at-All-Cost Image

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
With white eyes, black teeth and a porcupine shaft of hair, Bill Clinton stares ferally from the cover of this week's Time magazine.
The photo negative of Mr. Clinton, making him look like an alien from a 1950's sci-fi horror movie, and the cover line, "Why Voters Don't Trust Clinton," are the latest jolts to a campaign that is struggling grimly -- and hoarsely -- onward. 
 Mr. Clinton, a man who likes to talk, is still not able to talk, and his doctor forced him to cancel a major speech on economics scheduled for Tuesday at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.
Into the vacuum rushes a torrent of advice about what the likely Democratic Presidential nominee must do next. Some say he should deliver a modern "Checkers" speech, putting the character questions on the table. But for the moment, the Clinton camp is leaning against such an idea, saying that it would do more harm than good. Mea culpas on specifics are one thing, Clinton advisers say, but a blank-check apologia on the general topic of trust might be too much even for a deft politician like Mr. Clinton to pull off.
So, instead, he will try to act Presidential and talk about real change while George Bush tries to act Presidential and talk about real change.
In urging his re-election last week, President Bush redefined political chutzpah when he noted, "I think the people want change."
Although everyone is chattering about change, it is the similarities between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Bush that are in sharp relief at the moment.
If Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York had run against Mr. Bush, the race would have been a study in contrasts. The lower-class kid from Queens against the preppy from Kennebunkport, Me.
The brooding, intellectual Governor who likes to read and think and sleep in his own bed versus the buoyant, frenetic President who hates introspection and sleeping in his own bed if there's anywhere fun to travel. The liberal who is not afraid to defend welfare versus the conservative-manque who wants to cut welfare payments.
Similarly, Edmund G. Brown Jr. or Paul E. Tsongas would have offered something very different to voters disillusioned with Mr. Bush. But the Arkansas Governor and the President sometimes seem sketched with lines that offer the same basic curves.
They are both seen as men who want to win people over, at any cost. They are both seen as men who hate conflict, avoid confrontation and govern by compromise. They are both men of great charm who build networks of useful friends and make politics intensely personal. They are both men of enormous ambition, softened by amiable, caring facades, who sometimes give the impression of being manufactured because they have shifted stances out of expediency.
They are both willing to stoop to conquer. Before Jewish groups in New York, Mr. Clinton never seemed to mention his belief that West Bank settlements were an obstacle to peace, while his support for Israel shined especially brightly. Mr. Bush, who gave a sop to the right today by trying to curb unions' spending on political activities, is off to Michigan on Tuesday to court the Reagan Democrats of Macomb County and make car makers happy by announcing a veto of new pollution standards.
They are both married to strong, savvy women and yet they both enjoy the "good old boy" comfort level provided by campaign inner circles made up largely of white men. Sometimes the eagerness to make the right contacts leads them to give signals that many consider offensive: Mr. Clinton gave no more thought to playing golf for years at an all-white Arkansas club than Mr. Bush does to belonging to three all-male clubs.
Most damning, they are both seen as men who will do anything to be in the Oval Office, and one of the major themes that will begin playing out this week is their struggle to see who can make himself seem most genuine.
Even the generational energy that ought to work in Mr. Clinton's favor against the last President of the World War II generation is being dissipated by his ambiguous handling of the draft and marijuana.
Just as they talk about the many faces of George Bush -- the President looked like an alien on the cover of Time magazine last year in a picture that gave him two faces on one neck -- now they talk about the many faces of Bill Clinton.
Just as they once asked, "Who is the real George Bush?" now they ask, "Who is the real Bill Clinton?"
In the summer of 1988, when he was asked how he would turn around his bad image -- he was running 17 points behind Michael S. Dukakis at that point -- a grumpy but steely George Bush replied that he would win the election because he had friends.
Now Bill Clinton is hoping for the same salvation. Ever since New Hampshire, the Clinton campaign has been peppering the landscape with Clinton friends, some on the scene, available to spin reporters at campaign stops, and some defending the candidate in print and by telephone.
The campaign even took a full-page advertisement in The Manchester Union Leader during the first primary, listing more than a hundred names of Clinton allies, many of them state employees, who were available to take calls from voters with doubts and tell them what a great guy Bill is.
With the odds uncertain on his chances of beating George Bush, Mr. Clinton is once again desperately hoping that the people who trust him can help convert the people who don't.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidate's Health;
Laryngitis Silences Clinton Another Day

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
A common occupational hazard for politicians, chronic laryngitis from speaking too much, forced Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas to cancel a major economic address he had planned to give Tuesday in Pennsylvania, his staff said tonight.
Last week Mr. Clinton's personal doctor, Dr. James Suen, prescribed several days of silence for the Democratic Presidential candidate because he had overused his voice. After examining Mr. Clinton today, he recommended another day of rest. 
 "There was improvement from last week, but he still has some swelling of his vocal cords," Dr. Suen said.
George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's deputy campaign manager, said: "The doctor simply said if you go to work tomorrow, you undermine four days of rest. If you take one more day off, it's all the difference."
The raspy voices that are so common among politicians come from swelling and bleeding that damage the vocal cords. If the irritation persists for long periods, nodules, which are small growths on the vocal cords, can develop.
Laryngitis is generally not serious. But the swelling can sometimes interfere with breathing, and occasionally with eating.
Although the main culprit is simple overuse of the voice box, or larynx, and the muscles that control it, several other factors can aggravate chronic laryngitis.
One is dehydration. Another is anxiety, which can make the vocal cords tense. A third is continued irritation from things like cigarettes and pipes in smoky rooms. Colds and respiratory infections are also factors.
But one of the worst offenders is what specialists call the Lombard effect.
"The noisier the background environment, the more we tend to raise our voices to hear ourselves talk, and we don't even realize it," said Dr. David R. Edelstein, an ear, nose and throat specialist in New York.
The standard treatment for chronic laryngitis is resting the voice, drinking lots of fluid and using humidifiers. Sometimes doctors prescribe steroids for an acute episode, but they are not inclined to do that on a long-term basis because stomach ulcers, bone thinning and other complications can result.
The usual prescription is absolute voice rest for one to two weeks, with relative voice rest for an additional period, said Dr. Edelstein, who is an attending physician at Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital in New York but is not associated with Mr. Clinton's case.
Dr. Suen said he advised Mr. Clinton "to avoid overuse of his voice during the campaign."
But while such prescriptions are easy to write, politicians often find them hard to fill.

HEADLINE: Japan's Trade Surplus Rises

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 13

 BODY:
Japan's trade surplus rose by 29 percent to a record level in March, its 15th consecutive month of increase from levels a year earlier, the Finance Ministry reported today.
But for the first time in eight months, Japan's surplus with the United States declined from a year earlier, as Japan bought $337.45 million worth of American aircraft. 
 For the 1991 fiscal year, which ended on March 31, Japan's global surplus rose by 63 percent, to $88.35 billion, the second-largest surplus for any fiscal year, the ministry said.
Japan's surplus with the United States climbed 1.0 percent, to $38.46 billion, for the fiscal year. But for March alone, Japan posted a surplus of $3.16 billion with the United States, down 17 percent from the previous March.
Japan has worried that the surplus, already a point of friction with the United States, may become a more sensitive subject as campaigners in the American Presidential election emphasize economic issues.
There have also been suggestions that Japanese companies may aggressively promote exports to overcome effects of this country's economic slowdown.
Finance Ministry aides told a press briefing that they did not expect any rapid increase in Japan's surplus in the coming months. They said that many Japanese companies had moved production abroad and that the Government had announced measures to stimulate demand at home with an eye to promoting imports.
In March, Japan's global surplus totaled $10.99 billion, surpassing the previous monthly record of $10.43 billion set in February.

HEADLINE: Hueytown Journal;
Humming Along, and Howling Mad

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HUEYTOWN, Ala., April 7

 BODY:
For the last four months a loud hum that comes and goes erratically has bedeviled parts of this central Alabama city, keeping people awake and setting teeth on edge and dogs to howling.
It's called the Hueytown Hum, a low-pitched, steady sound emanating from the rolling hills surrounding this coal mining town of 15,000 people about 15 miles southwest of Birmingham. The hum, has turned bucolic subdivisions with names like Edenwood and Lakeview into zones of stress for up to three days at a time before fading away, only to return an hour or a week later. 
 "I catch myself trying to breath in time with its rise and fall in pitch," said an exasperated Jane Harless. And the sound has disoriented beast and man alike. "My dog Princess won't eat when it's going," she said.
Savina Bradberry, a high school math teacher, said it sounds like "the hum of a fluorescent light tube about to go."
The hum has led to jokes and numerous theories about its source.
In a broadcast from the steps of City Hall on April 1, a local radio station solicited tongue-in-cheek theories. Hueytown was humming because it didn't know the words, one listener suggested. Another said it was killer bees.
More serious theories involve electro-magnetic forces and high-voltage power lines.
The mystery is made more elusive by the fact that one area, with about 500 homes, seems to be most affected.
Such focused sound phenomena are not unheard of, said Clifford Bragdon, a professor of city planning at Georgia Institute of Technology and an expert on sound propagation.
Some years ago, Mr. Bragdon said, two communities 10 to 17 miles from the Aberdeen Proving Ground, an Army ordnance test center in Maryland, complained of noise from the tests, while communities adjacent to the base were barely disturbed.
What researchers eventually found, he said, was "an atmospheric anomaly" involving the interaction of temperature, humidity, barometric pressure, wind and topography that was "propagating, channeling and focusing" the sound to a point miles from the source.
"People try to get at these things by using the classical visual approach," the professor said. "But you need an acoustical Sherlock Holmes to solve things like this."
Using more circumstantial evidence, some residents have focused on the huge ventilation fans that have been installed in nearby coal mines. Federal safety regulations require that the fans be operated around the clock to pull methane gas and coal dust from the mines.
The USX Corporation's Oak Grove mines, 10 miles west of here, have five such fans, but a USX spokesman, Steve Sobat, said company engineers determined that its fans were not causing the hum. He conceded, however, that the clearing last year of timber from a USX-owned pine forest that had served as a buffer between Hueytown and the mines could have contributed to the problem.
Just south of USX's mines, Jim Walter Resources Inc. operates a mine that has three fans, one of which is a 3,500-horsepower monster with 12-foot blades. The $7 million fan went into operation last December, at about the time Hueytown residents recall first hearing the hum.
Dennis K. Hall, director of public relations for Jim Walter Resources, said the company was cooperating with Hueytown officials to resolve the mystery. But he added that any additional company expenditure in the effort, including hiring outside experts, would require the approval of a bankruptcy court that is supervising the mining operation while Jim Walter Resources reorganizes under Chapter 11.
Jim Walter is a major economic force in the area. Its mines extract 2.7 million tons of coal a year and a billion cubic feet of methane a month from the hills around Hueytown. The company employs 657 people here and pumps $41 million a year in wages and benefits into the local economy.
"We don't want to point any fingers," said Mayor Lillian Howard. "This area was built on money from the mines, and we have been around these fans all of our lives. We'll work this out together with the companies so it won't be a choice between the hum or jobs."

GRAPHIC: Map of Alabama showing location of Hueytown.
