HEADLINE: SANCTIONS ON LIBYA BEGIN TO TAKE HOLD AS DEADLINE PASSES

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Wednesday, April 15

 BODY:
Air transport links with Libya were cut, and United Nations sanctions took effect today against Libya for its refusal to hand over two of its citizens accused of blowing up a Pan Am airliner in 1988.
The banning of all flights is the most dramatic part of a United Nations sanctions package that also prohibits the sale of arms, aircraft and spare parts while requiring overseas offices of Libya's national airline to close. The Security Council's action requires all countries to reduce the size of Libyan embassies and restrict the movements of Libyan diplomats. 
 The sanctions are the first such punitive attempt to isolate a nation from the rest of the world. Their imposition came Tuesday, at the end of a day in which the World Court rejected a Libyan appeal to declare the restrictions invalid.
 
Effects Still Unknown
 It is not clear what impact the cut in air links will have. Egyptian, Tunisian and Maltese entrepreneurs are setting up alternative means of travel, including new bus and air routes, that meet the letter if not the spirit of the embargo. [Page A6.]
Tuesday, in an act of protest, Libya cut itself off from the outside world as it observed a day of mourning for victims of the 1986 United States bombing raid. That raid came in retaliation for what Washington called Libya's involvement in the destruction of a Berlin nightclub used by American servicemen. Among the 37 Libyans killed in the raids was the adopted daughter of Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
All telephone, telegraph and postal communications were cut and travel to and from the country by air, land and sea was halted for 24 hours, so there was no official Libyan reaction to the World Court ruling or the sanctions. But just hours before Libya shut itself down, Colonel Qaddafi's chief lieutenant, Abdul-Salam Jalloud, vowed that it "will never give up its sons" and urged Arabs to ignore the sanctions.
 
Defiance From Libya
 He told a convention of Arab labor leaders, "Libya cannot be humiliated and its dignity and sovereignty cannot be violated."
[ Reuters reported from Tripoli that when the 24-hour self-imposed isolation ended, hundreds of Libyan citizens took to the streets, chanting anti-Western slogans including, "We are ready for confrontation" and "We don't fear the United States."]
Under the terms of the Security Council action, the sanctions cannot be lifted until Libya takes "concrete actions" to show that it has renounced terrorism beyond handing over suspects in two air disasters. Libya has refused to turn over to Britain or the United States two men suspected in the explosion of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in which 270 people were killed, and has refused to send four other Libyans to France for questioning in connection with the downing of a French airliner over West Africa in 1989, with the loss of 171 lives.
In moving against Libya, the Council balked at banning the sale of oil, on which Libya's economy depends, after major European customers including Italy, Germany and Spain said they could not easily change suppliers.
A last-minute bid by Morocco, the only Arab country on the Security Council, to postpone sanctions to allow the Arab League to negotiate a compromise with Libya was rejected by the Council Tuesday afternoon, just hours before the deadline of midnight New York time, or 6 A.M. in Tripoli. Britain's representative, Sir David Hannay, said the Council "did not agree that a case had been made for delay."
 
Compliance Not Expected
 France's representative, Jean-Bernard Merimee, said: "Libya has practically ignored the Council. Maybe they did not realize the Council meant business, but we did."
He added, "There have been many negotiations, and these efforts have not been met by equal good will."
Libya also offered a last-minute compromise, saying it was ready to hand over the two suspects for trial by a court on the Mediterranean island of Malta, with whose Government Libya has good relations. But the United States and Britain rejected the idea.
"It falls short," the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said Tuesday in Washington. "It does not meet the requirements of compliance. And Libya knows very well what it has to do in order to meet compliance."
 
Arab League Attempts
 Since the Security Council moved against Libya in January, the Arab League has been trying to negotiate a compromise under which Libya would surrender the suspects to the United Nations or some other third party. Diplomats have said that they assume Libya does not want the two tried in a Western country because the suspects might defend themselves by implicating other more senior Government officials in the bombings.
Although the Security Council voted unanimously to order Libya to hand over the two suspects in the Pan Am bombing and to cooperate with the French investigation, the move to impose sanctions has divided Council members, with China, Morocco, India, Cape Verde and Zimbabwe abstaining in the vote.
Nevertheless, China was not prepared to put its relations with the United States, Britain and France at risk by exercising its veto as a permanent Security Council member. And none of the other opponents of sanctions went so far as to cast a negative vote.
Meanwhile, the United States, Britain and France stepped up their pressure on President Saddam Hussein Tuesday, warning him that their warplanes will start attacking anti-aircraft missile batteries he recently moved into northern Iraq unless they are withdrawn immediately and Iraq stops tracking allied air patrols on radar.
They also told Baghdad to lift the economic blockade it has been imposing on the northern Kurds since last October and stop shelling Kurdish strongholds as well as dissident Shiite groups hiding out in the vast marshlands of southern Iraq near the Iranian border.
In its earlier effort to head off sanctions, Libya appealed to the International Court of Justice in the Hague for an injunction against the United States and Britain to prevent any action to compel it to surrender the accused to foreign courts.
But the Court's 16 judges voted 11 to 5 on Tuesday to reject Libya's application.
Libya had argued that American and British pressure to surrender the two suspects violated the 1971 Montreal Convention on air safety to which these countries belong. But the Court said that the Security Council's orders override provisions of that convention.
The judges appointed by the United States, Britain, France, Russia, China, Japan, Poland, Italy, Norway, Guyana and Venezuela all voted to reject Libya's appeal, while those from Algeria, Sri Lanka, Madagascar, Nigeria and Libya itself voted in favor of the application.
The Bush Administration welcomed the verdict, which may also help make the sanctions slightly more palatable to Council's Arab and third world members, most of whom abstained in a critical vote earlier this year.
President Bush, in Detroit Tuesday, called the verdict "good news."
 In fact, Libyan residents will still be able to leave the country relatively easily by driving to neighboring Egypt and Tunis and picking up flights there. Egypt plans to allow Libyans to drive to the airport at the beach resort of Sidi Barrani 45 miles from the Libyan border and fly from there to Cairo International Airport. A regular ferry service also links Libya with Malta.
At Tripoli airport on Monday hundreds of foreigners lined up at counters for flights to Malta and Germany, the only destinations available. About 1,000 Americans and 10,000 Europeans now work in Libya, most of them in jobs connected with its oil industry. The airport in Tripoli reopened Tuesday evening but no international flights landed during the night.
The United States has already cut its air links with Libya. But Alitalia, Lufthansa and British Airways all fly to Tripoli from Europe. Lufthansa said it stopped issuing tickets for Libya to passengers in New York in 1989 requiring them to buy their tickets in Canada or Europe. Alitalia's New York office said Tuesday night it had received no instructions to stop issuing tickets for Tripoli.

HEADLINE: Union Agrees To End Strike At Caterpillar

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., April 14

 BODY:
The United Automobile Workers union unexpectedly agreed tonight to end a five-month-old strike against Caterpillar Inc. that had left more than 12,000 workers walking the picket lines.
The accord was widely seen as a setback for the union, which until Monday had characterized the company's offer as a "mean-spirited proposal." 
 Caterpillar, the world's largest manufacturer of construction equipment, agreed to end its efforts to hire replacement workers, and the union agreed to urge its members to return to their jobs.
 
Talks to Continue
 In a crucial provision that was recommended by a Federal mediator, both sides agreed that the employees would work under the terms of the contract proposed by Caterpillar and that negotiations for a new contract would go on.
The talks will continue to be conducted under the auspices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, which had brought the company and the union together for talks that began Monday in Hinsdale, Ill.
The agreement today is a milestone in a labor dispute that has commanded wide attention. The company's threat to replace the 12,600 striking U.A.W. members permanently if they failed to report to work by April 6 was widely seen as a new stage in the attack on unions by corporations. Never before had an industrial giant like Caterpillar tried to permanently replace thousands of union workers.
Caterpillar has offered a contract that will raise the salary of top workers to $39,000 in 1994 from the current $35,000. But the union is seeking the same top wage of $40,000 that will be paid workers at Deere & Company in 1994. In this the U.A.W. is practicing pattern bargaining, in which unions negotiate similar contracts with a number of companies within the same industry.
But Caterpillar is trying to break away from the practice, saying it cannot afford to keep matching Deere's wages because it would render the company less competitive globally.
 
Pressures on Both Sides
 Caterpillar makes 75 percent of its products in the United States and exports 59 percent of them, making it second only to The Boeing Company among industrial exporters.
The agreement was reached because it was widely believed that union leaders sensed an erosion in the resolve of their members to continue walking the picket line. Indeed, many striking workers here and at other Caterpillar plants had planned to cross the picket line if an agreement was not reached within about a week.
On the other hand, Caterpillar management had also begun to feel intense pressure. Industry analysts insisted that the company's inventories had reached perilously low levels and that the company was beginning to fill orders with production from its plants in Europe and Japan.
Many union members here were dismayed by the prospect of working under a contract that their leaders had rejected only a day before.
"I think it's going to create a lot of bad feelings," said Donald Carter, a 45-year-old machine operator who has worked at Caterpillar for 17 years. "These guys have been walking the picket line for months and they're going back for what's been on the table all the time."
 
Working Again, but When?
 Despite tonight's agreement, there were several points of confusion, primarily on when the workers would be expected to return to their jobs. At first, the U.A.W.'s secretary-treasurer, Bill Casstevens, said the union would urge all strikers to return to their jobs "immediately at their next regular shift."
Caterpillar executives later said they needed time to assess how quickly they could bring the workers back, since several manufacturing procedures had been modified during the strike. The company repeated that it was considering reducing its work force by 10 percent to 15 percent and said it would mail letters to workers informing them of when they would be expected to return.
For its part, the union said it retained the right to walk out again if negotiations fail to produce a satisfactory contract. Mr. Casstevens emphasized that the union was still seeking to reach an agreement that it considered more generous than the package offered by Caterpillar.
Mr. Casstevens denied that the agreement was a setback, saying: "There are no replacement workers that will be hired. We're not going to be negotiating on the company's last offer. We're going to negotiate on our own offer."
 
Triumph for Mediator
 The agreement represents a triumph for Bernard E. DeLury, director of the Federal agency that mediated the dispute. Mr. DeLury personally interceded to bring the two sides together, saying it was important to have such an important union and major manufacturer together and avoid a showdown.
"I feel good about it," Mr. DeLury said after the meeting. "It feels good when you can get 12,000 men and women back to work." He said that he would call another round of meetings to negotiate a new contract some time next week.
"They both need some time to let the dust settle a bit," Mr. DeLury said. "We'll take it step by step."
The strike, which began after the union rejected what Caterpillar called its last offer, has drawn nationwide attention because of the company's threat to replace the strikers permanently. If that threat had been carried out, the U.A.W.'s bargaining positions in negotiations next year with General Motors, Ford and Chrysler could have weakened.
Caterpillar began testing applicants yesterday for the strikers' jobs at an office on the northern outskirts of Peoria, several miles from where strikers were picketing.
While strikers had felt the strain of the labor dispute, the company was also apparently in a predicament. John A. Stark, editor of Stark's Off-Highway Ledger, a newsletter of the construction machinery industry, said Caterpillar's inventories were running low. "Their inventory window has become so narrow that they've had to shift some of their production to Caterpillar plants in Japan and Europe," Mr. Stark said. The company had declined to comment on either inventories or its production levels.
Mr. Stark said Caterpillar was eager to resume full production to take advantage of the expected pick up in the American economy and higher demand for construction machinery that is anticipated for the rest of this year. "History has shown that the most profitable period for a machinery company is in the early stages of an upturn," he said, "because customers have so much pent-up demand that they are eager to fill."
Some labor and management experts called tonight's agreement a standoff.
"The union was under tremendous pressure because more and more of the rank and file were thinking about crossing the picket lines and going back to work," said Edward L. Sattler, an economics professor at Bradley University here. "This agreement will quiet the discontent of the work force and give union leaders a chance to buy some time. It's a face-saving agreement for both sides."
 
'We're Pleased'
 At Caterpillar's headquarters downtown, Gerald S. Flaherty, a company group president, said: "We're pleased that our employees are coming back to work under an offer that is fair and will allow Caterpillar to remain globally competitive." He said the agreement was "good for our employees, good for Caterpillar and good for the communities in which we live and work."
While Caterpillar has agreed to end its efforts to hire replacement workers, the company emphasized that it will continue to honor its commitment to test and interview various applicants who have already been scheduled for interviews. Mr. Flaherty said the company expected to notify workers within the next few days when they should return.
"We need to evaluate what our work force needs are," said Gilbert Nolde, a Caterpillar spokesman. "This has caught us by surprise, too."

HEADLINE: CABINET IN RUSSIA WON'T STEP DOWN

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 14

 BODY:
The Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin and the Russian Parliament drew back today from a conflict that had threatened Mr. Yeltsin's program of economic reform.
The confrontation, watched anxiously by the West, was tentatively defused when the Congress of People's Deputies adopted "in principle" a declaration of support for economic reform. The compromise measure, prepared by Government officials and congressional leaders, effectively neutralized the most contentious provisions of a resolution the Congress of deputies adopted on Saturday.
 
Brady Sees 'Steps Backward'
 That resolution had prompted Deputy Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar, the chief architect of the Government's radical reform program, to lead the Cabinet in offering its collective resignation. In a statement made public on Monday, the ministers declared that the Congress's decision would inevitably lead to "a catastrophic decline in living standards, famine, social upheavals and chaos." 
 Gennadi Burbulis, Mr. Yeltsin's chief lieutenant, told reporters today that the new Congress declaration "eliminates the need for our resignation."
The struggle raised anxieties both inside and outside Russia. Western Governments watched carefully to see whether the conflict would unseat the economic reforms that are a prerequisite for billions of dollars in aid proposed by the West.
Visiting Moscow, the United States Secretary of the Treasury, Nicholas F. Brady, told reporters he had warned the Russians "that changes in the economic program by the Congress were steps backward, not forward."
If the economic program emerged largely in place, he added, the United States would still have the "confidence" to proceed with the aid.
Initial efforts to defuse the conflict failed on Monday when the Speaker of the Parliament, Ruslan Khasbulatov, issued a string of patronizing gibes that prompted the ministers to walk out.
The proceedings today opened with another brief clash as deputies backing the Government moved unsuccessfully to censure Mr. Khasbulatov. But efforts to calm the mood were evident from the outset, when Deputy Speaker Sergei Filatov took the chair instead of Mr. Khasbulatov.
The brief compromise declaration essentially took the steam out of Saturday's resolution without forcing the Congress to reverse its vote. It affirmed the legislature's support for Mr. Yeltsin's course of economic reform, and it said the Government should carry out the instructions of the Congress "taking into account real economic and social conditions."
That effectively leaves it to the Government to decide which measures it will adopt.
 
Yeltsin Stays Away
 The compromise also lifted an order to Mr. Yeltsin, who is his own Prime Minister, to propose a new premier within three months.
Mr. Yeltsin was once again absent from the Congress. He has not attended since the confrontation first began to take shape on Saturday, although he met this morning with his Cabinet. Rumors abounded that he would make an address, but as the compromise gained strength it appeared he preferred to maintain a statesmanlike distance.
Mr. Gaidar rose to speak in support of the resolution. He told deputies: "On the whole, I think this document would allow the executive branch to carry out further reforms."
But he also used the podium to swipe back at Mr. Khasbulatov's comments of the day before, when the Speaker had dismissed the Cabinet ministers as a bunch of disoriented youths.
"This is not a Government of capricious boys and girls," he said. "We are ready to work, but we need to have free hands and an honest economic policy."
Efforts to adopt the resolution directly, however, were voted down, and it was approved "in principle" -- meaning that the Congress could still vote amendments on Wednesday.
The resolution passed Saturday upset the Cabinet because it called for social and industrial spending that would work against the Government's stringent austerity program. The Congress, for example, asked for action to prop up declining industries, lower taxes and increase wages.
Mr. Gaidar's program has centered on restricting the money supply while letting prices rise in order to strengthen the ruble and prod market forces.
 
St. Petersburg Walkout
 The 1,024-member Congress is also plodding through a revised constitution article by article, and a battle over balance of powers is already being joined.
Even without Mr. Khasbulatov, tempers flared. One bizarre conflict erupted over a routine proposal to amend articles of the Constitution to read "St. Petersburg" instead of "Leningrad," reflecting the changed name of the city.
The change failed twice to muster the required two-thirds vote.
That roused the St. Petersburg delegates to stomp out in protest, declaring that they would not take part in the Congress until the name of their city was recognized.
Eventually the amendment passed, and the St. Petersburg legislators took their seats.
The struggle also spread beyond the Kremlin. Loud clutches of demonstrators gathered on opposite sides of St. Basil's Cathedral on Red Square, one group waving Russian flags and denouncing the Parliament, the other waving red Soviet flags and denouncing Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Gaidar.
The sides confirmed that the struggle is not only between a recalcitrant Legislature and an activist Government, but between the broad forces advocating change and those bemoaning the past.
Mr. Yeltsin, for his part, has his popularity in reserve. Since Saturday, he has remained above the fray and let his lieutenants and ministers battle it out. But there is little doubt in the corridors of the Kremlin that he would tap his considerable authority and popularity if that became necessary.

HEADLINE: CUNY Tuition Plan: A Big Jump in Cost But a Free Semester

BYLINE: By SAMUEL WEISS

 BODY:
The City University of New York is planning a major tuition increase next fall, but the rise is accompanied by a promise that if freshmen make it to their senior year they may attend their last semester before graduation free.
Educators say they believe the plan is the first of its kind in the nation and praised it as an innovative approach to the problems of retaining students and managing the rising cost of obtaining a college degree. 
 Faced with state budget cuts that would translate into an across-the-board tuition increase of $500 a year in the next school year, City University officials are proposing instead to assess the increase most heavily on freshmen. The university's chancellor, Dr. W. Ann Reynolds, has recommended that their annual tuition rise by $600 in the fall, to $2,450.
 
Internal Scholarship Fund
 That freshman class, which faces a 32 percent tuition increase at the system's 11 four-year colleges, would be the first to benefit from the university's plan to offer the last semester of instruction free. The tuition of upperclassmen and transfer students next year would rise by $350 a year, or 19 percent, to $2,200. In succeeding years, students who paid the higher tuition as freshmen would continue to pay it as sophomores, juniors and seniors, until all City University students paid that amount.
By the time they graduated, all students would have paid more than they do now, but less than they would have if the $500 tuition increase had been assessed across the board. Of course, the calculation does not take into account potential inflation or future tuition increases.
Educators said CUNY's plan effectively represented an internal scholarship fund -- or enforced savings plan -- to encourage the university's students, largely from working-class backgrounds, to finish their education.
City University officials said that more than 40 percent of baccalaureate candidates eventually get a degree, but that it takes many of them more than the customary four years to graduate. Because almost 60 percent of CUNY students never graduate, attrition would keep the number of free semesters much lower than the number of students in that year's freshman class.
The $600 increase would be the largest since the university began charging its students in 1976. But the free semester would recall the university's once-cherished policy of free tuition. The free semester portion of the plan would begin in 1996, 20 years after the university's 129-year-old policy of not charging tuition came to an end amid New York City's fiscal crisis.
Educators said yesterday that although a large number of schools have recently focused on keeping students, they had never heard of a university offering such a financial incentive for students to complete their degrees.
 
'It's a Novel Idea'
 "I think it's unique and unprecedented," said Dr. Ernest L. Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching and a former United States Commissioner of Education. "And at first glance, I think it's something very intriguing."
Dr. C. Peter McGrath, president of the National Association of State Universities and Land Grant Colleges, concurred. "It's a novel idea and I think its marvelous," he said, noting that it should help students persevere in their studies.
The proposal was approved on Monday by the university's fiscal affairs committee. University officials said yesterday the plan is expected to be approved by the university's full board of trustees when it meets on April 27.
CUNY officials said the graduation incentive would apply only to students completing bachelor's degrees at one of the university's 11 four-year colleges and not to students who earn associate degrees at its seven two-year community colleges. Students could take as long as they wanted to graduate, but they would be eligible for the incentive only once. If they did not graduate during the semester in which they were enrolled to complete their final credits toward their degree, they would have to resume paying tuition in following semesters.
Tuition at CUNY, with 200,000 students the nation's third-largest university system after the State University of New York and the California State University system, has risen by almost 50 percent in the last two years, resulting in widespread student protests and campus disruptions. Dr. Reynolds said that by keeping the tuition of students already enrolled lower than that of freshmen, she sought to "cushion" the blow of another tuition increase.
At the State University of New York, which, like CUNY, has a tradition of charging relatively inexpensively, tuition is $2,150 a year. SUNY also faces a tuition increase that would translate into $500 a year across the board but has not announced how it will address it.
The major participants in discussions on the plan were Lawrence F. Mucciolo, the university's deputy chancellor; Richard F. Rothbard, vice chancellor for budget, finance and computing, and Jay Hershenson, vice chancellor for university relations.
Although any tuition increase must be approved by the Governor and the Legislature, it is up to the university's trustees to impose one and to decide upon the amount.

HEADLINE: Peru and U.S.: What Course to Take?

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
While America's firm stand in support of the restoration of democracy in Peru may be laudable, is it practical?
Does it make sense to tell an impoverished country whose courts are widely believed to have been corrupted by drug traffickers and whose capital is under attack from vicious Maoist guerrillas that the only way out of its problems is to restore the democracy that existed before the Government crackdown -- even though its democratic institutions were not working and their removal had the support of 70 percent of the people? 
 There is much sympathy, even respect, among Latin American diplomats for the Bush Administration's immediate demand that the Peruvian President, Alberto Fujimori, restore his country's banned Congress, courts and Constitution, which Mr. Fujimori said he suspended in order to reform them by fiat. Few doubt that the United States should be seen as standing for the values of freedom and democracy in the world, and had the Administration done anything less it would have been denounced by both Congress and commentators.
But the Administration's action is also a bit confusing, because something is missing -- something it has never had to provide before: an explanation of why a restoration of a popular democracy under siege will not simply lead to a restoration of the impossible status quo. The Administration seems to be long on principles for Peru, but short on a clear-cut strategy that Peruvians might adopt to confront their crisis.
 
A Wider Problem for U.S.
 This is part of a wider problem faced by the Administration as more and more nations adopt democratic systems. In the case of Algeria and the former Soviet republic of Georgia, the question Washington faced was how to deal with democratically elected authoritarians. In Peru, the issue is even more complex: how should the United States deal with a democratically elected democrat who has popular support for temporarily using anti-democratic means to bring order to his country?
Addressing a meeting of the Organization of American States on Monday, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d declared: "All of us recognize that democracy can be inefficient, all of us recognize that democracy can be slow, and all of us recognize that democracy can be frustrating. But there is no alternative."
That may be true, but when the Peruvian Government is facing a guerrilla organization that many have compared to the Khmer Rouge of Cambodia, such arguments, no matter how valid, are not so easy to digest. That explains why Mr. Fujimori has received such support for his actions from the Peruvian people. They seem to believe that the restoration of constitutional democracy may be a necessary condition for re-establishing order, but is not sufficient.
 
Problems to Be Faced
 There are many problems in Peru and unless they are confronted with a comprehensive strategy, the country will fail, said Robert A. Pastor, Latin American expert at Emory University. "I agree with Baker, you cannot address the problems of the Shining Path guerrillas, the drugs and the corruption, unless you have domestic and international legitimacy. But simply restoring the democratic status quo ante will not work because it was not working before."
The American strategy has stressed why Mr. Fujimori will fail if he does not restore democracy, but it has not indicated clearly enough how he could succeed if he does, and what if anything the United States, Japan and the Organization of American States would do to make sure he succeeds this time around.
Privately, Administration officials say Mr. Fujimori should have called for a national referendum or plebiscite to give him special powers, or organized a special constitutional assembly to push through the reforms he wanted. He clearly has the popular support, officials argue, so why not use it in a constitutional manner that would not have jeopardized his international aid and backing?
 
Answers From Washington
 Beyond that, when State Department officials are asked what if anything Washington would be prepared to do to help insure that a restoration of democracy in Peru would not lead to a restoration of the status quo, they answer by pointing to the various aid programs that were in the works. The programs, they argue, could help lead Peru out of crisis if they are combined with democratically approved reforms by Mr. Fujimori.
Those arguments sound similar to ones used by Administration officials months ago, when asked why they were not doing more to aid the former Soviet Union. They would point to the long list of things they were doing, even while acknowledging privately that they knew their actions were not sufficient. Indeed, American officials dealing with Latin America often sound these days like their European affairs counterparts, worrying aloud that neither Congress nor the upper reaches of the Administration are ready to focus on the tremendous problems of Latin America in this election year.
"The historic mistake of the United States in Latin America is to be preoccupied elsewhere and to disengage and neglect the hemisphere at a time of great opportunity, great danger or both," said a senior Administration Latin affairs expert. "One of the dangers of our current national mood is that we are going to repeat that mistake."
 
State Dept. Aide in Lima
 When the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, was asked today at a briefing what exactly the Administration would do to make sure that the restoration of democracy in Peru does not restore the status quo, she began by saying that the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, Bernard Aronson, was in Lima on the eve of the suspension of democracy "with an entire interagency team to discuss things to do to help the Peruvian people in the economic field, I believe in the counternarcotics field, and a whole basket of things."
His visit, though "was aborted, when this happened," said Miss Tutwiler of Mr. Fujimori's suspension of democracy, "so I would not characterize it as we are saying return to the status quo."
She added: "We are now in the third year of a $3.4 million program to help Peru reform its judicial system. We have another $5 million budgeted for judicial and police reform over the next five years and a $500,000 program which has already trained judges and police officers in Peru. We are prepared to assist in other ways."
Saying that the United States is prepared, after the resumption of democracy, to resume substantial economic and security assistance for Peru, totaling some $260 million for fiscal 1992, Miss Tutwiler concluded: "We do not think that the status quo works either; quite the opposite. Our quarrel is not over the need for reform in Peru. It is over the way that President Fujimori has decided to carry it out. When Colombia carried out its far-reaching constitutional reforms, they began with a national referendum, not by arresting members of Parliament, judicial officials and journalists."

HEADLINE: Ford Unveils Cleanest-Running Cars for California

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EL MONTE, Calif., April 14

 BODY:
California state smog officials and the Ford Motor Company unveiled two new automobile models today that they said were the cleanest-running cars ever approved for mass production in the world.
They were updated versions of the Ford Escort and the Mercury Tracer, engineered to meet pollutant emission standards California has set for 1997 models, four years ahead of schedule. The new cars are to go on sale at Ford dealers in California starting May 21, when the 1993 models are introduced. 
 Leaders of the state's powerful Air Resources Board said the introduction of the cars vindicated their controversial act of September 1990, when they adopted a demanding timetable for manufacturers to begin introducing ultra-clean vehicles if they wanted to continue selling in the huge California automobile market.
The cars will sell for the same price as regular models sold in other states, though the cost to Ford will be $100 more for each vehicle. They will get one mile per gallon less in fuel efficiency and produce about half the noxious emissions permitted under current California standards, which are the strictest in the nation.
 
Stretching Current Technology
 The Ford vehicles are the first certified by the state under that plan, which was an attempt to force new smog-control technologies by establishing a four-step timetable for introduction of progressively cleaner-running cars from 1997 until 2003, leading ultimately to mass produced zero-emission electric cars.
The models will not immediately be available outside California, which has the worst smog problems in the country. Three Northeastern states, New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts, have adopted the California emission standards, but on a slower timetable. Six other Northeastern states, including New Jersey, as well as Maryland, Virginia and the District of Columbia, are considering adopting it.
"Today's car shows that these goals are definitely within reach," said Jananne Sharpless, chairwoman of the Air Resources Board.
Tests showed the new Ford cars emitted smog-producing hydrocarbons, carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxides at half or less of the current California standards for the 1993 model year, which are already the strictest in the nation.
Based on past sales, Ford expects to sell about 30,000 of the Escorts, whose base price is $8,802, and 4,000 of the Tracers, whose base price is $10,530. That would represent 3.4 percent of the million-plus passenger vehicles sold each year in California.
Today's announcement involved no major advance in pollution technology. Rather, according to Donald R. Buist, director of Ford's automotive emissions and fuel economy office, the company stretched existing catalytic converter technology to new limits as an interim measure while it develops alternative fuel, electric and other new propulsion systems.
The other major American and foreign auto makers are all developing new vehicles to meet the California rules, which will require 25 percent of all cars sold by each maker to conform to the new ultra-clean emission levels starting in 1997.
By the year 2003, 100 percent of vehicles would have to meet the levels, and 10 percent must have zero emissions.
Ford spokesmen said they did not plan to sell the new models in other states because the air is not as dirty elsewhere and they did not want to saddle buyers with the additional cost.
The Ford cars use conventional unleaded gasoline in a 1.9-liter internal combustion engine. The additional pollution controls were obtained mainly by enlarging the catalytic converter and moving it closer to the engine. The converter is filled with semi-precious metals that serve as catalysts to convert unburned hydrocarbons into water, carbon monoxide into carbon dioxide and nitrogen oxides into nitrogen and oxygen. Ford said it had used more of these metals than normal to raise the efficiency of the converter.
 
Increase in Efficiency
 In addition, the company said the engine was designed to use fuel more efficiently and the converter was altered to reach optimum temperature more quickly. About 95 percent of all noxious automobile emissions are created during the first few minutes after starting the car before the engine and converter are operating fully.
Current California standards limit emissions to .25 grams per mile of hydrocarbons, .4 grams for nitrogen oxide and 3.4 grams for carbon monoxide. In tests, the new Ford cars performed at .062 grams of hydrocarbons, .2 grams of nitrogen oxide and 1.3 grams of carbon monoxide. This met the 1997 standard of .075 grams, .2 grams and 1.7 grams, respectively. In addition, the cars are the first to meet California's strict new durability rules, which require that anti-smog systems continue to meet emission standards for 100,000 miles of driving, double the previous rule.
Under the plan approved by the Air Resources Board in 1990, low-emission vehicles, or LEV's, must be gradually introduced beginning in 1997, increasing to 96 percent of all cars sold by the year 2000.
The board also expects a new generation of clean-running cars, called ULEV's, or ultra low-emission vehicles, to start to be introduced in 1997 in small numbers. The plan specifies that 2 percent of all new cars should be ULEV's in 1997, rising to 15 percent in 2003. The final stage will begin with the introduction of ZEV's, or zero-emission vehicles, meaning electric cars. Makers must start to introduce them in 1998 and raise the proportion to 10 percent by 2003.
Except for electric cars, the board has not specified the type of technology to be used.
Manufacturers can use any combination of new emission controls, engine designs and fuel types to attain the required emission levels.
When the plan was imposed in 1990, many automobile experts said it was based on unrealistic expectations about new technology. Today air board staff members said, if anything, the standards may have been too lenient inasmuch as Ford met the initial requirements four years early.

HEADLINE: Banc One Set to Acquire Valley National for Stock

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Banc One Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Valley National Corporation, Arizona's largest banking company, in a $1.2 billion exchange of stock.
For the acquisition-minded Banc One, where buying other banks is a line of business and crucial to growth, the purchase of Valley extends its reach into a state where prospects for economic growth are brighter than the company's home base in Ohio. 
 Like Texas, which Banc One entered two years ago when it acquired a group of failed banks, Arizona has a rapid population growth that makes it an attractive market for Banc One, which concentrates on consumers and small businesses.
Valley National, whose lineage goes back to 1883, was the only large Arizona bank not owned by an out-of-state company. The alliance with Banc One is a chance to cast its lot with a stronger company that promised to keep current management. Also, Banc One was able to offer a price that few other banking companies could match.
Valley National's stock surged after the announcement yesterday morning, rising $11.75 in over-the-counter trading to close at $49.75. Banc One, which will exchange 1.2 shares of its stock for each share of Valley, fell $1.50 on the New York Stock Exchange to close at $45.625.
Based on Valley's closing price, Valley is being bought at twice book value under the share swap, although the pooling of interests accounting rules being used will permit Banc One to make it appear it bought Valley for less than book value. [Market Place, page D8.]
Richard J. Lehmann, Valley's 47-year-old chairman, who came to the company in 1988 after 17 years at Citicorp, said he had sought a merger because Valley lacked the financial strength to expand. Last summer Mr. Lehmann approached Banc One and described Valley's efforts to solve its problems -- it had a $149 million loss in 1989, which was attributed to problem real estate loans, and profits of only $8 million in 1990.
"We had some talks," John B. McCoy, Banc One's chairman, said, "but we did not want to take the risk that they could not turn around the bank." A month ago Mr. Lehmann called again, Mr. McCoy said, "and he showed that they had done better than their plan."
The next step was for Banc One to send a 40-member team to study Valley's loans last week, and verify that problems with its real estate loans were declining. The two companies agreed on a price with no bidding war between Banc One and other suitors.
Analysts at the First Boston Corporation issued a report yesterday calling the Valley acquisition a harbinger of another wave of bank acquisitions involving strong regional banks with dominant market shares.
Mr. McCoy cited Arizona's relatively strong growth prospects, and added that loan demand, particularly among consumers, was strong enough that Valley could continue using Arizona deposits for Arizona loans without tapping other parts of Banc One's existing eight-state network.
 
A Fast-Growing State
 Lynn Reaser, chief economist at the First Interstate Bancorporation, a California banking company that owns Arizona's third-largest bank, said, "The overall economy in Arizona is picking up this year, and the state is adding population and jobs much more rapidly than the rest of the country."
Mr. McCoy, after 107 acquisitions and two decades of rising profits that have made Banc One one of Wall Street's favorite bank stocks, said he was confident that Valley would become more profitable under the Banc One umbrella. Within three to five years he predicted that Valley's profits would rise from 80 cents per $100 of assets to $1.25 -- a performance that would be banking's equivalent to .300 hitter in baseball -- and is about the average for Banc One's subsidiary banks.
Unlike many other bank mergers, Banc One does not envision closing branch ofices or laying off employees. The only significant cut at Valley will be its computer-intensive data processing operation, which keeps track of customer transactions and balances and produces monthly account statements. Within two years Valley's data processing will be shifted to a processing center in Ohio for an annual savings of $20 million or more.
 
Banker With a Good Reputation
 Although Valley has a reputation as a strong consumer bank -- Banc One tried a few years ago to hire Richard D. Snewajs, head of retail banking at Valley -- analysts expect there is enough room for improvement that Mr. McCoy's goals will be met.
"The people at Valley have been forced to spend so much time managing their bad credits that they may have lost some of their ability to focus on developing the best products and pricing strategies," said Moshe Ohrenbuch, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. "That is an area where Banc One can help with its share-and-compare policy."
Share and compare refers to Banc One's practice of standardizing the products and accounting systems at its banking subsidiaries and encouraging its bankers to share the secrets of their successes and warn others of potential pitfalls.
By leaving each bank free to devise its own marketing strategies and prices, but requiring all banks to file monthly reports of their past results and forecasts, Bank One has found a way to leave local bankers with a sense of control, while the home office watches carefully enough to spot problems quickly.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Markets
Blue-chip stocks vaulted to new highs, as traders reacted to upbeat earnings reports. The Dow climbed 36.23, to 3,306.13, its first close above 3,300. [Page D1.]
Prices of Treasury securities dipped in slow trading, as dealers were once again without a Treasury futures market. [D18.] 
 The prospect of renewed Iraqi oil sales set off wide selling of crude oil futures. [D19.] The dollar was flat. [D19.]
 
Companies
I.B.M. moved into the black with quarterly earnings of $595 million, or $1.04 a share, rebounding from a disastrous 1991. [D1.]
Banc One agreed to acquire Valley National, Arizona's largest banking company, in a $1.2 billion exchange of stock. [D1.]
The U.A.W. said it would end a strike against Caterpillar that has left more than 12,000 workers walking the picket lines. [A1.]
Union Carbide will sell its last holdings in India to raise as much as $17 million to build and operate a hospital in Bhopal. [D1.]
Merrill Lynch reported its biggest quarterly profit ever. Charles Schwab and Paine Webber posted big gains. [D5.]
Most remaining parts of Apple's copyright suit against Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard were thrown out. [D5.]
American Home Products and Pfizer reported double-digit quarterly earnings gains. [D7.]
The New York Times Co. reported higher income, citing higher ad revenues in the newspaper and magazine groups. [D20.]
A chocolate a day keeps the dentist away -- that is the message of the Princeton Dental Resource Center (which happens to be financed by M&M/Mars). [A1.]
ARCO slashed its capital spending plans and said it expected sharply lower earnings. [D5.]

Olympia & York defaulted on an $800 million Eurobond issue secured by a tower in Manhattan's World Financial Center. [D1.]
Alan Bond was declared officially bankrupt after he failed to repay a $194 million debt. [D2.]
The U.S. plans to do more to help businesses invest in former Soviet republics, Commerce Secretary Franklin said. [D23.]
The Economy
Sales of North American-built vehicles rose just 3.8 percent in early April from a sluggish sales period a year earlier. [D6.]
Retail sales fell 0.4 percent in March, the Commerce Dept. said, after rising smartly the first two months of the year. [D6.]
The I.R.S. is focusing more attention these days on making it easier for people to comply with the tax laws voluntarily. [D23.]
 
Business Technology
Developing tools to sort through huge electronic libraries of pictures is the new challenge of computer researchers, now that they have refined the art of searching through megabytes of data for a single phrase. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Incomes of Young Families Dip 32% in 17 Years, Study Finds

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
Young families with children have significantly less money than their counterparts did a generation ago and suffer from child poverty rates that are twice as high, the Children's Defense Fund said in a study issued today.
Incomes in those families have dropped by 32 percent, the study found, and the child poverty rate is now a sobering 40 percent. 
 The study attributed slightly more than half of the decline to demographic factors, including the sharp rise in single-parent families. But even if family composition had not changed, the study said, almost half of the decline would have occurred, a result of eroded wages and declining government payments for welfare and unemployment.
The trends were most discouraging for young black and Hispanic families, and for those with little education, the study found. But young white families and those headed by high school graduates also saw their incomes fall and their poverty levels rise.
 
'Broad and Pervasive Trends'
 "These are very broad and pervasive trends that are reaching virtually all kinds of families with young children," said Cliff Johnson, an analyst for the Children's Defense Fund who helped write the report.
Political partisans wage ferocious interpretative wars over trends like these, with liberals citing a decline in economic opportunity and conservatives pointing to behavioral changes like the rise in out-of-wedlock births. But the numbers in today's report were sufficiently grim that both sides agreed that, whatever the causes, they cast a troubling shadow over the nation's future.
Marian Wright Edelman, the defense fund's president, said the numbers presaged "more substance abuse, more crime, more violence, more school failure, more teen pregnancy, more racial tension, more envy, more despair and more cynicism -- a long-term economic and social disaster."
S. Anna Kondratas, an Assistant Secretary of Housing who is a staff member of the Bush Administration's main anti-poverty planning group, the Economic Empowerment Task Force, used different words to express similar fears. The entire nation will suffer, she said, as more children grow up with "low skills, the lack of ability to compete in society, the alienation from society."
The study, performed by the defense fund, a research and advocacy group on children's issues, and Northeastern University's Center for Labor Market Studies, analyzed data from the Census Bureau's Current Population Survey, an annual sample of about 60,000 households. While median incomes fell for both young and old families with children, the trend was most precipitous among young families.
About half of all American children are born into families headed by a parent under 30 years of age. The study found that incomes for such families fell 32.1 percent, to $18,844 in 1990 from $27,765 in 1973. Those figures are held constant for inflation and expressed in 1990 dollars.
The incomes for families headed by people 30 to 64 years of age fell more modestly, by 6.4 percent, to $38,451 in 1990. By contrast, families without children saw their incomes rise by 11.2 percent over the same period, to an average of $36,020.
The report said the income declines occurred even though "today's young family heads are somewhat better educated than those in the generation preceding them."
From 1973 to 1990, incomes fell 15 percent for young families headed by a parent with some college education, to a 1990 average of $27,000. Incomes fell 30 percent for those headed by a high school graduate, to $20,000, and 46 percent for those headed by a high school dropout, to $10,213.
 
Young Minority Families
 Only those families with children headed by a college graduate saw a rise in income, a 3 percent gain, to $38,700.
The report said that part of the worsening statistical picture derived from the fact that young families today were more likely to be members of minority groups. Black and Hispanic people have lower average earnings than whites, a trend that may reflect both lower educational attainment and racial discrimination.
The percentage of young families with children headed by a nonwhite parent rose to 35 percent in 1991, from 23 percent in 1974.
From 1973 to 1990, incomes fell 22 percent for young white families, 28 percent for Hispanic families and 48 percent for black families. Poverty rates rose to 23.8 percent for the children in young white families, 43.5 percent for those in Hispanic families and 57.9 percent for those in black families.
Clearly, some of the gloomy statistical news resulted from the near doubling of the percentage of young familes that are headed by a single parent, to 37 percent in 1991.
Since 1973, incomes for young married-couple families have fallen 13 percent, to $27,000 in 1990. But incomes in female-headed households dropped more sharply, by 27 percent to $7,256.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Results for 2 Paper Makers Move in Opposite Directions

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The International Paper Company yesterday reported a first-quarter profit, in contrast to a loss reflecting an extraordinary charge a year earlier, while the Boise Cascade Corporation said its first-quarter loss widened from 1991.
International Paper cited substantial improvement in its timber and wood-products business, while Boise Cascade cited deteriorating prices for important grades of paper. 
 Following are the details of the companies' results:
 
 
International Paper
 The forest products giant said it earned $102 million, or 87 cents a share, in the first quarter, in contrast to a loss of $87 million a year earlier.
The 1991 quarterly loss reflected a big charge for post-retirement health-care and insurance benefits that many companies are taking to conform with new accounting rules.
Sales rose 9.7 percent, to $3.4 billion, from $3.1 billion a year ago.
The company, based in Purchase, N.Y., said earnings before extraordinary items fell to $104 million, from $128 million in 1991, because of lower prices for printing and writing papers. But its results also reflected higher prices and sales of lumber and panel products and higher bulk sales of West Coast timber.
International Paper said prices of uncoated paper in the United States began to stabilize in March and added that pulp and linerboard prices and demand were improving.
The company's stock gained $2.375 yesterday, closing at $72.375 on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Boise Cascade
The Boise, Idaho, paper products company lost $42.9 million in the quarter, compared with a loss of $16.9 million a year earlier. Sales fell 3.9 percent, to $953.9 million from $992.7 million.
It was the fifth straight quarterly loss for Boise Cascade.
Earnings from building products doubled in the latest quarter, but that was more than offset by depressed prices for paper, high interest rates and depreciation charges from a 1987 capital investment program. The growth in demand for office products distribution and pulp and paper products was slight.
The company's stock lost 25 cents yesterday, closing at $20.875 on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A Rebound For I.B.M. In Quarter

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
Rebounding from a financially disastrous 1991, I.B.M. reported yesterday that it moved into the black in the first quarter with earnings of $595 million, or $1.04 a share.
The profit contrasted with a loss of $1.7 billion a year earlier, when the company took a one-time charge of $2.26 billion, and it sent I.B.M. stock up 75 cents, to $88.25. I.B.M. helped propel the Dow Jones industrial average, of which it is a component, to a high of 3,306.13, up 36.23 points. 
 Yet while the world's largest computer maker's report was cautiously positive and its results stood in sharp contrast to the rival Digital Equipment Corporation, which reported a huge loss last week, financial analysts said it was too soon to credit the financial upswing to the company's restructuring announced in December.
 
A 'Sigh of Relief' Quarter
 One reason is that hardware sales, which had traditionally produced the majority of the company's earnings, dipped by 2.7 percent, falling to $7.1 billion for the first quarter of 1992 from $7.3 billion a year earlier.
"It was a sigh of relief type of quarter," said Steven Milunovich, a financial analyst at Salomon Brothers. But Mr. Milunovich added that he was a little disappointed about the decline in hardware sales "given that we're in a new mainframe cycle."
Historically, I.B.M.'s business has been driven forward by each new generation of its most powerful and expensive computers, an event that has come about every seven years.
For the first quarter, revenue was up 3.3 percent at $14.04 billion, compared with $13.59 billion in the period last year. Operating earnings before taxes rose 6.9 percent, to $991 million, from $927 million in the 1991 quarter, when the International Business Machines Corporation took a special charge to account for the future cost of retirees' health-care benefits.
Earlier this year, the Armonk, N.Y., company reported its worst financial results, recording a loss of $2.8 billion for all of 1991. Although most of that loss was from the 1991 accounting charge, the company's revenues also fell for the first time in the last 45 years last year, to $64.8 billion from $69 billion in 1990.
In December, the company put a number of changes into place and said it was beginning to transform itself into a collection of more autonomous subsidiaries. It also continued its half-decade process of paring its work force through incentives for voluntary departures.
The company, which had 344,000 employees at the end of last year, said in December that it planned to eliminate 20,000 jobs in 1992. That follows the departure of about 29,000 people last year.
But analysts pointed to a significant uptick in sales at the end of the first quarter. "The company pushed hard at the end of the quarter, but their guidance for the rest of the year is unchanged," said Steven Cohen, an analyst at the Soundview Financial Group.
I.B.M. seized the optimistic data as the first indication that its new business plan was working. It had spelled out the details in an end-of-the-year meeting in Manhattan with investors, analysts and reporters.
"Our recently announced plan to reshape I.B.M. into a spectrum of businesses is moving forward aggressively throughout the world, and a better focused I.B.M. is emerging," said John F. Akers, the company's chairman. "Over all, we're pleased with these results and believe we're on track toward achieving our financial objectives for the year."
 
Gains in U.S. and Asia
 Another bright spot was the company's United States business, which Mr. Milunovich estimated had risen between 8 and 9 percent for the quarter. The rise was offset by a sharp 5 percent decline in the computer maker's European business, which was recently battered by the slump in Western Europe's economy.
The company also saw growth in its Asian and Pacific businesses, but that was partly because of the purchase of a Japanese leasing company.
A number of Wall Street analysts cited improvement in I.B.M.'s ability to control its costs, a crucial component of its restructuring.
The company told analysts in a morning phone conference yesterday that its selling and administrative costs had declined by 3.5 percent and its research and development spending had fallen by 4.5 percent.

HEADLINE: Dow Closes At 3,306.13, A Record

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON Jr.

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks vaulted to new highs yesterday, as traders reacted to upbeat earnings reports from a handful of leading companies and sidestepped a futures market crisis caused by flooding in downtown Chicago.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 36.23 points, or 1.1 percent, to 3,306.13, marking its first close above 3,300 and the 14th time since Jan. 1 that the benchmark indicator set a record. The Dow's previous high was 3,290.25, reached on March 3. 
 "There are a lot of crosscurrents going on here," said Harrison Roth, senior options strategist at Cowen & Company. "But all things considered, it hasn't yet put the market under water."
 
Base of Optimism
 A solid base of optimism grew out of last week's easing of interest rates by the Federal Reserve Board, analysts said, and that provided a foundation for yesterday's rally when I.B.M. issued a better-than-expected earnings report.
Having started the day slowly, the Dow began its climb when I.B.M.'s news was released at midmorning. The Dow peaked at 3,336.54 at about 2:15 P.M., and retreated gradually until the close.
The continued strength of the stock market contributed to a surge in profits reported by three leading brokerages, Merrill Lynch, Charles Schwab and Paine Webber. Merrill, the nation's largest, reported its biggest quarterly profit ever. [Page D5.]
 
Disruption in Chicago
 In Chicago, water swelled in the basement of the Chicago Board of Trade building, flooding its electrical supply and forcing its futures markets to remain closed for a second day. The Mercantile Exchange, Chicago's other main futures market, was not directly affected by the flooding and resumed normal trading in the morning. Most activity was then halted at noon, an exchange official said, to allow member firms to catch up on a clearing backlog.
"About 40 percent of our members were forced to work out of makeshift offices," said Andrew A. Yemma, a spokesman for the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. "We had to give them time to catch up."
The Chicago Board of Trade plans to reopen at noon today for two hours of trading in all major sectors, said Michael Oakes, manager of corporate communications.
On the New York Stock Exchange, volume expanded to a healthy 231.1 million shares, up from 143 million shares in Monday trading that was slowed by the halt of futures trading in Chicago. Gaining issues outpaced losers by 1,220 to 512, and trading was affected only slightly by Chicago's disruption, analysts said.
 
Index Arbitragers Active
 With options and futures contracts expiring this week and markets closed on Good Friday, index arbitragers, who were made nervous by uncertainty in Chicago, traded stocks more actively yesterday than they might normally have. But as a futures trader at Morgan Stanley said, "Even if the spreads were a little larger, we were fairly comfortable making markets."
Apart from the Dow, no other major indicators set new records yesterday. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 6.31 points, or 1.55 percent, to 412.39, and the Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter stocks rose 6.66 points, or 1.13 percent, to 594.81.
The American Stock Exchange composite index rose 3.25 points, or less than 1 percent, to 392.14, and the Russell 2,000 index was lifted 1.85 points, to 198.91
 
Expectations of the Fed
 "There are now expectations built into the market that further steps will be taken by the Fed," said Robert Walberg, senior equity analyst at the Chicago office of MMS International, referring to the optimism sparked by last week's cut in the Federal funds rate. He and other analysts now expect a cut in the Fed's discount rate on loans to banks if the economic recovery does not gain speed.
But the spark that ignited yesterday's rally was the news on I.B.M.'s earnings. I.B.M. was the day's most actively traded stock, at 3.3 million shares, and while it rose only 3/4, to 88 1/4, the computer giant seemed to buoy the entire market.
"It enabled a lot of cyclical stocks to burst forth," said Mr. Walberg of MMS International. He cited International Paper, which rose 2 3/8, to 72 3/8; 3M, up 3 1/2, to 91 3/4, and General Electric, up 1 1/2, to 76 3/4. Procter & Gamble rose 4 1/2, to 104 1/2.
The Dow's rise since last week, however, has not fueled the sense of euphoria that infected Wall Street in January, when four new highs were set in seven days.
"People are going to have to focus on the broader market," said Paul Kronlokken, a technical analyst at Piper Jaffrey Inc. in Minneapolis. "Other indicators have lagged behind the Dow. We have to be on the lookout for a possible settling."
Mr. Walberg agreed. "It's going to be a little rougher ahead," he said. "Until we see some consolidation in the market, you have to be cautious."
Capital Cities/ABC and CBS also rose, apparently on expectations that each would soon report favorable earnings for the quarter. Capital Cities/ABC rose 11 1/4, to 442, and CBS gained 7 5/8, to 178.
In the over-the-counter market, Valley National shot up 11 3/4, to 49 3/4, after it announced it had agreed to merge with the Banc One Corporation.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidate's Health;
VOICE RECOVERED, CLINTON CAMPAIGNS

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 14

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton's voice has been hoarse and strained for months, but it was not until he won the New York primary that he had the political luxury of taking the advice any good doctor would have been giving him for months: Shut up.
And a week off from the road -- which ended tonight as Governor Clinton flew to Los Angeles for two days of West Coast appearances -- seems to have given the Arkansas Governor as much benefit in his quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination as delivering any number of policy speeches could have. 
 In the last several days, he has collected a steady stream of carefully timed endorsements, including those of Representative Thomas S. Foley of Washington, the Speaker of the House; Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, and Senater Jay Rockefeller of West Virginia, the Democratic Party's finance chairman.
The rallying-round-the-nominee feeling of the week was enhanced when the political arm of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. decided on Monday to recommend that the labor group back Mr. Clinton as well.
 
Brown Is Conciliatory
 Even Mr. Clinton's chief rival, Edmund G. Brown Jr., had conciliatory words for Mr. Clinton at a California Democratic Party meeting over the weekend, saying for the first time that he would support the party's nominee.
Mr. Clinton's traveling entourage will pay for the day's off the road almost immediately as the candidate attends fund raisers in Los Angeles and San Francisco Wednesday before flying overnight back to the East Coast. On Thursday in Philadelphia, he will deliver the economic-policy speech in that he was forced to cancel on Monday.
As Mr. Clinton has been recuperating, and the tempo of his visible campaign has slowed, the preparations have picked up for what his advisers see as an early start on the general election campaign. Strategists have used the time in Little Rock and Washington to meet with people from previous Democratic Presidential campaigns and to negotiate the timing of future endorsements.
The Capitol Hill endorsements, for instance, may have done more damage than good for Mr. Clinton while he was competing against the self-styled insurgent campaign of Mr. Brown in New York. "This isn't the year where you want to go stand on the steps of the U.S. Capitol and say how well you know the corridors of power," said Dee Dee Myers, the Clinton campaign press secretary.
 
Keeping Things Low Key
 So when the endorsements did come, they were not near any primary contests, and they were relatively low key. Mr. Gephardt, for instance, announced his support for Mr. Clinton on a Saturday evening Cable News Network talk show.
Mr. Clinton's advisers have also been debating how they can move the campaign debate beyond questions of Mr. Clinton's truthfulness and overall character to a direct challenge to President Bush.
"When you go out and campaign, people don't ask about this," said Mickey Kantor, the campaign chairman. "Somebody's going to realize some day that it's the press's issue and not the people's issue."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House Memo;
Bush Makes Habit of Announcements

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FRASER, Mich., April 14

 BODY:
After months of hearing Republican strategists say that President Bush had to demonstrate a mastery of Government programs, the White House has apparently taken the advice to heart -- after a fashion.
In appearances around the country and speeches in Washington, Mr. Bush has taken to unveiling a handful of domestic policy initiatives again and again. 
 Today in Michigan, for example, he announced that he was taking steps to help young people train for jobs -- for the second time in three months. On Monday, Mr. Bush announced that he was taking steps to curb political spending by labor unions -- for the second time in three weeks.
Every politician has a basic speech presenting his central political message, and every politician repeats it at almost every stop in a campaign. That is what Mr. Bush did here today as he delivered what the White House calls "the five pillars of reform" speech at a machine-tool plant in this town northeast of Detroit.
 
Fact Sheet After Fact Sheet
 But as it casts about for new ways to show that the President is coming to grips with domestic issues and offering specific ideas for change, the Bush team has come up with a new wrinkle on this old political practice: offering not just the same speech, but the same policy announcements and, in some cases, the same policies, over and over again.
These have not just been an incumbent's usual recitation of his achievements, but full-blown policy announcements, complete with impressive program titles, as in today's "Job Training 2000 Act," and the blizzard of fact sheets and press releases that the White House typically produces for such occasions.
Mr. Bush's campaign chiefs make no apologies for the practice. "There is nothing cynical about talking about what you are doing as President, one time or five times or 20 times," said Robert M. Teeter, Mr. Bush's campaign manager. "There is no one-time rule and there shouldn't be."
Indeed, it is common wisdom among political strategists that the way for any politician, including a President, to get his "message" out is to repeat it, again and again, until enough people have heard it.
 
Sprinkling Bits of News
 But to make sure it is heard outside the room in which the President is speaking, it must generate news reports. The way to do that is to salt his speeches with enough news to provide reporters with a reason to write about them, and for an incumbent that means policy initiatives.
Some Republican strategists and disgruntled officials say the White House either has not got that idea yet or is simply having difficulty coming up with newsworthy executive actions in an Administration where the domestic policy apparatus is widely described as paralyzed.
So, while some Republicans wince in frustration, Mr. Bush is pushing a plan to require Federal contractors to inform nonunion members that they can withhold the portion of their dues that is used for political purposes. He announced the plan on March 20, and he announced it again on Monday.
The only difference between his announcement in Michigan today that he was offering Congress a new job training bill, and the same announcement he made in Atlanta on Jan. 17, was that Mr. Bush specified he would send the bill to Congress when it got back from recess in two weeks.
 
Harder Sell in the Capital
 Sometimes, Mr. Bush attracts news reports with recycled announcements, as he did with the anti-union measure. But more often, he ends up speaking into a public relations vacuum.
Mr. Bush generally does better when he is on the road, since local news organizations report on his coming to their towns even if he does not say anything essentially new. But Mr. Bush has been largely confined to Washington in the weeks since he stopped traveling heavily to counter the challenge from Patrick J. Buchanan. Some of his events there, including at least two long speeches in recent weeks, have gone virtually unnoticed.
Mr. Bush's critics say the reason is that many of his proposals do not seem to have much meat in them, partly because the President has not given his staff a clear vision of what he wants to do and partly because his campaign strategy assumes that the economy will rebound more or less by itself.
Roger B. Porter, the domestic policy adviser, said the idea behind announcing the Jan. 17 proposal again today was to add "an additional level of detail" -- that is, to include specific amounts of money to be spent on the plan. But the White House could not make clear how much was involved.
The White House said the plan included $50 million to impose certification standards on vocational schools. But that money, and that program, were in the budget proposal Mr. Bush sent to Congress in January.
All told, Mr. Bush's plan would mean no increase in the $18 billion the United States already spends on jobs programs. Officials also acknowledged that the measure has no sponsor in a Congress that has shown little interest in passing Mr. Bush's plans anyway.

HEADLINE: Picking College by the Aid

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
As a result of tuition increases and the recession, students are increasingly making decisions about where to attend school based on how much financial aid they receive.
What is more, students who receive financial help, and their parents, are challenging the amounts more than ever before and pressing institutions for more money. 
 The cost of tuition, room and board, along with books and other expenses, has increased 10 percent to 15 percent in the last few years, according to several university financial aid officials. Among the eight Ivy League institutions, for example, the cost of a single year is approaching $25,000.
The cost is comparable with other private institutions, like the University of Chicago or Stanford University. And at the so-called "public Ivies," like the University of Michigan, the University of California at Berkeley and the University of Virginia, a year of education costs only a few thousand dollars less.
"We find the cost is outrageous at all the universities, to be honest," said B. R. Vohra of Laurel, Md., an accountant whose son has been accepted at several universities, including Duke University, the University of Pennsylvania and the University of Michigan, and who favors Michigan because it costs the least. "I have three other children who haven't gone to college yet."
Universities generally award a package of Federal and state student loan programs and university-supported scholarships, loans and work-study programs. The amount is usually based on a formula that takes into account a family's income, assets, debt and any additional children in college.
Every university has an appeal process. Generally, when a financial plan is appealed, the college will review the family's application once more. Sometimes -- but not often -- institutions will increase the financial package. "Honest mistakes are made," said Joe Paul Case, the dean of financial aid at Amherst College.
