HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Lawmaker's Life: Not So Wonderful

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTEREY, Calif., April 13

 BODY:
Here in Big Sur, Representative Leon E. Panetta has long been admired as a champion of fishermen and environmentalists against the oil companies wishing to drill offshore. He is also chairman of an important Congressional committee, by all accounts a serious legislator and, at least by Washington power standards, an abstemious fellow.
Never mind. His constituents want to talk about something else. 
 "What I want to know," said Jeffrey Bartholomew, a 39-year-old bellhop at a Monterey wharfside hotel, "is how many checks has Leon bounced lately."
For Mr. Panetta and his colleagues in Congress, each trip home these days is a trial on charges of arrogance and sloth. And especially when it comes to the perquisites of office, the presumption of innocence does not seem to count.
"You get the feeling someone is robbing your integrity for no reason," said Mr. Panetta, a 53-year-old Democrat who prides himself on the simple ways he inherited from his Italian immigrant parents. "And it hurts. I didn't come to Washington to get free office furniture, or discounted shoeshines and haircuts. It offends me when this kind of thing comes up."
 
Perks And Their Price
 And so it is that Mr. Panetta returned home for the Congressional recess last weekend mindful of things he has taken for granted in his 16 years on Congress: the $129,500-a-year Congressional salary (he voted for the most recent pay raise), the potted office plants supplied by the United States Botanical Garden, the Congressional photography staff, the House gym, the fawning aides, the foreign trips, the three-day workweeks, the black-tie banquets.
But for every privilege, there is a drawback or indignity. Mr. Panetta's existence is marked by regular absences from his wife and three sons. Meals often consist of a roll or a bunch of grapes on the run. There is perpetual jet lag from a weekly transcontinental flight home, plus the expense of maintaining two households -- one of which is a two-bedroom Capitol Hill townhouse he shares with three other lawmakers.
Mr. Panetta operates with unusual frugality, using his frequent-flyer mileage to finance much of his official travel and buying some of his own office furniture. He elicited snickering from some colleagues when he returned to the Treasury this year's 4.2 percent cost-of-living raise.
 
Explaining to Critics
 Still, in the current political climate, Mr. Panetta finds that he has some explaining to do. He says that as a result of sloppy bookkeeping he overdrew his account at the House bank twice over a 39-month period, but he adds that the bank, which has been shut down, owes him $2,500 for debiting his account twice for the same check last year. He has admitted he was once listed as delinquent in paying $5,000 to the House restaurant because Greenpeace, the environmental group he was dining with, was slow to pay its bill.
When asked, Mr. Panetta also acknowledges traveling on a handful of junkets paid for by private foundations and philanthropic groups to Israel, Japan and Italy in his 16 years in Congress. Several times, he took his wife, Sylvia.
Nobody expects Mr. Panetta to have trouble winning re-election this year -- his 16th District is solidly Democratic -- but he finds himself in the uncomfortable position of forever having to explain his conduct.
Last Saturday, Dennis Law, a 38-year-old Navy computer programmer, visited Mr. Panetta in his office here to, as he said, "speak my mind."
"You should dump that Mercedes-Benz and buy an American car!" Mr. Law said, raising his voice.
Mr. Panetta giggled and then explained that he did not own a Mercedes. In fact, he said, he owns an Oldsmobile, which he leaves with his wife in Carmel Valley.
Mr. Panetta's workweek typically begins at Dulles International Airport outside Washington, where he lands after a long working weekend in California.
Last week, as is often the case, he landed at 6 A.M. Tuesday, having caught a couple of hours of sleep on the red-eye flight from San Francisco. "Welcome to the morning shift," he said in mock ebullience to the Budget Committee aide who picked him up.
Dropped at his townhouse, the Congressman napped for an hour before walking to work.
When he arrived at his cramped office in the Cannon building, his press secretary, Barry Toiv, was waiting. With Mr. Toiv producing, Mr. Panetta took a news release on a Medicaid reform bill into his makeshift office radio studio -- a closet full of paint cans and a beat-up refrigerator -- to record some sound bites for a radio station back home.
There were few votes that day, but nevertheless Mr. Panetta's schedule ended at midnight. He met with the Budget Committee staff to plot hearings for a balanced-budget amendment, participated in a strategy meeting with other Democratic leaders and conferred with the president of San Jose State University about the possible conversion of part of a military base into a marine biology school.
He also joined a luncheon attended by Italian-American business leaders and lawmakers, during which he was touted as a contender for the Democratic Vice-Presidential nomination. But the meal was disrupted when one businessman rose to coarsely admonish the lawmakers for arrogance and ineptitude.
After the luncheon, Mr. Panetta was driven to a downtown hotel to follow President Bush and several newspaper columnists in addressing a business group. Tired of all the Washington-speak, a third of the audience walked out as Mr. Panetta stepped up to speak.
 
Minefields in the Office
 Back at his office, a stream of constituents came by, bearing small gifts and asking favors. Such visits are a minefield that every lawmaker has to go through without breaking ethical rules or offending influential constituents or fund-raisers.
Two California beer distributers visited. Mr. Panetta flattered one by remarking how much weight he had lost. The distributer smiled and then complained that the Office of Substance Abuse was overreaching its jurisdiction by linking alcohol to drugs in its public-service announcements.
"That's a good place to cut the budget," the distributer said, in a not-so-subtle request that Mr. Panetta use his position as chairman of the Budget Committee to enhance the beer-distribution industry.
Mr. Panetta shrugged, and then said with a giggle, "You probably won't see that because the office has got a good title."
Mr. Panetta's retreat from the lobbyists, rubber-chicken luncheons and budget battles is the townhouse he shares with Representatives George Miller of California, Marty Russo of Illinois and Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, all of them Democrats.
For the $400 monthly rent he pays Mr. Miller, Mr. Panetta shares the living room with Mr. Schumer, while the other Congressmen have bedrooms of their own. "He's on the bed where the piano should be and I'm on the couch," Mr. Schumer said. "I'm asleep when he comes in."
The roommates joke that Mr. Schumer has the annoying habit of eating whatever is left in the refrigerator and they sometimes engage in heated political arguments, but they appear to get along well. Some nights they sit together on Mr. Miller's bed to watch the late news or a talk show. Mr. Schumer said he did not mind when Mr. Panetta's son Jimmy recently shared the room for three months.
"The image of the average Congressman is on one end of the scale, and Leon is on the other," Mr. Schumer said.
Mr. Panetta still lives in the Carmel Valley ranch house built by his father from the money he earned in the restaurant business. For recreation, the Congressman tends the walnut trees he nurtured as a boy; he worships every Sunday at the Roman Catholic church where he attended parochial school.
"Coming back here restores me," Mr. Panetta said. "It re-establishes perspective. Washington can be so consuming."
But so can life in Carmel Valley.
On Saturdays he meets with constituents, guiding them through the red tape of the immigration service and hearing advice on how he should vote on a bill. Weekend nights are generally filled with some dinner or benefit, including a recent one sponsored by the Red Cross, during which he was asked to wait tables. On Sundays he usually answers constituent mail.
As soon as he arrives home on Friday afternoons, his wife, who doubles as his unpaid local office director, tells him of the newest emergency. Last week it was that a local Spanish-language radio station had falsely reported that Mr. Panetta was ready to grant extensions on unemployment compensation to the area's migrant workers.
Hearing the news, Mr. Panetta laughed, because he does not have such power. He and his wife conferred on how to coordinate with the State Employment Department on how to deal with the flood of inquiries. Pruning the garden would have to wait for another weekend.
"Anybody who takes this job for the perks," Mr. Panetta said, "is barking up the wrong tree."

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

DATELINE: U. of Chicago's Long-Indomitable Leader to Retire

 BODY:
The durable and highly visible president of the University of Chicago, Hanna H. Gray, announced yesterday that she would retire at the end of the 1992-93 academic year and return to teaching history.
Mrs. Gray, who is 61 years old, has been president of the highly selective private university since 1978, and was one of the first women to lead a major American research university. Her 14 years in office make her one of the longest serving presidents of any major American university, an unusual figure in a period when the average tenure of a university president is six years. 
 The University of Chicago -- celebrating its centennial year -- has seen its three top administrative leaders announce their departures.
 
Loss of Heir Apparent
 Last month, the university's provost and the person considered by many to have been Mrs. Gray's heir apparent, Gerhard Casper, was named president of Stanford University. He was replaced last week by Edward O. Laumann, former dean of the graduate social sciences division.
In another recent move, the chairman of the university's board of trustees, Barry Sullivan, was named Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development in New York City. He will be replaced by Howard G. Krane, a partner in the Chicago law firm of Kirkland & Ellis. Mr. Krane had been vice chairman of the university's board.
"It's too bad that in this centennial year we did not have a greater sense of stability," said Bertram J. Cohler, a professor of psychology in the College, Chicago's undergraduate division.
Mrs. Gray's tenure at Chicago was marked by a continued commitment to the university's academic rigor. But she also often said that improving student life on one of the most intellectually intense campuses in the country was a priority for her. A winter festival, Kuviasungnerk, was begun to help undergraduates through Chicago's gloomy winters.
 
Faculty Unrest

At Chicago, Mrs. Gray became a spokeswoman for private higher education, serving as president of the American Council on Education in 1979 and the Association of American Universities in 1990.
Her long tenure and strong-willed leadership gave Chicago unusual stability but also created faculty unrest, because some professors believed she had been in office too long. Some felt that if she had stepped aside sooner, Mr. Casper, a revered figure on campus, would not have been lost to Stanford.
"She once said to me that 10 years was long enough for a person to spend in an administrative position," said Lorna P. Straus, a professor of anatomy who is a former dean of students. "It has been 14 years since she came as president. It is time for the university to have new leadership. And I'm one of those disappointed that it won't be Gerhard Casper."
But Mrs. Gray said her actions had not influenced Mr. Casper. She said she had made her decision last fall and had told Mr. Casper of her plans before he took the position at Stanford. She also said she had not been pressured by the board to retire, as had been rumored on campus.
"I began to talk about this matter almost a year ago with our chairman and had come to a decision in the fall," she said. "We came to very comfortable decision that an announcement would be made in the spring."
Mrs. Gray taught at Chicago from 1961 to 1972. She was dean of the College of Arts and Sciences at Northwestern University from 1972 to 1974, then provost of Yale University from 1974 to 1978, when she became president at Chicago.

HEADLINE: U.S. Pledges to Help Trade With Ex-Soviet Republics

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
The Government plans to do more to help American businesses trade with and invest in the former Soviet republics, but it has not yet coordinated how to pay for the effort, Commerce Secretary Barbara H. Franklin said today.
United States exports to the region have risen sharply in the last year, as Eastern European enterprises have lost their preferential access to the market and as American businesses have unexpectedly grabbed market share, even from their rivals in other industrialized nations. 
 But American executives and even some Administration officials complain that the growth has come with little Government help and support.
 
No Government Export Loans
 The Government has yet to make any loans to finance exports to the republics and has only three commercial officers for all of them. By contrast, the German and Italian Governments have been pouring billions of dollars in export loans into the region, and Germany plans to open six commercial offices there by the end of the year.
Ms. Franklin said at a news conference that the Administration would start providing more money and information for American companies trying to do business in the former Soviet Union. But she declined to discuss how much money would be spent, saying her department still had to talk further with Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the Deputy Secretary of State.
Ms. Franklin said that she had set up a committee to look at how the Commerce Department could provide more help to exporters, and that she would meet with her Russian counterpart, Pyotr O. Aven, the Minister of Foreign Economic Relations, in June when President Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia also were to meet.
The Commerce Department is likely to set up an office within two months to start helping companies do business in the republics, said a department official who insisted on anonymity. The center would be modeled on the department's Eastern Europe Business Information Center, which has nearly a dozen employees preparing and distributing newsletters and reviews of Eastern European markets by country and by industry.
 
Survey of Businesses' Problems
 Ms. Franklin today released a month-old Commerce Department survey of American businesses' problems in the republics. The report cited a lack of commitment by the governments to exports as well as unclear regulations, unstable currencies, inadequate information about potential markets and business partners, poor communications and a lack of trade agreements.
The report gave only passing mention to American controls on products with militarily sensitive technology. "That's being fairly naive -- there are studies all over the place that they are a brake," said Willard A. Workman, the United States Chamber of Commerce's vice president for international issues.
Yet despite the problems, American exports to the republics reached $392 million in January of this year, compared with $216.9 million in January 1991. And while subsidized grain shipments account for much of the increase, exports of manufactured goods rose 36.7 percent last year.
Western countries exports to the region are growing overall because Eastern Europe has lost the preferential trade access that it once enjoyed from a complicated system of ruble exchange rates. But even compared with other wealthy democracies, the United States has fared better than average.
 
American Share on the Increase
 According to Commerce Department figures, American exports accounted for 7.7 percent of all exports to the region from 24 large industrialized countries during 1990. But during the first 11 months of last year, the American market share rose to 12.5 percent.
During last November, the most recent month available for all 24 countries, the American share hit 15.2 percent.
But Italy and other countries that are spending heavily on government-backed export loans may now be gaining ground on the United States, said David C. Johnson, an economist at PlanEcon Inc., a Washington-based consulting firm that specializes in the republics and Eastern Europe.

HEADLINE: Early-April Vehicle Sales Up 3.8% From Weak Period

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 14

 BODY:
Sales of North American-built vehicles rose just 3.8 percent in early April from a sluggish sales period a year earlier. The gain provided another sign that the auto market is recovering only gradually from a slump that began in the early stages of the Persian Gulf crisis in late 1990.
While light-truck sales increased 10.1 percent, to 99,834, in the April 1-10 period, car sales were virtually flat at 153,474. The increase in total vehicle sales, to 253,308 from 243,976, resulted from light trucks, which include pickups, mini-vans and utility vehicles. 
 The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate was 5.8 million, a drop from 6.2 million in late March but better than the 5.6 million rate in the 1991 period.
 
Assessments Differ
 "Fewer cars are being sold to fleets this year, so the actual strength of consumer buying is stronger than what is indicated by year-to-year comparisons," said Wendy Needham, an automotive analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham in New York.
But car dealers were divided in their assessment of the market. John Peterson, a Pontiac-GMC Truck dealer in Bloomington, Minn., said: "The economy is generally rebounding. People feel better."
He noted that G.M.'s Pontiac Grand Am and Bonneville cars were selling well, as were its GMC Suburban and Yukon light trucks.
 
 
'Hoping for Better'
 But Lee Beaman, a Nashville dealer who sells Pontiacs, Toyotas, GMC Trucks, Suzukis, Lincolns and Mercurys, called his sales disappointing. "Our sales were up 9 percent from last year and 11 percent from last month," he said. "But we had been hoping for better, at least 25 percent better. People are still apprehensive about the economy. They wonder if we have really turned the corner."
Mr. Beaman said that domestic brands were selling slowly, but that Toyotas were attracting customers "because of the new Camry."
Because sales of domestically built vehicles have improved somewhat, auto makers were able to cut by half the amount of down time in their factories in the last six months, compared with a year ago, according to Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry publication.
 The General Motors Corporation sold 72,350 cars during the period, 1.9 percent fewer than a year earlier, and 35,351 light trucks, up a scant three-tenths of a percent. Pontiac was the only one of G.M.'s five car divisions to post a solid gain over last year, on the strength of higher sales of its Grand Prix, Bonneville and Grand Am models.
The Ford Motor Company sold 44,432 cars, up 9.1 percent from a year earlier, and 36,668 light trucks, up 13.9 percent.
The Chrysler Corporation, which reports its vehicle sales once a month, sold an estimated 14,600 cars and 24,450 light trucks in the 10-day period, according to an estimate by Ward's.
 
 
New Camry Helps Toyota
 The Honda Motor Company sold 10,461 cars, an increase of 1.4 percent, while the Toyota Motor Corporation sold 6,255 cars, an increase of 63.5 percent. Toyota's increase is due largely to the popularity of its new Camry model, which is assembled in Georgetown, Ky.
Several of the Japanese auto makers had trouble selling cars built at their United States factories. The Mazda Motor Corporation's car sales dropped 27.1 percent, to 1,447. The Nissan Motor Company's car sales dropped 21.6 percent, to 1,602, and the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation's car sales dropped 17.5 percent, to 1,726.
In the fight for share of the market for domestically built cars, the Big Three gave ground slightly to Japanese producers, capturing an 85.6 percent share, compared with 86.4 percent a year earlier. But Detroit increased its lead in light trucks over its Japanese-based rivals, with 97.1 percent of the market, compared with 96.7 percent last year.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
ARCO Cuts Spending And Sees Lower Profit

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
The Atlantic Richfield Company said yesterday that it had slashed its capital spending plans for the next five years by 20 percent and that it expected to post sharply lower earnings for the first quarter because of lower oil and gas prices and difficulties in its chemical business.
Speaking to securities analysts in New York, Lodwrick M. Cook, ARCO's chairman and chief executive, said earnings for the first quarter would be "disappointing and below the fourth quarter of 1991." 
 ARCO earned $268 million, or $1.67 a share, in the fourth quarter of last year and $351 million, or $2.17 a share, in the first quarter of 1991. First-quarter 1992 results are to be released later this month; analysts were already anticipating a decline.
ARCO said capital spending would fall to $14.7 billion over the next five years from a projected $18.6 billion. The reductions will be spread across ARCO's operations, with the only increase being budgeted for the international division, ARCO said.
"We see a changed environment and are directing our spending plans accordingly," Mr. Cook said.
ARCO's stock gained 25 cents a share yesterday, closing at $107 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Mr. Cook said ARCO, which is based in Los Angeles, was not changing its basic business strategies. But he said that both ARCO's energy and chemicals divisions were facing cyclical difficulties.
"Important industry variables, such as crude oil and domestic natural gas prices, are lower than the 1991 average," he said. "In addition, the weak economic environment has continued to negatively impact ARCO's interests in chemicals businesses."
The continued capital spending increases on foreign operations reflects ARCO's decision to conduct more of its oil and gas activities outside the United States. The company has major development programs in Southeast Asia, the North Sea and other overseas locations.

HEADLINE: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Are Down Sharply

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit were down sharply for the week ended yesterday, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.
"Last week's cut in the Federal funds rate by the Federal Reserve Bank and Chemical Bank's quarter-point cut in its prime lending rate on Monday, to 6 1/4 percent, may mean that we may likely see another round of interest rate cuts before we see another uptick in interest rates," said Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor. 
 He also noted the significant drop in rates at the Treasury's weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills. The results of this closely watched auction sometimes reflect what banks might pay their deposit customers.
 
'Something Needs Fixing'
 "You don't get these kinds of cuts one after another unless something needs fixing," Mr. Heady said. "That the economy is not recovering as expected brings back to mind similar events of a year ago, when the economy slid back into recession."
This new round of cuts could send interest rates even lower, he added, and push depositors into investments, like stocks, bonds and mutual funds.
With April historically a high rollover month for certificates of deposit, some banks may still offer special rates but not as high as depositors would like, bank analysts say.
Yields at New York-area banks slipped significantly, with the average yield on a money market at 3.57 percent, down 6 basis points, and three- and six-month certificates, down 4 basis points, to 3.61 percent and 3.76 percent, respectively. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
Among New York commercial banks, the slip was the greatest, with money market accounts and three-month certificates down an average 7 basis points, to 3.30 percent and 3.41 percent, respectively. The average yield for a six-month certificate was down 5 basis points, to 3.50 percent. At savings institutions money markets were down an average 4 basis points, to 3.85 percent, while three- and six-month certificate dropped 2 basis points, to 3.83 percent and 4.03 percent, respectively.
The biggest yield adjustments in the New York area came from the Republic National Bank, which cut 26 basis points from both its money market account and six-month certificate, to 3.56 percent and 3.82 percent, respectively. While Manufacturers Hanover, dropped the yield on its three-month certificate by 25 basis points, to 3.15 percent.
Yields were also sharply lower at 20 large banks outside the New York-area, with the average money market account down 4 basis points, to 3.52 percent, and a six-month C.D. down 8 basis points, to 3.87 percent.
At the Treasury's weekly bill auction on Monday, interest rates dropped more than a quarter-point, with the average rate on three- and six-month bills at 3.60 percent and 3.73 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: Alan Bond Is Declared Bankrupt in Australia

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, April 14

 BODY:
Alan Bond, the executive best known for financing Australia's triumph in the 1983 America's Cup yacht race, was declared officially bankrupt today.
A banking group headed by the Hongkong Bank of Australia applied for a trustee to be appointed after Mr. Bond failed to repay $194 million arising from a personal guarantee he gave on a loan to a former nickel mining project. 
 The federal court in Sydney ended the yearlong legal battle by rejecting all arguments presented on Mr. Bond's behalf and appointed Robert Ramsay, an accountant, as trustee of his insolvent estate.
 
No Comment From Lawyer
 Mr. Bond's lawyer, Neil Lawson, refused to comment on whether an appeal would be filed, saying he would discuss the available options with his client.
The bankruptcy declaration was the latest chapter in the long fall for the British-born Mr. Bond, a former sign painter who created a financial empire based in Perth.
He was once named Australian of the Year, ranked among the country's richest men, and was virtually a national hero for financing the America's Cup victory over the United States.
But last September, Mr. Bond told the New South Wales Supreme Court that he had few assets left other than about $38,000 in three Perth bank accounts.
When the bankruptcy decision was issued, he was in Perth to appear before a specially appointed Royal Commission investigating possible irregularities in business-Government relations in West Australia state.
 
Trial on Rothwells Set
 Mr. Bond has pleaded not guilty to a charge that he had violated the Securities Code by inducing another executive, Brian Coppin, to contribute to the failed 1987 rescue of Rothwells, a merchant banking company, while concealing a $12 million fee.
Rothwells collapsed in November 1988, with losses of about $200 million. A trial is scheduled to start May 25.
At its peak, the Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd., the company he founded, included interests in brewing, media, resources and property. It had a gold mine and telephone company holdings in Chile, as well as brewing and other mining interests in the United States.
Mr. Bond rode out the stock market crash by living off proceeds from his beer business. Former Prime Minister Bob Hawke once called him "a great Australian."
 
Debts Beyond $6 Billion
 But Mr. Bond continued to extend and overextend his empire. The Bond Corporation eventually ran up debts exceeding $6 billion.
Heavy debts, rising interest rates and bad business decisions alienated Mr. Bond's bankers and creditors, put his Australian brewing interests into receivership and forced him to sell assets ranging from a Hong Kong office development to a coal mine.
Mr. Bond once paid $53.9 million, a record at the time, for Vincent Van Gogh's "Irises," only to be forced to sell it, reportedly for a loss.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Flat to a Bit Higher While Gold Prices Are Up

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was flat to marginally higher yesterday against most currencies, partly because of worries about political instability in Russia.
Gold prices were also higher. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold closed at $339.50 a troy ounce, up 30 cents. Later, the Republic National Bank in New York quoted gold bullion at $339.25, up 45 cents. 
 "It was a very quiet day," said Kevin Logan, chief economist for the Swiss Bank Corporation's New York office. "We traded in a very tight range and the markets barely moved."
Although President Borris Yeltsin of Russia reached a compromise yesterday with lawmakers that will allow him to continue free-market changes, there is still uncertainty surrounding Russia's political and economic future, traders said.
On Monday, Mr. Yeltsin's Cabinet offered to resign to protest the Russian Parliament's vote Saturday demanding changes in Russia's reforms.
Investors tend to seek the relative safety of the United States currency during times of international instability. Concern over a slowdown in Germany's economy and high interest rates there have also favored the dollar, Mr. Logan said.
The dollar rose against the mark in New York yesterday to 1.6535 marks, from 1.6530 late Monday. In London, the dollar finished at 1.6445 German marks, down from 1.6550.
United States retail sales figures released yesterday showed an expected four-tenths of 1 percent decline in March after a strong 1.3 percent gain in February. The weaker figures, however, did not hurt the dollar much, Mr. Logan said.
The report was seen as further evidence of an uneven recovery, rather than a return to recession. Other economic reports due out this week are not expected to have much impact on the dollar, Mr. Logan said.
In New York, the dollar closed at 133.00 yen, unchanged from Monday's close. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 133.05 yen, down 0.25 yen. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 132.70 yen.
Sterling in New York closed at $1.7640, up from $1.7625 late Monday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.7720 from $1.7630.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
2 Wisconsin Agencies Price $124.69 Million in Bonds

 BODY:
Two Wisconsin state agency bond issues totaling $124.69 million were priced for public sale yesterday.
A $72.94 million issue of housing revenue bonds from the Housing and Economic Development Authority through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation was tentatively priced to yield a maximum 7.15 percent for a debt security due in 2013. The bond is part of financing that may be subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax for some investors. Shorter maturities also subject to the tax are priced to yield from 5.25 percent in 1995 to 6.6 percent in 2002, with another long-term maturity due in 2007, priced to yield 7.05 percent. 
 Bonds that are not subject to the tax include an issue due in 2015 that is priced to yield 7 percent and another in 2022, priced to yield 7.1. percent.
The bond offering has a confirmed A-1 rating by Moody's Investors Service Inc., with the Standard & Poor's Corporation expected to rate it A.
The other Wisconsin agency in the market yesterday was the Health and Educational Facilities Authority, which is selling $51.75 million in revenue bonds for a project of the Children's Hospital of Wisconsin Inc.
Underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company priced the shorter-term serial bonds to yield from 5.2 percent in 1995 to 6.4 percent in 2003. The long-term issues, which include a bond due in 2011 and another in 2021, were priced to yield 6.65 percent and 6.7 percent, respectively.
Because of insurance from the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company, covering interest and principal payments, the bonds are rated triple-A by both Moody's and S.& P.

 BODY:
The B. F. Goodrich Company said today that it posted a small profit for the first quarter in contrast to a deficit a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Eating Well

BYLINE: By Marian Burros

 BODY:
IT'S the late 20th century and Lucy Ricardo's Vitameatavegamin of the 50's has been replaced by Jay Kordich's cabbage-spinach-carrot juice. Lucy would be so jealous. Mr. Kordich was selling juicers door-to-door and sleeping in his pickup truck when "I Love Lucy" was still a gleam in Desilu's eye. Now he sells Juiceman II machines on television and drives a Mercedes. His book, "The Juiceman's Power of Juicing" (Morrow, 1992), had a first printing of 300,000 copies and will be on the New York Times best seller list on Sunday.
Whether it's the Juiceman IIor one of the many other machines that separate juice from pulp, these machines are flying out of stores the way oat bran once did. "We can't keep them in the store," said Sheiliah Kissoondath, the office manager at Integral Yoga Natural Foods on West 13th Street in Manhattan. "Business is so good, it's bad. Manufacturers are not filling complete orders." 
 Eat your heart out, Cuisinart.
Mr. Kordith and his imitators have convinced hundreds of thousands of Americans that juicing is as close as they are going to get to the Second Coming. Drink juice, live longer. Have softer, younger skin, more energy. Cure impotency, migraines, anxiety, acne, bleeding gums, sunburn, tendinitis, arthritis, heart disease, cancer, prostate problems, hair loss and weak nails. A juicing fix will improve virtually everything.
"Some of those infomercials originally snagged me," said Allan Fromberg, the assistant editor at Courier-Life Publications, a chain of weekly newspapers in Brooklyn. Mr. Fromberg can't swear that it's the three or four trips to his juicer each day that have improved his energy level. "It's possible I've been eating better," he said. "I don't believe it's gospel, but I don't mind being a consumer pawn."
There's nothing wrong with drinking fresh fruit and vegetable juices. But the idea that juice is much better for you than a whole vegetable or fruit has some nutritionists seeing red. Bonnie Liebman, the director of nutrition at the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a consumer-advocacy group in Washington, doesn't understand why the juice advocates think it is so important that juice goes through your system faster than whole fruits or vegetables.
"What's the rush?" she said. "What difference does it make whether you digest a vegetable or fruit in two hours or two minutes? No one is paying for the use of your digestive tract by the hour."
Of course, juice is more easily digested than the plant from which it is made, but despite what these pitchmen (and women) say, fruits and vegetables do not put any strain on the normal digestive system, as some have suggested. "Juice is much easier on your body," said Manu Dawson, the nutritionist at Integral Yoga. "It's harder to digest the fiber." Then he added, in response to a question, "Fiber is very important so one should certainly have whole foods."
Mr. Kordich agrees on the need for fiber, but in his book he writes: "By drinking juice, you are eliminating a digestive process -- extracting the liquid from the fiber -- and efficiently supplying the body with nutrients. The juicer separates the juice from the fiber so that what you drink is pulp-free and your body receives the maximum amount of nutrients in minutes."
That's what Mr. Kordich says.
This is what the University of California at Berkeley Wellness Letter says: "Some nutrients stay behind in the solids -- thus the whole fruit may contain more of some nutrients."
And this is what Dr. James Duke, an economic botanist at the Agricultural Research Service of the United States Department of Agriculture, says about juice versus whole foods: "I have no reason to think juice is any better than whole fruits and vegetables. I certainly would not tell you to throw the fiber away.
"You do not know what compounds have been left behind when the juice is separated from the pulp. The ratio of these compounds in the fruit is not the same as the ratio in the juice itself."
Checking on fruit versus fruit juices, Dr. Duke found that some juices may have more minerals than an equal volume of the fruit. But he said in a letter that in most cases "the total nutrient or mineral per 100 grams juice is lower than the total per 100 grams fruit." This is particularly true for beta-carotene and tocopherol, both antioxidants.
Dr. Duke does not dismiss out of hand the medicinal claims made for juice or for whole fruits and vegetables. As a specialist who has worked with the designer foods program at the National Cancer Institute, Dr. Duke has a computer full of connections between foods and disease.
"There's no question about a food pharmacy," Dr. Duke said, but he said Mr. Kordich exaggerates the medicinal value of juices. "His statements are more positive than I could possibly make them, even with my more powerful data bases," he said.
For instance, studies on anti-cancer action by certain compounds have been done with the compounds themselves, not with the fruits or vegetables containing them. "Kordich takes a kernel of truth," Ms. Liebman said, "and extrapolates. To put it kindly, it's a theoretical connection."
In a telephone interview last week, Mr. Kordich said he was not exaggerating. "The only thing that works is live foods," he said, without explaining why he considers juice a "live food" but not whole raw fruits and vegetables. "Everyone who eats cooked foods has an immune system that is shot."
Unlike the Hadacol salesmen who peddled the worthless alcohol-based patent medicine for everything that ailed you, compounds in juices do have medicinal properties. But Mr. Kordich makes more out of the connections than science has proved.
The same can be said for most of Mr. Kordich's food cures, like cucumbers to prevent hair loss.
"I haven't heard that one," Dr. Duke said. "If it were true, we'd be selling a lot more cucumbers and a lot less Rogaine," a reference to the drug that can make hair grow.
Though Mr. Kordich would not budge on the validity of his claims, he did acknowledge that the amount of the medicinal compounds in juices is unknown. "Whether we know the amount or not," he said, "I do know that one glass of pineapple juice is the equivalent of 10 pineapples. We know they need a juicer whether the numbers are high or low."
Sensationalism is the word used by Dr. Duke to describe Mr. Kordich's efforts, and he offered his own example. "My data base indicates that corn salad contains more than three milligrams of boron per 100 grams. U.S.D.A. studies show that three milligrams of boron will double blood levels of testosterone. Sensationalists would jump to conclusions and say that a 100-gram serving of corn-salad juice containing three milligrams of boron would make an old man randy, or at least randier."

HEADLINE: More Advice for Doctors: U.S. Guides on Treatments

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
Doctors have no shortage of advice when it comes to treating patients, either before or after the fact. And now a new voice is murmuring over the physician's shoulder, speaking cautiously and softly but nonetheless representing the opinions of experts backed by the Federal Government.
The Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, established by Congress in 1989, has been charged with finding out what the nation gets for the billions of dollars it spends annually on health care and what can be done to improve the return on this investment. 
 Last month the agency began issuing a series of clinical practice guidelines that outline the optimum way for doctors, nurses and other health-care providers to treat certain conditions that affect many Americans. Experts say there is a tremendous variation around the country, and sometimes in the same community, in how doctors and others treat illness, sometimes to the detriment of the patient.
 
New Guides in Works
 The initial recommendations on managing pain after surgery and treating urinary incontinence will be followed in coming months by guidelines on pressure ulcers or bed sores, impairment from cataracts, asymptomatic patients infected with the AIDS virus, sickle cell disease and numerous other conditions.
Part of the agency's charge is disseminating its work, including the guidelines, not only to the medical professions and health industry, but to the public. Agency spokesmen say they have been inundated with requests from the public for copies of consumer versions of the guidelines issued so far.
Of all of its duties, developing guidelines for medical care may be the most controversial. Medical groups have been suspicious of such efforts, particularly when they involved the Government, because of fears that they could lead to standardized "cookbook medicine" that dictated specific treatments and interfered with the doctor-patient relationship.
But in recent years, doctors' groups, including the American Medical Association, have warmed to the idea of broad guidelines it calls practice parameters that outline acceptable therapy options. Adhering to accepted therapeutic approaches may result in better treatment while reducing malpractice claims and decreasing defensive medicine that results in prescribing unnecessary tests and care, some doctors have come to believe.
In this spirit, groups representing doctors and other health providers have supported the efforts of the new policy and research agency and given it their cautious support.
 
Support From A.M.A.
 "We're encouraged by the direction taken by the agency," said Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the American Medical Association. "This is a fine-tuning of the manner in which we provide health care in this country." He said the Government and others should speed the development of practice guidelines in an effort to reduce wasteful defensive medicine and better use health resources.
"We're giving an awful lot of care in this country that shouldn't be given," Dr. Todd said. "Developing practice guidelines can eliminate that care which is marginal."
Dr. J. Jarrett Clinton, director of the policy and research agency, which is part of the Public Health Service, said he was approaching practice guidelines in a new way in hope of increasing their chances of being adopted into standard practice. The agency does not write guidelines itself, but instead convenes panels of experts from other institutions to do the work or contracts with outside organizations to study certain medical procedures.
And instead of having just doctors work on treatment guidelines, the agency puts together panels that include all those involved with managing a disease or condition, as well as consumer representatives, Dr. Clinton said. This can include nurses, nutritionists, physical therapists, pharmacists, social workers, psychologists and many others.
 
Role as a Catalyst
 "We serve as a catalyst," Dr. Clinton said. "We have gotten groups that normally don't talk to each other to join around our table and determine what is best for patient care. Every panel person I talk to says how much they've learned about other people's specialties, and how they've developed a new appreciation for what other people do in managing a particular condition."
Dr. Clinton said the guidelines being developed tend to lay out options for care rather than picking certain practices as standards from which health workers should not deviate.For instance, if studies indicate three drugs are effective in treating a condition, the guidelines would list the drugs and what is known about them and doctors would have the option of choosing the one they consider best for a particular patient.
Unlike most recommendations on care issued by other medical groups, the new agency's guidelines are tested in clinics, medical offices and hospitals before they are released to make sure they are practical. This extra effort, coupled with periodic review of the guidelines to keep them up to date, should help persuade doctors and others to adopt them, Dr. Clinton said.
More significant than even the practice guidelines, Dr. Clinton said, are large-scale, nationwide studies of patient outcomes that are under way to determine how variations in care affect people's lives. So far, 12 Patient Outcome Research Teams, which Dr. Clinton calls "the jewels in our crown," have been financed to judge the effectiveness of treatment of heart attack, cataracts, arthritis and other conditions; initial findings should be available in a year or two.
Eventually, efforts like establishing treatment guidelines and studying the long-term benefits of certain therapies on patients could lead to reducing the cost of medical care, but that is not a goal of the agency, Dr. Clinton said.
"There are those in Congress who hoped, and still hope, that this effort would be a cost-savings device, but it has limited use for this purpose," Dr. Clinton said. "This is not about cost-cutting, but about getting the best value per dollar spent in the long run. In some cases, for instance, the guidelines may result in spending more money on some things."
Representative Henry A. Waxman, a California Democrat who was one of the main sponsors of the bipartisan effort to create the new agency, said he was pleased with its work so far.
"It is doing what we set out for it to do," said Mr. Waxman, the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health and Environment. "We not only want practice-pattern and outcome research to give us guidance for policy and reimbursement, but also to improve the practice of good medicine in this country."
If spending on health care must be cut, Mr. Waxman said, the agency's work would have another use. "I'd rather we do that with knowledge of what is appropriate care and not by arbitrary standards or some meat-ax approach," he said.
Dr. Robert H. Brook, a health-care researcher at the RAND Corporation and the University of California at Los Angeles, said it was too early to tell how effective the new agency would be. For more than 12 years, Dr. Brook has led a project that has documented the inappropriate use of a number of expensive surgical procedures, and he said the Federal agency appeared to be paying more attention to diseases than to some of these costly and overused procedures.
"To make the health system better now, we need to develop more guidelines for these major procedures, such as prostate surgery and hysterectomies," Dr. Brook said. And to get health professionals to accept guidelines, he added, clinical incentives like better care for patients must be combined with economic ones, like limiting reimbursement for those ignoring the recommendations.
Dr. John T. Kelly, the medical association's quality assurance director, said the nation's nearly 500,000 practicing doctors suffered from no shortage of recommendations and guidelines on how to do their jobs. Many medical specialty groups, general medical societies, government agencies like the National Institutes of Health, private research groups, insurance and reimbursement organizations and others offer advice, solicited or otherwise.
The medical association's latest directory of practice guidelines lists 1,300 sets of advice for the nation's doctors from various sources and 250 more under development, Dr. Kelly said.
"Since the 1930's, when the American Academy of Pediatrics released its first guidelines on immunization, they have become very broadly used because of their demonstrated success," Dr. Kelly said. "And in 1986, when the American Society of Anesthesiologists issued specific recommendations for monitoring oxygen and other gases, this had a tremendous impact on cutting adverse events and liability and quickly became a standard."

HEADLINE: Studying the Fine and Less Expensive Art of Dining at Home

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 14

 BODY:
Surrounded by steam kettles and double-stack boilers, a class of food aficionados gathered around a master chef at his cutting board recently as he filleted a salmon, bone by bone, and lectured on the art of selecting vegetables.
"Please don't buy those jumbo carrots," Bradley Ogden, one of the country's leading chefs, chided over the whir of exhaust fans. "The big ones have no flavor to them. When you buy one, smell it, see if it's heavy, if the stem is still attached, if it has an aroma. If it doesn't, put it back." 
 Before him, taking notes, stood an accountant, a chiropractor, a schoolteacher, a stockbroker, a general contractor and some insurance executives, all of whom spent close to $900 a couple plus air fare to hear these words of wisdom and chop onions and grate ginger with the best in the business.
They had flown in from Palm Springs, Fla.; Tulsa, Okla.; East Hampton, L.I., and Nashville, 88 people altogether who spent a tidy sum for a weekend of cooking school at the Four Seasons Hotel here.
It was one of a series of enormously popular cooking weekends organized by Food and Wine magazine in conjunction with Four Seasons Hotels around the country that seem to have flourished in these days of scrimping and cocooning. To these amateur cooks, this was not money out the window but a long-term investment in healthier eating and a quick lesson in re-creating the foie gras 80's without guilt.
"People are finding you can do it for less at home and on your own terms," said W. Peter Prestcott, a senior editor at Food and Wine. "Home is becoming the last fortress. People are redigging their moats, drawing the curtains and standing by their stoves with their nearest and dearest."
Like recovering shopaholics chastened by overspending, some of the people who gathered here on a brisk spring weekend admitted to the excesses of a cheerier decade, the $100 dinners that had become all too routine, the feigned ignorance about how to preheat an oven. Now they want to change.
"Our version of cooking was pushing the re-dial button on the telephone to see which restaurant delivered," said Melvina Ng, a Manhattan accountant, who came to the cooking weekend with her husband, Mark Ng, a teacher.
Now Mr. Ng was assisting Mr. Ogden, the executive chef of the Lark Creek Inn outside San Francisco, with the blood-orange vinaigrette, pouring the olive oil as Mr. Ogden stirred.
In another corner of the kitchen, Richard Shilowich, a general contractor from East Hampton, stood over a flat-top range grilling onions. The cooking weekend was his Christmas present from his wife, Terri Rauch, a chiropractor, and Mr. Shilowich, the primary cook in the family, was in nirvana.
"What you get out of a weekend like this is a lot of subtleties," Mr. Shilowich said. "You can always pick up a recipe."
For them, the weekend was a declaration of independence from long lines at hot restaurants and the pressure to be pretentious.
"We've all gotten tired of the $100 dinners that are mediocre," Ms. Rauch said. "We're all going back to home-style things. Now you're not embarrassed to serve Irish stew or beef burgundy or pizza. People are just happy to be getting together. And you don't have to worry about somebody dropping the Waterford."
The downscaling of the food experience was everywhere during the weekend. Instead of decadent centerpieces of fresh-cut flowers flown in from the tropics, the tables at the weekend's semiformal dinner had glass vases filled with things like turnips or artichokes in free-form vegetable sculptures.
And in a course on table-setting, Mr. Prestcott showed how even cheap reproductions from modest retailers like Pier 1 Imports could become elegant table art with the right touch. He held up a blue fish vase and, before anyone could say it, conceded that everyone in the class probably hated it. Then he put three of them together as the table centerpiece.
"Now it becomes Bernini," Mr. Prestcott said, pleased with himself. "It becomes a fountain. One thing finds another. It is not just a fish. It is a statement of mass and subject."
In a lecture that was part Dalai Lama and part Robin Leach, he admonished the class not to make centerpieces into hedges or to use too-skimpy napkins or to seat ex-spouses together, all the while extolling the dinner table's central role in "the ceremony of life."
"The table is a forum," Mr. Prestcott said. "It is where you present who you are, what you've learned, what is important to you, your way of living."
That is why, he said, no table, however humble or how tough the times, should go without a little artistry. "Even on your non-Queen Elizabeth, Cousin Betty table, you want to keep a certain symmetry and neatness about it," he said.
Over all, however, the weekend was devoted to lighter, more healthful cooking, and students were taught how to cook with less fat, using vinegars and chilis and herbs to bring out the flavor.
"There is rice vinegar, balsamic vinegar, tarragon vinegar, imported white-wine vinegar and raspberry vinegar, which you can easily make at home," said Mark Baker, executive chef at the Chicago Four Seasons Hotel.
Within minutes, the kitchen took on the scent of vinegar and raspberries coming to a boil, nearly ready to be stored in earthenware a couple of weeks before being bottled. At the same time, a salmon fillet was ready after 10 minutes in a dime-store bamboo steamer over tarragon and ginger in water, without an ounce of butter or oil.
And in another kitchen, Mr. Ogden was instructing students on such things as the best way to dress a tossed salad.
"Most people season the center instead of the whole," Mr. Ogden said. He told them to oil the inside of the bowl rather than the lettuce and to "work from the bottom. Toss lightly until the leaves are evenly coated."
Karen Santucci, a first-grade teacher from Rochester, was taking notes as if she were in a calculus class, afraid to do too much dicing of vegetables because she might miss something.
"I didn't come here to chop and mash," Ms. Santucci said. "I can always chop and mash at home."
She grew up watching her Italian grandmother make pasta from scratch and decided, recession or no, to take the leap and treat herself to a dream weekend as a present to herself.
"I don't drink or smoke," Ms. Santucci said. "I don't drive a fancy car. I've never been one to whip out the Visa card and spend on just anything. But this is something that makes me smile."

HEADLINE: There's Still Time to Save U.S. Shipbuilding

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Those who want to know how committed Congress and the Bush Administration are to saving United States manufacturing and American jobs will get their answer when a bill designed to end the foreign subsidies that are annihilating an important American industry goes to the floor of the House of Representatives.
This is H.R. 2056, the shipbuilding trade reform bill. Introduced a year ago by Congresman Sam Gibbons of Florida, it was first intended to give an incentive to industrialized countries engaged in multilateral trade talks to quit stalling and terminate their subsidies for shipbuilding and repair that have shut United States shipyards out of the commercial ship construction market in the last 10 years. When that objective failed, the bill became a piece of legislation to be taken seriously in its own right. 
 What H.R. 2056 does is make shipbuilding and repair subsidies illegal under United States trade law. Although subsidies connected with construction or repair of ships in the current fleet would be grandfathered, subsidies provided after the date of the bill's enactment would have to be repaid before the ships concerned could dock in United States ports. Once a country signs an agreement with the United States to terminate its shipbuilding repair subsidies, the requirement goes away.
In addition, H.R. 2056 defines a ship as a product subject to the same trade laws as airplanes, trains, trucks and other manufactured goods, thereby ending the special exemption enjoyed only by shipowners that allows them to take advantage of dumped ships without penalty.
Despite strong opposition from ship owners and operators, H.R. 2056 has undergone the unusual procedure of being scrutinized and approved by two House committees, first by Ways and Means and then by Merchant Marine and Fisheries.
No doubt, the reputation of Sam Gibbons has helped to keep this tough trade bill from being buried. It is difficult to label the legislation as "protectionist" when it was introduced by a Representative with impeccable antiprotectionist credentials, who is a staunch advocate of free and fair trade.
Another reason the bill has gotten so far is that the subsidies case is compelling. In no manufacturing industry in the world today is the evidence of direct government intervention to capture market share so clear and irrefutable as in foreign shipbuilding. Government support policies in the 1980's allowed shipyards in Japan, South Korea and Europe to charge ship prices that covered as little as 45 percent of production costs. There have been examples of commercial ship construction subsidies as high as 60 percent of contract price. Foreign shipbuilding subsidies still distort the market.
Is it any wonder then that United States shipyards -- which had their subsidies cut off in 1981 -- were forced out of the commercial ship construction market? One-third of American shipbuilding capacity was shut down, and 120,000 American shipyard and shipyard-supplier jobs were lost. Now the situation is even more critical. With the end of the cold war, the United States Navy does not require a sufficient number of new ships to keep American yards in business. Consequently, it is projected that by 1998, 180,000 more Americans working in United States shipyards and related supplier industries will lose their jobs.
Unfortunately, ship owners and operators, who are fighting to retain construction and repair subsidies for their ships, have generated fears that H.R. 2056 will harm other American business segments (such as the ports), despite the lack of evidence.
However, there is plenty of evidence that other segments of the American economy would be harmed by the loss of the American shipbuilding industry, which includes more than 1,000 associated shipyard supplier companies. This is not hyperbole. It is the grim reality that passage of H.R. 2056 can avert.
 
JOHN STOCKER
President
Shipbuilders Council of America
Arlington, Va., April 3, 1992

HEADLINE: Why Economists Shun Deficit Spending

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your March 31 Business Day report that some economists now favor an increase in the Federal deficit to stimulate the economy misstates why many economists continue to resist this traditional Keynesian prescription. They do not believe that deficit spending, "by putting more money into circulation, increases inflation."
That is an Eisenhower-era view, which few economists still hold, if only because Government borrowing does not put money into circulation and because inflation is seen as fundamentally a result of excessive money creation by the Federal Reserve. 
 Many economists oppose more deficit spending now because they recognize that, despite all the gloom, the recession is shallow and is gradually correcting itself. They doubt that Government can quickly crank uptargeted public investment projects. Every one of the 435 Congressional districts will have to get something. Worse, they fear such spending will build gradually, even as the private sector acquires momentum, and that it will be impossible to moderate or stop the new Federal spending and avoid overheating the economy.
Finally, interest payments on the deficit pre-empt future decisions on how to regulate fiscal policy and allocate the resources available to the Government. In this sense of foreclosed opportunities, the next generation will have to pay for today's deficit spending.
 
EDWARD COWAN
Washington, April 2, 1992
 
The writer is with Ried, Thunberg & Company, investment researchers.

HEADLINE: Nobody Migrates for Better Welfare Benefits

 BODY:
To the Editor:
According to an article on the Albany legislative impasse on the state budget (March 23), officials were "arguing about measures aimed at deterring people from moving to New York to qualify for welfare benefits."
This myth stems from a supposition that poor people calculate the marginal increase in their standard of living that life in New York's poor neighborhoods might bring about and voluntarily pull their children out of school, cut off their relationships with friends and family, and move to the promised land represented by this recession-ridden state. 
 In 1969, similar criticisms were made of New York City's welfare administration at a time when welfare rolls were mounting. The Federal Government sent a team of researchers to determine the accuracy of the assertions that such increases in public assistanace claims were due to migration sparked by the lure of munificent welfare benefits.
The researchers found no such evidence. They determined that some migrant families applied for assistance about a year after they arrived, after a period in which they tried to make it on their own in the difficult economic climate of the city.
Legislative action to reduce welfare benefits is as shortsighted as it is cruel. Reduction of benefits for children of families on public assistance will destroy the fragile nutritional foundation they need to lead healthy lives as children and later as adults. We will be paying for these reductions for the rest of their lives with early results becoming evident in reduced school attendance and lowered school performance.
If we increase the desperation in the lives of adults on welfare, we will pay for it in increased homelessness, higher Medicaid bills for sicker people and increases in the costs of courts, police and corrections.
I believe we are witnessing an effort by some politicians to throw off responsibility for the recession and their failure to do much to help its victims onto the victims themselves. They are not supported by economic fact, but by self-serving fictions which are the product of racial and class bias.
 
LOUIS LEVITT
Prof. of Social Work, Yeshiva U.
New York, April 2, 1992

HEADLINE: Albany Blunders in Cut To Child-Care Funds

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Cutting Title XX funds from the New York State budget is a clear example of the penny-wise, pound-foolish thinking that went on in Albany during state budget negotiations.
Title XX is one of the most successful programs the state has financed. In New York a significant portion is used for subsidized child care. It keeps the working poor working and off welfare. Single working mothers, who benefit most from these funds, will lose the most from this cut. Without Title XX, day care for these families will become unaffordable. Counties have been mandated by the Governor to shoulder the burden of the state's share of these funds. How they will do this, given their own fiscal woes, remains to be seen. 
 The Title XX cut may also have a domino effect. If the state cannot demonstrate to the Federal Government a maintenance of effort in paying for day care, New York will lose all or part of its share of the $2.5 billion in new Federal child care money. Subsidized child care more than pays for itself.
To cut Title XX funds when the recession is swelling the ranks of families who need to stay employed, shows fiscal absurdity, not fiscal responsibility.
 
HOWARD MILBERT
Executive Director
Ossining Children's Center
Ossining, N.Y., April 3, 1992

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Fly Now, Pay Later

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WANT to jet round trip to Hawaii for just $149? No problem. Just book 45 days in advance, stay over one Tuesday that is not a legal holiday anywhere in the Southern Hemisphere and complete travel in a month with fewer than 29 days. . . .
American Airlines' bold move to simplify fares and slash the margins between discounted and unrestricted seats is winning applause from both business travelers and computer-bleary travel agents. But their enthusiasm may be tempered by the prospect of less competition and higher prices in the future. 
 For in the view of some analysts -- notably, Michael Levine, the former president of New York Airways who is now dean of Yale's School of Organization and Management -- it could give American a commanding edge over weaker rivals. And it will almost certainly unhinge the survival strategies of the very weakest, perhaps pushing Continental and T.W.A. past the point of no return.
Like it or not, most airlines have followed American's move from 16 or 17 fares per route to four. Fares for unrestricted seats in both the front and back of the plane have been cut sharply -- one-way coach from New York to Chicago, for example, is down from $427 to $250. And the hodgepodge of discounts has been rationalized to just two advance purchase options with obligatory Saturday stayovers.
The biggest winners are the minority of business travelers who cannot plan ahead, but lack the muscle to negotiate special deals with individual carriers. The changes should also eliminate some headaches for the airlines, which have been losing the battle to make posted prices stick.
With unrestricted coach fares down 38 percent, Daniel Kasper, an airline consultant at the Harbridge House firm in Massachusetts, predicts that few corporate buyers will bother to press for better deals. And few penny-pinching business travelers will bother to play games with restricted fares -- evading the Saturday stayover rule, for example, by purchasing two deeply discounted round trips and tearing up the return portions.
There is a darker side, though, to what is widely viewed as a strategic coup by Robert L. Crandall, the hard-driving chief executive of American who has exploited the airline's size and technological edge with the finesse of a sumo champion. By eliminating incentives for corporate discounts, virtually all bookings should end up at posted fares. And Michael Levine argues that "American does best when all the cards are played face up."
The giant carrier owns Sabre, the most successful of the computerized airline reservation systems. It will thus reap a modest windfall from writing more tickets for other carriers. Then, too, the cut in off-computer bookings and the simplification of the fare structure will make it almost impossible for other carriers to undercut American's fares without being discovered.
But these are marginal considerations, Mr. Levine suggests, compared with the blunter competitive effects of the new pricing formula. Mr. Crandall acknowledges that American will take an initial hit on revenues from the dilution of fares. But what is merely painful for American and its deep-pockets rivals, Delta Air Lines and United, could prove crippling to financially pressed Northwest and USAir. And it is likely to put both T.W.A. and Continental in the intensive care unit.
The consequences for these latter two carriers, Mr. Levine argues, may be even more dire than they initially appear. For both have been using pricing strategies that exploited travelers' frustrations with sky-high unrestricted fares.
T.W.A. has been luring passengers who lacked access to corporate discounts by selling unrestricted tickets at steep discounts to full fare. Continental has played a variation on the same game, seating those who paid full-fare coach in the first-class compartment. T.W.A. has already responded to the American initiative by cutting unrestricted fares yet again, further diluting potential revenues. And Continental is between a rock and a hard place: First class at the competitive coach rate now means far less income for the beleagured carrier.
How one stands on the fare changes largely depends on where one sits. Mr. Crandall makes no secret of his disgust with a bankruptcy system that forces American to compete with deeply indebted airlines that need not make interest payments to keep on flying. He believes that the technology and economics of the business leave room for only three healthy airlines operating nationwide -- a scenario that would ground Northwest and USAir, as well as Continental or T.W.A.
Effective price competition on virtually all routes may still be possible with just three or four mega-carriers. But it remains a scary scenario for deregulation-minded economists, who always assumed that competition would be guarded by the relative ease of entry into the airline industry.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 17, 1992, Friday

 CORRECTION:
The Economic Scene column in Business Day on Wednesday misidentified the company once headed by Michael Levine. He was president of New York Air, an airline that served many cities from LaGuardia Airport before it went out of business, not of New York Airways, which provided helicopter service in the metropolitan area.

HEADLINE: Schools Cope With Influx of Immigrants

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
The huddled masses keep pouring into New York City's schools, infusing them with immigrant ambition and novel folkways but also overloading classrooms and straining the budget and the teaching staff.
An annual report issued yesterday by the Board of Education showed that about 120,000 immigrants from 167 countries had enrolled in the city's schools over the past three years, pushing the system's student population close to the million mark. This year's influx of 43,268 immigrants is greater than the 40,845 that enrolled in the 1990-91 school year, and even more than the 35,600 in the 1989-90 school year, indicating that the trend is nowhere near abating. 
 Robin Willner, the board's director of strategic planning, compared the tide to the immigrant waves of the turn of the century and the period after World War I when New York City's classrooms were brimming with Jewish and Italian immigrants who frustrated their teachers with their halting English and unfamiliar customs, but brought with them a vast reservoir of desire and hope.
 
Stretching a Shrinking Budget
 "There's a self-selection process for people who have been through incredible difficulties and they bring a lot of drive and determination," she said. "But these are also youngsters who have been through a lot of tumult and they are usually limited in English proficiency and going through differences in culture, and we need to provide services to make that transition easier."
Despite a shrinking budget, the board must find and pay for more bilingual teachers and teachers of English as a second language. It already has more than 5,200 such teachers, about 8 percent of its staff, and has had difficulty finding more, particularly for immigrant groups like Albanians, who have not historically been well represented in the city. The cost of immigrant language programs is $130.6 million a year, most of it paid with Federal and state money.
Many of the immigrants come from countries where education may not be compulsory for as many years as it is in the United States; New York City's teachers often must work with students who are illiterate even in their native languages. Ms. Willner said students also bring with them attitudes toward their teachers' authority and to class participation that are in sharp contrast to the more freewheeling customs of the United States.
The school board is also squeezed for classroom space. It has a $4.3 billion program for constructing new buildings and renovating old ones, but much of the program has been scaled back in the city's fiscal crunch.
 
Classes in Auditoriums
 Of the 120,000 students who have immigrated during the past three years, 23,000 are from the Dominican Republic, 10,000 from Jamaica, 8,000 from Russia and the former Soviet Union, 7,000 from Guyana, 7,000 from China, 6,000 from Haiti, 4,800 from Trinidad and 4,200 from Mexico.
One elementary school, P.S. 19 in Elmhurst, in Queens School District 24, has 2,100 students from 45 different countries and is so crowded that it equals the size of many high schools, which draw from far larger geographical zones.
John Falco, the district's deputy superintendent, told of classrooms in other schools in his district that are held on auditorium stages or in assistant principals' offices. One classroom with 45 students is taught simultaneously by two teachers in order not to violate the union contract.
Carlos Ledee, the district's bilingual director, said the district had enough Spanish, Chinese and Korean students to form bilingual classes of at least 20 on a grade. Students from Eastern Europe and other countries with small representations are assigned to regular classes and pulled out for 45 minutes each day for instruction in English as a second language.
 
2d-Generation Challenges
 The district, which includes Elmhurst, Corona, Maspeth, Ridgewood and Woodside, is getting two new schools and additions to another five.
"Our immigrant population is terrific," Mr. Falco said. "Without getting overly maudlin, it's more or less the way my family arrived in this country a generation or so ago. You have industrious people who come to this country for all the benefits our family came for -- freedom and economic prosperity -- with children eager to learn."
Dr. Emanuel Tobier, a professor of economics and planning at New York University, suggests that things may get tougher before they get better. Many of the immigrant couples who are bringing children will be bearing more children and many of the children they already have may be approaching child-bearing age themselves. All this promises a mushrooming in the numbers of second-generation children and the challenges they pose.
Mr. Tobier said that while hard-driving immigrants may find success among the city's employers, he wondered whether the children of those immigrants may lose some of their hunger to learn in schools that are overcrowded and underfinanced.
