HEADLINE: Topless Bars For a Crowd In Pin Stripes

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
AFTER a long day at work, Richard Siegel, a lawyer in his late 30's, likes to unwind with a cool beer, a little music and a circle of topless young women with cash stuffed in their garters.
"Hey, this is elegant -- it's not sleazy," he said, referring to Stringfellows, a nightclub in the staid Gramercy Park neighborhood of Manhattan that was popular in the 1980's and recently reopened with semi-nude dancers. "You can bring a date here and not give a bad impression." 
 Posh strip clubs like Stringfellows, with their coat-and-tie dress codes and $15 cover charges, have been opening with an astonishing frequency in the past few years. About 1,100 "quality" topless clubs now exist in 47 states, up from about 800 in 45 states five years ago, according to Gentlemen's Club magazine in Austin, Tex., a trade magazine for the $3 billion-a-year topless industry. New Jersey has the most, 110, followed by Texas, Florida, Pennsylvania and New York.
"A lot of people have realized that the yuppies will pay top dollar if the atmosphere is right," said Kevin King, publisher of Gentlemen's Club.
Unlike the dark dives of years past, today's clubs make 80's features like topless female boxers and mud wrestlers seem declasse. Some clubs, like Stringfellows, have high-priced menus and a faux-Folies-Bergere ambiance; the dancers peel off sequined evening gowns.
A few, like Scores, on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, bill themselves as topless sports bars, where customers who get bored looking at bare breasts can shoot baskets or watch hockey on a wide-screen television.
Others, like the Gold Club in Atlanta, the Men's Club in Houston or Cabaret Royale in Dallas, have amenities like valet parking, limousines, shuttle buses, executive dining rooms and fax-outfitted conference rooms, not to mention topless women who shine shoes and perform secretarial duties.
"What topless is doing is replacing disco in America," said D. Keith Mano, a writer who conducted 300 interviews over 10 years for his novel "Topless" (Random House, 1991). "What it is getting closer to is a kind of burlesque atmosphere."
The trend toward elegant topless clubs, which started in Canada a decade ago before spreading to Florida and Texas, may be attributed, at least in part, to novelty. Other factors include the fear of singles bars in the age of AIDS. But Jay O. Bildstein, a Manhattan investment banker who opened Scores late last year, thinks he has identified the real source of the boom: "This business has nothing to do with sex; it is about loneliness and low self-esteem," he said. "If anyone is being exploited it is the men, the guys buying into the fantasy of she really likes me."
Even so, the recent appeal of top-drawer topless bars comes at a curious time, especially considering the ruling by the Supreme Court of the United States last year in Barnes v. Glen Theater, which gave localities the right to ban the baring of female nipples unless they are covered with flesh-colored makeup and liquid latex, which is how pasties are concocted these days.
Campaigns to ban topless bars are being fought in towns across the country. In Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Michael J. Peter, who manages Stringfellows and who owns or operates 23 other high-priced topless bars in several states, has estimated that he has spent $2 million in the past 18 months on lawyers to keep his clubs open. The legal expenses are a trifle, though, as are the tens of thousands of dollars that his clubs give, for public-relations purposes, to local charities each year. Mr. Peter's own clubs, located in Florida, Minnesota, South Carolina, Hawaii and Texas, can easily gross $30,000 to $100,000 a week each in alcohol sales alone.
"What you see here is the entertainment night life of the 90's," said Mr. Peter, who graduated from Cornell University's School of Hotel Administration and is widely credited with applying modern marketing techniques (like selling trading cards featuring his topless dancers) to what had been considered a seedy, small-time business.
Many women understandably believe that the bars exploit women. "They are demeaning and degrading to women and treat them like sex objects," said Caia M. Mockaitis, a spokeswoman for Concerned Women of America, an advocacy group in Washington. "All they do is foster an unhealthy relationship between men and women."
Not all women share this view. Many dancers say their work is no more exploitative than most other forms of employment. Besides, they say, by dancing in a G-string they can earn in one night's tips as much as they could in a month in many other jobs.
"I can make $1,000 a night or more, if I really work at it," said Tara Obenauer, 21, of Massapequa, L.I., who dances at Stringfellows and graduated from Adelphi University last year. "I was supposed to start law school at N.Y.U. in January, but I put it off for awhile," she said. "The money here is just so good."
No studies exist about topless dancing, but Mr. Mano, the author, estimates that 250,000 women in American have danced topless professionally at one time in their lives.
To be sure, some men view topless dancing with disdain. "It's one more example of where voyeurism has replaced committed sexuality," said Robert H. Knight, director of the Cultural Studies Project at the Family Research Council, a research organization in Washington.
"It portrays women as objects merely for men's fancies," he said, "and it helps create the kind of world in which you fear for your daughters walking down the street and not being seen as a person, but as an outlet for someone's fantasies."
Male customers, for the most part, seem oblivious to the politics of topless dancing. "Of course it's sexist -- if you worry about that," said Jim Watson, who lives in Manhattan and recently visited Stringfellows a second time.
Female patrons can also be found at topless clubs, although they account for only a smattering of the audience, regardless of what some club owners claim. "It's modern art," said Teeney L. Lee, 27, a real-estate agent from Flushing, Queens, who visited Stringfellows recently. "They are beautiful women, but I would like to see male dancers in here as well."
At Stringfellows and many of the bars, the dancers also work between sets, slithering seductively from table to table. "Would you like a dance after your dinner, sir?" they inquire.
For $20, a woman will strip at a customer's table; it's called "table dancing." Then, there is "lap dancing" in which a dancer strips within touching distance of a customer -- who must keep his hands to himself. The service usually ends with the dancer sitting in the customer's lap. Tips for both stage and private dances are usually proffered by tucking a bill or two under the woman's garter. Dancers are not permitted to make dates or meet with customers after work.
Though topless clubs are being aggressively promoted as ideal places for business lunches and meetings, it can be dangerous for a male executive to entertain female clients or colleagues there. It could lead to a sexual harassment complaint.
"If I were a person setting up a policy for a company, in the frame of today's anger on sexual harassment, I would completely forbid any company activity taking place in these establishments," said Wendy Reid Crisp, the director of the National Association for Female Executives.
She added that the apparent popularity of the bars may be part of the male backlash against social, economic and political gains made by women. "Men want to feel that they are back in control, in a relationship between the sexes that they understand," she said. "They feel extremely threatened by the issues of sexual violence and harassment. They are desperately trying to reestablish a masculinity that is familiar to them."
The clubs themselves are trying to establish respectability. To lure out-of-towners, Stringfellows, for example, intends to apply for membership in the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau.
Said Rob Abner, publisher of Stripper Magazine, a three-year-old trade magazine in Manhattan, "There is a much more increased tolerance these days -- look at television and the tabloids. Even though most people think things have become more conservative, this kind of entertainment has actually become more common."

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Office Space In Houston: Plenty of It

BYLINE: By Lettice Stuart

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
THE Apache Corporation, which signed a lease for 220,000 square feet of office space here last November -- in the largest office lease transaction completed in Houston in 1991 -- is now relocating its corporate headquarters here from Denver.
The move by Apache, the country's fourth-largest independent oil and gas producer, gave rise to optimism here. It came as part of the steady rebound of the Houston office market since 1987, when a drop in oil prices sent the city's office vacancy rate soaring to 30 percent. Today the vacancy rate is 22.5 percent. 
 Now, however, another shakeout in the energy industry is slowing that progress. Continued low oil and gas prices, as well as restrictive regulations, are forcing some major energy concerns to shut down domestic exploration and production and shift operations overseas. That translates into vacant office space in Houston, where many of the companies have consolidated in recent years.
"There's no question that the office market is being affected by cutbacks in the energy industry and the national economy," said Edward H. Cappel, senior vice president of the CB Commercial Real Estate Group Inc. During the first quarter of this year the amount of empty office space in Houston actually increased by 106,000 square feet, Mr. Cappel said.
Cutbacks at just two companies -- the Transco Energy Company and Union Texas Petroleum -- will soon add more than 700,000 square feet to the city's inventory of 30 million square feet of empty office space.
To compound the problem, several companies that are doing well have decided on new construction to fill their expansion needs. Three high-rise office buildings with a total of nearly 1.4 million square feet are under construction for major tenants that will leave behind blocks of empty space in other buildings when they move.
The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation will occupy 306,000 square feet of a 452,000-square-foot building being developed in North Houston by the Friendswood Development Company. The 19-story Anadarko Tower is scheduled for completion in June.
British Petroleum Exploration Inc., will occupy 430,000 square feet in the 20-story, 588,000-square-foot BP Plaza when it is completed late this year. That project is on Interstate 10 in West Houston. The Barker-Patrinely Group is the developer.
And BMC Software is building a 20-story, 475,000-square-foot headquarters building in West Houston. It is scheduled for completion in late 1993.
But, according to Mr. Cappel, the office market will pick up through the remainder of the year and end on a positive note with a net absorption of about 1.8 million square feet. Absorption is an increase in occupancy that reduces the city's total inventory of available office space.
When the major oil companies pull out, independent energy concerns like Apache will move in, Mr. Cappel predicted. "But that doesn't happen overnight," he said. "It takes time for companies to shut down their operations and sell off their oil and gas properties."
Apache decided to move its corporate headquarters to Houston last year after acquiring an Amoco subsidiary that owned a large amount of oil and gas properties in the Gulf Coast area, Jeanne Buchanan, Apach e's director of corporate communications, said. The move is intended to get management closer to operations.
Apache will occupy 14 floors of the 20-story 1 Post Oak Central building in the Galleria area. Some tenants in the Post Oak building were relocated to open up the necessary space, but a large chunk of the building had been vacant for several years, said Tim D. Relyea, executive vice president of Cushman Realty, who handled the lease transaction, along with Scott Wegmann.
The space has been completely gutted, and Apache is moving employees in as floors are built out. Apache will relocate 125 employees from Denver and hire additional staff in Houston for a total work force of 450, Ms. Buchanan said. Apache currently occupies 145,000 square feet of space in 1 United Bank Center in downtown Denver.
Mr. Relyea also recently leased 70,000 square feet of space in 1 Allen Center downtown to the Phibro Energy Company, a large oil trader that is relocating its corporate offices to Houston from Greenwich, Conn.
But despite such positive signs, Mr. Relyea does not see the current problem in the oil patch as short term. He said office rents had already started to decline in the central business district and the Galleria area, the two areas with the greatest concentration of office space.
According to a survey by the Kerr Resource Center, the average rental rate for office space in the central business district, which has 41 million square feet of office space, is $15.75 a square foot. The average rate in the Galleria area, which has 33 million square feet of office space, is $13.85. Both areas have a vacancy rate of 21.4 percent.

HEADLINE: $44 BILLION NEEDED TO AID EX-SOVIETS IN 1992, I.M.F. SAYS

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund said today that the former Soviet Union would need $44 billion in foreign aid this year to help insure that the transition to a market economy does not break down.
In presenting the fund's first official estimate of the needs of Russia and the 14 other republics, Michel Camdessus, the I.M.F.'s managing director, confirmed an estimate by the United States and Germany that Russia required about $24 billion and said the 14 other republics would need about $20 billion more in outside help this year. 
 Most of this would be for financing crucial imports like food and spare parts.
Indeed, I.M.F. officials said the 130 million people of the 14 other republics, including the three Baltic nations -- Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania -- would need more aid to finance imports than the 150 million people of Russia.
 
Exports Help Russia
 Russia's financing needs are smaller, the officials said, because it has traditionally been a large exporter of oil, natural gas and machinery, while most of the other republics, which were never large exporters, import most of their energy needs.
At a news conference at the International Monetary Fund's headquarters here, Mr. Camdessus said that over the next four years, the lands of the former Soviet Union would need more than $100 billion in outside aid from the I.M.F., the World Bank, the governments of industrial nations and private investors.
He estimated that the I.M.F. would provide $25 billion to $30 billion in loans over the next four years and that the World Bank would lend $12 billion to $15 billion.
American officials said the Group of Seven nations, already discussing aid to the 14 republics other than Russia, have identified where more than half of the $20 billion needed this year would come from.
 
Aid From Europe and Others
 They said the United States, the European Community countries and other industrial nations were talking about providing $7 billion in direct government-to-government aid, including $500 million in commodity credits promised by President Bush.
The I.M.F. and the World Bank are expected to provide $2 billion to $3 billion in aid. Then there is $3 billion more coming from the deferral of principal and interest payments on the republics' foreign debts.
"The magnitude of the problems facing the 15 republics is unprecedented," Mr. Camdessus said. "They go far beyond what is generally understood by the concept of economic transformation. These peoples are creating new nations, from scratch and in a very brief period."
The amount that Mr. Camdessus said was needed for the former Soviet lands this year dwarfs aid to most other countries. The total foreign aid budget of the United States is about $15 billion a year. The I.M.F.'s current aid package to India, which has 850 million people, is $1.65 billion.
Early this month, President Bush and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany announced the aid package for Russia, including $18 billion to help finance imports and $6 billion for a ruble-stabilization fund.
Today, though, Mr. Camdessus said he was unsure when large-scale aid would begin flowing to the former Soviet republics.
"They face serious obstacles," he said in further remarks tonight, at a speech at Georgetown University. "There will be setbacks, time and time again. We must help make the move to freedom irreversible."
Mr. Camdessus said he hoped the I.M.F.'s 156 members would vote to approve membership of Russia and 13 other republics in the fund in time for the fund's spring meeting on April 27. He said Azerbaijan's membership application had been delayed by a snag in communications with Baku, that republic's capital.
Mr. Camdessus said fund officials would go to Moscow in May to negotiate an agreement calling on Russia to make market-oriented reforms and meet certain economic goals in the hope that major aid would begin flowing in July.
Such agreements with other republics would probably be signed later in the summer, opening the doors to I.M.F. loans. Direct government aid and debt rescheduling are often contingent on the signing of an I.M.F. agreement.
 
A Sense of Urgency
 "Can these countries wait so long?" Mr. Camdessus said. "I hope so. They are under a tremendous financial squeeze, and the sooner the program is in place, the better."
Mr. Camdessus predicted that in several years the former Soviet republics would begin enjoying economic growth of a robust 4 percent a year, after last year's 17 percent plunge in output.
Mr. Camdessus said the recent clash between the reform team of President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and a Parliament hostile to rapid change was to be expected and was a healthy development that could help create a consensus in Russia on reform.
With the I.M.F. stepping up its negotiations with the 15 republics, Mr. Camdessus sought to prod them to faster reforms, calling on them to remove price controls, remove trade barriers, privatize state enterprises and slash their budget deficits to prevent hyperinflation. He also called on them to adapt laws and institutions to enable a market economy to function.
Because the transition to a market economy and lifting of price controls is creating trauma in the already poor republics, he called for greater effort to protect the poor.
"The need for adequate social safety nets is greatest when society is undergoing far-reaching upheavals, which is now," he said.
Mr. Camdessus said the I.M.F. would be more generous in aiding republics that are more aggressive in embracing reform. "The stronger the program, the stronger the financing will be," he said.
He acknowledged, though, that it would be the unwise for the I.M.F. to push countries to move too rapidly with reforms because the pain they cause could set off a popular explosion that would end reforms. Poland's Prime Minister, for instance, was in Washington this week to talk with the I.M.F. about a reform program that many Poles believe is too harsh.
Mr. Camdessus said that in light of the heavy financing demands that the former Soviet Union and many developing countries are making on the fund, it was important for the I.M.F.'s funding to be increased. The failure of the United States to approve an additional $12 billion contribution is holding up a planned overall $60 billion increase in the I.M.F.'s capital.
After months of not pressing the issue, the Bush administration has stepped up its call on Congress to approve this contribution.
"The vote by the U.S. Congress is absolutely critical," Mr. Camdessus said.
President Bush has said the United States will finance about one-fifth of the $24 billion in aid to Russia, but American and I.M.F. officials say it is too early to specify how much the United States or any other country will contribute toward the $20 billion needed by the other 14 republics. The United States says it will contribute $2 billion in direct aid to the Russian Government, mostly credits for it to buy grain from American farmers.
The United States has about a 19 percent share in both the I.M.F. and the World Bank, and thus will indirectly finance 19 percent of the money those institutions lend to the former Soviets republics. But because of those loans will be repaid and because the United States contributed this money to the I.M.F. years ago, the costs are not really felt by American taxpayers. And since the United States holds very little of the more than $60 billion in debt that Russia is seeking to defer, debt rescheduling will have little effect on the United States.

HEADLINE: ISOLATION OF LIBYA GROWS AS ITS LINKS TO WORLD ARE CUT

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 15

 BODY:
Air traffic between Libya and the rest of the world appeared at a standstill today as both Arab and non-Arab countries began enforcing the second major punitive embargo the Security Council has imposed on a United Nations member since the end of the cold war.
Libyan passenger jets were turned back in flight and many countries began expelling diplomats from the North African nation as the sanctions against Tripoli started to take effect. 
 All this put pressure on Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, to hand over two suspects in the Pan Am bombing over Scotland in 1988 for trial in Britain or the United States, and to make others available for interrogation by France in connection with the destruction of a French airliner over West Africa in 1989.
 
Arab Nations Comply
 Libya's Arab neighbors generally appeared to be cooperating with the air embargo, as flights were canceled across the Middle East. Libyan travelers and foreigners working in the country were reported flooding into neighboring Egypt and Tunisia by road in search of planes to foreign destinations.
The measures being taken against Libya are far less onerous than the economic blockade the Security Council imposed on Iraq in 1990 after its invasion of Kuwait. Nevertheless they show again how the collapse of Communism has given the Security Council the cohesion needed to enforce its orders. That was impossible in earlier crises like the seizure of the American Embassy hostages in Teheran in 1979 or Indonesia's annexation of East Timor three years earlier.
Italy said it scrambled F-104 jet fighters to intercept a Libyan passenger jet as it was approaching Italian airspace on its way to Zurich. The action was taken after Italy refused the aircraft permission to fly over its territory. But the plane turned back toward Tripoli before the fighters reached it. Although not a United Nations member, Switzerland said it would observe the air embargo.
Egypt, which spearheaded Arab efforts to resolve the dispute over Libya's purported role in two airline bombings, closed its airspace to Libyan planes and turned back two Libyan aircraft as they were trying to reach Cairo. Officials said Cairo has canceled all flights to and from Libya.
Tunisia, another North African neighbor, also sent back a Libyan plane heading for Tunis. It said all air links with Tripoli were suspended until May 9. Morocco, the only Arab country on the Security Council, canceled its four daily flights to Tripoli while Jordan said it was canceling its biweekly air link.
But the Sudan's Parliament urged its Government to ignore the air embargo today, calling it "an international crime." It was unclear if the Government of Col. Omar Hassan al-Bashir will try to maintain air links with Libya.
Turkish airlines and Tunisia's domestic line, Tuninter, were also reported adding extra flights to the Tunisian vacation island of Djerba near the Libyan border to accommodate Libyan travelers. The ferry service between Libya and Malta was also reported to be increasing its activity.
 
'No Planes Are Flying'
 Other European, Middle Eastern and North African airlines with regular services to Tripoli also said they were suspending these flights for the duration of the sanctions. "No planes are flying to any destinations," the Libyan Arab Airlines director general, Saleh Sirjani, told Cable News Network in a telephone interview from Tripoli.
Meanwhile, France, Belgium, Japan, Sweden, Denmark and Germany said they were ordering some Libyan diplomats to leave in accordance with the Security Council's order that all countries should reduce the size of Libyan embassies and missions. The United States and Britain have already broken diplomatic ties with Libya. But the United States said it would expel an undisclosed number of diplomats from Libya's 16-member mission to the United Nations.
Libya's official news agency, Jana, reported Tripoli was planning "reciprocal measures" against countries expelling its diplomats, suggesting a series of tit-for-tat expulsions.
Libyan radio attacked the sanctions, calling them "the continuation of a war by the imperialist states against other peoples and an attempt to force them to submit to hegemony."
In addition to cutting all air links with Tripoli and reducing the size of Libya's foreign missions, the sanctions also include a total arms embargo and a requirement that its Government demonstrate its renunciation of terrorism by undefined "concrete actions" that could involve providing details of terrorist actions it planned.
As yet, the sanctions are more bothersome than crippling to Libya because Libyans can still drive to airports in neighboring Egypt and Tunisia to catch flights elsewhere. And the embargo does not affect oil sales, which Libya depends on for virtually all its income.
But Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd of Britain told the BBC today that an oil embargo might be imposed next if the current sanctions package did not achieve its aims. This, however, might be opposed by other European countries that depend heavily on Libya's light, high-grade oil.
President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt also hinted at possibly tougher measures to come, saying, "If there are no political solutions, no one can predict how far the escalation will go."
Support for tougher sanctions also came from a spokesman for the families of victims of the Pan Am bombing. Bert Ammerman told a news conference here, "We applaud the United Nations and the Security Council for imposing sanctions but the next step must be an oil embargo."
Besides handing over the two Libyans accused of destroying Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988, with the loss of 270 lives, the Security Council wants Libya to send four other suspects for questioning by a French magistrate investigating the destruction of the French plane. That disaster took 171 lives.
The Russian Embassy announced today that Russia planned to withdraw some 1,500 military advisers working in Libya.

HEADLINE: Census Data Show Boom Before Bust

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
New information from the 1990 Census provides a haunting still life of New York in the glittering and affluent 80's, an ever more cosmopolitan center of sophisticated jobs, rising educational attainment and soaring incomes that had begun to make a dent on the intractable problems of the poor.
By almost every measure, from falling dropout and poverty rates to increases in income, life in New York City and its environs improved during the last, heady decade, characterized by conspicuous consumption and economic growth. While nationally, the income of a typical household increased only slightly, it went up 21.5 percent in New York City. 
 The Census was taken in a few frenzied weeks of enumeration two years ago, when the New York region had just begun to drift into a deepening recession.
Since then, economists and planners say, virtually all the 80's job growth in New York City and in the state has been wiped out. Welfare caseloads have soared, and the poverty rate is back up to perhaps its highest levels ever.
"When the Census was taken, most of the bad news was still to come," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the Regional Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "After that, the deluge came, and New York City was the center of the storm."
 
The Last of the Boom
 The Census catches the end of a boom fueled by the city's huge financial and services industries and by a surge in immigration that more than made up for New Yorkers who moved to the suburbs and beyond.
In statistical reports released today, the Census Bureau is providing the first portraits of daily life in some of the largest counties and cities in New York State, culled from detailed questionnaires sent to one in six households in the 1990 Census.
Almost a million new immigrants -- nearly one in seven New Yorkers -- were drawn to the city, especially to the middle-class neighborhoods of Queens, and thousands more moved to the surrounding counties. Two of every five people in the city said they did not speak English at home, and half of those said they did not speak English very well.
Many immigrants were drawn by the boom in jobs. There were more jobs created within New York City in the 1980's -- overwhelmingly high-skilled, high-paying managerial, professional and technical jobs -- than there are people in Buffalo, the state's second largest city: population, 328,123.
In 1989, the median household income rose to $29,823 in New York City and to $32,965 in the state. In Nassau County, often listed among the wealthiest counties in the country, household income was $54,283; in Suffolk, it was $49,128. More than 929,000 jobs were created in the state.
"This the story of a resurgence in New York during the 1980's, a powerful and extraordinary comeback," Mr. Ehrenhalt said. "It brought with it a shift to a more information-oriented economy, and more better-paying professional, technical and managerial jobs."
The Census reports reveal that city education levels rose significantly -- more than two-thirds of New York City residents had high school degrees and one in four had at least a bachelor's degree.
During the 1980's, many New Yorkers -- living with growing homelessness and panhandling -- became convinced that the city was in the midst of decline. But the Census figures show that poverty had not worsened during the decade and had even begun to decline slightly.
Among teen-agers, the census bureau reported, the proportion of 16- to 19-year-olds who had dropped out of school declined in the city, moving to 13.5 percent from 15.7 percent. Statewide, one in 10 youngsters in the survey had dropped out.
New York City's Board of Education, using a different way of counting, said that 19.2 percent of its high school students in the class of 1990 had dropped out and is predicting that this year's number will be even lower. But some researchers have disputed this figure, arguing that the real figure must be higher.
 
Decline in Poverty Rate
 The Census reports also document a small decline in the poverty rate in the city, with 19.3 percent of all people and 30 percent of all children reported living below the poverty rate. In Queens, the poverty rate dropped below the statewide figure of 13 percent.
The percentage of households reporting public assistance payments also declined, from 9.1 percent to 7.5 percent, illustrating that economic growth had only begun to improve the life of the poor before the downturn.
"You would have expected the poverty rate to have gone down more than it did," said Emanuel Tobier, a professor of economics and planning at New York University.
But the poverty rate rose to 25 percent in 1991, according to New York City's count, the highest level ever recorded, Professor Tobier said.
City officials fear that the 1990 Census numbers will delude people about the the problem of poverty.
"Any reasonable person would not accept these numbers as a true picture of the poverty population as it exists today," said the city's Human Resources Administrator, Barbara J. Sabol, in a statement. "There is a danger that some people might use these numbers as a depiction of current economic conditions in this city."
One byproduct of the 80's economic boom was the soaring cost of housing. The median rent in New York City doubled to $498 a month, a 41 percent increase after inflation. On Long Island, median rents were even higher and went up faster, with a median of $749 in Nassau and $802 in Suffolk.

HEADLINE: Caterpillar Workers' Shock: Jobs Aren't Ready for Them

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., April 15

 BODY:
Although Caterpillar Inc. agreed Tuesday night to take back the workers who have been on strike for five months, it did not say when it would do so. So Jerry Dolan and thousands of other employees who showed up at their plants early today, hoping to put the bitterness behind them, met one more rude surprise.
Foremen told Mr. Dolan and all other strikers: Go home and wait to be summoned to return. 
 In fact, many workers are still a bit skeptical that they will ever be called back. Although Caterpillar agreed to abide by the terms of its latest contract offer, which guarantees six years of job security to all current employees, company officials have also said some seemingly conflicting things. They have said, for example, that they think they could run their plants with 10 to 15 percent fewer workers.
So, while the strikers feel some relief, it is far outweighed by their anger and frustration.
"We could have had this agreement signed months ago," said Mr. Dolan, a 50-year-old supply carrier who has worked for Caterpillar for 26 years. "We've been walking the picket line and doing without for months, and what do we have to show for it? Nothing."
In their five months on strike, they have braved financial calamity and the doubts of their families, who wondered if they were doing the right thing. Now, as they prepare to return to their jobs, under the terms of a contract offer that their leaders had dismissed as a "mean-spirited proposal," many union members feel betrayed by their union and are angry at their employer. They describe themselves as pawns in a high-stakes chess match between two powerful opponents.
 
'This Things Stinks'
 It was their own leaders who urged many union members to report for work today. But Caterpillar officials said they were thrown so off-guard by the speed of the events, which resulted from a meeting called by a Federal mediator, that Caterpillar was simply unprepared to resume regular production. The company said employees would have to wait, possibly well into next week, before it could absorb the strikers and return things to normal.
"This thing stinks," said Morris White, a 38-year-old systems operator who has worked at Caterpillar for nine years, when asked about the agreements to end the strike. "It seems like we're back where we started because after all the hardship we've been through, we've gotten nowhere. I doubt that life in this company will ever be what it used to be."
The resentment of the union members was fueled by the company's vagueness not only on when the workers would be asked to return but also on whether all strikers would be invited back. Company officials today said they were still determining their personnel needs.
"We would like to have all of our employees come back," said Terry Thorstenson, a Caterpillar spokesman. "But we aren't sure what the process for their return will be."
Mr. Thorstenson added that Caterpillar had anticipated having weeks to prepare for a return of its members, a period that would have included a strike ratification vote by the union rank and file. "The events of the last day were completely unexpected," he said. "We have been operating differently during the strike, with 4,000 management workers. We can't just absorb 12,000 people in a matter of a few hours."
 
'We're in Limbo'
 Still, union officials said that an immediate mass return to work was what the company had sought when it told striking workers to return to their jobs by April 6 or risk losing them.
The scene today on Washington Avenue in East Peoria, where there are three entrances to Caterpillar plants, was sharply different from previous mornings, when crowds of boisterous strikers waved picket signs and honked their car horns. Only a handful of U.A.W. workers stood forlornly around the gates today.
"We're not locked out," said Ronald Walker, a 55-year-old mechanic who has worked at Caterpillar for 25 years. "We're not on strike, we're not working, we're in limbo. How can they agree for the workers to return to work and not let us go back to work?"
Caterpillar employees had the same experiences at other Illinois plants where workers have been on strike: Mossville, Decatur and Aurora.
Throughout the day, more than 1,000 members of the union stopped by the office of Local 974 of the U.A.W., which represents 9,000 Caterpillar workers here, in an effort to get clarification of the agreement between the company and the union.
Jerry F. Brown, president of the local, said the strike had been a success because the five-month dispute had shown that "the membership of this union can stand together and stand up to this corporation and this attack on the membership." Mr. Brown said the union had not been broken because "we're going to continue to negotiate."
"Anything they do that we're not happy with will be an issue on the bargaining table," he said. He said the union would never ask its members "to commit economic suicide."
Those sentiments are apparently of little consolation to many of the former strikers. "I just don't understand this agreement," said George E. Petty, a U.A.W. member a heat treatment technician at the Caterpillar plant. "It just makes you feel that everything we did was for nothing."

(David Zalanik/Peoria Journal Star)

HEADLINE: Bridgeport U. Clears Path For Bailout

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 15

 BODY:
Deeply in debt and fast running out of students, the University of Bridgeport tonight agreed to pursue a bail-out plan that would give control of the private university to the Professors World Peace Academy, an affiliate of the Unification Church.
If threats made by students are carried out, hundreds, perhaps thousands, will leave rather than attend a university controlled by a church they see as opposed to academic freedom and democratic values. 
 But there are barely 3,000 students now, half of them part-time, after the university's long slide from a peak enrollment of 9,100 in 1970. What weighed most heavily on the trustees was the university's $22 million debt.
Having spent, with court permission, the university's restricted endowment funds, and having failed, in a sinking economy, to sell any part of the 80-acre campus a block from Long Island Sound, the trustees finally accepted the World Peace Academy's offer of a first-year investment of $20 million and the promise of $30 million more and thousands of new students.
Colin Gunn, chairman of the trustees, said the board planned to vote on a final agreement within a week or two, and approval is expected.
"This agreement and the substantial funding it will provide," Mr. Gunn said, "will protect the vital interests of both students and faculty by assuring that U.B. will stay open with complete academic freedom and ample finances."
 
First of Five
 The University of Bridgeport, Mr. Gunn said, would be the first of five World Peace Academy universities established around the world.
Officials said it remained undetermined how many seats on the board of trustees would be given to the World Peace Academy, which is 90 percent financed by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon and the Unification Church. The academy wanted majority control when it first proposed affiliation last October, offering an initial investment of $10 million.
"The board of trustees was faced with a momentous decision," Mr. Gunn said defiantly. "Whether we were going to continue this university, or do away with the university."
People, he said, now had choices. "Students can leave," he said. "Faculty can leave." But there would be an operating campus in Bridgeport's South End, he said.
Trustees, concerned that they may be held personally liable for the university's $22 million debt, have been trying to reach agreements that would preserve the university as a financial entity that could continue to make payments on the debt.
In agreeing to pursue affiliation with the World Peace Academy, the trustees rejected proposals by several colleges and universities in Connecticut to take over academic programs, keeping them on the Bridgeport campus.
Even those proposals focused on the university's financial condition, converting the University of Bridgeport into a real-estate holding company collecting rent and fees from other institutions.
 
$2 Million Short
 The most comprehensive offer, from Sacred Heart University in neighboring Fairfield, fell $2 million a year short of what trustees said they needed to survive financially, even if not academically.
"They've got a $22 million debt, and the banks don't want the land, they don't want the buildings, they want the money," Annie Baldwin, the one student allowed to speak to trustees tonight, said.
Speaking as a representative for the College of Professional Studies, she urged trustees to allow the college to affiliate with the University of New Haven rather than stay as part of a university affiliated with the World Peace Academy.
"They asked me pointed questions," she said. "They asked me, 'What would you do?' "
Trustees arriving for their meeting were greeted by students and faculty opposed to any agreement with the World Peace Academy. Many had signed petitions asking trustees to release their schools to affiliate with other institutions, as the law school did this winter with Quinnipiac College, in Hamden.
"We have a very rich history," said Kristin Minihan, a second-year student at the Fones School of Dental Hygiene, part of the original junior college from which the university grew. "You have a lot of credibility when you graduate from here. Unless they go with the P.W.P.A."
Both students and professors predicted a wholesale transfer of students to other colleges if the academy won control.
The student government president, Scott Miller, a senior graduating in May with a degree in fashion merchandising, said five of his 20 fraternity brothers transferred at the beginning of spring semester.
And in every job interview, Mr. Miller said, he is asked about the university and Unification Church. "The job market is terrible," he said. "You're always fighting that, and you're always fighting the reputation of the university."

HEADLINE: Third World Economies Shrink Again

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15

 BODY:
For the first time since World War II, per-capita income in the third world has declined for two consecutive years, the World Bank said in a report released today.
But for the 1990's as a whole, the World Bank forecast that the economies of the third world would do better than in the 1980's, largely because many developing nations have embraced economic reforms. 
 The report said Middle Eastern countries had been particularly hurt by the war in the Persian Gulf, and Eastern Europe by its transition to a market economy. The slowdown in the United States and other industrial nations hurt all third world countries, which rely on them for export revenues.
 
Growth in Future Seen
 According to the report, income per capita in the third world fell by two-tenths of 1 percent in each of the last two years. For the rest of the decade, the report said growth in per-capita income in the third world countries would jump to 2.9 percent a year, up from 1.2 percent a year in the 1980's.
"We are most optimistic about growth in East Asia and are least optimistic about per-capita income growth in Sub-Saharan Africa," said Lawrence Summers, chief economist for the World Bank.
According to the report, the industrialized nations could greatly spur growth in the third world by removing their many import barriers to manufactured goods. If the United States, European Community and Japan reduced their trade barriers by 50 percent, that would increase the third world's exports by $50 billion anuually, the World Bank said. That is almost equal to the net flow of official development aid in 1991.
The bank's economists said a successful completion of the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade talks would reduce the industrial world's trade barriers by about one-third.
The report, entitled "Global Economic Prospects and the Developing Countries," views increased exports of manufactured goods as a crucial way for the third world to grow.
Cheap labor remains the main competitive advantage of the developing world, the report said, but it added that remaining a low-cost supplier required more than cheap labor. The report said developing nations must improve their marketing expertise, telecommunications systems and transportation networks to remain competitive.
 
Estimating Export Growth
 The report predicted that growth in the seven major industrial countries will average 2.6 percent a year this decade, down from 2.8 percent in the previous decade. It said Germany's high interest rates, the large American budget deficit, and the efforts of American banks and companies to improve their balance sheets will be factors behind the slower growth.
It added that growth of one percentage point a year in the industrialized world over three years would raise exports from the developing world by $60 billion a year.
Between 1990 and 2000, East Asia's economic output will grow by 7.1 percent a year, compared with 7.9 percent in the 1980's, the report said. In Latin America, growth is expected to average 4.2 percent a year this decade, up from 1.6 percent in the 1980's, because of a continued resolution of the debt crisis and "a significant shift toward market-friendly policies."
The report predicts that in Sub-Saharan Africa growth in domestic output will rise from 2.1 percent a year to 3.5 percent a year this decade. Factoring in population growth, per-capita income is expected to rise by three-tenths of 1 percent in Sub-Saharan Africa this decade, compared with a drop of nine-tenths of 1 percent in the last decade.
In South Asia, which includes India, growth of output is forecast for 5 percent a year (3.1 percent per capita), compared with 5.4 percent in the previous decade.
For Eastern Europe, growth is expected to rise to 1.9 percent a year from growth of 1.4 percent in the 1980's.
The World Bank foresees a continuing shortage of capital that will hurt developing countries struggling to attract investment. One result of this shortage, the report said, is that real interest rates will be a high 3.3 percent this decade, which will nonetheless be lower than the record 3.8 level of the 1980's.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Two Military Contractors Post Big Gains in Quarter

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
The General Dynamics Corporation and the Northrop Corporation, two of the nation's largest military contractors, reported sharp increases in first-quarter earnings yesterday.
Like other weapons producers and aerospace companies, General Dynamics and Northrop have been posting solid results for more than a year as they work off a backlog of orders from the last decade. But over the next several years, analysts said, earnings growth will become much harder to sustain because the Pentagon's budget cutting will start biting more deeply into the industry's sales and profits. 
 Following are details of the companies' results:
 
General Dynamics
 General Dynamics, which is based in Falls Church, Va., said its net earnings for the quarter surged to $435 million, or $10.32 a share, from $57 million, or $1.37 a share, in the corresponding period last year. Sales were flat at $2.1 billion.
Earnings for this year's first quarter included a one-time after-tax gain of $358 million from the sale of the Cessna Aircraft Company. General Dynamics said its earnings on continuing operations increased 44 percent, to $72 million, or $1.71 a share, from $50 million, or $1.20 a share, in last year's first quarter.
In recent months the Bush Administration moved to kill General Dynamics' contract to build additional Seawolf submarines for the Navy, although Congress is now reconsidering the issue. General Dynamics has continued to benefit from long-running weapons programs, including the F-16 jet fighter.
General Dynamics stock gained 75 cents a share, closing at $65.375 on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Northrop
 Northrop, based in Los Angeles, reported net income for the quarter of $47.2 million, or $1 a share, in contrast to a net loss in last year's first quarter of $34.8 million. Sales rose 4 percent, to $1.3 billion.
The net earnings figures for the 1991 period included the effects of an accounting change. Before restating the earnings to reflect the change, Northrop had posted net income for last year's first quarter of $32.6 million, or 69 cents a share, figures that included a charge of $6.7 million for the accounting change.
Northrop said it benefited from higher sales on the B-2 bomber program and from its role as a subcontractor on the F/A-18 jet fighter. But it said most of the earnings gain came from an increase in pension income and a decrease in interest expense.
Northrop stock gained 50 cents, to $26.375, on the Big Board.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
TRW Net Up 15%
 CLEVELAND, April 15 (AP) -- TRW Inc. reported a 15 percent gain in first-quarter earnings today on a 6 percent rise in sales.
The automotive, aerospace technology and information systems company said it earned $41 million, or 65 cents a share, in the first quarter on sales of about $2 billion, compared with earnings of $35 million, or 57 cents a share, on sales of about $1.9 billion a year earlier.
"We are pleased with our profit improvement, which was particularly strong in our air bag systems business," TRW's chairman, Joseph Gorman, said in a news release. "We remain cautiously optimistic about the economic recovery."
TRW said sales in the automotive segment were up 14 percent, to $1.12 billion, from the comparable quarter last year, while sales were off about 6 percent in the space and defense segment, down to $709 million.
In the information systems and services segment, which includes TRW's credit reporting network, sales were up 12 percent, to $200 million. TRW stock gained $2.25, to $50.75, on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: Peru's Chief: Every Bit the Emperor

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, April 15

 BODY:
Alberto K. Fujimori, Peru's pragmatic and business-suited President, has lived up to his flashy street nickname, the Emperor.
Four months ago, the President shrugged off the crown, telling a Peruvian business conference, "Even though it might be convenient if there were an emperor, that emperor won't be me, because I'm very respectful of the Constitution." 
 But with the nation's courts and Congress padlocked by presidential decree last week, Peruvians now have a clearer picture of the obscure university dean who burst onto the national scene in elections two years ago.
"Fuji's a shy man," Hernando de Soto, an economist who resigned in January as the President's drug policy adviser, said today. "And like all shy people, by the time they manifest themselves, they have punched you in the nose."
Former President Alan Garcia may feel that way. Mr. Fujimori's Government announced today that it had issued arrest warrants for Mr. Garcia and other leaders of his Aprista party, charging they were responsible for weapons it said were found in the party's headquarters in a raid on April 5.
Mr. Fujimori, the 53-year-old son of Japanese immigrants, has made a career out of being underestimated.
In the 1990 presidential election, Mr. Fujimori, a virtually unknown agronomist, ran a shoestring, word-of-mouth campaign, using a tractor called the Fuji-mobile. He handily beat Mario Vargas Llosa, the internationally acclaimed novelist, who ran a multimillion-dollar campaign.
 
A Slap at Japan
 In office, President Fujimori has gored sacred cows.
Roman Catholic Church leaders sputtered when the new President advocated a national family planning program because he was "tired of seeing children eating out of garbage cans."
United States officials were furious when Mr. Fujimori, at a regional conference on drugs in Texas in February, accused the United States Drug Enforcement Administration of "corruption" and then warned that stationing American military advisers in Peru could provoke another "Vietnam War." United States officials have long charged that Peruvian corruption prevents a crackdown on the nation's coca leaf crop, the world's largest.
In an obvious effort to soothe American feelings, Mr. Fujimori gave the Peruvian Air Force authority last week to control airports and to shoot down unauthorized planes in the major drug-growing region.
Last month it was the turn of officials in Japan to fume. On a weeklong visit, Mr. Fujimori met the Emperor, addressed Parliament in Japanese, visited his parents' hometown and negotiated a $126 million aid package. On leaving, he told reporters that the aid money was "insufficient."
But Mr. Fujimori's disregard for the niceties of diplomatic convention and, more recently, for democratic institutions has kept his public approval ratings high, generally above 50 percent.
Last month, the President's popularity was shaken at a startling news conference offered by his wife, Susana Higuchi Fujimori. The First Lady charged that the President's sister, Rosa Fujimori Aritomi, and his brother, Santiago Fujimori, had sold clothing donated to Peru by Japanese charities for personal profit.
To explain her action, skeptical Peruvians offer three theories: she sought revenge against her husband for leaving her behind when he went to Japan; she sought to curtail influence enjoyed by her in-laws in palace politics, or she sought to further her ambition to run this year for Mayor of Lima. In a meeting with a prosecutor, she failed to provide proof of her charges.
With last week's attack on Congress and the courts, Mr. Fujimori soared to the highest ratings of his 20-month-old presidency -- 70 to 85 percent.
Aware that public opinion can be fickle, Mr. Fujimori has labored from the start of his Government to build a solid power base among the army. Manipulating promotions, Vladimiro Montesinos, a cashiered army captain who is the President's security adviser, has built a corps of commanders who owe their positions to Mr. Fujimori.

HEADLINE: Several Big Banks Post Higher Quarterly Profits

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Several large banks around the country yesterday reported large gains in profits during the first quarter as problems with bad loans declined and they benefited from a wider spread between the interest rates they pay on deposits and the interest rates they collect on loans.
The Bank of New York earned $80 million after losing $63 million a year ago, while the Norwest Corporation of Minneapolis reported a 29.7 percent gain. The First Fidelity Bancorporation of Newark, N.J., said its profits rose 16.8 percent from a year ago. 
 In New England, the Fleet Financial Group, formerly known as the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group, earned 97.6 percent more than a year ago, while the Shawmut National Corporation earned $43.3 million after losing $116.7 million a year ago.
Although most banks are still burdened by a high level of non-performing assets -- badly delinquent loans and real estate acquired through foreclosure -- analysts have been expecting a rebound in profits because the level of troubled loans has begun to decline and banks have already recognized most of the losses from those loans.
Following are details of the earnings reports:
 
Bank of New York
 The Bank of New York's first-quarter profit of $80 million, or 97 cents a share, was attributed to a sharp decline to $133 million from $343 million in the amount the company added to its reserve for loan losses. The smaller addition to the loss reserve coincided with a continued decline in holdings of badly delinquent loans and real estate to $1.29 billion from $1.85 billion a year earlier.
The company added that fees from record-keeping services for mutual funds rose sharply, and it was able to reduce slightly its costs for salaries, equipment and other overhead.
 
Norwest
 The Norwest Corporation, said a decline in problems with bad loans led to a record quarterly profit of $122.4 million, or 82 cents a share, up from $94.3 million, or 68 cents. Its home mortgage financing unit earned $15.3 million, up 62.1 percent as lower interest rates led to a sharp increase in home-financing activity.
 
Shawmut
 At Shawmut, the first-quarter profit of $43.3 million was helped by a decline to $83.5 million from $140.2 million in the amount of loans the company wrote off as a loss. Shawmut, which owns Connecticut Bank & Trust Company and Shawmut National Bank in Massachusetts, also said it added $68.5 million to its reserve for future loan losses, down from $234 million a year ago.
 
Fleet Financial
 Fleet Financial earned $50.4 million, or 31 cents a share, in the first quarter, up from $25.5 million, or 21 cents a share, a year earlier. In addition to a wider interest-rate spread, the company's profits were helped by a sharp reduction in the amount it added to its loan-loss reserve, to $11 million from $96 million a year ago.
Fleet's mortgage-financing business earned $24.5 million in the quarter, more than twice as much as a year ago.
 
First Fidelity
 First Fidelity Bancorporation, the largest banking company in New Jersey, said first-quarter profits were $65.5 million, or 81 cents a share, up from $57.8 milllion, or 87 cents a share a year ago.
The earnings per share declined despite the increased profit because the company issued 14.3 million additional shares, assuming conversion of preferred stock to common shares. At the same time as non-performing assets declined slightly, First Fideltiy reduced the amount it added to its loan loss reserve to $61 million, down from $85 million a year ago.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Gains at A.T.& T., Sprint and Telesis

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
A.T.& T. and the Sprint Corporation, two leading long-distance telephone companies, reported strong first-quarter earnings yesterday, in large measure because of cost-cutting moves like layoffs and plant closings. But the recession continued to take its toll with lackluster revenue growth in the quarter.
Another telephone company, the Pacific Telesis Group, the provider of local-telephone service in California and Nevada, reported that its first-quarter net income rose 24.4 percent. 
 Following are the details of the companies' results:
 
A.T.& T.
 The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which also has operations in computers, telecommunications equipment and credit-card services, said that earnings in the first quarter rose 16.5 percent, to $883 million, or 67 cents a share, from $758 million, or 59 cents a share, a year earlier. But quarterly revenue continued flat at $15.38 billion, up less than 1 percent from the $15.27 billion a year earlier.
The earnings for A.T& T. were slightly better than expected by stock analysts, although they found some troubling aspects in the financial report.
Charles W. Schelke, a telecommunications analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, had projected earnings of 65 cents a share for A.T& T., 2 cents below the actual results. But the depression in the computer industry hurt A.T& T.'s NCR unit.
Nonetheless, the stock market reacted favorably.On the New York Stock Exchange, A.T& T. shares closed at $42.875 a share, up 25 cents.
At A.T& T., telecommunications services, about 64 cents of every revenue dollar, rose 3.3 percent in the quarter, to $9.87 billion. Such services consist of not only domestic and international long-distance, but also directory-assistance, calling-card services, and toll-free "800" lines. Growth was relatively strong across the board, both internationally and domestically.
But sales of products and systems, like computers and telephone switching equipment to corporations and other nations' telephone companies, dropped 6.3 percent, to $3.45 billion. Lease of computers and other telecommunications gear also dropped 4.5 percent, to $1.64 billion.
Financial services and leasing, which includes A.T& T.'s successful Universal card, rose 32 percent, to $407 million.
 
Sprint
 Sprint, formerly United Telecommunications, reported that first-quarter operating income rose 19.5 percent, to $99.9 million, or 45 cents a share, from the final net of $83.6 million a year earlier, or 38 cents a share. An accounting change added $36.4 million to Sprint's 1992 earnings, which totaled $136.3 million, or 62 cents a share. Quarterly revenue rose 2.2 percent, to $2.21 billion, from the $2.16 billion a year earlier.
Also on the Big Board, Sprint closed at $23.75 a share, up $2.25.
Mr. Schelke of Smith Barney had projected Sprint's earnings 2 cents lower at 43 cents. He said intense competition between A.T& T. and the MCI Communications Corporation might bruise third-ranked Sprint, which could not spend as much money on expensive television advertising.
At Sprint, the accounting change was due to adoption of Financial Accounting Standard No. 109, which governs the accounting for income taxes that were accrued in the past but deferred for future payment. The standard assumes that today's tax rates will apply to the past period. For example, today's top corporate tax rate of 34 percent would apply to a deferred tax of a few years ago.
All companies must adopt No. 109 by next January, but Sprint chose to adopt the standard, which also governs acquisitions, because of its recent acquisition of the 19.9 percent of Sprint that the company did not already own.
Sprint's long-distance division posted a gain in net income of 28.8 percent, to $67 million, while revenue rose only 1.5 percent, to $1.34 billion. Sprint's local-telephone business posted a 6.6 percent rise in profit to $178 million and a rise in revenue of 3.8 percent, to $714 million. The balance of profit and revenue came from Sprint's distribution company for telecommunications equipment and a publisher of telephone directories.
 
Pacific Telesis
 Pacific Telesis said its quarterly net rose to $331 million, or 83 cents a share, from $266 million, or 68 cents a share, a year earlier. Quarterly revenue rose 2.7 percent, to $2.47 billion, from $2.41 billion a year earlier.
Pacific Telesis also said its directors would consider a proposal to spin off its Bell operating companies, including Pacific Bell, which handles California traffic, to shareholders in an effort to increase shareholder value.

HEADLINE: Albany Reaches Tentative Labor Pact

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 15

 BODY:
New York State reached a tentative contract agreement with its largest public employees union today, ending a contentious period in which disgruntled state workers have labored without a contract for more than a year.
The agreement, which will affect about 100,000 state workers represented by the Civil Service Employees Association, calls for a wage increase of 4 percent next April and an increase of slightly more than 4 percent in the next fiscal year. Workers will also receive bonuses in December 1993 and September 1994. 
 In exchange, the union offered a number of concessions, including an agreement to drop its court challenge of an accounting device known as the "lag payroll." The method, which was devised by the state in late 1990 to reduce its budget gap by $135 million, deferred the payment of a week's salary to state workers. The workers will receive the money when they leave state employment. A number of unions, including this one, had contested the legality of the device and the courts thus far have ruled in their favor.
The union's salary increases are expected to cost the state $87 million in the next fiscal year and $103 million in the year after that. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the State Legislature just finished closing a $4.8 billion budget gap in constructing this year's $30.8 billion budget.
 
Risks to Budget Tolerated
 But the Cuomo administration apparently believes that any financial risk posed by the salary increases would be diminished significantly by eliminating the lag payroll lawsuit and by the other concessions offered by the union, state officials said.
Most members of the Civil Service union, which represents more than half of all state workers, are blue-collar or clerical employees. They include secretaries and janitors who work for state agencies, laborers on road maintenance crews and therapy aides in state mental institutions.
No agreements have been reached with the state's other unions.
The contract would grant state workers the largest part of their salary increase in 1994, when the state's economy may be stronger and when Mr. Cuomo would face re-election if he chose to run for a fourth four-year term. Mr. Cuomo said today that he did not think state workers should continue to bear a disproportionate share of the state's fiscal burden.
"I couldn't do it this year and I couldn't do it last year but I thought it was too much to ask our people to take another sacrifice next year," Mr. Cuomo told reporters today after an appearance in Waterford.
The union contract represents the first break in a labor logjam that has severely strained the once amiable relations between Mr. Cuomo and the state's public employees.
The state workers unions, which claimed a large share of credit for Mr. Cuomo's first election as Governor in 1982, have vilified him in the last two years.
Since November 1990, the state's work force, which then numbered 185,700 employees, has been reduced by 21,300, including 6,100 layoffs. A reduction of another 3,000 jobs, including up to 1,800 layoffs, is expected by next March. State workers last received raises in April 1990, when they pocketed a 5.5 percent increase.
In response to that treatment, public employees unions have denounced Mr. Cuomo in speeches, newspaper advertisements, campaigns and marches by the thousands on the Executive Mansion.
Joseph McDermott, the president of the Civil Service union, nearly lost his re-election campaign last year after endorsing Mr. Cuomo for re-election in 1990. His opponent called him Mr. Cuomo's invisible running mate. Last December, when Mr. Cuomo was still actively considering a Presidential campaign, Mr. McDermott announced that he would not support the Governor if he ran.
The union contract agreement was reached after a marathon negotiating session that began last Saturday in a meeting room at an Albany hotel. A team of state negotiators, led by Joseph Bress, the director of the Office of Employee Relations, bargained with Mr. McDermott and his aides, with little sleep, almost continuously for five days.
The contract, if approved by the Legislature and the union's membership, would cover four years but would be retroactive to April 1, 1991, when the union's previous contract expired. It does not call for either a retroactive wage increase for that year or for an increase in the 1992-93 fiscal year, which began 15 days ago.
It would grant 4 percent raises on April 1 of the next two years and an additional 1.25 percent increase on Oct. 1, 1994.
The union agreed to increase the number of years required for an employee to reach the maximum pay grade for a given job, to seven years from five, and to a slight reduction in workers' compensation benefits.
The state is still negotiating with its other unions -- the Public Employees Federation, which represents about 53,000 white-collar workers; Council 82 of the Security and Law Enforcement Employees, which represents about 22,000 prison and security workers; United University Professions, which represents about 20,000 university workers; the Police Benevolent Association, which represents about 4,000 state troopers and investigators; and District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, which represents 600 rent regulation workers in New York City.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chrysler Will Sell Dual-Fuel Vehicles Soon

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation will soon begin selling cars that can run on methanol as well as gasoline, Lee A. Iacocca, the company's chairman, said yesterday. Unlike some dual-fuel cars now being sold, the Chrysler models will be offered at no additional charge, he said.
The feature will cost the company several hundred dollars a car, automotive engineers say, but it will give Chrysler valuable credits in meeting Federal gasoline mileage requirements. 
 In a breakfast speech in which he dwelled on environmental matters, Mr. Iacocca described the offer to reporters who had gathered for a preview of the New York Auto Show. The offer, which will cover the Plymouth Acclaim and Dodge Spirit models, was first announced in January. The cars will go on sale in July.
They can run on gasoline or a blend of gasoline and as much as 85 percent methanol, the standard at pumps where the fuel is sold. Methanol, also known as wood alcohol, causes less air pollution than gasoline.
 
Predicts Move by Competitors
 Mr. Iacocca predicted that Chrysler's competitors would eventually have to offer the option free too.
General Motors now sells "variable fuel vehicles," in the form of the Cheverolet Lumina mid-size model, in California. These cars, which can run on methanol as well as gasoline, cost $1,500 extra, but that does not cover the company's additional expense, a spokesman said.
California offers buyers a $2,000 subsidy on dual-fuel vehicles, potentially making the buyer's cost lower than for models that run on gas only.
Automotive engineers estimated that if the production of dual-fuel vehicles rose into the tens of thousands, the additional cost would fall to $200 to $500 a vehicle. Chrysler would presumably spread that cost over all of its vehicles.
A Chrysler spokesman, Tom Kowaleski, said the cars would run just as well on pure gasoline as an ordinary car and would perform better on methanol. He said they would be lower-priced than competing dual-fuel models.
The extra costs come about because methanol is corrosive, requiring special seals and hoses. A larger-capacity fuel pump is also needed, as well as a sensor to measure the mixture in the tank and send instructions to the fuel injector.
 
Sold Mostly in California
 Very little methanol is sold outside California, and even there, sales have disappointed some early backers, but Mr. Iacocca did not put any geographic restriction on the offer.
He did not state a motivation for the offer, other than California air officials' finding that methanol burns substantially more cleanly than gasoline. But Congress, in an effort to stimulate the market for the new fuel, has offered the auto companies an inducement to build the cars. The inducement is a credit in calculating the fuel economy of their fleets.
Samuel A. Leonard, the director of automotive emission control at General Motors, said a car that would get 25 miles on a gallon of gasoline would count as a 40-mile-per-gallon vehicle if it could use methanol.
The law allows an auto maker to use that benefit to raise its fuel economy rating by up to 1.2 miles. The current standard is 27.5 miles a gallon, so a company whose cars averaged only 26.3 miles a gallon could still be in compliance if it sold enough cars that could use methanol.
Chyrsler, which sells mostly small and medium cars, is already in compliance, but the credits can be "banked" for future years.
Some environmentalists opposed the credit for dual-fuel cars when it was first proposed, saying some of the vehicles might never use a fuel besides gasoline.
But Mr. Leonard described the provision as an effort by Congress "to beat the chicken and egg problem": almost no one buys methanol-powered cars because almost no one sells methanol, and vice versa.

HEADLINE: New York Logs 500,000 Jobs Lost Since 1989, a Record High

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
Job losses in New York State over the last three years were worse than they have been for half a century, since records began being kept in 1939, a leading economist said yesterday. But he also reported signs that the pain may be easing.
The report by Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, Regional Commissioner for the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, is just another sign of just how concentrated the national recession has been in this region. Over the last two years, New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have suffered the second-worst declines in nonagricultural employment of any states in the nation. The worst declines were recorded in the region encompassing Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Rhode Island. 
 Since employment peaked in the New York State in April 1989, over half a million jobs have been lost, or 6.3 percent of the state's total, according to Mr. Ehrenhalt, who yesterday released a review of the state's economy. Before this recession, the most severe loss of jobs, 5.9 percent, occurred in 1945.
This does not mean that half a million people were necessarily added to the unemployment rolls. Some may have left the state, retired, or otherwise dropped out of the workforce. What the job losses do indicate, however, is a shrinkage of the state's economy and a much tougher market for those seeking work.
Despite the gloomy picture, Mr. Ehrenhalt said he saw some signs that the pain in New York State may finally be easing. In the first two months of the year, employment losses totaled 13,000. If job losses in March run at about the same rate, the first quarter of 1992 will show job losses of about 20,000. Although that is still a decline, it is a dramatic improvement over the 71,000 jobs that were lost in the state in the last quarter of 1991, and the 66,000 that were lost the quarter before that.
Also providing a ray of hope for the state's fortunes are tax receipts. Collections of the state's 4 percent sales tax were up five-tenths of 1 percent in the first three months of this year over the same period last year. "That's not a strong increase, but at least it's an increase," said Karl Felsen, a spokesman for the state's Department of Taxation and Finance. Last year, by contrast, sales tax receipts in each quarter showed declines when compared to the previous year's.
 
Higher Tax Collections
 And thanks to bonuses paid by Wall Street firms, tax collections in the first part of this year were $40 million to $50 million higher than expected, James W. Wetzler, the state's tax commissioner, said. "Things seem to be bottoming out," he said.
In previous recessions, manufacturing typically accounted for the vast majority of the state's job losses, but in this recession, virtually all sectors of the state's economy have suffered, especially business services, construction and trade.
That is not to say that manufacturing industries have prospered. Over the last three years, the state has lost 180,000 manufacturing jobs, 15 percent of the total. That is dramatically more than the rest of the nation, which lost 6 percent of its manufacturing jobs during that same period. Mr. Ehrenhalt could not explain why New York State's manufacturing sector, which now has 2,000 fewer factories than it did four years ago, had fared so poorly.
If there was an region to avoid during the last three years, it was clearly downstate, which accounted for 92 percent of the state's employment decline. The worst-hit area was New York City, which lost 8.7 percent of its jobs. By contrast, urban areas upstate, like Syracuse and Rochester, registered employment declines of less than 1 percent, while the Albany-Schenectedy-Troy area registered no decline at all.
"A very considerable part of the state was relatively little affected by the state's steepest decline in decades," said Mr. Ehrenhalt. He noted that the recession of the last three years has wiped out just 6 percent of the job growth that occurred during the 1980s in the upstate area, whereas it eliminated nearly two-thirds of the job growth downstate.
But it is the area around New York City that drives the rest of the state's economy, so any troubles there have far-reaching consequences. Mr. Ehrenhalt noted that although New York City accounts for just 43 percent of the state's private-sector employment, it generates 53 percent of the earnings, about $100 billion. And income generated by jobs in Manhattan accounts for about three-quarters of that amount, making that island a key contributor to the state's economic engine.
In an earlier study of New Jersey's economy, Mr. Ehrenhalt found a similar geographic concentration of that state's economic troubles. Eight of the state's 21 counties accounted for about three-quarters of the state's job losses for the two-year period that ended in March 1991. The eight were Union, Passaic, Hudson, Bergen, Camden, Sussex, Morris and Monmouth. All but Camden are clustered in northeastern New Jersey.
