HEADLINE: HARTFORD JOURNAL;
On One Side of Gun Control, She Puts Connecticut on the Other

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
THE State of Connecticut, through its public investment in the Colt's Manufacturing Company, has become a major, if perhaps unwitting, force in the effort to overturn or undermine restrictions on assault weapons across the nation, a leading gun-control advocate contended yesterday.
The advocate, Sarah Brady, who heads Handgun Control, the Washington-based lobby group, said here at a news conference that by almost any measure it was possible to conclude that a "pro-assault weapons policy" is the official view of the state, which owns 47 percent of Colt's stock through the state employee pension fund. 
 Mrs. Brady asked the state treasurer, Francisco L. Borges, who manages the fund, to disavow Colt's or force the company to stop making the Sporter rifle, which is a modified version of the AR-15, a civilian version of the M-16 military rifle.
The Connecticut Development Authority, a state-sponsored organization that has also given Colt's loan guarantees, issued a statement attacking Mrs. Brady's group as having inaccurately portrayed the company and the state in an effort to "make a trophy" of a "wounded company they can bring down." The authority also denied that the Sporter was an assault weapon "by any legal definition."
The president of Colt's, Ronald E. Stilwell, said in an interview yesterday that Mrs. Brady's "strident" statements "continue to deal with emotions." Mrs. Brady's husband, James, was shot and partly paralyzed in the attempted assassination of President Reagan in 1981. The facts are, Mr. Stilwell said, that because the Sporter is semiautomatic, requiring a pull of the trigger to fire each bullet, it cannot be considered a true assault rifle, which can fire in continuous bursts.
The state pension fund invested $25 million in Colt's in 1990 to strengthen the financially troubled company and save more than 900 jobs. Colt's had voluntarily halted production of the AR-15 semiautomatic rifle but began production of the Sporter -- a slightly modified version -- shortly after the state investment, despite Mr. Borges's vehement objections.
Since then, Colt's has become more aggressive in producing the rifles and defending them as recreational sport weapons, even as the company's fortunes have continued to decline. Industry analysts said Colt's, which filed for Federal bankruptcy protection last month, had reduced its product line, thus linking its fate -- and Connecticut's involvement -- all the more securely to continued sales of the Sporter.
The Sporter is by far the best-selling domestically produced assault-style rifle, according to the handgun group, which cited figures from the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. In recent months, the company has filed or participated in lawsuits attempting to overturn bans on such weapons in Ohio and California.
The company has said that private donations have funded those legal changes, not stockholder's funds from the state, and the development authority statement also denied at length any direct participation by the state.
Mr. Stilwell said the company did not break out sales figures and declined to say how important the Sporter was to Colt's survival through the period of its reorganization in Federal Bankruptcy Court.
But Federal figures and industry analysts suggest that it is a fairly heavy reliance. From 1984 to 1989, for example, when Colt's halted production of the AR-15, the company produced between 13,000 and 20,000 such rifles a year. In 1990, when production of the Sporter began, production jumped to 38,013, according the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms.
"It's certainly one of their better-selling products," said Scott A. Farrell, editor of Shooting Industry magazine.
At the same time, many of the company's other lines have been slumping in the recession. Colt's recently introduced a new 9-millimeter semiautomatic pistol, for example, that Mr. Farrell said is about five to seven years behind the competition in design and technology.

HEADLINE: Industrial Output Gains Second Straight Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15

 BODY:
Aided by a weather-induced surge in demand for electric and gas, industrial output rose two-tenths of 1 percent in March, producing the first back-to-back advance since last summer, the Federal Reserve reported today.
The rise, which closely matched predictions, was seen by economists as further evidence of a modest economic recovery even though last month's gain was less vigorous than February's five-tenths of 1 percent. 
 "The recovery's still shaping up pretty much as people have been expecting," Robert T. McGee, economist at the Tokai Bank in New York, said. Bruce Steinberg, a senior economist at Merrill Lynch, added, "The industrial sector is slowly coming back to life."
 
Business Sales Gain
 A separate report by the Commerce Department showed that business sales posted a second straight solid gain in February while inventories held steady. This suggested that companies would be called on to raise production in coming months if stepped-up demand continues.
Helping to push up industrial production, which covers roughly one-third of the economy, was output of such durable consumer goods as trucks, appliances and furniture as well as higher production by the nation's utilities.
Over all, however, the gain in manufacturing was just one-tenth of 1 percent, compared with five-tenths of 1 percent in February, and mining output eased two-tenths of 1 percent last month after an advance of seven-tenths of 1 percent.
The halting nature of the economic recovery, economists said, meant that the Fed would remain inclined to add some additional monetary fuel. They cautioned, however, that the next set of figures that might touch off another round of interest-rate cuts would probably be the Labor Department's survey of April employment conditions, which will not be published until May 8.
 
First-Quarter Decline
 For the first quarter, industrial output declined at an annual rate of 4.1 percent, a deterioration from the seven-tenths of 1 percent rate of decline in the final three months of 1991. At 107.2 for March, the Industrial Production Index remained about 1 percent below its level of last October.
Today's report also showed a small increase, one-tenth of a point, to 78.1 percent, in the operating rate of the nation's industry. But this was entirely attributed to a faster pace at utilities, where activity had been curtailed over the winter months by unseasonably warm weather.
Production of consumer durables climbed five-tenths of 1 percent last month despite a decline in output of automobiles, assembled at a 5.2 million annual rate compared with 5.4 million in February. Furniture output was particularly strong, rebounding from an early-year decline.
Nondurable consumer goods rose four-tenths of 1 percent, spurred by energy for residential use.
Business equipment other than motor vehicles rose two-tenths of 1 percent as most major categories posted increases. The Fed noted, however, that the business sector "has remained weak," even when allowance is made for the strike at Caterpillar Inc. Output of construction supplies edged lower last month after being unchanged in February.
 
Surge by Utilities
 The surge in output by the nation's utilities, which account for 7.8 percent of the total index, was 2.1 percent last month. This was enough to more than offset the decline in mining, which represents 7.5 percent of the index, and the minimal gain in manufacturing, which represents 84.7 percent.
Today's report also showed the operating, or utilization, rate fell in manufacturing for both primary and advanced processing. These have weakened since fall, the Fed noted, "with large drops occurring" in transportation equipment, primary chemicals and in paper, rubber and plastic products.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metal Prices Fall As Investors Turn to Stocks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Precious metal futures prices crumbled yesterday as the soaring stock market and a weakening inflation outlook prompted investors to dump gold and buy stocks.
Gold for April delivery dropped $3.50, to $336 a troy ounce, on New York's Commodity Exchange; April silver sank 9.5 cents, to $4.006 a troy ounce. April platinum fell $2.90, to $343.30 an ounce, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. 
 Large commodity funds sold precious metal holdings to take advantage of the Dow Jones industrial average's second straight daily increase of more than 47 points.
"The stock market's going up like nobody's business and you're seeing people shift their investments away from the metals and putting them into the equity markets," said Randolph Donney, head of commodity research for the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
He said the spot gold price could drop as low as $320 an ounce before finding major buying.
Analysts also cited the general downtrend in commodity prices as measured by the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 markets. The C.R.B. index, which is considered an inflation yardstick, fell about one-half point yesterday, to 205.55.
Gold is considered an investment hedge against inflation, so low inflation is a disincentive to own gold.
The C.R.B. index is around its 1978 level, said James M. Nevlar, an analyst for the New York-based bureau, which is owned by the Knight-Ridder media company.
Gasoline led a rebound in fuel and crude oil prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Wholesale gasoline prices, which fell more than 3 cents in the two previous sessions, regained about a third of that amount after the American Petroleum Institute reported a 3.78-million-barrel drop last week in domestic gasoline supplies.
Crude oil for May delivery edged up 1 cent, to $19.87 a barrel; May heating oil climbed 0.51 cent, to 55.59 cents a gallon; May unleaded gasoline jumped 1.14 cents, to 59.37 cents a gallon; May natural gas rose 6.4 cents, to $1.34 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Soybean futures rose but corn and wheat prices ended narrowly mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade in an abbreviated two-hour trading session that marked the end of a two-day emergency shutdown.
Volume was described as fair to active as traders returned to the grain pits for the first time since an underground flood in downtown Chicago on Monday forced the shutdown of electrical systems in the affected area.
Exchange officials scheduled another abbreviated session for today. The Board of Trade, like other financial and commodity markets, will be closed tomorrow, Good Friday.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Hanson Viewed As Undervalued

BYLINE: By Barnaby J. Feder

 BODY:
AFTER years of trying, Hanson P.L.C. has finally nudged the level of American ownership of its stock over 20 percent. However, that is far short of the goal the industrial and natural resources conglomerate outlined to American analysts and portfolio managers during the company's recent investment roadshows.
The company wants to be "a core investment holding here as we are in Britain," according to Lord White, head of its American operations. Hanson's track record certainly warrants attention. The company has reported increased profits every year since it was founded in 1964 when Lord White and Lord Hanson merged their fertilizer, commercial vehicle distribution and printing businesses and built the conglomerate with a string of successful takeovers. 
 By now almost no company in Britain or the United States is too large to be considered a potential Hanson acquisition, a point driven home by the furor that erupted in London last summer when Hanson began buying shares in Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. for investment purposes. And some analysts say the stock, which is traded on the New York Stock Exchange where one American depository receipt represents five British shares, is currently undervalued. It closed yesterday at $20.50, down 37.5 cents.
"It's extremely cheap right now," said Geoffrey Allum, leader of the analysts who follow Hanson for County NatWest Wood Mackenzie in London. "It doesn't need to acquire any more assets to benefit hugely from any economic pickup."
In recent years, over half Hanson's business has come from American operations, where its natural resource holdings include Peabody Coal, the nation's largest coal company; Cavenham Forest Industries, and Gold Fields Mining. Other businesses include Jacuzzi health spas, Endicott Johnson shoes, Faberware cookware, Kaiser cement, Ames tools and Grove Worldwide, the world's largest producer of construction cranes. The American businesses together would form a company with revenues that would rank among the top 60 in the nation. Hanson, which formerly owned the Smith Corona Corporation, took it public in 1989 but retains a 48 percent interest.
Hanson's holdings in Britain, where it is the fifth-largest company, include Imperial Tobacco, Britain's Ever Ready battery company and a huge stake in the construction industry, which was recently enlarged by the acquisition of Beazer P.L.C.
Most analysts are less impressed than Mr. Allum by the prospects for Hanson's stock. The company has become so large that they see scant hope that it can continue achieving 28 percent annual returns. Bruce Davidson, who follows Hanson for Smith New Court in London, describes it as "mature but cyclical" with over a third of its revenues coming from economically sensitive businesses.
Operating income fell in the fiscal year that ended last Sept. 30 for the first time, and net income is likely to be down this year for the first time unless a fairly sizable business is sold at a hefty profit. Net income in the quarter ended last Dec. 31 fell 21.2 percent, to $349 million, on revenues of $3.93 billion, from $443 million in the last quarter of 1990, which was bolstered by $92 million in one-time profits from the sale of businesses.
The earnings slowdown comes as Hanson is trying to shed its image as a deal-driven company dependent on its founders. Another stumbling block for investors has been the company's accounting practices, a result of operating an array of companies under differing American and British accounting standards.
The argument for Hanson is that companies that have been retained under its umbrella have typically recorded huge productivity gains and improved their strategic position. That record was tarnished, company executives admit, by the decline in Smith Corona's fortunes after the public offering.
During the recent roadshow, Hanson executives said that similar partial disposals were unlikely in the near future and that they remained open to selling companies or acquiring new ones. In the United States, the most likely targets are extensions of existing businesses. Hanson is also interested in expanding into Europe through friendly takeovers but is leery of European Community and local laws that might prevent it from pursuing productivity-enhancing employment cutbacks and factory consolidations.
The company's high dividend -- $1.17 an A.D.R. for a yield of 5.59 percent -- is especially appealing to American investors, but analysts say the real payoff depends on economic recovery. The stock currently trades at a discount of almost 30 percent to the market in Britain, compared with a 100 premium in 1984, according to David Ireland, an analyst with Hoare Govett in London. It will take renewed earnings growth to narrow the discount.
"To invest in Hanson, you have to expect that the economy is going to get better," agreed Sidney J. Heller, who follows the company here for Shearson Lehman Brothers. Shearson's London office has a "neutral" rating on the company, which Mr. Heller accepts although he describes himself as more favorable than his London counterparts. Mr. Heller said a potential investor in Hanson might do better with two American conglomerates, Allied-Signal and Textron. "You can already see that things are going well for them," he said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts General Gains, Still Rallying Against Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar gained against most foreign currencies yesterday as it continued its rally against the German mark.
Foreign exchange dealers directed most of their attention to the relationship between the dollar and the mark, said James Lorenzo of ABN-Amro Bank. 
 The dollar fetched 1.6625 German marks late in the day in New York, stronger than Tuesday's late level of 1.6535.
 
Volume Is Sluggish
 Mr. Lorenzo said there were no fundamental factors to buoy the dollar, and new United States economic reports failed to stir much interest among currency dealers.
Among the figures released in Washington was a Federal Reserve report that production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose two-tenths of 1 percent in March. The slight gain in the industrial production index followed a five-tenths of 1 percent advance in February.
Currency trading volume was moderate at best, Mr. Lorenzo said. Activity is expected to be even more sluggish today ahead of the Good Friday holiday. European financial markets will be closed tomorrow and Monday, which will curb currency dealings here.
In New York, the dollar closed at 133.38 Japanese yen, up from 133.00 yen late Tuesday. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.20 yen, to a closing price of 133.25 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 133.35 yen.
The dollar strengthened against sterling in worldwide trading. The pound closed at $1.7550, down from $1.7640. In London, the pound fell to $1.7570, from $1.7720 late Tuesday.
Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with Tuesday's late levels, were: 5.6230 French francs, up from 5.5995; 1.5330 Swiss francs, up from 1.5225; 1,249.00 Italian lire, up from 1,243.25; 1.17925 Canadian dollars, up from 1.18215.

HEADLINE: Businesses' Sales Rise 1.4%, As Inventories Hold Steady

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15

 BODY:
Business sales shot up in February while inventories held steady, the Government said today, a combination considered a good sign for the economy's future.
The Commerce Department said sales increased 1.4 percent -- the steepest rise in 10 months -- to a seasonally adjusted $544.85 billion. That gain followed a rise of nine-tenths of 1 percent in January. 
 Inventories, meanwhile, held steady at $812.99 billion after a decline of five-tenths of 1 percent a month earlier.
 
Positive Signal
 Falling or flat inventories in the face of rising sales are a positive signal for the economy. If higher sales are sustained, businesses with depleted stocks will soon start ordering more goods from factories, which in turn will increase production and eventually lead to new hiring.
Industrial production registered an advance of two-tenths of 1 percent in March, according to a separate report by the Federal Reserve.
Sales last fell in December. Inventories had risen each month from September through December.
 
Inventory-to-Sales Ratio at 1.49
 In February, the combination of rising sales and flat inventories brought the inventory-to-sales ratio to 1.49, down from 1.51 a month earlier and the lowest since August. The latest figure means that it would take 1.49 months to exhaust inventories at the current pace of sales.
By sector, February sales jumped 2.1 percent at factories, five-tenths of 1 percent at wholesalers and 1.3 percent at retailers. An advance estimate for March showed retail sales falling four-tenths of 1 percent.
Manufacturers reported a drop of three-tenths of 1 percent in inventories in February. Retail backlogs were unchanged over all, although they were down at department stores and up at automobile dealers. Wholesale inventories rose six-tenths of 1 percent.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Inventory-Sales Ratio" shows the total month-end business inventories divided by total monthly business sales from Sept. '90-Feb. '92. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A 10.8% Gain For Gannett

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va., April 15

 BODY:
The Gannett Company today reported a 10.8 percent increase in profits for the first quarter of 1991 over results in the comparable period last year.
The company reported net income of $55.5 million, or 39 cents a share, for the quarter, up from $50.1 million, or 32 cents a share, a year earlier. Some of the per-share earnings gain reflected the repurchase of 15 million shares in June 1991. 
 Revenues climbed 1 percent, to $793.1 million from $786.5 million.
Gannett said recent trends, including favorable interest rates and lower newsprint costs, "suggest a more encouraging economic environment."
The company's total newspaper advertising revenues were flat for the quarter. Gannett, however, sold The Arkansas Gazette in October. Newspapers owned in both quarters showed a 1 percent rise in advertising revenues for the reporting quarter.
For the entire company, classified advertising linage was up 4 percent in March, compared with a year earlier.
Gannett publishes 81 daily newspapers, including USA Today, and operates 10 television and 15 radio stations, along with North America's largest outdoor advertising company, the Gannett Outdoor Group.
Total advertising revenues at USA Today were up 4 percent, but paid advertising pages at the national newspaper were off 3 percent.

HEADLINE: At 'Guys and Dolls,' Seeking Fun and Breaking a Record

 BODY:
When the head porter at the Martin Beck Theater showed up for work at 8 A.M. yesterday, the line had already formed for "Guys and Dolls." Then it grew, and grew. Even Michael Jukovsky was impressed. Mr. Jukovsky, well known to theater personnel up and down Broadway as New York's most persistent patron of musicals, holds the distinction of having bought the first ticket for the first preview of "Guys and Dolls."
Surveying the crowd lining up for advance tickets, he shook his head and said, " 'Crazy for You' had lines, but nothing like this." Theater management acted quickly and set out a table with free coffee and many of those in line indulged in reminiscence. With memories of Vivian Blaine and Sam Levene thick in the air, older patrons recalled watching the original in the same awed tones that some baby boomers use when talking about Woodstock. 
 By 9 P.M., 6,870 tickets had been sold, a box-office take of $374,737, breaking the day-after-opening record of $359,000 set by "The Phantom of the Opera" in 1988. No one in line seemed surprised at the response.
"There hasn't been a real musical for years: not like the old ones," said Susan Andelman of Manhattan, waiting in line. "We're in a recession, so we don't want messages. We want uplift and good tunes."

HEADLINE: Where the Money Comes From To Fuel the Boom on Broadway

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
In a recession, and after one of the most disastrous fall seasons in years, Broadway has 23 new productions this spring, more than at any time in recent memory.
So where's all the money coming from? 
 The director of research for the League of American Theaters and Producers in Manhattan, George Wachtel, said, "There are more different and new investors this year than in any of the last five seasons."
They include corporate entrepreneurs looking for a big score, foreign corporations trading for ancillary rights, and individuals like the musician and music executive Herb Alpert and Nobunao Furuyama, a Japanese real-estate developer.
 
Investing Out of Gratitude
 Mr. Alpert has invested an undisclosed amount in the musical "Jelly's Last Jam," which opens April 26, and Mr. Furuyama anted up half a million dollars for "Shimada." Mr. Furuyama said the money for the play, a drama about tensions between a Japanese businessman and an Australian former prisoner of war that opens next Thursday, was an expression of his gratitude "to the American education system and my contribution to American culture." His son attends a prep school in Washington.
The investor who has got the most attention is Roger Horchow, of Horchow Collection catalogue fame, whose long-held admiration for Gershwin's "Girl Crazy" extended to his pocketbook: he put up two-thirds of the $7.5 million capitalization of "Crazy for You." Mr. Horchow has invested in productions before, but never to this extent.
Nonprofit theaters, which with eight shows are more of a Broadway presence than ever before, have also become major financial contributors to their own productions. One, "The Most Happy Fella," was produced by three nonprofits -- Lincoln Center Theater, the Goodspeed Opera House and the Center Theater Group -- as well as commercial investors like Japan Satellite Broadcasting/Stagevision and the Shubert Organization. And "A Small Family Business," the Alan Ayckbourn comedy that opens April 27, is being financed by Manhattan Theater Club Productions, a profit-making subsidiary set up by that nonprofit theater, along with a commercial producer, Weissman Productions. Such subsidiaries make it possible for nonprofits to share in money-making without jeopardizing their tax-exempt status.
 
They Don't Grow on Trees
 New backers, of course, have not simply appeared, unprompted, from the wings. On the contrary, said Roger Berlind, a producer of "Death and the Maiden" and "Guys and Dolls." "Investors have been more reluctant to risk capital in a time when everything is marked down," he said, "and their house or their art is worth less than they thought."
Thus, said Elizabeth Williams, a co-producer of "Crazy for You," "Producers have had to become more ingenious, they've had to work harder to find corporate sponsorship and investment, and to find individuals who are both passionate about the theater, and comfortable with risk."
In their search for corporate assistance, many producers have found help abroad, with angels like the Tokyo-based entrepreneurial company Office 2-1, which the producer, Emanuel Azenberg, said had put a "significant" amount of money into "Jake's Women" and would also provide part of the financing for Mr. Simon's $7 million musical version of "The Goodbye Girl," scheduled to come to Broadway next fall.
Increasingly, foreign corporations are investing in Broadway productions in return for ancillary rights. The Dutch-owned Polygram Diversified Entertainment, for instance, has invested $1 million in "Jelly's Last Jam" in return for pay-per-view television rights, and TV Asahi, the Japanese partner of Jujamcyn Theaters, received the right of first refusal for a Japanese production of "Jelly's Last Jam" in exchange for a $500,0000 investment in the Broadway version.
 
Saving Something for Later
 This trend "is one way to bring in new blood in a time when producers have to be increasingly resourceful," said Margo Lion, a co-producer of "Jelly's Last Jam." "The challenge is that you don't want to sell off everything up front so that investors can share in subsidiary rights later on."
Much of the money for plays this spring has come from familiar sources: veteran investors who have jousted on the theater scene for years, corporations that have long had financial arrangements with Broadway productions, even the occasional playwright with a solid-gold track record (Neil Simon is the principal investor in "Jake's Women," though he won't say how much).
The $1.5 million for "A Streetcar Named Desire" came from "our traditional partners," said Gerald Schoenfeld of the Shubert Organization, referring to Capital Cities Communications and Suntory International, the Japanese whisky maker, which began its investing relationship with the Shuberts in 1979.
And most of the 22 investors who chipped in the $1.4 million for Herb Gardner's "Conversations With My Father" were angels from past Gardner plays like "I'm Not Rappaport."
Despite the celebratory atmosphere created by all the new shows, and the variety of financing sources, however, many theater people are reluctant to view all the new productions as the harbinger of a bright Broadway future.
Some producers feel that the spring boomlet simply reflects a pent-up explosion of capital constrained earlier in the season, when only one new production, "Dancing at Lughnasa," was a success with both critics and audiences.
But others, noting the delays that most of this season's shows endured on their way to Broadway, believe the spring lineup has, as James Walsh, the producer of "Conversations With My Father," said, more to do with "sheer coincidence."
"I would like to think that this is a new wave," said Mr. Walsh, "but I think it's an aberration."
 
Like Comedy, It's All Timing
 John Breglio, a theater lawyer at the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, said the spring season was driven by the Tony Awards, which are presented in late May. "The so-called spring gold rush is a matter of timing," he said, "and it's gotten out of hand. Producers feel they've got to have the momentum of going into the Tonys." So Broadway, he said, has now evolved "into a two-and-a-half-month season."
There is a difference of opinion, too, on the increased role of nonprofit productions on Broadway. Mr. Breglio, who calls it "a significant change in the Broadway season," said, "to me, the nonprofits are filling the gaps, doing what traditional producers used to do."
In putting their own shows on Broadway, the nonprofit companies maintain creative control over projects and stand to reap more profits if the show is successful. The money to mount their shows and pay for marketing can come from the surpluses from previous successes (the New York Shakespeare Festival used the profits from "A Chorus Line" to finance many other productions), or from other institutional or commercial partners.
 
Nonprofit Threat to Business
 Although nonprofits frequently pay full freight when renting a theater, they occasionally get a discount, as in the case of the National Actors Theater, which pays the Shubert Organization little more than the cost of lighting, heating and other fixed expenses for use of the chronically underoccupied Belasco Theater.
But though it is filling Broadway houses that might otherwise be dark, the growing presence of the nonprofits, and the competition for money and audiences they bring, is not universally embraced. "It's not a trend that I look upon with celebration," said Rocco Landesman, the president of Jujamcyn Theaters. "It's a legitimate question, whether we should be competing on Broadway with subsidized productions. Long term, I don't think it's healthy for those institutions, or for Broadway."
Mr. Landesman said it put unsubsidized producers at a competitive disadvantage monetarily, accustomed audiences to look to the nonprofits for plays, and discouraged investors from mounting productions that might compete with those of the nonprofits.
The involvement of nonprofits can also cut down on revenues to commercial partners: "The Most Happy Fella," which received critical raves, has offered discount tickets to Lincoln Center Theater subscribers, thus extending the time of recoupment.
There can be pitfalls for the Broadway-bound nonprofits too, which are not immunized by their subscription lists, or their subsidized status, from the travails that can afflict commercial producers. The Circle Repertory Company, which hoped to open the new Lanford Wilson play, "Redwood Curtain," last Thursday at the Nederlander Theater, fell $120,000 short of its $800,000 financing, and the opening was postponed to next fall, when a commercial producer may bring it to Broadway.

HEADLINE: Home Video

BYLINE: By Peter M. Nichols

 BODY:

The Hits Are Coming
Stuck for months with generally humdrum titles, video stores will soon have a dozen splashy movies to offer for rent. Video releases usually follow theater openings by four to six months, and from May into the fall will come the big films -- from "The Addams Family" to "The Prince of Tides" -- that got people into theaters last winter and in a couple of cases went over the $100 million mark at the box office. 
 Divining the right release date is as big a headache for studio video divisions as it is for their theatrical counterparts. Last week Warner settled on May 20 for "J. F. K." (on two cassettes) to precede a schedule crowded with "Cape Fear" (June 4), "The Addams Family" (June 18), "Grand Canyon" (June 25) and "Bugsy" (July 1).
But May, if schedules don't change, is crowded, too, especially the last week: "Father of the Bride" (May 27), "My Girl" (May 27) and "For the Boys" (May 28). In an attention-getting move also scheduled for late May, Orion will drop the price of "The Silence of the Lambs," the big Oscar winner and a best renter for months, to $19.98.
In July, according to plan, will come "Star Trek VI" (July 1) and "The Hand That Rocks the Cradle" (July 15). The month might also produce "The Prince of Tides," though a specific date hasn't been confirmed.
Two later entries are "Beauty and the Beast" ($24.99), which Disney is saving for Oct. 30, and "Hook," which could be released at about the same time and also at a low price.
 
Unexploited Audience
 Performing-arts titles make up a minute percentage of the overall video market, but to hear the public opinion pollster Louis Harris tell it, the industry is missing out on a veritable bonanza by not promoting the genre.
Recently L. H. Research, of which Mr. Harris is chairman, polled 1,500 Americans at all economic levels to determine their attitudes about supporting the arts and viewing them in all mediums. When it came to video, 40 percent of the respondents from VCR households reported that they increasingly watched cassettes rather than television programs and 56 percent said they would like to rent or buy arts tapes.
Using this and other of his research findings, Mr. Harris has made some rough projections. Eight percent of the respondents said they would be certain to rent or buy arts tapes if they were available. Take 8 percent of 178 million adult Americans in VCR households and that comes to 14.2 million potential renters or buyers of arts tapes.
The Harris report found that respondents who patronized the arts rented tapes an average of 28.2 times over the past 12 months. Multiply 28.2 by 14.2 million and that makes about 400 million rentals. If the rental is $2, say, then a hypothetical arts market could reach $800 million.
"Someone's going to connect on this sooner or later," Mr. Harris said.
 
New Video Releases

 
The Last Boy Scout
1991. Warner. $94.99. Laser disk, $29.98. 1 hour 45 minutes. Closed captioned. R.
Bruce Willis plus Damon Wayans plus goons, gore and auto wrecks add up to a sort of poor man's "Lethal Weapon." Tony Scott's formula thriller is the brutal, graceless story of a pro-football team owner who will do about anything to get senatorial backing for a bill to promote legalized gambling on sports. Into the Gibson "Lethal Weapon" position steps Mr. Willis as a burned-out private eye; in the Danny Glover slot is Mr. Wayans as his seedy sidekick. Though the film sinks in mechanical sleaze, "the news isn't all bad for Mr. Willis. 'The Last Boy Scout' is better than 'Hudson Hawk' " (Vincent Canby).
 
1,000 Pieces of Gold
1991. Hemdale. $89.95. LD, $39.95. 1:45. PG-13.
In famine-stricken China during the 1880's, young Lalu (Rosalind Chao) is sold to a marriage broker and shipped to America, where she finds herself the slave of a rapacious saloon keeper (Michael Paul Chan) in the gold-mining town of Warren's Diggens, Idaho. Nancy Kelly's film, based on a true story, addresses the larger issue of labor exploitation in the mines and on the railroads. Ms. Chao's impressive performance as a survivor and Ms. Kelly's straightforward narration turn what could have been an overwrought story into "cool, clear-eyed historical drama" (Stephen Holden).
 
Liebestraum
1991. MGM/UA. $89.99. LD, $34.98. 1:49. CC. R.
A Mike Figgis film can mix odd ingredients. In this one, named for a Liszt piano composition, there's an architectural writer (Kevin Anderson), a bored wife (Pamela Gidley), a dying mother (Kim Novak) and a cast-iron department-store building where a murder took place 40 years earlier. In the present day the building is about to be torn down, the writer is having an affair with the wife, whose husband (Bill Pullman) is supervising the building's demolition. From the players in that situation Mr. Figgis "is very capable of of teasing a a voluptuous blend of danger and sexual possibility" (Janet Maslin).
 
Mambo Mouth
1990. Polygram$19.95. 1:00. No rating.
"You too can be a crossover success," says a neatly dressed Japanese lecturer. He's really John Leguizamo, a performer of Colombian and Puerto Rican extraction, who in this skit from his 1990 one-man Off Broadway show turns himself from a "loud, obnoxious Latino holding my crotch for self-assurance" into a "Japanese warrior who listens to Lite FM" In this and six other sketches Mr. Leguizamo delivers hilarious renditions of Hispanic braggadocio and bitterness, playing characters "with the edgy, finger-snapping energy you might imagine, but also with flashes of pathos that are apt to catch you totally off guard" (David Richards).
 
Arts and Artistry
 The arts on video tend to sell slowly but steadily over a period of years. Here is a selection of popular tapes from various distributors.
 AIDA. Highlights from the La Scala production starring Ghena Dimitrova, Luciano Pavarotti and Maria Chiara, conducted by Loren Maazel. 1988. Home Vision. $39.95. 1 hour.
 BARYSHNIKOV AT WOLF TRAP. The dancer's American debut in 1976 at the performing arts center in Virginia includes the "Don Quixote" pas de deux. 1992. Kultur. $29.95. 50 minutes.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Former Football Star Gets Job at Drug Maker

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Nicholas A. Buoniconti, whose career has run from professional football to charities to business, yesterday was named vice chairman and chief operating officer of Columbia Laboratories Inc., a pharmaceuticals company.
Mr. Buoniconti, 51 years old, the former Miami Dolphins linebacker and former president of UST, a big maker of snuff and chewing tobacco, is returning to the business world after a two-year sabbatical to raise money for The Miami Project to Cure Paralysis, which he co-founded. 
 He joined Columbia's board last summer at the invitation of Columbia executives whom Mr. Buoniconti had known for more than 20 years. In January, he was offered a more active role after the chairman resigned to pursue other business interests.
Although Mr. Buoniconti has not worked in the pharmaceuticals industry before, he pointed out that he has had experience in operating a company. At UST, he was in charge of 4,000 employees at the Fortune 500 company. He said in an interview yesterday that while Columbia, with 40 employees and based in Hollywood, Fla., is a much less established company, he "felt they were qualified and their product line was innovative."
Columbia recently set up licensing agreements with several companies, including Warner-Lambert, to market and sell its products in domestic and foreign markets. A typical arrangement calls for Columbia to receive 28 percent to 30 percent of the product's sales price.
Mr. Buoniconti said one of his principal roles will be to work with licensing partners. Columbia also plans to open a factory in Ireland in 1994 for manufacturing its products, now made by subcontractors. Columbia has chosen Ireland because of tax advantages and its central location to the company's worldwide markets, he said.
Columbia's over-the-counter products, based on a patented technology, include Replens, a remedy for vaginal dryness. The company is also developing some prescription drugs, but Columbia has not yet decided whether it will license those products or sell them itself. Columbia had revenues of $10.6 million last year and a net loss of $14.5 million.
Mr. Buoniconti has an economics degree from the University of Notre Dame and a law degree from the Suffolk University Law School in Boston. He and his wife, Terry, live in Coral Gables, Fla., and have three adult children.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Rising Gorge

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Outrage is In. The fashion color for spring is red in the face. The national gorge on the rise.
Pollsters assure us that this is the year of the mad-as-hell voter. Popularity ratings mean nothing; only the feared "negatives" are counted -- and in that inverted rating, to be behind is to be ahead. 
 Radio talk shows have become snarlfests; the most successful call- in hosts are the dudgeonaries who whip listeners into new danders at representatives checking their caches.
Television news has tapped into the hyperarticulated frustration. Its anchors are heard spreading the disparaging word, and its cameras linger lovingly on images of joblessness, homelessness, hopelessness and lessnessness.
The print media are not to be outdone in the surliness sweepstakes. The tabloids trash the candidates with garish glee, raising "in your face" to the year's hottest compound adjective. Meanwhile, the sobersided sachems of the responsible press lionize a couple of Senators who quit because they are bored with their jobs, and treat the handsome pair as heroes for disdaining the anxieties of public service.
The politics of resentment is being covered -- and of course, exaggerated -- because enough people are persuaded that it is more fun to sound off than to sign on. As a result, the nation's most visible product is steam, which is being let off at a great rate.
Five years ago, you couldn't stir up outrage with any provocation. Saddam Hussein slaughtered 5,000 Kurds with poison gas and a handful of moralists hollered in vain; professors at our own Army War College are still explaining that the atrocity never happened, and while watchdogs yawned the State Department helped Iraq prepare for war.
That was then, when cool was in. Those who inveighed against the abuse of the franking privilege by a Congress stuffing its constituents' mailboxes with advertising were shrugged off as scolds.
Now a combination of recession, restlessness and a loss of the focus of anti-Communism has transformed the public mood. Outrage bestrides the stage.
Fringe political types, who always capitalize on fads in philosophy and feelings, moved in on the mood swing. Today's attitude is to take offense, and would-be leaders rush to affront lines to lead the national tantrum.
Thus we have the mirror-image candidacies of Brown and Buchanan, catering to the voguish resentment by espousing nativism, protectionism and isolationism. Their answer to alienation is to bait the aliens.
Thus we have the weird wish for the All-Positive Candidate, unblemished by the experience and compromise that burden the candidates of reality.
Republicans let themselves be infuriated at the demonstrated shortcomings of George Bush; Democrats vent their wrath at being forced to accept a "flawed candidacy" of Bill Clinton. The election will be decided by how many more Democrats cannot stand Clinton than Republicans cannot abide Bush.
Mr. Bush, the candidate of continuation, styles himself as the agent of change; that's a joke. Mr. Clinton, the candidate of a new generation, has genuine change to offer, but the moment's majority prefers only to express outrage at the status quo -- not to take a chance on loving a stranger.
This general embrace of outrage, this trendy glorification of outsiderhood invites a far-out candidacy to flower. The most self-possessed nation in the world has indulged its frustrations to the point of creating a constituency of the dispossessed.
Enter Ross Perot, the man on computerback. He scoops up the troops of Buchanan and Brown, inherits the wind of resentment and buys loose votes with a billionaire's riches without causing concern because he's seen to be "too rich to steal."
For those stressed out by life's complications, Mr. Perot has no- sweat answers. His simple message has great appeal to simpletons. He says he'll handle the deficit by eliminating "waste, fraud and abuse."
But it is our indulgence of selfish grumpiness that is the waste. It is the notion that the democratic system is unfair that is a fraud. And it is the willingness of free people to be diddled by misdirected outrage that is an abuse.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Old Mills and Factories All Over the Northeast Get a New Life

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As an architect and a historic preservation consultant involved in two major mill restoration projects, we would like to comment on some of the statements quoted in your March 23 article about Trenton's efforts to reclaim old factories left for dead.
While it is true that many older industrial buildings are contaminated with hazardous materials unknowingly used in the past, this does not mean that they are beyond hope of salvage. In most cases, cleanup consists of removing or encapsulating lead paint or asbestos-lined heating units or transformers. Where extensive contamination exists, even new construction is impossible without a thorough cleanup, often requiring state or Federal assistance. 
 The architectural and historical value of many of the mills warrants extensive study of their potential reuse. Many of the mills we have examined are cathedrals of industry, imbedded into the social fabric of the communities surrounding them. With their heavy, timber-frame construction and masonry walls, they were built with a precision and care unknown today, and designed to last despite decades of neglect.
You quote Stephen M. Segal, a Trenton broker of industrial real estate, as being concerned about the limitations of reusing old mills for modern industry. While we agree that 19th-century factories are not easily converted to modern production methods, it is unlikely that this kind of industry will ever return to the Northeast, no matter how up to date the facility.
That does not mean there are not many other uses for mill space. The "low ceilings" Mr. Segal refers to are often 15 feet high, maybe not enough for modern manufacturing, but more than ample for offices, retail establishments and loft-type residences.
There have been too many successful mill conversions throughout the Northeast for anyone in Trenton to lose hope. The former Winchester Rifle Works in New Haven, which you refer to, is only one example of creative reuse of an obsolete, historic mill. There are numerous examples of everything from factory outlets to artists' lofts. And the often spectacular riverside or waterfall settings of old mills only add to their appeal.
 
RENEE KAHN, ELENA KALMAN
Stamford, Conn., April 2, 1992
 
The writers are, respectively, director, Historic Neighborhood Preservation Program, and an architect.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Drop in Slow Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped in slow trading yesterday, as liquidity continued to be drained from the credit market in the aftermath of the underground flooding in Chicago that interrupted futures trading there.
The Chicago Board of Trade did open for a couple of hours yesterday, but traders said that most futures traders have essentially gone on vacation for the rest of the week. The Board plans shortened hours again today and will be closed tomorrow, Good Friday. 
 The largest price decline was seen among shorter-term notes, securities that have rallied sharply for two weeks.
"Given the Fed easing and the way the market reacted to it, this just shows that things are calming down," one government securities trader said. "And with the Board essentially out of business, that means we are going to stay in a pretty narrow trading range."
 
Retail Activity Brisk
 A sharp rise in Japanese stock prices and a report from the Johnson Redbook Service, a consumer survey organization, showing that retail activity was fairly brisk in early April helped to push down prices of Treasury securities early in the session.
That decline was not overcome during the remainder of the session even though the two-tenths of a percent rise in industrial production during March reported by the Federal Reserve Board was a bit weaker than expected.
Analysts said the rise in industrial output was consistent with an economy that is recovering sluggishly.
"Talk from last week that the Fed was going to cut the discount rate imminently is fading," said Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at the Bank of America. "Now people realize the Fed isn't about to do that, and they are trimming back positions in advance of the long weekend."
The coming auctions of new two- and five-year Treasury notes are also beginning to weigh on the market, traders said.
Yesterday the Treasury announced that it will sell $14.75 billion worth of two-year notes on Wednesday and $10.25 billion of five-year notes next Thursday.
In when-issued trading following the announcement, the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 5.27 percent, and the five-year notes were offered at a price to yield 6.67 percent.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 10115/32 , down 3/32 , to yield 7.87 percent, compared with 7.86 percent late Tuesday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered late yesterday at 10031/32 , down a quarter of a point, to yield 7.35 percent. And the 7 percent seven-year notes were offered at 9930/32 , down 6/32 , to yield 7.01 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates dipped slightly.
Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 3.60 percent, down a basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 3.71 percent.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the Gulf States Utilities Company offered a total of $600 million worth of 12-year and 32-year first mortgage bonds through an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The 8 1/4 percent 12-year bonds were priced at $99.796 to yield 8.276 percent, 92 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The remaining $300 million of 8.70 percent bonds due 2024 were priced at $98.203 to yield 8.869 percent, one percentage point over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds at the time of pricing.
The 12-year bonds are noncallable for life. The 32-year bonds are not callable for 10 years.
The issue is rated Baa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
New Junk Bond Issue
 In the high-yield junk bond market, the BT Securities Corporation acted as lead manager for an offering of $175 million worth of senior notes from Food 4 Less.
The 10.45 percent securities, which are not callable for four years, were priced at $100, or par.
The size of the issue was increased from $150 million due to strong demand.
The securities are rated Ba-3 by Moody's and BB-minus by Standard & Poor's.
Corporate bond traders said that prices of most investment-grade securities were little changed on the day.
And participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said that prices of most actively quoted bonds rose by about a quarter of a point.

HEADLINE: Lessons in Protection -- A special report.;
Trade Curbs: Do They Do the Job?

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15

 BODY:
In the midst of the recession and election campaign, protectionist pressures have boiled to the surface, but economists say that import restrictions have had glaringly mixed results for the industries they were supposed to help.
For a few industries like motorcycle manufacturers, protection has provided the breathing room they wanted to begin to regain their strength. But several other industries, most notably autos, are worse off. For some industries, like steel and machine tools, the results of protection have been less than desired. And in most cases, economists generally agree, one clear loser is the American consumer. 
 "Except for motorcycles, I can't think of a case where the benefits that protection gives to producers outweigh the injury suffered by consumers," said Gary Hufbauer, a fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. He figures that in the mid-1980's quotas on Japanese car imports cost American car buyers an average of $500 a car, whether the car was imported or domestically made.
 
Weighing Costs and Benefits
 Several Presidential candidates, including Patrick J. Buchanan, a Republican, and Edmund G. Brown Jr., a Democrat, have backed protection, viewing it as much-needed medicine for the nation's ailing industries. President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas say they support free but fair trade and have shunned strong protectionist rhetoric.
The protectionist drumbeat, which reached a peak during the Michigan primary, is expected to remain strong in April when the primaries continue in industrial states like Pennsylvania.
Many economists say they are unenthusiastic about protection because, in their view, Washington's trade negotiators have often failed to chose its most effective forms. This has sometimes produced painful results, as when import quotas prompted Japanese car makers to build factories in Detroit's backyard.
"The lesson is that very often protectionist measures can behave in an unanticipated way and can even be counterproductive," said Daniel Roos, director of the International Motor Vehicle Program at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Tariffs are generally more helpful than quotas, because they have a direct effect in making foreign products less competitive. In contrast, quotas, which limit a product's supply, can strengthen foreign competitors by enabling them to raise prices and profits, giving them more money to expand or develop new products.
"Quotas are an extremely blunt instrument," said Robert Z. Lawrence, professor of international trade at the the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.
One novel form of protection came in 1986 when American semiconductor companies, worried about cutthroat pricing by Japanese competitors, pressed Washington to get the Japanese to sign an agreement setting a floor on computer chip prices.
Industry analysts say the agreement came too late to save many American producers of the main type of basic memory chips, but by subtly helping persuade Japanese chip makers to be less aggressive, the accord helped American companies making some newer types of chips. Nonetheless, many American computer makers complained that the agreement made them less competitive against the Japanese because they had to pay more for their computer chips.
Companies can grow stronger under protection if they use it as an opportunity to invest in equipment, improve product quality and otherwise shape up, economists say, although lazy companies can use protection as a cushion.
"Quotas give you a window of opportunity," said Eli Lustgarten, an industrial analyst at Paine Webber. "If you don't take advantage of that window to solve your problems, then you're going to disappear."
Labor unions are often the biggest fans of quotas and voluntary restraint agreements. "They are designed to provide an industry with time to adjust to specific foreign competition," said Rudy Oswald, chief economist for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "It's desirable to allow industries to do that because, otherwise, we will put whole industries out of business."
While most economists say protection means higher prices and fewer choices for consumers, Mr. Oswald argues that protection can mean more competition and lower prices in the long run by preventing Japanese cartels from dominating the American market and jacking up prices.
But in the view of many economists, the political debate about protection too often focuses on the needs of industry, while ignoring consumers, many economists say.
"Protection has cost American consumers big bucks," Mr. Hufbauer said. "If people knew how much it was going to cost them, wouldn't they insist that the nation, that the industries involved, get a better payoff from protection?"
 
Autos
For the Big Three, A Policy Misfires
 Cars imported from Japan had 20.5 percent of the American market when a voluntary-restraint agreement on such imports took effect in 1981. Last year, Japanese imports and cars built in Japanese factories in the United States grabbed 30.3 percent of the domestic market. What is more, despite a decade of quotas, the Big Three lost a record $7.5 billion last year.
What went wrong?
The quotas helped Japan's auto makers by fattening their profits. As American demand for Hondas and Toyotas outstripped the supply, prices and profit margins rose, giving the auto makers more money to invest in new models and factories.
The quotas also encouraged the Japanese to build ultramodern factories in the United States. While this has hurt Detroit, many economists say the transplant factories are a positive development, asserting that they are creating jobs and a more efficient domestic car industry, although one that is Japanese-owned.
By limiting the number of cars -- rather than the total value of Japanese imports -- the quotas gave Honda, Toyota and others a big incentive to build larger, more profitable cars. Honda turned its hot-selling Accord into a midsize car, while Toyota with its Acura, Honda with Lexus and Nissan with Infiniti put new entrants in the upper tier.
At the same time, the quotas swelled the profit margins of Detroit's Big Three, reducing the urgency for them to grow more competitive. Instead, the industry bought financial institutions, computer services companies, electronics companies and foreign auto makers, like Jaguar. If that money had gone into building more modern plants, Detroit would not be in such bad shape, many economists say.
"We created an incentive for the foreign producers to become more competitive, and we created an incentive for the domestic producers not to get more competitive," said Michael Borrus, co-director of the Berkeley Roundtable on the International Economy at the University of California. "What's perverse is American consumers paid for all of this."
The Big Three did invest billions of dollars in new plants, equipment and designs, but most industry analysts say that the Big Three still lag behind the Japanese in managing their employees, building quality into the assembly line and developing efficient factories.
"There have been some successes, but they happen to be in a broader context of failure," said Harley Shaiken, a visiting scholar at the Institute of Industrial Relations at the University of California at Berkeley.
And Mr. Roos of M.I.T. added: "There is no question that the American product has improved, but you are competing against a moving target. It isn't sufficient to play catch-up baseball."
 
Motorcycles
Harley-Davidson A Rare Success
 After recession and a flood of Japanese imports threatened Harley-Davidson Inc.'s survival in 1982, the Government agreed to impose five years of tariffs on Japanese motorcycles. The tariffs began at 45 percent in 1983 and were scheduled to decline to 10 percent in 1987, before being phased out.
A company known for making the roaring machines Marlon Brando rode in "The Wild Ones," Harley by the early 1980's was known for motorcycles that leaked oil and broke down easily. Under the umbrella of protection, it re-engineered its motorcycles, improved quality, and cut its costs by adopting new inventory methods and laying off layers of management. As a result, its market share has soared to 63 percent in large motorcycles, up from 23 percent in 1983. The plunge of the dollar after 1985 also helped.
"The tariffs gave us time to complete the revitalization that we had undertaken," said Jeffrey Bleustein, executive vice president at Harley-Davidson. "The fact that the tariffs declined told us we better get going as fast as we could."
Harley-Davidson regained its health so quickly that it asked Washington to eliminate the tariffs a year early. In fact, Harley is doing so well it is exporting aggressively to Japan.
"The Harley-Davidson case was exactly the way protection is supposed to work," said Mr. Hufbauer, the economist. "If you had many examples like that, you would be much more enthusiastic about protection."
 
Machine Tools
Help for Some, Hurt for Others
 The machine tool industry shows how protection can have mixed effects, with some companies saying quotas have rescued them, while others say quotas have nearly drowned them.
In 1986, when imported machine tools were flooding in at bargain prices, the industry asked for protection. The Pentagon lent a sympathetic ear, fearing that the nation's leadership in building weapons would suffer if the industry that made metal-cutting machinery was crippled.
So in 1987, the Government, finding that Japanese and Taiwan competitors had dumped machines on the American market at improperly low prices, got those competitors to accept a voluntary-restraint agreement, called a V.R.A. The quotas sought to keep imports from rising above 50 percent of the market.
Many machine tool manufacturers say the quotas, and the weaker dollar, have stabilized the market and increased their profits, enabling them to spend more on capital investment and developing new products.
Since the quotas took effect, for example, Cincinnati Milacron, a large machine tool producer, has increased its research and development budget by 50 percent, company officials say. It now introduces twice as many new models a year as before the quotas. "The V.R.A.'s have allowed us to rededicate ourselves to turning the machine tool business around," said Christopher C. Cole, vice president for strategy at Milacron.
But some machine tool makers say the quotas have hurt. For example, Brian McLaughlin, chief executive of Hurco, a machine tool company in Indianapolis, said the quotas almost drove his company bankrupt by preventing it from buying parts from Taiwan parts that represented 30 percent of the value of Hurco's machines.
Mr. McLaughlin said Hurco had cut back spending on developing advanced items like electronic controls because the quotas have forced it to invest in low-technology machines to produce basic cast-iron parts once obtained from Taiwan. He said the quotas might push Hurco to move production and 500 jobs overseas.
 
Choking Off Supplies

 
 "All we want to bring in are a few routine parts from Taiwan, and then incorporate 70 percent U.S. content," he said. "The quotas are telling us, 'You have to take U.S. jobs somewhere else,' because they're forcing up the costs of our production."
While many executives hail the quotas, economists ask why, if the quotas have been so successful, the industry still asked the Bush Administration last year for five more years of protection. In a compromise in December, President Bush extended the quotas for two years.
"We've put a tremendous amount of money into developing new machines over the past few years so we asked for an extension of the V.R.A.'s to give us more time to market these machines so we can make the money back," said John Fedor, president of Masco Machine Inc., a machine tool company in Cleveland.
 
Steel
Breathing Spell Spurs A Fragile Comeback
 When steel companies and steelworkers lobbied for protection in 1984 and again in 1989, they argued that temporary relief from low-priced imports would allow the industry to regain its strength.
Now, eight years after the quotas began, the nation's major steelmakers have staged a comeback by improving productivity and quality, but they lost more than $2 billion last year because capacity still outstrips demand. The quotas expired March 31, and the Bush Administration has decided not to extend them, preferring to rely on existing trade laws to battle unfairly priced imports.
In the Administration's view, the American industry has been shielded enough from competition and should be able to stand on its own. The industry is certainly a more formidable competitor than before, but many analysts say this transformation was brought about only partly by protection and mostly by the strong dollar and competitive pressures from low-cost, nonunion domestic mini-mills.
 
History of a Turnaround
 Some industry analysts say the big steelmakers did little to increase efficiency in the late 1970's and early 1980's when they were protected by a so-called trigger price mechanism that protected steelmakers against low-priced imports. They say this is a classic example of protection coddling industries into laziness.
The industry's attitude changed radically after 1982, when recession and a strong dollar drove it into crisis. Since then, the big steelmakers have vastly improved quality and productivity, with the number of man-hours required to produce a ton of steel cut in half. Steelmakers have slashed employment from 240,000 in 1984 to 160,000 today, showing that protection is not always friendly to workers. And the industry has spent more than $12 billion on equipment since 1984, although Japanese and Korean companies have helped finance many of these modernizations.
"The V.R.A.'s gave us some breathing room to become more competitive," said Lynn Williams, president of the United Steelworkers of America. For their part, industry officials say the quotas fattened their profits during the late 1980's, giving them cash to invest.
Still, faced with recession and worldwide overcapacity the nation's steelmakers complain that foreign competitors are dumping steel at cut-throat prices. For example, a ton of cold-rolled steel, which is used in automobiles, sells for $440 a ton, compared with $504 a ton in 1980.
All this shows that protection is no panacea. "Just because you've become much more competitive doesn't necessary keep you from losing money," said James Hughes, a spokesman for the American Iron and Steel Institute, the industry trade group.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Home Desk

HEADLINE: Studio! Life Style! Empire?

BYLINE: By JAMES SERVIN

 BODY:
ORIBE, the star hair stylist to the star models Linda Evangelista, Naomi Campbell, Christy Turlington et al, lingered for a moment outside a converted garage on Washington Street in the West Village. Wearing tight purple jeans and a leather jacket, he turned a well-heeled cowboy boot toward a huge glass doorway. Running a hand through a head of matinee-idol-thick black hair, he buzzed and then entered a cavernous concrete white-washed space.
Inside, a youngish woman in T-shirt and denim overalls sat behind a black matte desk. The phone rang. "Industria," she said, pronouncing the word with an Italian inflection. 
 White lights shone from a futuristic steel fixture above. Sinead O'Connor wailed a tortured song. All across the reception desk, office supplies bore a tiny, determined-looking, white-on-red label: "Industria." It appeared everywhere. On a stapler. A Rolodex. A book jacket.
Welcome to the world of Industria, a smooth-running model of politically correct fabulousness. Photo studio by day, sometime party place by night, Industria has been hired out for events whose hosts were Eddie Murphy, Ralph Lauren, Chanel and American Vogue. It's very 90's: Studio 54 with an early wake-up call. Even if a party draws thousands of guests and carries on until 4 A.M., a twilight cleaning crew assures that by 8 A.M., every last trace of confetti has vanished. Enter Steven Meisel, ready to photograph Madonna.
In the beginning, Industria was simply a great photography studio. Brainchild of the photographer Fabrizio Ferri and sister organization to Superstudio, Mr. Ferri's 9-year-old warehouse-size operation in Milan, Italy, Industria opened last February to instant popularity.
With 22,000 square feet of space, five studios and a smorgasbord of services (from equipment rental to catering to set-building to an adobe-style cafe), Industria offered magazines and ad agencies an attractive, recession-wise alternative to outdoor location shooting.
In its one short year on the block, however, Industria has become much, much more. The essence that all that is model-world-clubby, photo-studio trendy and Italiano seductive now infuses a range of products marketed under the Industria label. A core design team of five, headed by Mr. Ferri, sketches and plans product ideas, and Italian factories and artisans execute them.
Industria has already produced a spring collection of clothes (cashmere and suede shawls, leather vests, silk shirts and the like), and furniture is to follow. Overweening? Overextended? Or right on the money? No one can say at this early point, but plans are already under way for Industria watches, Industria stores and the inevitable Industria perfume.
"Industria is a place that embraces all of you, not just your professional side," Isabella Rossellini said as she was being made up for a Steven Meisel session. "There is a family feeling here -- I can bring my child if I want to. And there is that wonderful cafe."
The Industria esthetic is calm, solid, basic and unobtrusive. What provides the flash, and the life-style endorsements, are the models who wear the Industria sweaters (Calvin Klein's model of the moment, Lisa Taylor, says she has ordered a few), the film stars who sit in the slatted-back mahogany Industria chairs.
Industria's first avocational venture, the clothing line, appears to have been received well. Confirmed orders from Charivari, Barneys New York, Linda Dresner, Ron Ross, Ultima and Greta insure that the upscale countrywear (wool parkas for $690, cashmere and suede scarves for $1,500) will be in stores this August.
The furniture is another story. Industria has commissioned an Italian designer to handcraft three chairs and two tables. There is a straight, slatted-back chair, in mahogany or walnut, for $1,200, and two similar chairs with pliable slatted backs (an armchair is $1,300; a rocking chair, $1,550). Both Barneys and Charivari have expressed interest in buying a mahogany display table topped with glass and removable set of drawers ($1,800). No firm distribution plans are set for the furniture.
"The craftsman who makes the pieces sits in a courtyard in Milan, filling orders as they come in," said Industria's director of marketing, Lisa Immordino. "I have no idea how we're going to handle the furniture yet."
Then there is the series of massive, one-of-a-kind tables, chairs and beds fashioned from roots of Brazilian rain forest trees that will displayed and sold at Industria starting May 20. "Of course, only dead trees have been used," said Ms. Immordino. Over bottled water in Industria's cafe, she told the tale of their origin, of the 40-year-old "crazy man" who lives in a hut and carves the pieces.
"We like to say it's a sculpture," she said, examining a photograph of an hourglass-shaped piece of wood, "but technically it could be used as a plant holder." Where are the real things? "They're in two Mack trucks," Ms. Immordino said, "sitting in a garage."
Fabrizio Ferri, the man behind all this activity, has a suitably broad resume. Photographer to the international Vogues (English, Italian and German), among other publications, he has also worked on ad campaigns for corporations from Versace to Lanvin. Driven to capture serenity on film, Mr. Ferri will fly to New Mexico to shoot a Gucci bag on white sand, at sunset. When asked to explain what Industria is all about, Mr. Ferri comes up with a perfectly pitched ad-man's answer. "Industria is less about design and more about experience," he said from his Italian office. "It's about what you think you have but you really don't."
Days later, he made a slightly jet-lagged appearance in Industria's cafe. Dressed all in black and bodyguard robust, the bearded, 6-feet-4-inch Mr. Ferri stalked like a matador to kiss-kiss the model Toukie Smith, who came clattering down the hall in a bright red dress, her trademark gold hoop earrings flying. Ms. Smith was getting ready to be hostess of a benefit at the studio. "Fabrizio, baby!," she cried, disappearing into his chest.
"I like to say that I started the chair collection because I'd broken too many myself," Mr. Ferri said. "I hate the idea of a chair that's fragile. I broke one last week in our restaurant in Milano."
Sipping espresso, Mr. Ferri spoke captivatingly about Tantelleria, his retreat off the coast of Italy. He described the beauty of this volcanic island where the wind whips and burns everything in sight; where orange trees have walls built around them for protection; where palm trees grow with brave beauty out of the stony terrain; where Linda Evangelista, when she visits Mr. Ferri's home, washes the dishes every night and walks around barefoot.
It is in Tantelleria that Mr. Ferri is developing yet another concern. "I want to renovate some stone houses that look out to the sea," he said. "They have a biblical quality. I would like to restore them and share them with all my best friends."
Like any well-marketed status product, Industria offers an invitation to mythic exclusivity. The difference is that what's being pushed is, in a roundabout way, utter normalcy -- with a price tag. The world-weary photographers, models and stars who spun out the opulent fantasies of the 80's are now settling into the comfort afforded by all things solid and dependable. At least that's the idea.
"I always say that the only way to get out of a recession is to invest," said Mr. Ferri, finishing his espresso. "This recession has a good quality to it. Being Italian, it comes easy to me to say this, but it's like when you drain pasta? All the water goes down and the good pasta stays."
Spoken like a man who truly has his plate full.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrat;
Clinton Challenges Bush on Economy

BYLINE: GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, April 16

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, broadening his attacks on President Bush, called today for a new national economic strategy that emphasizes education, investment tax credits and converting military spending to domestic uses.
In a speech delivered at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania, Mr. Clinton offered a sweeping but essentially repackaged version of ideas he has offered for months. 
 But the plan, for college tuition assistance, retraining workers and renovating the nation's highways and bridges, was presented this time as a direct challenge to President Bush, who unveiled his own tuition assistance program today while also campaigning in the state. Pennsylvania holds its Presidential primary on April 28.
Mr. Clinton portrayed the nation's economic choices as a battle to stay competitive in a world economy where Japan and Germany are "beating our brains in" with smarter investment and growth decisions.
"In 1992, the very future of the American dream is at stake," he said. "Unless we decide we want a very different kind of President with a very different economic policy, unless we decide we are going to be more responsible citizens, responsible for our common problems, we're in for more trouble."
 
Focuses on Pell Grants
 Mr. Bush, he said, proposed a budget last year that would cut the Government's Pell education grants to families making more than $10,000 a year, "but just 12 days before the Pennsylvania primary, the President comes to Pennsylvania to promise universal access to college loans, a program that has been at the core of my Presidential campaign since the day I announced," he said. "Now, they say I'm slick?"
Saying the Presidential campaign should not be "just another shallow political quarrel between the establishment philosophies of Republicans and Democrats in Washington," Mr. Clinton nevertheless used his speech to get in several digs at the President's tuition assistance proposal.
"I looked at that today, and I thought the President had decided to celebrate the 500th anniversary of Columbus' discovery of America by discovering America himself," he said.
The details of Mr. Clinton's proposal include these elements:
*Full financing for Head Start, which would cost about $5 billion; creating a $1 billion-a-year apprenticeship program for high school graduates who are not college-bound, and creating an $8 billion-a-year tuition assistance "trust fund" that would allow students to borrow money for higher education and pay it back as a percentage of future income or by participating in a national service program. Mr. Clinton has said he would replace the current $14 billion student loan program.
*Creating $2 billion in investment tax credits for new businesses, making the research and development tax credit, which costs about $1 billion a year, permanent. Mr. Clinton would also support a new "enterprise tax cut" that would cost about $200 million a year.
*Setting up a "future budget" that would be designed to increase investment in areas like education and environmental technology, and to accelerate spending on highway and bridge construction and upkeep.
George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's deputy campaign manager, said most of the programs Mr. Clinton calls for would be financed by savings in military spending, a 3 percent across-the-board cut in administrative costs and an effort to restrain costs from rising faster than personal incomes.
Mr. Clinton said: "We spend a quarter of what our competitors do on training programs for our workers. Last year Germany and Japan had productivity growth rates several times ours because they educate their people better and they organize their economies to change better than we do."
"This is not a Democratic or Republican issue," he said. "It's America against the rest of the world."
Mr. Clinton also suggested creating a civilian research and development agency that would be financed by money taken out of savings accrued from cuts in military research and development.
The Governor said he would encourage early retirement and pro-rated pension benefits for people whose jobs are lost because of cuts in military spending, and help create a retraining fund for military scientists that would be administered by the National Science Foundation. He has also said he would support granting the President a line-item veto, a power to reject specific parts of budget legislation. Many governors have line-item veto power, but Congress has withheld that power from Presidents.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Governor Bill Clinton speaking yesterday at the Wharton School of Business of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. (Associated Press)
