HEADLINE: The Plight of Unlikely Altar Mates;
Passover-Easter Weekend Strains Space-Sharing Schedules

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN

 BODY:
During tough economic times, it is not just families and businesses that are doubling up in cramped quarters. Houses of worship are, too, and in sharing space, they are stepping across religious, denominational and linguistic barriers in new ways.
Korean Methodists are meeting in Presbyterian church basements. Lutherans are sharing space with Baptists. In a few cases, even churches and synagogues are doubling up under one roof. 
 These relationships, born of economic necessity, have often flowered in ecumenical and ethnic harmony. But that harmony could be tested by ecclesiastical gridlock this weekend, as people flock to church and synagogue for the religious equivalent of the political Super Tuesday: Easter-Passover Super Holiday Weekend.
Friday is both Good Friday and, in the evening, the first seder of Passover. For most Christians, this weekend culminates on Sunday with Easter, the central event of Christian faith; the Jewish festival continues for another week with family gatherings and prayer services.
One church that will be feeling the holiday crunch is St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., which is home to both the Episcopal congregation and to the Greenwich Reform Synagogue. Balancing the needs of the two congregations is usually easy: the Jews meet on Friday nights and the Christians on Sundays.
 
Quick Change
 When the synagogue meets, a church employee hangs cloth banners with Jewish themes like the menorah or the Star of David over the stained glass windows that depict the life of Jesus from birth to the resurrection. The banners are translucent to let in the light, although sometimes an image of Baby Jesus shines through a Jewish symbol as well.
An ark containing the Torah scrolls is placed before the marble altar where the Christians normally consecrate bread and wine. The American flag remains on the pulpit but the Episcopal Church flag is replaced with the flag of Israel.
"It's like an interfaith marriage," Rabbi Robert B. Lennick of the Greenwich synagogue said of the relationship. "We are always very conscious of each other's boundaries."
This holiday weekend, the Jews decided to yield. Since the main Passover observance is the seder -- the ceremonial meal held in the home that commemorates the Exodus, the Israelites' flight from Egypt -- the Jewish congregation decided not to hold services in the church on Friday night, but is encouraging members to gather with family at home.
In Manhattan, where Congregation B'nai Jeshurun shares space with St. Paul and St. Andrew United Methodist Church, rabbi and pastor argued over who should get the sanctuary. Both insisted that the other take it.
For nearly a year, the Jewish congregation, which is Conservative, has been a guest of the church at 86th Street and West End Avenue. But it refused to impose on the church's holy weekend, so it will hold services elsewhere this week.
While some Jewish congregations have canceled or moved their services, the different Christian groups that share space all want to be in church this weekend. "Everyone likes to worship in the best place in the house, which is our sanctuary," said the Rev. Austin H. Armitstead, the senior pastor of Community United Methodist Church of Jackson Heights, in Queens.
Four Methodist congregations worship in his church each Sunday, each in a different language -- English, Chinese, Spanish and Korean.
The four congregations used to meet in different locations in the sprawling 72-year-old building at 81-10 35th Avenue. But this year the pastor decided to give them all the sanctuary on Sunday, albeit at different times. The English-speaking congregation gets the space at the most popular hour, 10:30 A.M.
The congregational choreography will have to be especially precise this weekend. The number of churchgoers is expected to swell with out-of-town visitors and others who are moved to attend church on Easter even if they do not go the rest of the year.
While no one keeps a precise count, church officials agree that more congregations have been doubling and tripling up since the recession began.
The Rev. Patricia Reeberg, executive director of the Council of Churches of the City of New York, said that renting space in an established church has traditionally been a way for new churches to form. "They may start off as a Bible class or a home church and then expand from there, moving into the basement of another church until they can build their own edifice," she said.
But with the recession, she said, many small churches "are stuck" and cannot move to the next step of acquiring their own building.
While the poor economy has contributed to church overcrowding, the phenomenon apparently is a result of the same number of people going to fewer churches, rather than more people going. The recession has not driven more people to church, according to a recent study by the Princeton Religion Research Center, an affiliate of the Gallup Poll.
The Rev. Spencer Gibbs, general presbyter of the Presbytery of New York City, said doubling up can benefit not only the emerging church but the host as well. Many of the host churches are saddled with large heating and maintenance bills that the guests can help defray. "It's become mutually advantageous," he said.
In Greenwich, sharing has been mutually advantageous for another reason -- both sides have learned. The Rev. Canon Samir J. Habiby, a Palestinian who is the interim rector of St. Paul's Episcopal, said that the affiliation with the Greenwich synagogue "has enabled us to get back to our Old Testament roots."
Rabbi Lennick said that his congregation has a new appreciation for Jesus. "The Christ character has been villainized for so long in Judaism," he said. "We've developed a new understanding of Jesus as a Jew."
The Jewish congregation has rented space from the church for 11 years. But now it has raised the money to purchase its own space and hopes to move later this year.
It recently bought a Catholic school building, itself a victim of the economy when it was closed by the local Catholic diocese, the Diocese of Bridgeport. But the diocese kept open the neighboring church, and so the new synagogue will be next to -- and share a parking lot with -- St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church.
"The ecumenism continues," said Rabbi Lennick.

GRAPHIC: Photo: St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., is home to both the Episcopal congregation and to the Greenwich Reform Synagogue. Rabbi Robert B. Lennick, left, helped the Rev. Canon Samir J. Habiby to hang a banner over the church's stained glass window. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW RULES FOR PILOTS
Breaking sharply with a policy that gives broad discretion to pilots, the Federal Aviation Administration intends to establish rules on when pilots can take off in snowy and icy weather. The rules come in reaction to the crash last month of a USAir jet at La Guardia Airport during a snowstorm. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
THE SOURCE OF THAT SMELL
After years of community outrage and scientific confusion, New York City officials have finally identified the central source of the debilitating odors at Harlem's North River sewage plant: They come from beneath an eight-block concrete roof where acres of foul air collect until periodic gusts roll off the Hudson River and blow them onto land. A1.
 
A PLAN TO ENCOURAGE GIVING
Mayor Dinkins endorsed a change in tax policy intended to encourage companies to increase their contributions to museums, parks, libraries and other cultural institutions by millions of dollars. The change would allow companies to take credits against commercial rent taxes for some charitable contributions. B3.
 
RESTORING SPENDING CUTS
The Dinkins administration said it had found a way to restore $600 million in proposed spending cuts for school reconstruction and $220 million in cuts for low-income housing. B3.
 
ASSAULT GUN LAW: MIXED RESULTS
On the eve of the deadline for residents to sell or relinquish their assault rifles or else move them from the city, almost two-thirds of the guns are still unaccounted for, whether out of their owners' ignorance, procrastination or defiance. B3.

INSURANCE RISE FOR NEW JERSEY
The State Insurance Commissioner approved an average 8 percent increase in health insurance premiums starting June 1 for nearly half a million individual subscribers of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey. B5.
 
A PROFILE OF NEW JERSEY
New Jerseyans on the whole got richer, better educated, more diverse and more mobile during the prosperous 1980's, according to an economic and demographic portrait released by the Census Bureau and by the state. Yet despite the widespread benefits of the boom, which has since passed, the decade also had its losers: the number of young children living in poverty almost doubled between 1980 and 1990. B5.
 
THE LAST, BEST HOPE
Six months ago, trustees of the University of Bridgeport rejected an offer of aid from an affiliate of the Unification Church, saying they feared damage to the university's reputation and holding out hope that other aid might materialize. When trustees reversed themselves on Wednesday and decided to pursue an affiliation with the church group, one factor had changed: there was no longer any hope of another rescuer. HEADLINE: All Strikers, Happy or Not, Can Go Back to Caterpillar

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., April 16

 BODY:
Saying it wanted to restore good employee relations in its plants, Caterpillar Inc. said explicitly today that it would rehire all of the workers who had been out on strike for five months and that most could be back to work Monday.
But the announcement seemed to do little to dispel the ill will many workers said they felt toward the company. 
 On Wednesday, one day after reaching agreement with the United Automobile Workers to end the strike and resume negotiations on a new contract, the big earth-mover company had indicated that it might not recall 10 or 15 percent of its workers because of production changes instituted since the strike began.
That hint only stirred the already deep distrust of the strikers. They had assumed they would all be recalled after their union's leaders accepted the company's terms for resuming work.
 
Replacements as Threat
 During the strike the company gained leverage over the union by saying that thousands of unemployed people could be given the Caterpillar jobs permanently, leaving the strikers on the street. In threatening to use these permanent replacement workers, the company sent a signal to other unionized companies that the tactic could work.
At a news conference at the corporate offices here, senior Caterpillar executives said the company had found that it needed 1,350 fewer union workers than the 12,600 who had struck the company. But they said they would shed those positions by offering voluntary early retirement and by attrition, rather than by layoffs.
"Because we want to rebuild good relations," said Gerald S. Flaherty, a group president, "we have invited back every striking hourly employee in good standing." He added that because of their conduct on the picket lines, some -- fewer than 10 -- would not be recalled.
"We recognize that this has been a difficult period for our U.A.W.-recognized employees and their families," he said.
Addressing what he said was one source of the workers' anger -- their expectation that they would start work on Wednesday, the morning after the union and the company agreed to halt the strike and negotiate a new contract -- Mr. Flaherty said it simply was not possible to have the plants ready so quickly. But he added, "We do think we will be able to build good working relations."
Another executive, Wayne M. Zimmerman, vice president for human services, said Caterpillar would continue testing 8,000 men and women whom the company recruited as possible replacement workers during the strike. He said the company would not hire them, but the clear implication was that it would do so in the event of another strike if the contract negotiations fell through.
There might be an element of ruse to these threats. In the waning hours of the strike the company said it was inundated with phone calls from job-seekers living in this recession-depressed state and elsewhere. It referred the applicants to a vast warehouse-like metal building for tests in simple arithmetic.
During a two-hour period on Wednesday, a reporter counted only 29 applicants entering the center, and only 3 with out-of-state license plates. One striker, who recorded the cars coming and going throughout the day, had counted only 80 by 4 P.M.
And it was unclear whether any applicants proved to have sufficient expertise to assume the skilled jobs of Caterpillar workers. But the possibility that these job-seekers would take their jobs frightened enough workers to call for a settlement.
 
Greater Animosity Now
 At Local 974 in East Peoria, close to several of the company's major factories, workers expressed relief that they would be back on the job but little gratitude toward the company. Man after man -- and just about all the hundreds milling around outside the union hall were men -- said he felt much greater animosity than after an even longer strike 10 years ago.
"My problem is, O.K., they won this round, and now they are like kicking you at the end of the round after the bell's ringing," said Ron Osborne, a 48-year-old pipefitter with 28 years at the company. "Eighty-two, I wasn't angry then. This time the company hasn't budged an inch."
Joe Martin, 45, a machine operator and 22-year employee, said: "They stripped us of our dignity and everything else. They played dirtier than they ever have."
Gary Romans, 43, a pipefitter with 24 years at Caterpillar, said: "Cat has done nothing but lie to us from Day 1. Now they're saying, 'Trust me.' "
These men, like most Caterpillar employees, are not far from the 30 years they need to retire with full pensions, and that is where many seem to have set their sights. Bob Ferguson, a toolmaker, rolled by in his van and yelled, "I'll be out in 1,068 days!"

HEADLINE: The House Bank: Trying to Halt a Scandal;
Speaker Declares House Bank Case Closed But Political Reality Promises to Intrude

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
On a day of little Congressional good cheer, the most upbeat thought came from the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, who said the disclosure of 247 current and 56 former members who wrote dubious checks "brings to a close this whole matter of the House bank."
In a formal way, perhaps. But not politically. 
 Indeed, the comment avoided political reality, just as much of Mr. Foley's handling of the highly charged issue. The Washington Democrat has avoided the very real threat to the re-elections of those touched by the scandal since the bank's mismanagement was brought to his attention in late 1989.
Today, for instance, though Republicans were about as likely to make the overdraft list as were Democrats, their party's campaigners had a new television spot ready to hand out as soon as the list was released. Its theme was bouncing balls, bouncing checks and "Bounce the Democrats."
This issue seems to have a resonance that extends far beyond its inherent facts.
Mr. Foley repeated again and again that no taxpayers' money was involved. He said those who wrote overdrafts were "following a practice of long standing." And he told a news conference that the press had made the situation worse by mistakenly calling the checks "bounced" or "kited" when in fact they were usually paid, whether there was money in the account or not.
 
Missing From 'Abusers' List
 But as a political reality, details like that pale before the 841 overdrafts in 39 months written by Representative Ronald V. Dellums of California, or the 697 by Representative Gerry Sikorski of Minnesota, or the 551 by Representative Louis Stokes of Ohio, the chairman of the House ethics committee, or the 547 by Representative Dennis M. Hertel of Michigan, or the 515 by Representative Chalmers P. Wylie of Ohio. Only Mr. Wylie is a Republican.
None of the five lawmakers were included on a list of the 22 "abusers" that was made public April 1. So those totals served as reminders that when the House ethics committee compiled the list last month, its standards were, to say the least, arbitrary. And that comes right back to the political problem that underlies excitement over the bank, the idea that Congress lives in a different world and speaks a different language from everybody else.
 
House Speaker's Hope
 Mr. Foley's hope is that the Democrats, with this issue "closed," and a House administrative reform plan passed last week, can now begin "concentrating fully on the public agenda." When Congress returns the week after next, he said, the House will be "taking up unemployment compensation, energy, I hope the beginning of some health care legislation, and perhaps job legislation."
But even if the bank scandal recedes into the background, at least in Washington, there are two crucial difficulties facing the Democrats.
The first is themselves. Democrats can probably agree on unemployment legislation fairly quickly, and are happy to fight the Bush Administration's insistence that the time is not ripe for fundamental repairs of the system.
But the energy bill involves conflicting committee jurisdictions. Jobs legislation involves major budget problems. And on health care, while Democrats of all stripes consistently report that it deeply troubles their constituents, there is nothing approaching consensus on how to deal with it, and the leadership seems to have done little to press for agreement.
 
Republicans' Strategy
 So it is not clear that the Democrats, on their own, can change the subject.
And they will not be on their own. The second problem they face is the House Republicans. The Republicans are not here to legislate, in the sense of working out differences and making compromises. But when the Democrats bring a bill to the vote, they will have alternatives, to make a point of contrast.
Indeed, they will soon begin a series of news conferences to lay out the equivalent of a House Republican "platform" for challengers to use when they tire of talking about the bank.
And then it is expected that the Republicans will change the subject to the House post office, whose scandals developed without any Republican role at all, and will try to make an issue of excessive Congressional staffing. By excessive, they mean Democrats do not give Republicans a sufficient share of committee jobs.
None of these Republican approaches may be as politically damaging as the bank scandal. But they will all offer distractions from the legislative agenda on which Mr. Foley would rather be concentrating.
 
Misperceptions of Public
 In his news conference today, Mr. Foley also seemed to hope that once the public better understood the details of the bank, the problem would lose political steam. But a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll suggests that is not a good enough prospect on which to bet, say, an election.
Forty-seven percent of the public said, incorrectly, that taxpayers' money was used to make good the overdrafts. Only 25 percent knew that other members' deposits were used. But those two groups did not differ greatly on approval of Congress in general or of their own representative, or on several other questions about Congress.
But there was some hope that education would matter in the long run. A third of the group that thought taxpayers' money was used also said that writing overdrafts, by itself, would be enough to make them vote for someone other than their sitting representative. That figure was cut in half for those who knew that other members' deposits covered the checks.
That is one truth most members will want to tell.
But Republicans, even though 88, or 33 percent of the current members, on the two lists are from their party (compared with 39 percent of the House as a whole), will be pushing other themes. Along with the National Republican Congressional Committee's "bounce" ads, they will offer messages like the one Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, their second-ranking leader, offered today while apologizing for 22 overdrafts.
He made a point of saying he was still proud of pressing for disclosure of all the names of lawmakers, when Democratic leaders had preferred a smaller number. And he boasted that at least none of his overdrafts had gone for business investments or politics.
And considering the pain that so many of his constituents had felt only Wednesday, perhaps he was just being kind when he neglected to put in his statement the fact that his biggest overdraft, for $9,463, was written at this season in 1990 -- to the Internal Revenue Service.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Got Richer In the 1980's

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
Like that of its neighboring states, New Jersey's population got richer, better educated, more diverse and more mobile during the prosperous 1980's, according to an economic and demographic portrait of the state released by the Census Bureau and by the state yesterday.
Yet despite the widespread benefits of the boom, which has since given way to recession, the decade also had its losers: the number of young children living in poverty almost doubled between 1980 and 1990, the years for which the Census Bureau reported. 
 "These figures confirm what a lot of people know about the 80's, that it was a real growth decade for the state, but that not everybody benefited," said Connie O. Hughes, an assistant director in the state Department of Labor for occupational and demographic research. Ms. Hughes's office published a comparison of the Census Bureau's 1980 and 1990 figures.
Ms. Hughes noted that in 1990 the state's rate of economic growth had started to slide. The Census Bureau's figures therefore describe not the New Jersey of today but the state's economic progress in the last decade.
 
Income Rises
 The result is a mostly cheerful snapshot of New Jersey's economic and demographic transit through the 80's, during which the state's population grew by 5 percent, to 7.7 million. Yet the picture also contains some dark corners. Some of the findings were these:
*Household income during the decade rose 23.3 percent in constant dollars, to $41,000, the second highest in the nation. In New York State, the comparable figure is $33,000, and Connecticut leads the nation with a household income of $42,000.
*The number of households where a language other than English is spoken at home increased by 28 percent, while the number of Spanish-speakers who say they do not speak English "very well" doubled.
*And while the fastest growing car-ownership category was households owning three or more automobiles and the number of households without telephones nearly vanished, the number of families with children 5 or younger living in poverty rose from 23,000 to 45,000 during the decade. The next largest category of poverty-level New Jerseyans was unrelated adults living together.
The figures are derived from questionnaires mailed to one New Jersey household in six by the Census Bureau. They are thus samples rather than actual counts.
While New Jerseyans went to work in large numbers during the decade -- the labor force grew by more than half a million -- they also went to school. The number of New Jerseyans with less than ninth-grade educations declined by 311,000, or 40 percent, while the proportion with high school diplomas rose from 67 percent in 1980 to 77 percent in 1990.
They came to New Jersey in greater numbers from outside the country: more than half of the state's population growth of 365,000 during the decade represented immigrants from other countries, more than half of whom in turn arrived in the United States during the last decade.
Although the immigrants are not separated by nationality in the Census data, Spanish speakers clearly accounted for most of them: the number of New Jerseyans who speak Spanish at home rose by 200,000, nearly 9 percent of the population.
Being better off, New Jerseyan's also grew wasteful when it came to getting to work during the decade: 71 percent drove to work alone in 1990, compared with 64 percent in 1980. The increase came from those who gave up shared or pooled rides, who dropped from 18 to 12 percent of all commuters.
New Jerseyans increasingly worked in offices and stores during the decade. The largest increase in employment was for technical and support workers, followed by administrators and sales personnel. The largest employment declines, 28 percent, were for machine operators and assemblers, while the second largest percentage decline may be reflective of the availability of jobs elsewhere: the number of people employed as household servants dropped by nearly a quarter.
 
More Landscapers
 Meanwhile, one of the strongest areas of job growth was agriculture, forestry and fisheries, where employment grew by 64 percent. Part of the increase resulted from the growth of the suburbs, not farms, however, since landscapers, lawn-care operators and tree surgeons are included in the group.
For its poverty data, the state Labor Department compared 1979 and 1989 figures, and they show progress in escaping poverty across a broad front except among households with young children.
The number of households receiving welfare payments declined over the period, from 190,000 to 150,000, a decrease of more than 16 percent. The number of New Jerseyans living below the poverty line also decreased, from 690,000, or 9.5 percent of the population, to 570,000, or 7.6 percent of the population. The number of households with children younger than 18 that were in poverty also dropped by a quarter, to 88,000.
But for households with children younger than 5, the number nearly doubled, to 45,000, amounting to more than 10 percent of all such families.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Aides Plan to Restore Housing and School Funds

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration said yesterday that it has found a way to restore $600 million in proposed spending cuts for school reconstruction and $220 million in cuts for low-income housing without increasing the city's overall cost of borrowing to finance those projects.
The restored financing will allow the city to build 10 new schools and fix 36 schools in disrepair, thus helping to alleviate overcrowding, the city's School Construction Authority said. The housing money will allow the city to build at least 6,000 apartments for poor families each year for the next four years. 
 The school projects were scheduled to be delayed for several years under the Mayor's plan to cut $729 million from the city's capital budget that goes to education over the next four years.
 
Fears for the Economy
 When the Dinkins administration announced deep cuts in the capital budget in January, city officials said that they would look for ways to restore some of the cuts. But their search apparently did not yield results before construction groups, bond dealers and some fiscal monitors voiced concerns that the cuts would hurt the economy.
Mayor David N. Dinkins revealed his plan to restore the spending at a meeting with reporters yesterday, after he was asked what he thought of a similar plan from City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman that would achieve essentially the same results.
Aides to Mr. Dinkins said the city plans to use its state allocation for school maintenance to finance the debt owed on the city bonds that would pay for the $600 million in education capital spending. City officials said that the state money had long been used for general education spending, rather than specific maintence expenses. It was unclear yesterday which education accounts might suffer if the state money is dedicated to capital spending.
Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, who had called on the Mayor to restore capital budget cuts to education, said: "I am delighted that they are restoring a significant portion of the school construction budget. It is desperately needed to improve the quality of life in New York City."
 
Debt Payments Are a Concern
 City budget officials have been meeting this week to devise a plan to reinstate much of the $3.7 billion in capital-spending cuts that Mayor Dinkins announced in January but at the same time curtail rising debt payments on long-term bonds that are used to finance the four-year capital budget. Those debt payments are a major concern of bond raters, who have threatened to lower the city's rating this year, thus increasing its cost of borrowing.
The officials are considering several ways to reduce the cost of construction, including reconfiguring timetables for building and financing projects, taking advantage of low construction costs and applying for new Federal and state matching funds.
James Vlasto, a spokesman for Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, said that while Mr. Fernandez has not yet seen the details of the administration's plan, "it appears that the restoration will allow us to proceed with many of the projects that have been put on hold for future years, and that's good indeed."
Concerning the housing money, aides to the Mayor said that the city plans to restore $220 million of a proposed $500 million cut during the next four years. Kathryn Wylde, president of the nonprofit New York City Housing Partnership, said the restored money would help to ease the pain of thousands of New York families who are in desperate need of housing.

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

Authenticity Challenged
In November, at Sotheby's sale of Impressionist and modern paintings in New York, 17 works with an estimated total value in excess of $14.5 million by such renowned artists as Cezanne, Sisley, Pissarro and Monet were being sold by Arnold Gumowitz, a New York developer. High reserves -- the price below which the consigner will not sell a work -- prevented all but five of these paintings from finding buyers. 
 But one painting in Mr. Gumowitz's collection never found its way to the auction block. It was "Peasant Laboring," from 1882-83 and attributed to Seurat. Mr. Gumowitz had bought the 6 1/4-by-9 7/8-inch oil painting of a peasant working in the fields in 1987 for $600,000 from Wildenstein's New York gallery. Since then, Mr. Gumowitz said, Gary Tinterow, a curator of 19th-century paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and other art experts whom he declines to identify have questioned the painting's authenticity. "It is clear that the authenticity of the painting has been put at issue," said Rodney Brown, Mr. Gumowitz's lawyer.
This week, Mr. Gumowitz filed suit in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, citing Mr. Tinterow; the Metropolitan Museum itself; Wildenstein & Company and its owner, Alec Wildenstein; the art historian John Rewald, and the New York art dealer Stephen Mazoh. The suit, among other things, charges fraud, deceptive trade practices and breach of contract during the purchase and sale of a painting. The developer is asking for damages in excess of $1 million.
According to court papers, at the time Mr. Gumowitz bought the painting from Wildenstein, Mr. Rewald independently authenticated the work. Mr. Gumowitz now says Mr. Rewald had been engaged by Wildenstein and had received a commission from the gallery. Mr. Rewald is ill and could not be reached for comment. Wildenstein's lawyer, Richard Bernstein, said through his secretary that he would not comment on pending litigation.
In May 1991, when Mr. Gumowitz was showing his collection to auction house experts and art dealers to explore the possibility of selling many of his holdings, he agreed to sell the Seurat to Mr. Mazoh for $800,000. The next day, Mr. Mazoh changed his mind. "No, I didn't find out the painting was a fake," Mr. Mazoh said in a recent telephone interview. "I chose not to pursue the picture because its publication history was inadequate. There just wasn't sufficient critical support to satisfy my requirements."
Mr. Mazoh's lawyer, Matthew C. Kesten, said there had never been any written agreement signed by either Mr. Mazoh or a representative of his corporation. "A number of allegations in this suit simply are not true," Mr. Kesten said.
Mr. Gumowitz said he believed that Mr. Tinterow had told Mr. Mazoh the painting had not been included in the Met's Seurat exhibition last fall because it was not authentic. "Now Wildenstein refuses to take it back," Mr. Gumowitz said. "I don't understand why. I have been a good customer. Over the years, I bought three paintings in excess of a couple of million dollars. The Seurat was my first purchase."
Mr. Tinterow said: "Every allegation regarding myself and the Met is untrue and will be denied. We consider this a nonsensical case that will quickly be dismissed." Mr. Tinterow also said he refused to comment on the authenticity of the work.
Meanwhile, Mr. Gumowitz says his Seurat is tainted. "Once you've got problems like this," he said, "a painting is impossible to sell."
 
Infighting at Barnes
 More battles at the Barnes Foundation. On Wednesday, the trustees filed a petition at the Montgomery County Orphans' Court in Pennsylvania, charging that more than $8 million used to set up the Violette de Mazia Trust, which supports art education at the foundation, based in Merion, Pa., may have come from the sale of paintings that never legally belonged to Miss de Mazia, but to the Barnes. Miss de Mazia, who died in 1988, was the former education director of the foundation and an intimate of its founder, Dr. Albert C. Barnes.
"This is a colossal red herring," said Gordon Elkins, the De Mazia Trust's lawyer. The De Mazia Trust had previously acted to block plans by the board to sell some works to pay for modernization of the Barnes building, and also sought the trustees' ouster. The De Mazia Trust also argued that a conflict of interest might be involved in the board's award of a contract to Alfred A. Knopf for publication of color photographs of the Barnes collection, since S. I. Newhouse, Knopf's owner, had made a $2 million contribution to Lincoln University. (Three out of five trustees of the the Barnes Foundation are also on the board of Lincoln, a small, historically black college 45 miles west of Merion.) "We have been trying to obtain a specific statement from Barnes about what paintings they are talking about and they refuse to give it to us," Mr. Elkins added.
According to an affidavit by Nicholas King, a former superintendent of the Barnes Collection, a painting sold by Miss de Mazia's estate for $450,000, Thomas Hart Benton's "Beach," never belonged to her. "There is evidence that many other paintings which at one time were in the Barnes's inventory were sold at Christie's in 1989 in the de Mazia estate sale," said Bruce Kaufman, a lawyer for the Barnes Foundation. "Dr. Barnes kept fairly detailed records."
A court date has been set for May 8 to hear the allegations.
 
Museums That Grow
 While museums like the Whitney, Detroit and Brooklyn have put on hold plans for expansion at least until the economy picks up, there continues to be a lot of new construction.
Last month, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago unveiled its plan for a $55 million building designed by a German architect, Josef Paul Kleihues. A week and a half later, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art broke ground on its new $85 million building designed by a Swiss architect, Mario Botta.
Now, after a two-year search, the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston announced that a Spanish architect, Rafael Moneo, has been chosen to design a $50 million complex to be built on two museum-owned parcels that are east of the institution's main building. "I would love to break ground in mid-1995 and open in 1999," said the museum's director, Peter Marzio.
Mr. Marzio said the museum had begun its search for an architect with a list of 30 names. After reviewing and visiting the architects' work, it reduced the number of candidates to 10 and finally to 4. The finalists, besides Mr. Moneo, were Robert Venturi of Philadelphia, Tadao Ando of Tokyo and Norman Foster of London.
"Our reasons for picking Rafael were many," Mr. Marzio said. "His ability to handle natural light was extremely sophisticated. His work also had a wonderful balance between classical sensibilities and modern life. He was able to handle a wide range of materials and showed a tremendous understanding of the history of art."
Mr. Moneo, who from 1985 to 1990 was the chairman of the architecture department of the Harvard University Graduate School of Design, has designed the National Museum of Roman Art in Merida, and the Miro Museum and Gardens in Palma de Mallorca, both in Spain. He is completing designs for the Thyssen-Bornemisza Collection Museum in Madrid and has been commissioned to design the Museum of Modern Art in Stockholm and the Davis Art Museum at Wellesley College in Massachusetts.
The Houston museum has been involved in an extensive expansion plan since the sculptor Isamu Noguchi designed its Cullen Sculpture Garden in 1986. Two other additions, Cullinan Hall and the Brown Pavilion, completed in 1958 and 1974, were designed by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe. "Being able to build next to Mies," Mr. Marzio said. "That's the real challenge."
 
Canaletto to Composer
 Christie's salesroom in London was all abuzz on Wednesday when Canaletto's "Old Horse Guards, London, From St. James's Park" sold for $17.7 million to Andrew Lloyd Webber, the 44-year-old composer. The price set a record for the artist (the previous auction record was set three years ago when "The Thames From Westminster" sold for $2.1 million in London). It also exceeded the $13.4 million paid for Titian's "Venus and Adonis" at Christie's in London in December, which was the highest price paid for a painting on either side of the Atlantic in 1991.
"Horse Guards" had been purchased by the Earl of Radnor from Canaletto's studio and was bequeathed at his death in 1757 to James Harris, a member of the House of Commons. The picture was being sold by the Harris family. The Tate Gallery in London "had expressed an interest in the painting," said Noel Annesley, the deputy chairman of Christie's International, "but they only offered $8.5 million."

HEADLINE: Review/Film;
New Scenes From a Mall, With Music

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY

 BODY:
In "Window Shopping," Chantal Akerman's Belgian-French co-production opening today at Le Cinematographe in Manhattan, the world is a place where the sun doesn't shine though it's always fair weather. The locale is a piece of late 20th-century environmental art, an underground shopping mall in which the air is conditioned, the temperature controlled by thermostat, and the lighting fluorescent with zingy neon accents.
Anyone familiar with the Belgian-born director's earlier films, including the chilly, severe "Jeanne Dielman" (1975) and "All Night Long" (1982), might expect "Window Shopping" to be some kind of indictment of consumer society. It may be, in its own devious way, but "Window Shopping" is more interested in the tiny problems that loom so large in the lives of the people within that society. 
 As if that weren't already uncharacteristic of the Akerman mode, "Window Shopping" is also a musical that recalls Jacques Demy's considerably more grandiose "Umbrellas of Cherbourg" and "Young Girls of Rochefort." Although the characters do not sing their dialogue, as in the Demy films, they don't hesitate to express themselves in song when the mood hits them.
The result is an unpretentious, absolutely charming romantic comedy-with-music, the small scale of which perfectly suits the passions of its characters.
Among these are Jeanne (Delphine Seyrig) who, with her husband, Monsieur Schwartz (Charles Denner), and son, Robert (Nicolas Trunc), runs a men's boutique; Lili (Fanny Cottencon), a femme fatale and the proprietor of a beauty salon, and Mado (Lio), a lovely innocent who works in the beauty salon and yearns for Robert, who yearns for the older, more worldly Lili.
John Berry, the American director ("He Ran All the Way," "Claudine"), who is a longtime resident of France, plays Eli, an American businessman who becomes the story's catalyst. One day, Eli wanders into the mall looking for a shave and finds Jeanne, the woman he loved 30 years before when he was a soldier stationed in France.
"Window Shopping" was made in 1986 and looks it. Beginning with the opening credits, presented against a montage of the well-shod feet of women purposefully crisscrossing the mall's marble floor, the film is as determinedly stylish as all those magazines that came out in the mid-80's designed for up-market readers.
Seen today, in the midst of a recession, "Window Shopping" appears to be both an artifact of a bygone era and possibly something of an omen. That may not have been Miss Akerman's intention. Yet, like any work of substance, "Window Shopping" seems somehow prescient. It is so naturally accurate that the slow bust that followed the 80's boom now seems to be its subtext.
This is not to overload the movie with solemn import, only to suggest that although the movie is a fairy tale, it is not necessarily out of touch.
The two parallel love triangles, involving Lili, Robert and Mado and Jeanne, Eli and Monsieur Schwartz, are worked out in a lightly satiric fashion that is enriched by Marc Herouet's romantic and comic score and Miss Akerman's lyrics, which are translated with a good deal of unexpected wit by English subtitles.
How great it is to see Seyrig looking so beautiful, so intelligent and so amused, although "Window Shopping" was one of the last films she made before her death last year. This great actress, whose first two films were Robert Frank's "Pull My Daisy" and Alain Resnais's "Last Year in Marienbad," was as much at ease in avant-garde films, including those of Miss Akerman and Marguerite Duras, as she was in Francois Truffaut's and Luis Bunuel's.
Another standout in "Window Shopping" is Miss Cottencon who, although she has made a number of films in France, will probably be new to American audiences. She's a pretty, slightly brassy comic presence as the scheming beautician who loses her heart to a man all wrong for her, at least financially.
At the end of the film, Seyrig's Jeanne comes up out of the mall into the light of the real day. The sun appears incredibly bright and warm. Until that moment, the real world has been forgotten, which is possibly just what Miss Akerman intended. "Window Shopping" is both sweet and a little spooky.
 
Window Shopping
Directed by Chantal Akerman; screenplay by Ms. Akerman, Jean Gruault, Leora Barish, Henry Bean and Pascal Bonitzer (in French with English subtitles); directors of photography, Gilberto Azevedo and Luc Benhamou; edited by Francine Sandberg; music by Marc Herouet; production designer, Serge Marzolff; produced by Martine Marignac; released by World Artists. At Le Cinematographe, 15 Vandam Street, Manhattan. Running time: 96 minutes. This film has no rating.

The Economy
The U.S. merchandise trade deficit narrowed sharply to $3.38 billion in February, with exports reaching a record and imports falling slightly. The deficit, smaller than most economists expected, gladdened Administration officials. [Page D1.]

HEADLINE: Dow Up 12.74, Closing at Another Record

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON Jr.

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks edged higher yesterday in jagged trading, as sporadic selling cooled the week's rally. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 12.74 points, to 3,366.50, a third consecutive closing record, but other indicators dipped.
The Dow, which weathered two selloffs in the morning and another in the afternoon, was lifted nearly 15 points in the session's final minutes, apparently by index arbitragers who adjusted their positions in expiring futures and options contracts. 
 The Dow has now gained 185 points, or 5.7 percent, in the five sessions since the rally began a week ago.
 
Improving Economic News
 "News on the economic front seems to get better every day," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment strategist for the First Albany Corporation, explaining the market's resilience. "Claims for unemployment were down, and news about the trade deficit gave us a pleasant surprise."
Trading was active yesterday, with 233.2 million shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange, up from 229.7 million on Wednesday. Losing issues led gaining ones by 898 to 805.
The Standard & Poor's Index of 500 stocks was off 0.23 point, to 416.05. Smaller stocks performed worse, as the Nasdaq composite index fell 8.22 points, to 591.81, and the American Exchange composite dropped 1.52 points, to 392.64.
The stock and other financial markets will be closed today for the Good Friday holiday.
The expiration of April futures and options contracts provided some of yesterday's extra action. Arbitragers who took advantage of the abnormally low price of index futures when the Dow fell sharply last week -- buying the futures and selling stock short as a hedge -- bought back that stock at yesterday's close to lock in a profit on the overall transaction.
"You had a sudden torrent of orders," said Harrison Roth, senior options strategist at Cowen & Company. "And it drove stock prices up artificially."
Mr. Johnson said, "Even though things are looking good, prices are very high." The Big Board's most active stock yesterday was General Motors, which rose 2 3/8, to 42 1/4, as analysts predicted that the auto giant, coming off its biggest yearly loss in history in 1991, might report a quarterly gain in earnings soon.
Triton Energy rose 4 3/8, to 33, apparently on the strength of an upbeat analyst's report. Alcoa rose 2, to 76 5/8, extending a climb that began after Monday's report of favorable earnings. TRW rose 3 3/8, to 54 1/8, after announcing quarterly earnings that rose 16 percent.
Several drug and medical-equipment companies faltered yesterday. U.S. Surgical dropped 5 1/8, to 109 7/8, despite reporting an 84 percent increase in quarterly earnings. The stock, with a price/earnings ratio of 72, has raised unusually high expectations among investors.
Pfizer dropped 3 3/8, to 69 3/4, after reporting a 10 percent climb in earnings, while Critical Care America fell 4, to 45 1/2. Merck fell 2 3/8, to 148 7/8, after reporting slower earnings growth on Wednesday.
Baldor Electric, a maker of industrial motors, rose 1 5/8, to 25 3/4, after reporting 7 percent growth in quarterly earnings. Synergen fell 3, to 35 1/2.

HEADLINE: A.T.& T. Signs Pact With Hanoi

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, April 16

 BODY:
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company signed an agreement with Vietnam today on reopening telecommunication links that have been severed since the end of the Vietnam War.
The memorandum, signed by Vietnam's state telecommunications company, paves the way for the first link since the South Vietnamese Government fell to Communist forces from the North in 1975. 
 "I believe that it is a major step forward for the two countries for the role that telecommunications will play in further improving relationships between our two countries and enabling citizens to speak to one another again," said James Hansen, A.T.& T.'s managing director for Southeast Asia.
Washington cut relations with Hanoi and imposed economic sanctions in 1964. It extended the measures to a reunified Vietnam in 1975. But in October, the United States said it was ready to move toward lifting the embargo and resuming diplomatic ties with Hanoi. It said Monday that it would modify the embargo to allow A.T.& T. to re-establish telecommunications links.

HEADLINE: Ontario Joins Beer Dispute Between U.S. and Canada

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, April 16

 BODY:
Further escalating Canadian-American trade tensions, the Ontario government agency that monopolizes the sale of beer in Canada's most populous province announced a ban Wednesday night on American beer imports.
The surprise action, which was made without prior knowledge or approval of the federal authorities in Ottawa, came in response to an American threat to impose duties of up to $8 a case on beer imported from Canada, effective April 13. 
 The move by the Liquor Control Board of Ontario, which came as trade negotiators for both countries are locked in talks in Ottawa to try to resolve the dispute, affects about $70 million worth of beer sold in Ontario annually by such companies as Stroh and Heileman. Other leading brewers, like Miller Brewing, Anheuser-Busch and Coors, are not affected to a great extent because they have licensing arrangements allowing Canadian brewers to produce and sell their beers.
That sum, rung up in 625 provincial retail outlets, represents 3 percent of beer sales in the province and is about one-third of total American beer sales in Canada.
 
Moved Called Unhelpful
 While the Office of the United States Trade Representative had no official comment, some American officials speaking privately called the move unhelpful.
On the Canadian side, Marthe St. Louis, an aide in the federal trade department, said it was purely a business decision by the Ontario board, seeking to protect its commercial interests.
Privately, however, some Ottawa officials were described as miffed at Ontario's intrusion into a difficult trade conflict with the United States, but the International Trade Department of the Ministry of External Affairs stressed that Ontario was well within its jurisdiction. The Progressive Conservative Party controls the national Government, while the socialist-leaning New Democratic Party is in power in Ontario.
American brewers reacted strongly. Christopher T. Sortwell, senior vice president of the Stroh Brewery Company of Detroit, labeled it "an absurd action by an apparently panicked Canadian brewing industry."
The Canadian provinces took over beer and liquor retailing in the late 1920's, a decision that was made at the time Americans had Prohibition.
The roots of the trade dispute go to an American complaint against restrictive pricing and distribution practices that the provinces now use to protect markets and jobs for the Canadian industry.
 
Washington Wins a Ruling
 Nearly four years ago, the United States brought its complaint to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which ruled late last year in Washington's favor, citing techniques used to keep out foreign beer, including administrative charges, distribution levies, high retail markups and outright prohibitions.
Canada now says it is willing to get rid of its restrictions within three years, but Washington has threatened retaliation if the Canadians do not open the market by July 1.
The United States was set to impose duties on Canadian imports last Monday, but at the last minute, Ottawa made a peace offer that is now being negotiated in Ottawa. At the same time Ottawa warned that any American retaliation would be met by immediate and matching countermoves.
Chris Layton, a spokesman for the Ontario board, denied that the agency was seeking to become involved in trade policy. He said the action was taken because beer sales are very price sensitive. He said the board did not want to be left with a lot of beer it could not sell.
The beer fight is only one of a series erupting in recent months; others involve lumber, automobiles and carpets. Even as the two countries are talking with Mexico about expanding North American free trade, the bilateral tensions have increased, aggravated by a recession that has raised sensitivity about jobs on both sides of the border.

HEADLINE: Jobless-Pay Claims Drop

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
New claims for jobless benefits fell in the latest week to a five-month low, the Government said today in a report that suggested the economic recovery was inching forward.
The Labor Department said the number of Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits declined for the second straight week, falling 18,000, to 415,000, in the week that ended April 4. 
 Americans filed 433,000 claims during the previous week and 456,000 two weeks earlier.
The Bush Administration hailed the report as a sign that the trend of job losses was reversing.
"Today's report indicates that business activity is strengthening and layoffs are on the decline," Labor Secretary Lynn Martin said. Unemployment and the recession are top issues in the Presidential campaign.
The number of unemployment claims was the lowest since October, when 414,000 people sought benefits, the department said.
Economists had expected a moderate increase.
"We are probably staring at job growth in the economy," said Donald Ratajczak, director of economic forecasting at Georgia State University. "It is not vigorous, but at this point we are certainly adding jobs."
The four-week average fell to 437,750, from 442,000 and 448,750 in the previous two periods.

HEADLINE: BankAmerica Profit, Security Pacific Loss

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
On the eve of their merger, two California banking giants were a study in contrasts in the first quarter, with BankAmerica yesterday reporting a 7.4 percent profit gain, to $303 million, while Security Pacific said it lost $496.3 million.
Profits at the BankAmerica Corporation totaled $303 million, or $1.22 a share, up from $282 million, or $1.25 a share, a year earlier. Profit per share declined because the company has issued more than seven million shares of additional stock. 
 While BankAmerica has avoided the worst of the problems that have hurt other California banks as that state's economy weakened and real estate prices fell, the Security Pacific Corporation's holdings of bad loans have risen steadily since the merger was announced in August.
Nonperforming assets at BankAmerica, badly delinquent loans plus real estate acquired through foreclosure, fell to $2.95 billion from $3.11 billion a year ago and $3.08 billion at the end of the year. At Security Pacific, nonperforming assets increased to $3.45 billion from $2.32 billion a year ago and $2.75 billion at the end of the year.
But despite the problems at Security Pacific, BankAmerica officials say they are satisfied with the merger, and have not changed the agreement to issue 0.88 share of BankAmerica stock for each Security Pacific share.
 
Problems From Poor Loans
 Banking analysts say the rapid increase in loan problems at Security Pacific reflects the poor-quality loans made when the bank was independent, and an intensive effort by the companies to examine all Security Pacific's loans according to the standards used at BankAmerica.
If the loan losses had not been recognized by Security Pacific during the last few quarters, it would only have created a bigger problem when the merger was completed and BankAmerica set its own estimate on the value of all Security Pacific's loans.
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, BankAmerica's shares gained 87.5 cents, to $43.50, while Security Pacific's followed in lockstep, adding 75 cents, to $38.25.

HEADLINE: Citibank's Credit Card Rates To Be Cut for Best Customers

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Citibank, defending its position as the leading issuer of bank credit cards, said yesterday that it would reduce interest rates for nine million of its best card customers at the end of the month. The banking company is also planning other features, including a card that bears a photograph of its holder, to bolster its business.
The moves by Citibank, with more than 30 million credit card customers, come when competition is rising and interest rates are generally declining. That has led many other card issuers to reduce their interest rates, cut or eliminate annual fees and offer extra benefits. 
 Citibank said it would reduce its rates to 13.9 percent, from 15.8 percent, for some holders of its "preferred," or gold, Visa and Mastercards, and to 15.9 percent, from 19.8 percent, for some holders of its "classic" cards.
The new rates will be adjusted quarterly, at 7.4 percentage points above the prime rate for preferred cards and at 9.4 percentage points above prime for classic cards.
The lower rates will be assigned to customers with good payment records, and who are significant card users. Customers who use Citibank for other banking needs will also be favored. The lower rate will not apply to Choice cards, which already carry a 15.9 percent rate, or to holders of Advantage cards, which earn free travel on American Airlines as they are used. Eligibility for the lower rates will be reviewed quarterly.
Susan Weeks, a Citibank spokeswoman, said the photo cards "have been immensely popular in the New York test because they help guard against use of stolen cards, and they are another form of I.D." The company also plans to issue photo cards to customers in parts of the country with no Citibank branches, she said, but declined to provide details.
Although many banks already charge lower interest rates than the new ones set by Citibank, analysts said the company's prominence in the crowded credit card business would heighten the pressure on other banks to lower their rates.
Earlier this year, the American Express Company lowered interest rates for holders of its Optima card. Late last year, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, whose Universal card has been one of the fastest growing in the industry, reduced interest rates sooner than required by its floating-rate formula.
"Over the next three months, there will probably be a dozen different banks announcing lower rates for some customers," said David Robertson, the president of The Nilson Report, an industry newsletter based in Santa Monica, Calif. "Their aim will be to keep their best customers and give them an incentive to use their card, rather than a competitor's."
 
Outstanding Balances Up
 Robert B. McKinley, the president of RAM Research, a company based in Frederick, Md., that monitors the card industry, noted that outstanding credit card balances grew by 28 percent last year at banks that offered lower interest rates, while the industry as a whole grew by only 7.9 percent. Citibank's customer base has not grown in the last year.
James Bailey, the head of Citibank's credit card business, said, "We decided to pass along some of our expense savings to protect the franchise."
Mr. Bailey said that customer feedback to Citibank's 3,000 telephone operators clearly pointed toward a need to reduce rates. "People called to say they were good customers, interest rates were down, and ask what we could do for them, and how we could be fair," he said.
He said the lower interest rates would not have any significant effect on the profits of Citibank's credit card business, because the rate cuts will be offset by increased use of the cards, as well as reduced attrition, and a lower cost of financing loans on cards that carry a floating rate rather than a fixed interest rate.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Overseas Sizzle for McDonald's

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
With its profits abroad growing nearly three times as fast as those at home, McDonald's is stepping up the pace of its expansion overseas.
Last year, for the first time, McDonald's opened more restaurants overseas than in the United States: 427 abroad, compared with just 188 in the United States. The company plans to open 450 in foreign countries and 250 in the United States this year, with Latin America and Asia expected to be the fastest-growing areas. 
 "We made the decision to push the international development a little harder," said James Cantalupo, president and chief executive of McDonald's International. "We will increase the pace each year."
Already, the top 10 McDonald's restaurants in sales and profits are on foreign soil. In just two years, more than half of McDonald's profits are expected to come from restaurants overseas.
The busiest McDonald's are in Moscow, on the Champs-Elysees in Paris and in central Rome. With far less competition abroad, the average McDonald's overseas does 25 percent more business than its counterpart in the United States.
McDonald's has had little choice but to look abroad in the face of slow growth at home. And although domestic sales could well pick up when the recession ends, McDonald's priorities for new outlets have clearly shifted abroad.
Next week, the company plans to open a store in central Beijing, on a main shopping street a few blocks from Tiananmen Square. "Eight hundred thousand people walk past our front door every day," Mr. Cantalupo said.
McDonald's recently opened its first stores in Czechoslovakia, Greece and Portugal. The first McDonald's will soon open in Poland and Brunei. At the end of 1991, McDonald's had 12,418 restaurants, with 8,764 in the United States and 3,654 abroad.
In another sign of the new emphasis, last week, McDonald's announced plans for its first unified global advertising campaign. The corporation will be a sponsor of the 1994 World Cup soccer playoffs, which will be held in the United States. While the company will continue to tailor most of its advertising to local markets, the World Cup sponsorship demonstrates the economies of scale that are benefiting McDonald's as its overseas presences grows.
It used to take up to 10 years for an overseas McDonald's to turn a profit. In fact, it often took years just to secure a prime location and find the right suppliers of meat and potatoes to even open a restaurant overseas. Having refined its systems so that some foreign outlets can turn a profit in just a year or two, the company is expanding more quickly into new regions.
With McDonald's in 60 countries, when it opens a new market, there is generally a country nearby that can help out with supplies and management talent. For instance, when it opened stores in Indonesia in 1990, it relied on a network of suppliers from Malaysia and Singapore. Indonesian operations turned a profit in its first year.
Although it seeks suburban sites in the United States, when moving into a new country McDonald's aggressively sets up shop in the main shopping area of the largest city. The prominent locations attract a great deal of attention.
"We forget that the average person in Indonesia probably never heard of McDonald's," said Jack Greenberg, the company's vice chairman and chief financial officer.
In focusing beyond United States borders, McDonald's is seeking to emulate the success of the purveyor of another American icon, the Coca-Cola Company. Coke now earns 80 percent of its profits outside the United States, with its fast-growing international markets making it a star performer on Wall Street. But McDonald's earnings and stock price have lagged of late, with slow growth at home the main ailment.
"McDonald's is similar to Coca-Cola 10 years ago," said Becky Barfield, an analyst with First Boston. "It's on the verge of becoming an international giant, with the United States as a major market, but overseas as the driving force."
Coke is in 185 countries.
 
Mostly in Six Countries
 Twenty-five years after McDonald's opened its first store outside the United States in the Canadian province of British Columbia, three-quarters of the company's foreign restaurants are in six countries: Japan, Canada, England, Germany, Australia and France.
When McDonald's moves into a new market, it generally maintains ownership of most of the restaurants. But as the company becomes better known in each country, it increases the number of franchises.
The operation in each country runs fairly autonomously, with its own managing director who is generally a native of the country. In fact, McDonald's has only 25 United States executives posted abroad. McDonald's hires local real estate experts to find the best sites and recruits local advertising executives to tailor advertising to each country's consumers.
"Our objective is to be a local company," Mr. Cantalupo said.
Still, foreign executives running McDonald's operations in other countries are required to make pilgrimages to Hamburger University, McDonald's executive training center in Oak Brook, Ill., a suburb of Chicago.
McDonald's can still spend years cultivating suppliers in a country before it is ready to open. In China, the local potatoes did not make good french fries, so company food technologists spent seven years working to develop a new strain. "Now the Chinese have a new potato that McDonald's helped them with," Mr. Greenberg said.
The company plans to open 20 more stores in China, investing $50 million in the next three years.
While there is far less competition internationally, the company does face risks overseas. Profits can hurt when exchange rates fluctuate. And a global presence subjects the company to a wide range of economic conditions. Last year, poor sales in Canada and England hurt the company's overall profits.
Still, McDonald's needs the fast-growing foreign markets to improve its earning growth. Last year, the company's profits increased by 7 percent, a disappointing rate for a company accustomed to growing twice as fast. Facing swarms of competitors and customers resistant to price rises, profits are expected to grow by 6 percent a year in the United States.
But abroad, profits have recently grown by an average of 28 percent a year.
"It's the most important part of their future growth," said Ron Paul, president of Technomic, a food consulting firm in Chicago.
In 1991, 37 percent of McDonald's sales and 40 percent of the company's operating income came from outside the United States. McDonald's revenues were $6.6 billion and operating income was $1.67 billion last year.
But not all analysts think the international business will lift the performance of the company as a whole. "You still own the whole company," said Michael Mueller, an analyst with Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. "The United States market is still at risk. That's where they have most of their restaurants."
McDonald's officials, of course, are not as gloomy about the company's domestic prospects. "The U.S. growth market has a lot of growth in it," said Mr. Greenberg, the chief financial officer. Even though growth has slowed in the United States, he said, McDonald's is opening hundreds of stores a year in this country. It closes a handful each year.
 
The Menus Vary Somewhat
 Menus are remarkably similar across the globe, offering the basic burgers, fries and shakes. In Asia, where chicken is more popular than beef, the company sells a lot of its chicken sandwiches.
Regional variations are also tolerated. In the Philippines, which has a low per capita income, the company sells an inexpensive spaghetti dish. In New Zealand, local managers have put Kiwi Burgers, featuring beet root sauce, on the menu. The company has even tested products in the United States that originated overseas, like an "Oriental" chicken salad developed in Germany.
Mostly, customers who go to McDonald's restaurants around the world want to eat hamburgers, just as the Americans they see on television and in movies do. "McDonald's stands for American culture," said Mr. Paul, the food consultant.
But there are still a few places where burgers do not travel well. India is the one major market that has not yet been graced by the Golden Arches. Although Government restrictions on foreign investment are loosening, many Indians avoid eating beef for religious reasons. "We are looking at India," Mr. Cantalupo said. "We haven't totally figured that one out yet."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Texas Instruments Reports First Profit Since Late 1990

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, April 16

 BODY:
Texas Instruments Inc., benefiting from cost-cutting programs, higher royalty payments and improving demand for its engineering products and computers chips, reported its first profitable quarter since the fall of 1990.
Net income totaled $40 million, or 35 cents a share, compared with a loss of $54 million in the comparable period last year. The company's revenues rose by 3 percent, to $1.69 billion. 
 Texas Instruments, based in Dallas, said it had trimmed 5,300 jobs last year through layoffs or voluntary retirement programs, and had reduced its work force by an additional 1,100 through layoffs, to a total of 61,806 employees at the end of March.
 
Royalty Income Higher
 The retrenchment lowered costs and contributed to ending the string of six consecutive unprofitable quarters. The company reported a big increase in royalty income, to $95 million, including a one-time payment of $30 million from two Japanese companies, from $76 million in the 1991 quarter.
Profit from operations amounted to $63 million, compared with a loss of $35 million. Texas Instruments' capital spending was also slashed, to $80 million from $157 million.
"We are beginning to see gradual improvement in the U.S. economy," said Jerry R. Junkins, the chairman and chief executive. "Distribution orders for semiconductors are on an upward trend, which is a good leading indicator. We now expect the U.S. semiconductor market to grow about 13 percent, a slight increase from our forecast earlier this year."
 
Chip Unit Sales Up
 Sales in the company's computer chip unit, which contributes nearly half of overall revenues, rose by 7 percent in the quarter, mainly because of rising shipments of custom chips, known as application-specific integrated circuits.
Yet losses in the unit narrowed despite falling chip prices, Texas Instruments said, but the size of the loss was not disclosed. Sales in Japan were weak, and growth in the overall chip market in Japan is expected to decline this year by 2 percent, Mr. Junkins said.
Over all, the world market for computer chips is projected to grow by 8 percent, to $59 billion this year, "with stronger growth going into 1993," he said. Production efficiencies improved at several Texas Instruments plants, and output of chips with four million characters of memory has increased at new plants in Taiwan and Italy, the company said.
 
Military Revenues Off 9%
 Cutbacks in military orders pared revenues in the company's military electronics unit by 9 percent, but profit margins increased. Orders to restock military hardware used during the Persian Gulf war, such as Navy aircraft missiles, amounted to $400 million in 1991 and should total that this year.
Texas Instruments' shares rose $1 each, to $36.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: February Trade Gap Narrowed

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
The nation's merchandise trade deficit narrowed sharply to $3.38 billion in February, with exports reaching a record and imports falling slightly.
The deficit, smaller than most economists expected, gladdened Administration officials, who are looking for an election-year bonus in export sales to help lead the nation into recovery. 
 Over all, exports rose 6.8 percent in February, to $37.81 billion, from $35.41 billion in January. Imports fell four-tenths of 1 percent, to $41.20 billion from $41.36 billion.
Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, pointed out that if the rest of the year followed the pattern of January and February together, then this year's trade deficit could total as little as $56 billion, down from $66.26 billion last year. But many private sector economists predict that the trade deficit will actually widen this year, as economic recovery in the United States draws in more imports while recessions in Japan and many European countries dampen growth in American exports.
 
Jump in Aircraft Sales
 They noted that more than one-third of the February jump in exports came from a $909 million increase in shipments of commercial aircraft and parts. "That may have been a one-shot deal," said Brian M. Jones, an economist at Salomon Brothers Inc., who pointed out that aircraft worth $100 million or more apiece are often delivered in bunches.
But Mr. Jones and other economists said that even leaving aircraft shipments aside, they were surprised by how much exports increased.
Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley, said, "I was looking for a $5 billion deficit, which was a little more optimistic than the consensus but hardly consistent with the sharp narrowing of the deficit."
In another bit of upbeat news, the Government reported that the number of workers filing unemployment claims in early April declined significantly for the second consecutive week. [Page D2.]
 
Some Price Advantages
 February's trade deficit, which followed a gap of $5.95 billion in January, was the smallest since a $2.84 billion deficit in March 1983. Several monthly deficits in the last year have been the lowest since 1983, as the low value of the dollar and small annual cost increases for American manufacturers have erased the $100 billion-plus annual deficits of the late 1980's.
For the last year, rapid growth in exports to third world has been offsetting stagnation in shipments to industrialized markets. But today's figures also showed a widening of the trade surplus with Western Europe, to $2.63 billion from $1.69 billion in January.
The politically sensitive trade deficit with Japan shrank to $2.97 billion from $3.82 billion in January, while the deficit with China dwindled to $1.23 billion from $1.40 billion.
Excluding oil, imports rose slightly. The nation imported less oil and paid 43 cents less a barrel in February than in January.
Exports of high-technology products, including not only aircraft but sophisticated medical and telecommunications equipment, jumped to $9.2 billion from $7.9 billion. Imports of these goods edged up to $5.1 billion from $4.9 billion in January.
Administration trade officials used the report to push their various causes. Barbara H. Franklin, the new Commerce Secretary, who is organizing a Cabinet-level review next week of Government assistance to industries, said in a statement that sustaining strong exports made it necessary "that we intensify trade promotion efforts in partnership with the private sector."
Mrs. Hills greeted the growth in exports as a sign that the United States was better off trying to open foreign markets than protecting its own market. "They're very, very strong," she said. "They continue to show how important it is to open markets."
But Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., the president of the Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington public policy group, disagreed with assessment by Mrs. Hills. "Do these numbers reflect an opening of foreign markets?" he asked. "If it's mostly aircraft, that doesn't reflect the opening of markets."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Notes and Bonds Fall

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Surprisingly good trade and jobless claim numbers combined yesterday with the risks that accompany a long holiday weekend to push down prices of Treasury notes and bonds, sending interest rates higher.
Credit market participants sold securities almost immediately after the Government reported that exports rose to a record in February and that the merchandise trade deficit fell to its lowest level since March 1983. 
 A report from the Labor Department showing that initial unemployment claims fell to a five-month low in the week ended April 4 provided additional momentum to the selloff. Most analysts had been looking for a slight increase in claims.
It was the second straight rise, and it prompted analysts to suggest that employment conditions may be improving slightly.
So, too, did the long weekend, as traders chose to lighten up positions rather than run the risk of any adverse developments that might take place between now and Monday.
Although the Chicago Board of Trade operated on an abbreviated schedule yesterday, credit-market traders said that volume remained light.
"The thin conditions exaggerated the price declines," analysts at MMS International, an economic information and service company, noted in their daily market commentary, "and much of the selling pressure came from position squaring rather than outright market bearishness."
On the advice of the Public Securities Association, an industry trade group, trading in the Government securities market halted at 2 P.M., Eastern time. The market will be closed today in observance of Good Friday.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 10026/32 , down 5/8 point, to yield 7.92 percent, compared with 7.87 percent late Wednesday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 10014/32 , down 18/32 , to yield 7.43 percent. The 6 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 10017/32 , down 14/32 , to yield 6.74 percent. And the 5 3/4 percent two-year notes were offerd at 10027/32 , down 7/32 , to yield 5.28 percent.
Rates on short-term Treasury bills moved higher.
Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 3.64 percent, up four basis points, or four one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by five basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.76 percent. And one-year bill rates rose by eight basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.02 percent.
Late in the day the Federal Reserve Board reported that two of the three measures of the nation's money supply grew during the week ended April 6. The broadest money measure, M-3, fell by $4.8 billion.
The Fed issued its report after traders had gone home for the long weekend.
Business was very slow in the investment-grade corporate and tax-exempt municipal bond markets.
No new corporate or municipal debt issues were priced yesterday.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt securities said that prices of most widely quoted municipal bonds fell by 1/4 point to 3/8 point.
