HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Higher as Data Show Good U.S. Economic News

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most major currencies yesterday on better-than-expected jobless figures and trade data.
Gold prices were higher in the United States but mixed abroad. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery rose $1.40 a troy ounce, to $337.40. Later, the Republic National Bank in New York quoted an ounce of gold bullion at $337, up $1.30. 
 Currency dealers said trading was sluggish ahead of the Good Friday holiday. The currency markets will be open in the United States but closed in Europe today and Monday for the Easter weekend, which is expected to curb currency dealings here.
The Labor Department reported that 415,000 workers applied for unemployment benefits during the week ended April 4, the fewest since late October and down from 433,000 a week earlier.
 
Trade Deficit Improves
 The Government also said the United States trade deficit improved dramatically in February, falling to $3.38 billion -- the best showing in nearly nine years and a big improvement from January's $5.95 billion.
The positive United States economic data dampened any potential profit taking ahead of the long weekend, said Mike Faust, a currency dealer with MMS International.
"The dollar continued to rally today, so people who might have sold out after this week's good performance held on," Mr. Faust said.
Fears of increased Middle East tension after the United Nations imposed sanctions against Libya should support the dollar over the weekend, he added. The dollar is considered a safe-haven investment in times of political turmoil.
In New York, the dollar rose to 133.95 Japanese yen, from 133.38 late Wednesday. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 133.45 yen from 133.25 Wednesday. In London, it rose to 133.90 yen.
The dollar strengthened against sterling. In New York, the pound closed at $1.7460, down from $1.7550 Wednesday. In London, sterling fell to $1.7477 from $1.7570.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's late levels, were: 1.6685 German marks, up from 1.6625; 1.5440 Swiss francs, up from 1.5330; 5.6405 French francs, up from 5.6230; 1,254.25 Italian lire, up from 1,249.00, and 1.18215 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17925.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Is Liberalism Back in Saddle?

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:

I often think it's comical
How nature always does contrive
That every boy and every gal,
That's born into this world alive,
Is either a little Liberal
Or else a little Conservative.
GILBERT AND SULLIVAN wrote those lines in 1882, about the political-genetic coding of the English. But they have never applied to American voters. Americans shift from liberal to conservative to liberal with the changes of generations, the rise and fall of crises and issues and the ability of particular Presidents to dominate the public agenda. 
 After 12 conservative Reagan-Bush years, is liberalism back as the dominant force in American public opinion? William G. Mayer, a political scientist at Northeastern University, has concluded after a detailed analysis of a great deal of survey data, that liberals have made up much of the ground they lost to conservatives in the late 1970's. Looking backward, he finds "stability" in political attitudes between 1960 and 1965, a "liberal shift" from 1966 to 1973, a "right turn" from 1974 to 1980, and, against the conventional wisdom, a "liberal resurgence" from 1981 to 1988.
In the spring issue of The Public Interest, a journal not known for having a liberal bias, Mr. Mayer offers evidence of the return of liberalism on a wide range of issues -- including military spending, relations with the former Soviet Union, taxes, domestic spending and environmental protection. In addition to those areas, he finds that from 1981 to 1988 public opinion shifted toward liberalism on many other issues, including racial equality, busing, the size and power of government, nuclear energy and the role and status of women.
In 1980, half the public agreed with the statement that "the Government in Washington is getting too powerful for the good of the country and the individual person." In 1988, only one-third felt that way.
Support for greater spending for the environment, health care, education and even welfare all increased, according to survey data. But there remains a contradiction between what people want government to do and what they are willing to pay for. However, the belief that Federal income taxes were too high declined from 68 percent in 1980 to 55 percent in 1988. In 1980, a majority of Americans favored higher military spending; by 1988 only 15 percent did.
The shift to what Mr. Mayer identifies as liberal views did not apply across the board. Issues on which public opinion exhibited little or no change toward either liberalism or conservatism included public attitudes toward business, gun control, sexual mores, foreign aid, government assistance for the poor, the balanced budget amendment, the United Nations and military intervention. Public opinion did become more conservative on a small number of issues, including business profits, crime and punishment, divorce, abortion and economic rights and privileges.
Mr. Mayer finds in the latest data important implications for the 1992 election. At a minimum, he says, "they indicate that new Democratic initiatives in such areas as education, day care and health care will receive a considerably more sympathetic reception than they would have 12 years ago."
Recession, economic stagnation and unemployment during recent years have doubtless intensified the public desire to have Government play a more active role in economic problem solving.
Among American economists, there appears to be a reassertion of the importance of using government to correct market failures and a greater realism about what "the magic of the market," as Mr. Reagan called it, cannot do.
In a new book, "Eminent Economists," edited by Michael Szenberg of Pace University, several prominent economists speak up for greater stress on human values in economics and economic policy making. Richard A. Musgrave of Harvard and the University of California at Santa Cruz, declared: "The miracle of the invisible hand by which self-interest yields the common good only goes that far, as Adam Smith in his 'Theory of Moral Sentiments' well knew."
But cycles of public opinion, or the ideas of economists, do not, at least in the short run, determine the outcome of elections or even the political-economic character of an Administration. Despite the shift toward liberalism apparently going on even during the Reagan years, a President may dominate public opinion.
"It was Ronald Reagan's intuitive understanding of this point," Mr. Mayer says, "that helps explain why liberalism was so timid and dormant up through the end of his Administration." And he adds, "It is precisely this power that George Bush has largely abdicated, particularly in the realm of economic policy, over the last three years."
The big question for the 1992 election is whether the Democrats have overcome their timidity and have found a leader capable of exploiting the shift of public opinion toward a more activist government role to solve social and economic problems -- or whether the incumbent President can ride that tide by presenting himself as the agent of change.

HEADLINE: Behold, in Russia: Democracy!

 BODY:
Americans watching the turmoil in the Russian Parliament this week have two reasons to be pleased, even thankful. Moscow's young reformers, confronted by strong opposition, triumphed on the economic front. What made the victory even sweeter, the struggle provided reassuring evidence that a rough-and-tumble parliamentary democracy is beginning to take shape.
In the midst of crisis, with the structure of the economy and constitution at issue, politicians devised a workable compromise. Those who expected President Yeltsin to strong-arm or short-circuit the Parliament waited in vain. The process left many loose ends but it worked, giving reformers the leeway needed for essential changes. 
 The victory probably would have been impossible without the promise of Western aid. That aid armed the reformers with an argument and a bargaining chip to persuade waverers. The Government's threat to resign, jeopardizing Western aid, was enough to carry the day.
The struggle in Russia's Parliament posed a familiar choice about the speed of reform. Politicians agonized anew about whether to plunge into the cold bath of markets or to protect themselves against reaction to hardship by hesitating or going slow. But there's something bigger behind the debate, a struggle for power.
Too rapid a leap to privatization could undermine the managers of state enterprises and collective farms who ran the old Communist economy and whose support is essential if reforms are to succeed. They dismiss the young architects of reform around Mr. Yeltsin, like Deputy Prime Minister Yegor Gaidar, and want a greater say in the reform process. For prime minister they prefer one of their own, like Arkady Volsky, who heads an organization of state-owned enterprises.
The Parliament, which was chosen before Boris Yeltsin was elected President, amply reflects the views of local power brokers -- often those who head large industrial companies or collective farms. The powerful speaker, Ruslan Khasbulatov, acts as their spokesman.
One obvious course for the Yeltsin Government might have been to call new elections. But the current economic distress puts the outcome of an election in doubt. Instead, Mr. Gaidar and the other reformers threatened to resign. Their departure would have demolished the reform program and imperiled Western aid.
Their stratagem worked. Even Russia's news media did their part to nourish the democratic process, keeping the public closely informed with leaked documents and TV interviews.
Americans need not take sides in the power struggle, nor try to dictate the precise pace of reform. But they can watch with pleasure how reform moves forward -- through politics that is confusing, ragged and even rough. Good.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
$1.5 Trillion 'Defense'

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
We face no serious military threats. Our economy stagnates and our country crumbles. And still our President and a Congressional majority commit us to spend nearly $1.5 trillion over the next five years on "defense."
The threats billboarded again by Defense Secretary Cheney yesterday seem mostly a mirage. 
 The real threats to our national security come far less from abroad than from within our own borders -- not from Mr. Cheney's vague uncertainties and faceless enemies, but from the certainty of internal rot; not from missile gaps, but mental gaps.
We are threatened by having the office of President of the United States vacant in all but name. George Bush has no clue how to lead America out of the cold war and into a war against deterioration and despair.
We are threatened by the absence of a viable White House alternative. Bill Clinton seems to be saying interesting things, including about cutting defense spending. But his candidacy looks crippled already by public mistrust.
We are threatened by a Congress that cannot legislate its way out of a paper bag. It drowns in partisan gridlock, scandal, indecision and fear. In the last weeks, both the Senate and the House soundly defeated proposals to double Mr. Bush's proposed cuts in military outlays. Few noticed.
We are threatened by the inability of our political system to make an elementary decision about priorities. In the face of obvious and pressing needs, the Washington bunch is actually moving ahead with spending nearly $1.5 trillion -- YES, THAT IS ONE AND A HALF TRILLION DOLLARS -- on Pentagon business between now and 1997. Washington cannot bring itself to cut this windfall by even one-third, or even plan to cut it by one-third.
Maybe Pentagon planners and a few Congressional Martians actually believe the U.S. must shell out $1.5 trillion for "defense." But Earthlings will find that level of prudence to be an extravagance.
The Soviet Union lies in ruins. No other state -- Germany, Japan, Iran or a resurgent Russia, name your nightmare -- can marshal military power to threaten the U.S. for perhaps a generation. Better to worry about underfinanced U.N. peacekeeping forces and unhelped ex-Communist states.
The Pentagon brims over with smart people who could figure out how to defend against these threats for only $1 trillion. But they have every incentive not to be so smart. To plan for deep cuts is to invite deeper cuts.
And smart Pentagon planners know something else that goes to the heart of American politics today: the link between military outlays and good middle-class jobs. If the Pentagon does not show Congress how to make deeper cuts, or more specifically if it produces no plan to convert defense industries to civilian use and retrain those in uniform, then Congress cannot and will not make further spending cuts.
Politicians are not about to tear a million-plus workers from the Pentagon teat, toss them into the ranks of the unemployed and commit political suicide. To eliminate Pentagon jobs, Congress needs to provide new civilian jobs.
By not offering plans for conversion, the Pentagon transforms a military bill into a jobs bill. And it has now become the biggest jobs bill in U.S. history, far bigger than Franklin Roosevelt's W.P.A. during the Depression.
To maintain jobs this way is, by almost any measure, stupid and wasteful. It is stupid because a defense dollar buys fewer jobs than almost any other Federal dollar. Two or three times as many people could be put to work by devoting those same dollars to, say, building roads, bridges and schools. It is wasteful because the extra missiles and submarines being built serve no current military or economic purpose. Spending those same dollars on, say, mass transit and retraining programs would stimulate further economic growth and even more jobs.
Senator Sam Nunn and Representatives Dave McCurdy and Les Aspin are urging conversion planning. But without full Pentagon involvement and without a President to lead, conversion ideas are just talk.
Meantime, there is little to finance peacekeeping operations and put ex-Communist states back on their feet. And there is no peace dividend, nothing left to help ourselves.

HEADLINE: Criticism of the House Bank Is Overdrawn

BYLINE: By Thomas S. Foley; Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, is Speaker of the House.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Yesterday, the House Ethics Committee released the names of current and former members who had at least one overdraft at the former House bank. This final step, following the closing of the bank and other administrative reforms, means the bank story should by rights be over.
The members named yesterday did not abuse their privileges at the bank. It would be more accurate to say that most members were abused by the bank and its practices. 
 The bank was not a bank at all. It was a payroll disbursing office. It did not pay interest or make loans. Unfortunately, it also did not follow accepted commercial record-keeping and reporting practices.
The bank's poor management and failure to follow written rules encouraged carelessness. The House bank has covered overdrafts of members for at least half a century. Congressmen are not paid until after the end of a month; as a result, the bank considered overdrafts a draw against members' accruing salary. Confident of automatic monthly payroll deposits, the bank had little incentive to handle overdrafts as a commercial bank would.
The checking service was underwritten solely with members' deposits. Thus, some members' funds were used to cover overdrafts written by others. Virtually all checks were honored, not one was delayed and no payee lost money. No public funds were ever used or lost.
While the bank honored members' checks, it did not consistently inform members when they had overdrafts. It did not give written notice of overdrafts and arbitrarily gave oral notice to relatively few members. In most cases, members had no idea they had overdrafts. Their monthly statements never reported overdrafts or showed a negative balance. Consequently, many were genuinely surprised to find the bank had attributed overdrafts to their accounts.
According to an American Bankers Association report, if prevailing banking industry standards had been followed, "a significant number of the checks alleged to have been written with insufficient funds would have been, in fact, fully covered."
Since the bank paid no interest on deposits, its administrators did not keep accounts up to date. The bank ordinarily stopped crediting deposits relatively early in the day, sometimes at 11 A.M.; deposits received after the early posting time were credited the next day. Members had no notice of this practice, and reasonably assumed their deposits would cover checks presented the same day, as in commercial banks.
When the General Accounting Office's report of overdrafts was issued in September, the House acted swiftly to close the bank. On April 9, we approved sweeping reforms that will insure professional management.
I do not condone carelessness in any of the House's subordinate operations. I regret that mismanagement of a minor support office has caused so much needless embarrassment to members and unwarranted questions about their integrity.
But what I regret most is that this affair has diverted attention from the urgent issues confronting the country. On March 26, the House passed an education bill that will increase access to higher education for millions of economically disadvantaged Americans. On April 9, the House passed the most significant reform of campaign spending laws in a generation. Neither bill received a fraction of the coverage given to the bank.
Lawmaking is the reason members run for office in the first place. They were not elected to run a bank. Every member, regardless of party, wishes to concentrate on the people's business. That is exactly what the House is now doing. Perhaps this too deserves coverage.

HEADLINE: Why Go to Texas to Repair Verrazano Bridge?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You report that Greiner Engineering Inc. of Irving, Tex., has been chosen to design repairs for the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge in New York City (Business Day, April 7).
It is both shocking and disappointing to me that the municipal officials responsible for granting this contract were not able to find a competitive engineering and design organization from the many that have their offices in the five boroughs of New York City. As a start, I refer them to the listings in the Manhattan Yellow Pages. 
 If a suitable company could not have been found within the confines of our great metropolis, then they might have chosen such a candidate from one situated in the metropolitan New York area.
The entire New York metropolitan region is suffering from severe unemployment and weak overall business activity, to say the least. Whatever the size of such a contract, the multiple effect on wages, salaries, demand for services, consumer purchases and tax revenue would have been several times the actual value of the repair contract.
Maimonides postulated that if faced with a situation where there is a beggar from afar and there is a beggar from your neighborhood, you must first favor your poor neighbor.
At this time of economic crisis for New York City and New York State, one wonders what the mind-set is of the authorities who send our precious tax dollars to distant areas, when the same skills and talent are probably found in our midst at competitive rates.
 
E. MAGNUS OPPENHEIM
New York, April 7, 1992
 
The writer, an investment adviser and economist, heads a company of registered investment advisers.

HEADLINE: Business Tax-Credit Plan Would Aid Arts Groups

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday endorsed a change in tax policy intended to encourage companies to increase their contributions to museums, parks, libraries and other cultural institutions by millions of dollars.
The change would allow companies to take credits for some charitable contributions and apply them against the amount they pay in commercial rent tax. Early reactions by other political figures needed to insure the proposal's ultimate passage were favorable. 
 Those familiar with the proposal said that it could result in the city's libraries, museums and parks receiving as much as $60 million in new contributions. Last year, according to the Department of Finance, corporations gave about $250 million to cultural institutions.
Reactions from the arts community -- hard-pressed by recession-driven cuts in government and corporate contributions over the last two years -- were, for the most part, jubilant.
"Anything that encourages the arts in New York City is wonderful news," said Gillian Attfield, president of the board of directors of the New York City Ballet.
 
Will the City Cut Back?
 But a few arts leaders expressed concern that the city might be using the tax-credit approach to replace its own contributions. "I just hope it's not passing the buck, and that the city will not begin to curtail its own contributions," said Judith Daykin, executive director of the City Center Theater.
In January, the Dinkins administration said that it planned to reduce its arts appropriation for the next fiscal year beginning July 1 by 28 percent, from $87 million to $63 million.
The idea for a tax credit came out of a report presented to the Mayor yesterday by a group of prominent business, labor and political leaders that proposed ways that the city could increase its spending on economic development. Among the other suggestions in the report that the Mayor endorsed was a development bank, to which he committed $50 million in funds from the city's capital budget over the next four years to be used for large public projects that would spur development.
At a news conference yesterday, Mr. Dinkins said he viewed these proposals as signaling that the relationship between the business community and the city was finally changing for the better.
Mr. Dinkins said he hoped the cultural tax credit would become available in January 1993. Those who have researched the proposal estimate that the revenue shortfall to the city could amount to about $30 million a year, with the first impact felt in the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1994.
Businesses would be allowed to take a $1 tax credit for every $2 in contributions they made over what they had given in the past, up to 10 percent of their commercial rent tax. They would be able to choose the institutions that would receive their donations, although certain restrictions would be put in place to insure that contributions were spread across all boroughs and all sizes of institution.
Although city tax officials said they did not believe the cultural tax credit proposal would require state legislative approval, because it did not involve any change in rates, they said it would require approval by the City Council.
Peg Breen, a spokesman for the City Council, said Peter F. Vallone, the majority leader and Speaker, was still studying the report but that, "particularly on the cultural institutions proposal, he had a very favorable first impression."
But Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, said she fears "the commission's approach to giving tax credits for new contributions will prove an administrative nightmare."
Business executives on the committee that produced the report said they were sure there would be substantial interest by other corporate executives in taking advantage of the proposed tax credit.
"I get the sense among business people, especially those concerned with foreign business, that they believe that cultural institutions attract and keep people here," said Ronald K. Shelp, president of the New York City Partnership, a business lobbying group. "I suspect they'll find it an inducement, especially since they find it such an onerous tax."
The development bank may face a more uphill battle. The committee that produced the report, whose chairman was Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of Levitt Media Company, called for the bank to receive an initial injection of $250 million in capital, with matching funds to come from other public agencies like the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the state's Urban Development Corporation.
However, Stanley Brezenoff, executive director of the Port Authority said, "We just don't have any money," and a spokesman for the development corporation indicated the same, adding that he also thought there were enough development banks in the state already.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 18, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about proposed tax credits for donations to cultural institutions misstated the timing of the Dinkins administration's most recent cut in city appropriations for the arts. The 28 percent reduction occurred in this fiscal year, which ends June 30.

HEADLINE: Nika Hazelton, Whose Cookbooks Influenced U.S. Tastes, Dies at 84

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL

 BODY:
Nika Hazelton, whose cookbooks have been a mainstay of serious cooks for nearly half a century, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.
She died of natural causes after a lingering illness, said her son, Dr. S. A. Standen, who lives in London. 
 Mrs. Hazelton, the daughter of a German diplomat, was born in Rome, attended school there, and studied at the London School of Economics. She began her career as a reporter in 1930, covering the League of Nations for the German Press Association and then moving on to freelance work.
After marrying and emigrating to the United States in 1940, she began writing cookbooks with recipes culled primarily from home cooks throughout Europe and South America.
She published 30 books and they reflected her firm, no-nonsense taste in food. "American Home Cooking" (Bobbs Merrill, 1967), "French Home Cooking" (Viking Penguin, 1979,) "International Cookbook" (Harper & Row, 1967) and "The Italian Cookbook (Henry Holt, 1979) remain standards.
She was also a frequent contributer to the major food magazines and for several decades wrote a column about food, wine and travel for The National Review.
As cooking became trendy and precious in the United States, she seemed to raise a speculative eyebrow. Facing a group of wine writers in New York several years ago, Mrs. Hazelton waved aside questions about white truffles and little-known family vineyards. "I'm here to show you a meal from Tuscany that has the virtue of not being too expensive and not taking much genius or fuss to prepare," she informed her audience and proceeded to demonstrate the proper way to make escarole and rice soup.
Her first marriage ended in divorce in 1954. She married Harold Hazelton in 1956. He died in November.
Mrs. Hazelton is survived by two sons, Dr. Standen and J. O. Standen, a lawyer in San Francisco, and three grandchildren.
A memorial service will be held at 3 P.M. on April 28 at St. Agnes Church on East 43d Street in Manhattan.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 18, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary yesterday about the cookbook author Nika Hazelton misstated the day of her death and the date of a memorial service. She died on Wednesday, and the service will be on April 27, at 3 P.M., at the Church of St. Agnes, 141 East 43d Street, in Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Transit Officials to Cut Subway Rush-Hour Service on 9 Lines

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
For the first time in more than a decade, transit officials are planning to reduce rush-hour service on a broad swath of New York City's subway lines because of sharply declining ridership.
A total of 43 trains on 9 lines will be eliminated during the Manhattan-bound morning and outbound evening rush hours, transit officials said yesterday. Thirteen additional trains will be dropped from other routes or at other times. 
 The officials said the reductions were minor, and would generally add only one or two minutes to passengers' waits for trains during the rush hours. They also said the changes, scheduled to go into effect in July, would save $2.9 million a year, primarily in salaries.
 
A, B, C, D, F, J, N, Q and R
 But critics, including some members of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's board, contended that the changes would significantly increase crowding in subway cars and would drive away more riders. They said that cutting service would ultimately be counterproductive, worsening the subway system's financial problems rather than helping to solve them.
The plan calls for eliminating some rush hour trains on the A, B, C, D, F, J, N, Q and R lines. Service on the A and D lines between the Bronx and midtown Manhattan would be reduced the most, proportionately. The F line between Manhattan and Queens, the most crowded in the city, would not be altered.
The plan was presented yesterday to the committee of the M.T.A. board that oversees the Transit Authority, the subsidiary that runs the city's subway and buses. Although the plan does not require the approval of the M.T.A. board, some board members indicated yesterday that they would seek to have it reconsidered.
 
Sharp Decline in Subway Use
 "I think this is a devastating cut," said Lucius J. Riccio, the city's Transportation Commissioner, who is also an M.T.A. board member. "It brings into question what we're in business for."
Mr. Riccio and other members appointed by Mayor David N. Dinkins said they would try to persuade the full board next week to postpone the reductions.
Officials of the Transit Authority argued, however, that the schedule changes were limited, and that they represented a reasonable response to a sharp decline in subway use. They said that they had decided to eliminate some trains and expand the time between trains because the average number of weekday subway riders had fallen 7.7 percent since 1989.
The number of trains to be cut amounts to less than 1 percent of the 7,000 trains that run through the vast system each weekday, transit officials said. The reductions will diminish the number of trains that operate during rush hours on the affected lines by only 7 percent, they said.
"We have to be able to manage our services to the demands placed upon them," Alan F. Kiepper, the Transit Authority's president, said during a brief discussion of the plan.
Mr. Kiepper noted during a lengthy interview last week that the Transit Authority had been buffeted during the recession by declining fare revenues and declining city and state subsidies. To compensate, the agency has reduced its work force from 48,000 to slightly under 44,000 in the last three years, without layoffs. Last year, the authority's operating expenses declined by 3.6 percent, and its budget this year calls for another drop of 1.1 percent, he said.
But continued financial pressures have forced transit officials to begin trimming service during the rush hour on the lines that are losing the most riders, Mr. Kiepper said. Service was trimmed on many lines during the last three years, but most of those changes involved trains operating during the midday, evenings or weekends.
"We're not malicious service cutters," Mr. Kiepper said in the interview. "We're trying to do a prudent, reasonable job of managing the public's resources."
Mr. Kiepper also contended that the latest service changes were so minor that most riders would barely tell the difference. "Probably if someone didn't tell you, you wouldn't notice," he said.
On the A line, for example, ridership has declined 8 1/2 percent in the last two years, Mr. Kiepper said. A total of seven trains will be eliminated between Manhattan and the Bronx during the morning and evening rush hours. Instead of trains running every 6 to 8 minutes, they will run every 7 to 10 minutes, transit officials said.
 
Smaller Shoulders
 On the D line between Manhattan and Brooklyn, two trains will be cut during the last part of the morning rush hour -- called the shoulder period by transit officials -- and three trains during the end of the evening rush hour. Waiting times will expand to 8 to 10 minutes in the morning and 7 to 9 minutes in the evening, from 6 to 8 minutes now.
Critics, including many elected officials and rider advocates, said that eliminating trains would make the rest significantly more crowded. "It's simply no way to treat your customers," said Gene Russianoff, staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign.
Mr. Russianoff and other opponents of the service reductions said the Transit Authority's own estimates showed that crowding would increase. The authority -- which frequently surveys ridership and which has guidelines for both crowding and waiting times -- projects that on A trains from the Bronx, cars will have an average increase of 25 percent during the morning rush hour under the plan, to 127 people from 102.
Transit officials said that such crowding was well within guidelines -- at least 3 square feet per standing passenger -- created by the M.T.A. board five years ago. But critics argued that riders would suffer, and that some would stop using the subway. Mr. Russianoff contended that the agency should save the $2.9 million by canceling a planned expansion of its station manager program.
 
'In the Service Business'
 "The whole point of a transit authority is to provide service," he said. "They are in the service business, and service comes first."
Transit officials said yesterday that the recession was also affecting their effort to rebuild the subway system. Jerome Foreman, a senior vice president at the Transit Authority in charge of engineering and construction, indicated that the agreement last month by the State Legislature and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to guarantee only one year of construction financing had thrown the program into some disarray.
Over the last decade, the M.T.A.'s rebuilding programs were financed in five-year segments to allow for broad planning and to account for the lengthy time required by many reconstruction projects. Transit officials had sought approval earlier this year for a third five-year plan, which would cost more than $10 billion.
But because of the state's fiscal problems, the Governor and legislators decided they could only approve one year of financing. They estimated that the one-year package was worth $1.6 billion, of which about $1.3 billion would go to the Transit Authority.
But Mr. Foreman told the M.T.A. committee that the agency might have as much as $1.3 billion or as little as $840 million to spend on rebuilding this year. He said that the state cuts had put into doubt the Transit Authority's ability to qualify for some Federal money that requires matching commitments by the city and state.
In addition, Mayor David N. Dinkins released a letter to Mr. Cuomo yesterday, in which the Mayor threatened to veto the entire M.T.A. capital plan when it came before a review panel of the M.T.A. Mr. Dinkins said he found the one-year plan "significantly flawed."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 21, 1992, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about cuts in New York City subway service misidentified the northern terminus of the A line. The last stop is 207th Street in Manhattan.

HEADLINE: 42% of Young Black Males Go Through Capital's Courts

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
After a decade in which both the drug trade and police sweeps expanded with similar zeal, 42 percent of the black men in the District of Columbia, aged 18 through 35, were enmeshed in the criminal justice system on any given day last year, according to a study made public today.
"In effect, the social safety net has been replaced by a dragnet," said Jerome G. Miller, president of the National Center on Institutions and Alternatives, which conducted the study. The nonprofit group promotes alternatives to imprisonment.
 
21 Percent in Prison
 The study found that 15 percent of Washington's black men in this age group were in prison, 21 percent were on probation or parole and 6 percent were out on bond or being sought by the police on any one day in 1991. Mr. Miller said a vast majority of these people had committed felonies. 
 As many as 70 percent of black men in Washington are arrested by the time they turn 35, the study estimated, and about 85 percent are arrested at some point in their lives. A large percentage of those arrests are for misdemeanor charges, Mr. Miller said.
The numbers -- higher than those reported in similar studies -- quickly set off a debate that goes to the heart of America's vexing inner city problems: Is society turning many of its young black men into criminals, or are these men doing it themselves? Or are, as John Wilson, the chairman of the City Council, contended today in discussing the study, "both things occurring"?
 
Making Matters Worse
 Mr. Miller said the study found that an emphasis in the 1980's on more arrests and mandatory sentences had not only failed to curb crime but might also have made matters worse by exposing young men to the brutal effects of arrest and imprisonment.
"We're criminalizing people we should be treating in other ways," he argued. "The majority of people we march through the system are people who have other problems -- the retarded, the mentally ill, the alcoholic, the homeless, the minor offenders."
Others concurred in calling the numbers depressingly high but said they saw few immediate options for reducing the role of criminal justice.
"What laws does he propose to repeal?" asked Mark A. R. Kleiman, a professor of public policy at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard who has written widely on drug laws. "If you said to people in the neighborhoods, 'Should we stop arresting the crack dealers?' I think they'd say no."
While there have been similar national studies of black men and criminal justice, today's study is the first to focus on a single major city.
In 1989, the Sentencing Project, a Washington research and advocacy group, found that almost one in four of the nation's black men age 20 to 29 were in prison, on probation or on parole. A year later, two private groups found a similar pattern holding true for black men in New York state. There, 23 percent of black men in the same age group were incarcerated or on probation or parole.
 
More Expansive Definition
 In arriving at the higher number of 42 percent, Mr. Miller's study not only focused on one city but used a more expansive definition: It included black men who were free on bond awaiting trial and those who were sought for arrest.
The study did not include corresponding figures for whites, Mr. Miller said, because that number "would have been negligible, less than 10 percent." As evidence, he cited the racial composition of the main prison in the District's Lorton correctional center, where 98 percent of the inmates in the main prison were black men and 1 percent were white men.
The 1990 study of New York found that 3 percent of young white men were in prison or on probation or parole. That study was conducted by the Correctional Association of New York and the New York State Coalition for Criminal Justice.
While there have been no studies of young black men in other cities, Mr. Miller suggested that the proportion in the criminal justice system would be the same as in Washington.
Mr. Kleiman, the Harvard professor, said he thought the numbers would hold true in other cities with many poor people, like Cleveland or Detroit, but not those like Miami, where the city limits include large suburban, middle-class areas. "A lot of this depends on where you draw the boundaries, where the black middle class lives," he said.
 
Disbelief Over Numbers
 In an interview on Thursday night with WRC-TV, Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly said, "I know that we've got a staggering problem," but added, "There are too many successful well-adjusted young people, young black men in this city for me to believe that 42 percent is a reliable number."
That sentiment was markedly different from the one expressed by Mr. Wilson, the council chairman. "I'm not skeptical of the numbers at all," he said. "It doesn't seem that whatever the programs we come up with there's any improvement in the situation at all."
Census figures for 1990 show that 65.8 of the District's 606,990 residents are black. Another 29.3 percent are white, and 5.4 percent are of Hispanic origin, a category that includes both blacks and whites.
The report found that on an average day 21,800 of the District's 53,377 young black men were involved with the criminal justice system. Of those 7,800 were in jail or prison, 6,000 were on local probation, 3,700 were on local parole and 1,300 were on Federal probation or parole. The report estimated that 3,000 others were awaiting trial on bond or being pursued on felony or misdemeanor warrants.
Mr. Miller arrived at these figures by taking the actual number of people in prison, or on probation or parole, and estimating the percentage who were black men between 18 and 35.
He said he based his estimates on a two-year-old study for the District's correction department that broke down the prison population by age, race and gender. "Those figures don't change much in two years," he said.
The report did not calculate how many of the men had been arrested for drug charges, but in an interview Mr. Miller said he would put the figure at 40 to 45 percent. That does not include those arrested for drug-related acts, like robbery to finance drug purchases.
Mr. Miller's numbers were of such magnitude that they astonished prominent blacks immersed in the very problems they describe.
C. Glenn Loury, an economist at Boston University, said, "What it suggests to me is an advanced breakdown of social order that even I had been unaware of."

HEADLINE: Intense Fighting in Sarajevo Threatens U.S. Aid Flights

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, April 17

 BODY:
Serbian militias stepped up their attacks near the capital today, overrunning a town only 30 miles away and pounding Muslim Slav neighborhoods with mortar fire. The fighting raised new security concerns for a United States airlift of humanitarian aid scheduled to begin on Saturday.
One Serbian militia leader suggested partitioning Sarajevo, the capital of the newly independent republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which was granted formal recognition by the United States and the European Community last week. The Serbian militias are fighting to carve out their own part of this republic that is made up of Serbs, Croats and Muslim Slavs. 
 Cyrus R. Vance, the United Nations special envoy, said today that he was not encouraged by his talks this week with officials of the three factions and the Yugoslav Army.
"I can't say I'm an optimist in this situation," Mr. Vance said as he arrived in Zagreb for talks with Croatia's President, Franjo Tudjman. "Continued fighting is going to benefit nobody. It will be a disaster and there will be no winners."
Mr. Vance, who helped mediate the cease-fire that halted similar ethnic fighting between Croats and Serbs in Croatia, called again for a halt to the fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina and support for European Community-sponsored negotiations.
 
U.S. Expresses Concern
 With fighting continuing, United States officials said there were growing security concerns for the airlift set to begin on Saturday with the arrival here of two military transport planes carrying food and blankets. Three more cargo planes are to arrive on Sunday.
"The Yugoslav Army has given their approval," a diplomat based in Belgrade said, adding that the United States Defense Department was "getting cold feet over the food delivery because of security."
"The Serbs were demanding that the flights first go to Belgrade for customs clearance," the diplomat said, adding that the United States refused that condition.
[In Washington, a Pentagon spokesman said that the flights were still scheduled for Saturday but that United States officials were seeking safety guarantees from Serbian forces.]
Serbian militias, which have been armed by the Serb-led Yugoslav Army, have antiaircraft guns mounted on trucks, but it is unclear whether any are at Sarajevo's airport. Neither the Yugoslav Army, which controls the airport, nor the Serb Government in Belgrade, claim or seem to have full control over the Serb militias.
 
Serbs Hijack U.N. Trucks
 Diplomats and United Nations officials said that Serbian irregulars had hijacked six 22-ton trucks loaded with United Nations food aid during the night. One group is said to have threatened to kill a United Nations official who complained. Under the United States aid plan, the American humanitarian supplies are to be handed over to United Nations relief workers for distribution. The aid is intended to help overcome a food shortage and to underscore Washington's backing for the republic's independence.
The new attacks today by Serbian militias flared across an arc-shaped corridor populated mostly by Muslim Slavs and Croats but considered strategic to the Serbs because it links predominantly Serb enclaves in the republic.
Foca, a town of about 20,000 people on the Drina River about 30 miles southeast of Sarajevo, fell today after a week of attacks. It was the sixth town to fall to the Serbs in just over two weeks.
Virtually all of Foca's population had fled over the last week to Montenegro and the town of Gorazde, which is the last important town in eastern Bosnia not in the hands of the Serbian militias. Diplomats and Government officials here expect the Serbs to attack Gorazde next.
In the town of Bosanski Samac, Serbian guerrillas initiated a daylong firefight by overrunning a police station and closing Bosnia's last passable bridge over the Sava River into Croatia, local news reports said.
Serious clashes also erupted near the towns of Derventa, Mostar and Capljina. Sarajevo television reported tonight that several dozen civilians were indiscriminately killed today during fighting near Bosanski Brod. Western diplomats said they had received independent reports of the incident.
 
Battles in the Capital
 Overnight gun battles broke out near Sarajevo's electric utility company, and Serb mortar fire pounded Sarajevo's Muslim quarter. The streets of the capital have become a maze of barricades, checkpoints and tank traps.
Serbian nationalist leaders called for the partitioning of Sarajevo as the starting point for the division of the entire republic.
"Work on the map should begin in Sarajevo," said Nikola Koljevic, one of the Serbian leaders. "Sarajevo should be partitioned, and then we would go further. We think that this would be the best step toward peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina."
Mr. Vance's visit and warnings by the United States and European Community on Wednesday to isolate Serbia politically and economically have failed to persuade Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, local Serbian leaders or the quarreling commanders of the Yugoslav Army to try to rein in the Serbian militias.
Tonight, Serbia's Government in Belgrade accused Washington and the European Governments as well as news organizations in the United States, Germany and Austria of unleashing an "unscrupulous and unrestrained" campaign to malign Belgrade.
Bosnia and Herzegovina has a population of 1.9 million Muslim Slavs, 1.4 million Eastern Orthodox Serbs and 750,000 Roman Catholic Croats. Most Serbs here oppose being separated from Serbia, and for months their leaders warned of civil war and partition of the republic if it gained independence. The Muslim Slavs and Croats, however, oppose remaining part of a Serbian-dominated Yugoslavia, and declared the republic's independence.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Economic Policy;
Clinton Proposals Seek Political Middle Ground

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton told his audience at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania on Thursday that, if elected, he would be "a different kind of President with a very different economic policy" from George Bush's.
By all accounts, he would be. Mr. Clinton wants to pull the American economy in the direction of the managed capitalism found in Japan and Western Europe, where governments play a larger role than Washington in shaping industries and markets. And to achieve that transformation, he is offering a bundle of programs, from tax breaks for start-up businesses to a multibillion-dollar agency for commercial research and skills training for all American workers. 
 Mr. Clinton avoids using the term "industrial policy" because it is often associated with the notion of a large, centralized bureaucracy trying to designate industries as winners and losers. But to compete with nations like Germany and Japan, he said in a recent interview, "we need to put Government on the playing field, not to manage or direct markets but mainly to help create markets." He continued, "I don't consider that heavy-handed industrial policy."
 
Search for a Middle Ground
 To his admirers in business and academia, Mr. Clinton's proposals are a coherent economic strategy to cope with increased global competition, lagging productivity and a widening gap between the wealthy and other Americans. They are the result of a decade-long effort by intellectuals aligned with the Democratic Party to find a middle-ground between traditional tax-and-spend Democrats and laissez-faire Republicans.
"Clinton is offering a third choice based on the view that in today's global economy the old solutions, both on the Democratic and Republican sides, don't work anymore," said Robert Shapiro, a Clinton adviser who is a political economist at the Progressive Policy Institute, a research group linked to the Democratic Party.
To critics, Mr. Clinton's plan is a misguided effort to get the Government involved in making investment decisions best left to the marketplace. And in an election year when voters' distrust of Government is running high, they say the Clinton program will be tough to sell. "I think it's a complete misreading of where the American public wants to go," said Lawrence Kudlow, chief economist of Bear Stearns & Company and a free-market conservative who served in the Reagan Administration. "Economic policy could be Clinton's Achilles' heel."
 
Sluggish Productivity Growth
 Mr. Clinton's agenda represents an evolution of thinking about economic solutions to America's long-run problems. For two decades, through Democratic and Republican Administrations, the American economy has been afflicted with sluggish productivity growth. Since 1973, output per worker has increased by less than 1 percent a year, far below the rate of earlier years and well behind the rate of other leading industrial nations.
Slow productivity growth means eroding living standards. Had productivity maintained its pre-1973 pace, the typical American family's income would be more than $10,000 ahead of its current $35,000 a year.
In Mr. Clinton's view, the goal of Government is to help create as many high-paying skilled jobs within America as possible. Education policy, tax incentives, subsidies and trade policy should be aimed at insuring that companies, whatever their nationality, place those jobs in the United States.
The Clinton vision is strikingly similar to that of Robert B. Reich, a political economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, in his influential book on global economics, "The Work of Nations" (Vintage, 1991). That is not surprising; the two men have been friends since 1968, when they met on an ocean liner while heading to Oxford University as Rhodes scholars.
"We started a conversation then that's continued ever since," Mr. Reich recalled. "Bill Clinton has been burdened with every book and paper I've ever written. And to my amazement, he's actually read and absorbed most of it."
 
Academic Connections
 Indeed, Mr. Clinton's ad hoc group of advisers on economic matters is heavy with people he knew at Georgetown and Oxford universities. Another former Rhodes scholar is Ira Magaziner, a business consultant and author. Derek Shearer, a professor of public policy at Occidental College, met Mr. Clinton at Oxford. Roger C. Altman, a Wall Street investment banker, was a classmate at Georgetown. Mr. Shapiro, also a key economic adviser, met the candidate in 1990 when Mr. Clinton served as chairman of the Democratic Leadership Council.
Because Mr. Clinton's goal is to generate skilled jobs in engineering, computerized manufacturing and other high-technology fields, one of his favorite speech lines is, "Education is economic development."
Some of the most costly programs in Clinton's platform are educational. He plans, for example, to expand Head Start to include all 3- and 4-year-olds, a commitment of roughly $4.5 billion a year. The biggest price tag is for his National Service Trust Fund, a plan for guaranteed college tuition loans that would be repaid with either post-graduation earnings or with two years of public service in areas like teaching, law enforcement or child care. By its sixth year, the college loan program would cost a projected $14 billion a year, only 43 percent of which would be recovered by eliminating the $6 billion-a-year Federal student loan program.
 
Military Technology Model
 Mr. Clinton's clearest industrial policy initiative is his recommendation for a multibillion-dollar-a-year civilian version of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, or Darpa, a small agency formed in 1958 in the panic after the Soviet Union's launching of Sputnik. Financed from the military budget, Darpa's mission has been to promote military-related technology. But Darpa has also financed research with broad civilian applications, particularly computer technology. Today, many fundamental computer technologies can be traced to Darpa backing.
"Historically, we have justified that kind of industrial policy only in the defense area," Mr. Clinton said. "But I think we ought to do the same thing on the civilian side, to work in partnership with industry to convert ideas into manufacturing jobs."
Experts differ on what lessons can be drawn from Darpa, and whether a large-scale version for commercial research would be successful. But Mr. Clinton and his advisers are optimistic that 50-50 investments between the Government and the private sector in fields like telecommunications, high-speed trains, aerospace, silicon wafers, new materials and biotechnology could help accelerate the development of new markets.
The Government contribution might be as much as $7 billion a year, compared with $1 billion for Darpa. "The public money would allow companies to engage in longer-term research and development projects than they are now, given the pressures they face to generate profits," Mr. Magaziner said.
 
Breaks with Party's Reputation
 For a Democratic candidate, the handling of the Federal budget deficit is viewed as an important test of economic competence, and Mr. Clinton is adamant in portraying himself as a break with the party's big-spending reputation. Last month, when a group of economists advocated spending $50 billion of Government money quickly to pull the economy out of recession, Mr. Clinton declined to endorse the proposal.
Mr. Clinton proposes to divide the Federal budget into three parts: past, present and future. The past budget would include interest payments on debt and the costs of rescuing the savings and loan industry. The present budget would include current spending on programs like social security and defense. The future budget would be for investment in areas like education, highways and research.
His goal is to curb past and present spending, while doubling the share spent on investment in the future to roughly 18 percent -- based, again, on the premise that spending on things like infrastructure, education and research will improve productivity and thus living standards.

HEADLINE: Ever So Warily, People Are Buying Again

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Connie Santucci of Valley Stream, L.I., is shopping for spring clothing, and she is not about to compromise on either quality or value. "Just because clothing is on sale, I'm not going to settle," she said.
Attracting customers like Mrs. Santucci is a daunting task these days for retailers and catalogue merchants. 
 As the spring selling season peaks this weekend with the Easter holiday, there are signs that consumers who have been hesitant to buy during the recession are beginning to open their wallets for new apparel. Pent-up demand, retailers say, is finally bringing shoppers into the stores in a buying frame of mind.
With retail sales accounting for about a third of the nation's business activity, any changes in buying patterns can have a major effect on the general economy.
"I don't think it is overwhelming," said Gerald Mathews, executive vice president and director of stores for Saks Fifth Avenue, "but there seems to be more energy out there, whether in the men's suit department or in women's sportswear."
Charles Monte, owner of Grace Charles Fashions, a women's clothing store in Lynbrook, L.I., said: "People are shopping later. We used to have people coming in as soon as new merchandise came in, and they'd shop for the whole season. Now they are shopping, but they are buying one outfit, as opposed to two or three."
Behind this cautious optimism lies a 2.9 percent rise in overall retail sales during the first quarter of 1992, the strongest quarterly gain since an identical one in the last quarter of 1988. There are also expectations of higher apparel sales in April because of warmer weather and the relatively late Easter buying season this year. However, consultants and security analysts warn that the free-spending patterns of the past decade are unlikely to return, regardless of general economic conditions.
"The spring season is going to be just slightly better than last year's," said Walter Loeb, president of Loeb Associates, a New York retail consulting firm. "The consumer, as I see it, remains very cautious, and retailers are keeping their inventories under very tight control."
Susan O'Dell, president of Service Dimensions, a North American consulting concern based in Toronto, pointed out: "We still see what we call the reluctant customer -- the customer who is spending because she has to, not because she is getting joy out of it. Excess is no longer a sign of success. Today it is O.K., and in fact even desirable, not to spend."
 
For Customers, a Strategy
 Nevertheless, when consumers do spend, they tend to target their purchases carefully. Gail Brewer, a product manager of L. L. Bean, the big mail-order house in Freeport, Me., said that this spring, "people are looking for colorful items to update their outfits." Among the best-selling colors are deep teal and plum, soft blue and pink, and "outdoor" colors like coral. "The concept is to have color themes that interrelate and coordinate," she said.
Isaac Lagnado, a principal of Tactical Retail Solutions, a retail consulting busines in New York, cited two niches in the apparel category that are getting unusual consumer attention now, women's large-size clothing and shorts. "Designers are finally designing merchandise for the large-size segment, although the business is still underdeveloped at retail," he said. "As for shorts, it's a fashion blip across the country."
Mr. Lagnado pointed out that budget items that lure customers into stores are generally doing the best. "Promotions are still the name of the game and are driving items like career clothing and sportswear," he said."
Promotions are not limited to lower-price merchandise, though. Said Robert F. Buchanan, a senior retail analyst for Alex. Brown & Sons, a Baltimore securities firm, "Even the high end is very price sensitive. I don't think people are going to spend like drunken sailors any time soon."
 
Ambiance Counts, Too
 In addition to price, many returning customers are displaying a new-found choosiness, demanding more in the way of merchandise and atmosphere, experts say. "Retailers today have wisened up," said Kurt Barnard, publisher of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report. "Consumers must see a good shopping ambiance that is pleasing. A dirty store is one that would attract suspicion immediately."
Richard Feinberg, director of the Purdue University Retail Institute, agrees. "People want to be treated better in the stores once they get in there," he said. "And more and more stores realize they've got to treat their customers well."
But other retail specialists say that a broad selection of merchandise will be the key to long-term improvement in the marketplace. At the same time, stocks of apparel have been generally low since the beginning of the year, thus reducing the range of goods available for potential customers.
"I want to look at long skirts and at short skirts," Mrs. Santucci said." "What I want is variety."
 
 
SPRING SALES ARE COMING
 Here are some of the major clothing items that retail executives say will be marked down after Easter in many stores across the country:
Women's all-weather coats
Men's shirts
Dresses and blouses
Handbags and women's shoes
Girls' sportswear and accessories.

HEADLINE: A Rural New York County Mired in Poverty

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SPECULATOR, N.Y., April 16

 BODY:
If wealth could be measured solely by natural surroundings, no one would be poor in Hamilton County, where the last vestiges of snow are giving way to the magnificent greenery of an Adirondack spring and the lakes glisten as they thaw in the sunshine.
But gauged by numbers, the landscape here is grim. This winter the unemployment rate hit 19.1 percent, the highest of any county in the Northeast, and labor officials expect that it will rise above 20 percent for April now that the North Country's mud season has arrived and most timber companies have shut down their logging operations until late May. 
 Even when people can get work, the average yearly wage here is just $11,931, the lowest in the 62 counties in New York. And Hamilton County has another distinction that speaks in part to pastoral charms, but also to economic straits -- it is the only county in the state without a single 24-hour bank machine.
The recession has, of course, struck all parts of the country, and in New York State, more than 90 percent of the 500,000 jobs lost in the last three years have come from New York City and its suburbs. But in pockets of rural New York, where winter joblessness is a perennial problem even when the national economy is in good shape, the recession and a dearth of heavy tourist-attracting snowfalls this year have combined to drive unemployment to levels almost unimaginable in downstate areas and among the worst in the nation, state officials say.
Evidence of the economic distress is certainly obscured by the splendor of the forest that seems to rise all around the county, but it is there. It can be found along places like Page Road, atop a hill at the edge of the village of Speculator.
A mile and a half down the rock-dirt roadway is Lee Page, 28 years old, who jokingly refers to the "family compound," a collection of seven patched-up trailers and a half-completed log cabin that are home to Mr. Page, his wife, their three children, his brother and his brother's family, his parents, three uncles, two aunts and cousins.
Mr. Page, his brother, his father and one of his uncles are all laid off from logging jobs and have uncertain prospects of returning even when the mud dries up. Mr. Page's only income is a $150-a-week unemployment check and the money his wife takes in sporadically as a substitute clerk at the Big M supermarket in Speculator.
 
'I Guess We're Pretty Close'
 "It's gotten pretty rough up here," Mr. Page said inside his family's trailer, where a gas stove helps to heat the home as well as cook the food. "I guess we're pretty close to what you might almost call poverty-stricken."
Jerry Perkins, who lives in his grandparents' former house on Route 8, the main street here, held various jobs last summer and fall mixing concrete, pounding nails and operating the weed-eater at a golf course in Lake Pleasant nearby. But no work since then, said the 37-year-old Mr. Perkins, who is collecting unemployment.
"There's nothing going on here," he said. "It's all shut down."
The economic afflictions in rural New York are by no means confined to Hamilton County. Of the four other counties in the state whose unemployment rates are above 15 percent, two are just to the west of here, Lewis and Jefferson, and two to the east, Essex and Warren.
In the southwestern part of the state, several counties have topped 12 percent unemployment recently. By contrast, the statewide average was 9.3 percent for February, the most recent month for which state Labor Department figures are available, with New York City at 10.9 percent.
Aside from the frustration brought on by months of idle job searches -- "It's enough to start making you go nervous," said Mr. Perkins, whose wife is expecting their first child next month -- the economy has also strained social-service agencies. Requests for county-sponsored free food packages, which typically include pasta, milk and some canned goods, are up between 40 percent and 60 percent over last year, local officials said.
Still, as bad as times are in Hamilton County, several factors combine to give poverty here a different face than in many urban areas.
For one thing, it is so cold that local authorities say they know of no one who is homeless. And even when people are destitute, life seems to be lived on a small enough scale -- the county's total population is 5,279 -- that government seems able to help.
 
Bus Fare for Homesick
 Last fall, a Venezuelan immigrant couple took a bus to Indian Lake from New York City and announced they were both jobless and homeless, recalled the county's Commissioner of Social Services, Arthur D. Haynes Jr.
Mr. Haynes put them up in a local motel and gave them work caring for the grounds at the county building. But after a few days they said they were homesick and wanted to go back to New York City.
"So what could I do?" said Mr. Haynes. "I paid for their bus fare, and they went back."
Winter unemployment also seems to have become so chronic that some people have learned how to plan for it. Dan Moran, who is a state campground supervisor in the summer, worked only two days last fall, supervising the booths for a local election. He stayed unemployed until earlier this month, when he secured a three-week stint acting as the Hamilton County jailer while the county sheriff was away on vacation.
Mr. Moran and his wife grew a huge garden last summer, canned most of the produce and stored most of the fish and deer he caught in the fall.
"We're getting sick of the taste of venison," he said. "But if we hadn't done it this way, we'd have been in really tough shape this winter."
Some residents even seemed to take the latest economic news with a grain of salt, suggesting that winter unemployment held a certain appeal to many who were experiencing it.
 
Offense at Being Called Poor
 "What it means is that there are a lot of people out here looking for work and hoping to hell they don't find any," said George Perkins, 68, Larry Perkins's father and a retired construction worker.
Finally, as much as people here say they are angry about the lack of jobs, many seem to take considerable offense at the notion that they are actually suffering.
In one example, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo flew to the North Country in 1984 to apologize to angry residents for referring in his keynote speech at the Democratic national convention to "the abject poor of Essex County."
With no heavy industry of note other than logging, the economy in Hamilton County is almost entirely dependent on tourists, and most of them come in the summer and fall.
In any event, the dominant mood here seems to be one of resignation, tinged with hope for better times -- and an end to the mud season.
"Mostly you just have to set around and wait for it to dry up," said Lee Page, the logger. "And there's sort of two ways to go. Some people go crazy, and some go fishing."

HEADLINE: Trenton Sees Proposed Train Station Stealing Its Business

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAMILTON, N.J., April 17

 BODY:
Trenton's leaders have long complained about the way development has seeped away from the city and into its suburbs, leaving behind joblessness and decay.
The malls that grew up along U.S. 1 in the 1970's helped end the city's role as a retail center. In the 1980's, a rapidly expanding government seemed to put as many new state office buildings outside the capital as in it. Now, as a crowning blow, city officials say, the state-run commuter railroad wants to build a new passenger station in this suburb, where Trentonians fear it will compete for riders with Trenton's station less than four miles down the line. 
 N.J. Transit, the state agency that operates the rail and bus system, said that when the new station in Hamilton opened in the mid-90's it would take the overflow from Trenton and help solve a parking shortage there.
 
Draining Off Business
 The agency calls the planned $30 million Hamilton complex, which will include a bus-repair yard, a "park and ride," and notes that Amtrak, the national rail carrier that makes 19 stops daily at Trenton, will not stop at the new station, which will primarily serve people commuting to and from New York City.
But Trenton officials view the prospect of a new commuter station so near their own as another example of the suburbs draining off business and investment that should be theirs.
Besides flexing their muscle in the State Legislature, Trenton officials plan to make the station an early test of the new state land-use plan, which is expected to be adopted this summer and which calls for state agencies to focus their investment in urban core areas.
"We have the infrastructure in the city already," said State Senator Dick LaRossa, a Trenton Republican and an influential opponent of the Hamilton project. "The only way we are going to revive the economy of this city is to redevelop the available land we have, instead of continuing to use up open land in the suburbs. Let's redevelop the urban areas first, because the better urban areas do the better the suburbs do."
 
Way to Avoid Trenton?
 Betty Holland, a Trenton City Council member, predicted that commuters would avoid Trenton if they had an alternative only a few miles away, with easy access off Interstate 295.
"People will avoid coming to Trenton because they have this misperception that it is not safe, and ridership at Trenton station will fall off," she said.
A restaurateur, Fred Merlino, worries along with his brother Anthony that the Hamilton station might drain away some of the customers from their steakhouse, Pete Lorenzo's Cafe, across from the Trenton train station.
"Businesswise I'm definitely concerned," he said. "You have an existing station here, why go out and spend all that money to build one in the suburbs, where it will only hurt the one we have?"
Jeff Lamm, a spokesman for N.J. Transit, said that the agency expected a strong increase in ridership from the Trenton area in the next year, particularly from the Philadelphia suburbs that already send many New York-bound commuters across the Delaware and into the Trenton station daily. Parking is already crowded at Trenton, he said, and there is a waiting list of 1,500 for monthly parking spaces at Princeton Junction, the next stop on the line to New York.
The Hamilton station would have 1,600 parking spaces, Mr. Lamm said, adding that the agency was spending money in Trenton as well. The station's leaky platform roofs are being repaired, and there are plans to add another 900 parking spaces.
Mrs. Holland, the city council member, has objected in particular to the absence of a plan concerning the Hamilton station, and to the lack of an invitation for public comment.
 
Regional Issues at Stake
 "I thought we had come of age in this state, and were ready to start dealing with things on a regional basis," Mrs. Holland said. "Certainly a transportation facility should be considered a regional matter and should be subject to some sort of regional review and hearing. But a train station in Hamilton is certainly not part of the Mercer County land-use plan, and if we're doing long-range planning in this state, I would assume that New Jersey Transit would at least have raised the question."
But N.J. Transit seemed unaware that there might be a state or regional planning issue involved in the proposed station and Mr. Lamm, the spokesman, declined to address the issue.
The issue moves next to the Legislature, where on April 27 N.J. Transit is scheduled to have its budget reviewed by the Senate appropriations committee. Senator LaRossa, a member of the committee, said he would use the occasion to raise the Hamilton station issue.

THE ECONOMY
Greenspan said the economy grew at a 2 percent annual rate in the first quarter. That is the most specific, and optimistic, projection he has made and would make the quarter the best since the 1989 period, when President Bush was inaugurated. [Page 1.]
Construction of new homes and apartments rose 6.4 percent last month to their highest level in two years, the Government said, in the latest sign of an economic rebound. Private economists cautioned that the 6.4 percent increase probably overstated the strength because the gain came solely from a surge in apartment building that they said was unsustainable. [34.] 
 By linking products to abortion rights, AIDS prevention, gun control and other issues, a new generation of executives is beginning to change the way many goods and services are sold. [33.]
Michael Hammer has a message of radical change, which he calls "re-engineering the corporation." One of the nation's hottest industry consultants, he tells managers to rethink the way they do everything, from buying notebooks to responding to customers' complaints -- or else. [33.]
Bill Clinton wants to pull the economy in the direction of the managed capitalism found in Japan and Western Europe, where governments play a larger role than Washington in shaping industries and markets. [7.]
 
COMPANIES
Digital Equipment is radically overhauling its corporate engineering structure in a move that may lead to huge layoffs. The reorganization dissolves the hardware engineering group and moves engineering into the marketing division. [33.]
Time Warner said it planned to arrange a private placement of $1 billion in long-term debt with institutional investors. [33.]
Pat Robertson has been achieving a quiet success as a TV executive. The parent of his Family Channel plans to sell shares to the public next week, leaving the evangelist and onetime Presidential candidate with stock worth as much as $14.4 million. [33.]
Fleet/Norstar and Massachusetts's Attorney General have agreed on assistance to homeowners deceived into taking second mortgages, home-equity loans or home-repair contracts. [35.]
Star Banc rejected a $1.2 billion takeover offer from Fifth Third Bancorp as hostile. [35.]
GlenFed reported a $106.7 million loss and fell out of compliance with Federal capital requirements. [35.]
The Exxon Valdez spill did much more harm to fish, marine mammals and other resources than had been thought, a new report concludes. [6.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
Czechoslovakia has lifted most price controls, abolished subsidies, balanced budgets and freed businesses to exchange the local currency. Yet unemployment and inflation remain at acceptable levels. Now comes the tough part -- the testing of Czechoslovaks' will to endure far greater hardship. [33.]
 
MARKETS
All stock and commodities markets were closed in the U.S. and most foreign countries for Good Friday. There was no U.S. trading in corporate, municipal or Government securities.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
GlenFed at Risk of Seizure After Loss of $106 Million

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: GLENDALE, Calif., April 17

 BODY:
GlenFed Inc. reported a $106.7 million loss today and fell out of compliance with Federal capital requirements. It had previously predicted the developments.
GlenFed, the parent of Glendale Federal Bank, is now technically at risk of seizure for having too little cushion against losses on risky ventures like real estate investments. 
 No such drastic action is expected soon. GlenFed said it would submit a capital restoration plan to the Office of Thrift Supervision by June 1. It noted that the thrift office could impose a range of sanctions if it is not satisfied with the plan.
 
 
Chief Had Resigned
 Citing the troubled commercial real estate market, GlenFed had predicted the loss last month, when Norman M. Coulson resigned as chairman and chief executive. He was replaced as chief executive by Stephen J. Trafton, a vice chairman who has headed cost-cutting and retrenchment efforts.
The loss for the January-March period, the third quarter of GlenFed's fiscal year, compared with net income of $1.4 million, or 4 cents a share, a year earlier.
GlenFed set aside $131.8 million for loan losses in the quarter, and another $17 million for losses on repossessed real estate. It reduced the carrying value of its direct real estate investments by $66 million.
There were positive signs. Operating expenses fell. GlenFed benefited as interest rates on certificates of deposit fell faster than those on adjustable-rate loans. Its interest spread -- the margin between its cost of funds and return on loans -- rose to 3.01 percent by March 31, up from 2.54 percent a year earlier.
Net interest income was $126.6 million for the quarter, compared with $113.3 million a year earlier.
But mounting loan and real estate troubles showed in the percentage of assets classified as nonperforming, which rose to 4.45 percent, from 2.94 percent in March 1991.
 The results contrasted with reports Thursday from two stronger California competitors.
The Great Western Financial Corporation, parent of Great Western Bank, said its quarterly profit rose 18 percent, to $81.6 million. The Golden West Financial Corporation, the parent of World Savings, said its earnings rose 33 percent, to $70 million.
